Somebody posted this on IDM & I thought it was interesting enough to
forward to sfr. It's pretty old (definatly pre-90), but theres some cool
stuff in there.


<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

Acid Over, by Simon Reynolds, with Paul Oldfield

	House music is so impersonal, minimal and repetitive it seems to
take effict beneath the level of conscious hearing, sweepoing you up by a
process of `molecular agitation'.  Acid house is the purest, barest
distillation of house, the outer limit of its logic of inhuman
functionalism.  With acid, black music has never been so alien-ated from
traditional notions of `blackness' (fluid, grooving, warm), never been so
close to to the frigid, mechanical, supremely `white' perversion of funk
perpetrated by early eighties pioneers like D.A.F. and Cabaret Voltaire.
	Acid house is not so much a new thing, as a drastic, terminal
culmination of two tendensics in house: the trance-inducing effects of
repetion and dub production; a fascination for the pristine hygiene and
metronome rhythms of German electronic dance.  Pure acid tracks like
Tyree's `Acid Over' recal the brute, inelastic minimalism of D.A.F. - it
consists of nothing but a bass synth sequencer pulse reiterated with
slight warps and eerie inflections.  Other tracs parallesl the obscure
innovations of bands like Suicide, the Normal (`Warm Leatherette'),
Liasons Dangereuses (very big in Chicago), Die Krupps (proto-metalbashers
and an early incarnation of Propaganda).  Ex-Sample's `And So it Goes'
combines cut-ups (`Heroin Kills'), unidentifiable bursts of distorted,
sampled sound, and human cries torn from their context (agonies of ecstasy
or distress), in a manner not unlike Front 242.  Reese's `Just Want
Another Chance' sets a guttural, Cabaret Voltaire monologue of desire over
the spookiest of Residents synth-drones, an ectoplasmic bassline fourtimes
too slow for the drum track.  `Strings Of Life' by Rhythim-Is-Rhythim
(a.k.a. Derek May, a prime mover on the acid scene) takes the sultry swing
of Latin disco and clips into a spasmodic tic that's deeply unsettling;
his `Move It' is a perimeter of trebly rhythm programes that restlessly
orbit the black hole where the song should be, and strangely recalls one
of those lost, desolate Joy Division B-sides.
	Weirdest of all is `Acid Trax' by Phuture, the record that started
the whole fad off.  The `Cocaine Mix' starts with a treated voice midway
between a dalek and the Voice of Judgement that announces, `This is
Cocaine Speaking'; spectral eddies of a disembodied human wail
(reminiscent of nothing so much as PIL's `No Birds Do Sing') simulate the
soul languishing in cold turkey; then we're launched on a terror-ride that
again reminds me of PIL's `Careering' or `Death Disco'.  `I can make you
like for me/I can make you die for me/In the end/I'll be your only
friend.'  If disco was always ment to be about escapism, acid is about
no-escapism.
	In this, acid house takes after the white avant-funk of the late
seventies/early eighties, its concept of disco as trance, a form of
sinister control or possession.  The flash and dazzle of disco classics
like Chaka Khan's `I'm Every Woman', Micheal Jackson's `Off the Wall'
album, or anything by Earth Wind and Fire, is replaced by a clinical,
ultra-focused, above all inhibited sound.  Expansive and expressive
gestures are replaced by a precise and rigorous set of movements,
_demands_ on the body; flamboyance and improvisation by a discipline of
pleasure.  Perhaps there's a kind of `liberation' in submitting to the
mechanics of instinct, soldering the circuitry of desire to the circuitry
of the sequencer programmes.
	As for the connotations of `acid', all involved in the Chicago
scene deny that hallucinogenics have anything to do with the sound.  The
name comes from the slang term `acid burn', which means to rip somebody
off, steal their ideas (i.e. sample their sound).  However many club-goers
take Ecstasy, a drug related to LSD which provides its euphoric sense of
communion (and aphrodisiac effects) without causing hallucinations.  
	House has been bordering on the psychedelic for some time anyway,
with the spaciness of its dub effects, its despotic treatment of the voice
and its interference with the normal ranking of instruments in the mix
(encouraging `perceptual drift').  On one mix of Nitro Deluxe's `On a
Mission', a single phrase of female voice is vivisected, varispeeded and
multitraced into a sychedelic babble of sub-phonemes and vowel-particles,
becomeing an airborne choir of lunatic estasied, a locust swwarm of
placeless peaks and plaints spirited free of their location in a syntax of
desire.
	On the Kenny Jones mix of Ralphi Rosario's `You Used to Hold Me',
stray sibilants from Xavier Golds's vocal flake off to bob inhumanly in
their own parallel slipstream, until her vocal is absorbed into the
backing track, with one spasm of passion turned into a jack-knifing rhythm
effect.  On the `Devil Mix' of Master C & J's `In the City', Liz Torre's
voice is distored and distended in a manner uncannily akin to the The
Butthole Surfers!
	With pure acid house, however, it's not really a question of
acid-rock's 24-track techinicolour overload, of a dazzling, prismatic
opening of the doors of perception , but more like a contraction or
evacuation  of consciousness.  Not a matter of being saturated by TOO MUCH
but of being compelled to focus on TOO LITTLE, reduced to a one-track
mind.  If people do drop a tab or two to `acid house' they must have
strage digital visions, enter Mondran phantasmagorias, Spirograph inner
orbits.
	What the berserk strobe-flicker of acid house is most reminiscent
of is an episode from `Star Trek': miscreants are punished by bing
subjected to a strobe-like flaing lightbox which clears the brain, leaving
them suggestible and capable of being literally re-formed.  But one
deviant is left in the machine, brainwashed but unprogrammed, lost in a
terrifyingly blank catatonic limbo.
	Like D.A.F.'s new savagery, like psychedelia's orgiastic
utopianism, house incites a superhuman/inhuman insatiability.  With the
jettisoning of the song/storyline, sex loses narrative and context,
becomes asocial and fantastical.  There's no sense of trajectory
(courtship/seduction/foreplay/union), no sexual healing, no communication,
no sense of `scene' in Baudrillardian sense (dramatic relations between
human agents).  Instead there's an ob-scene explicitness, a a graphic
depiction of a fantastical algebra of pornotopian configurations.  Sex
turns in to a series of quadradic  equations, flesh becomes spectral. 
Nothing is ever resolved:  house is the beat that can never satisfy or be
satisfied.  The stutter-beats, the costive basslines, sound neurotic: the
music's a repetition complex, a symptom of some unstaunchable vacancy of
being.  Every bar of the music becomes an orgasm, making the idea of
climax meaningless.
	And where acid rock imagined utopia as a garden of pre-modern
innocence, acid house is futuristic, in love with sophistication and
gtechnology.  Acid house imagines a James Bond/Barbarella leasure paradise
of gadgetry and designer drugs.  House is a kind of pleasure factory (an
orgasmotron, in fact) and as Marx wrote, the factory turns human beings
into mere appendages of flesh attached to machinery.
	If house, acid, new beat, etc, are radical, it's a radicalism
that's inseparable from their simple effectiveness, pure pleasure
immediacy.  Here's a pop culture based around the death of the song,
minimalism, repetition, departure from the stability of the key and
harmonic structure in favour of sonority and sound-in-itself.  No need for
interpretation, context or rhetoric, all the things that people turn to
the music papers for.  No delay, no mediation, but a direct interface
between the music's pleasure circuitry and the listener's nervous system.
	Nobody even cares who made the music, which is why the personal
appearances of the `stars' are so farcical (most clobgoers continue to
dance with their backs turned to the stage, while the band mimes to the
record).  Does this make the scene dehumanized and impersonal?  You could
argue, as some do, that it's a realizaionton of one interpretation of
punk: not `anyone can be a star' so much as `no more stars', a
deconstruction of stardom (most new beat or house `stars' are merely
fronts for the producer).  There's a similar kind of deconstruction to
that wreaked by seventies glam:  the gestures and iconography of showbiz
are exaggerated amplified and disconnected untile nothing is signified but
a style that can only be sustained here...There's just intensity whout
pretext or context (just the music).
	And this is a blank generation if ever you saw one, sucked into
house's void and left adrift, prttily vacant.  But if the scene is
`democratic', it's with a capitalist inflection;  the music is pure
product, consumer-tested on the dancefloor, with an inbuilt obsolescence
factor.  Some tracks are monumental constructions, Brutalist ziggurats you
could gaze at in wonder for a lifetime.  But in a club, it's compatibilyty
rather than difference that rules, with a seamlessness that has you happy
as a nodding dog.

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

Some people say acid-house makes you do crazy things, like putting holes in
your body and doing the jerk & twitch. Hmmm...
	josh

Favorite CD's So Far:

1. Ethnotechno - Sonic Anthropology Vol. 1; Wax Trax.  A variety of
   techno styles featuring "ethnic" or "world" style vocal samples,
   instruments, rhythms and melodies.

2. New Young American Primitive : ZoeMagik Records (415)641-8023.
   Trancy/tribal consistantly good all the way through.  Probably
   the single best techno group I've heard to date.

3. One A.D. - Waveform Corp.  A collection of ambient techno with
   a more than passing beat.

Where I buy them:

Tower Records, but only if its on a listening station.

City Discs in Greenbrea, Marin County.  They don't have a lot of techno, but
they always have something new, and best of all, They let you listen before
you buy and have a satisfaction guaranteed return policy to boot.  You can
also order something and choose not to buy it if you don't like it.  The
store has a great vibe too.

Does anyone know if there are stores like City Discs in the city?

--

Michael E. Clay:
> ( raves ) should be truly all ages - large extended families celebrating 
> together. What comes to my mind are village dances and celebrations of
> so called "primative" tribes.

Keep in mind that these village dances & celebrations are an integral
part of those cultures, i.e. they represent the spiritual and community-
building aspects that are a normal part of their everyday lives. 
 
Although raves may represent an ideal of community and life celebration, 
I have to question whether they are useful for preparing children for 
dealing with our current culture.  Without the guidance of a wise guide, 
it might prove to be very difficult for a child to integrate the rave 
experience with other aspects of our reality.  Which isn't to say that 
kids shouldn't go to raves on their own.  What I'm saying is that if 
people go to raves to escape the reality-at-large, then this is a very 
different activity from the ecstatic celebrations that have gone on in 
other cultures.

Of course, just being part of a subculture can be a wonderful thing.
But is this subculture going to take care of you when you can't pay the
rent?  Is it going to provide suitible paths leading to spiritual,
emotional and intellectual fulfillment?  Is it going to help make the
world a better place?  Perhaps it doesn't matter.  To many (most?),
raving is just a way to have fun when you're not at work or in school.

> Instead, our so called "advanced" civilization
> pairs up and sets at home comatose in front of millions of boob tubes -
> what a way to promote mental and physical health.

In a way, the TV program directors, and other media authorities have
become society's village elders - preparing (brainwashing?) youths
to become a conforming member of our society.  Hopefully, the rave
scene can provide direction for how ravers (of all ages) can integrate
the rave experience into a fulfilling and enriching lifestyle.  And 
hopefully, such rave-influenced lifestyles can integrate and effect 
some positive changes to our world culture.   I hope that those to whom 
raving is nothing more than a way to have fun can find things in the world 
that are enriching in other ways - unless of course they feel that there 
really is nothing more to life other than having fun.  


Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (   ( ((truth-love-energy))  )   )   lee@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar  1 11:36:14 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA20456; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 11:36:14 -0800
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA20445; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 11:36:08 -0800
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/UCD2.05)
	id AA20604; Wed, 1 Mar 95 11:36:06 PST
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 11:36:06 PST
Message-Id: <9503011936.AA20604@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Kids at Raves
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>Michael E. Clay:
>> (raves) should be truly all ages - 

Lee is on the money,

> Keep in mind that these village dances ... 
> are an integral part of those cultures

Raves are a subculture.  A teeny tiny part of our whole culture.
This distinction seems lost on a lot of folks.  I don't think we have
to be talking about just kids here.
 
> Although raves may represent an ideal of community and life celebration 
> I have to question whether they are useful for preparing children for 
> dealing with our current culture.  

I think the positive spin on this would be similar to how some people
view their drugs - it gives them a "happiness reference point" - a glimpse
of how they can feel.  But the drugs wear off.  And no rave lasts forever.
I believe that maybe One such a reference point experience is valid and
after that it turns into escapism.  A slippery hill.  Picture me rolling
my eyes as someone trys to validate their drug usage with this little
story - one we've all heard a Thousand Times ...

> Without guidance ...
> it might prove to be very difficult for a child to integrate the rave 
> experience with other aspects of our reality.  

Well, I sorta think this applies to just about everything in terms of
raising a child.

> Which isn't to say that 
> kids shouldn't go to raves on their own.  

You bet - kids all have to have their "out on their own" experiences and
I think raves are great for that.

> Of course, just being part of a subculture can be a wonderful thing.
> But is this subculture going to take care of you when you can't pay the
> rent?  Is it going to provide suitible paths leading to spiritual,
> emotional and intellectual fulfillment?  Is it going to help make the
> world a better place?  

No No Maybe 
and that last one reminds me of Cher for some reason

here's why I like the all age raves only occasionally - cuz I feel
some responsibility not to Blow Their Innocence Out of the Water just
cuz I've heard it before.  Presumably, raising a kid is all about
re-experiencing the world with them.  I don't have kids.  I'm 
Too Busy selfishly Experiencing the world myself to spend 
time re-treading the same old thing.  That's me.  Now.

My time is infinitely valuable.  Despite the "joy" it might
bring me to see life through their eyes - I have no interest in puppy
pile counseling sessions.  Too high people who want to chat.  Deep
philosiphizing.  I want to party with a bunch of folks who are
Down - so we can shake it, Together. (ComeUnity)

Dave


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar  1 11:41:55 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA20847; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 11:41:55 -0800
Received: from netcom8.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA20839; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 11:41:51 -0800
Received: by netcom8.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id LAA27200; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 11:40:12 -0800
From: peterf@netcom.com (Peter Fogel)
Message-Id: <199503011940.LAA27200@netcom8.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Kids at Raves
To: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 11:40:11 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9503011634.AA15443@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM> from "Lee Fogel" at Mar 1, 95 08:34:56 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2808      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  
> Although raves may represent an ideal of community and life celebration, 
> I have to question whether they are useful for preparing children for 
> dealing with our current culture.  Without the guidance of a wise guide, 
> it might prove to be very difficult for a child to integrate the rave 
> experience with other aspects of our reality.  Which isn't to say that 
> kids shouldn't go to raves on their own.  What I'm saying is that if 
> people go to raves to escape the reality-at-large, then this is a very 
> different activity from the ecstatic celebrations that have gone on in 
> other cultures.

Wow, here's a big dose of reality from Lee.  In a way raves are an escape 
from reality for me, but it also helps me connect to reality at large. 
Raving helps me understand more about the joy of connecting.  Coming home 
from atomic pig I couldn't help thinking about all the connections that 
went on.  
Because of the safe loving enviroments of raves, I'm learning 
that giving love brings love.  Love or that place we get a taste of where 
we are all connected can help us alot dealing with all aspects of 
reality.  At least speaking for myself, it does for me.  Raving helps me 
cellabrate existence, and it helps me acknowledge and see the beauty of 
our togetherness and see the beauty in our separateness.  There is more 
of a sence of separateness for me in the realities outside of raves.  
Loving that separateness (which raving is helping me do) helps me get 
things done like the rent being paid.  I think it is important to 
celebrate our individual existence and taking care of it is one way that 
I do that.  
For to deny my indivual importance is to deny a part of the whole.  Every 
part is important to the whole. 

 
 > In a way, the TV program directors, and other media authorities have
> become society's village elders - preparing (brainwashing?) youths
> to become a conforming member of our society.  Hopefully, the rave
> scene can provide direction for how ravers (of all ages) can integrate
> the rave experience into a fulfilling and enriching lifestyle.  And 
> hopefully, such rave-influenced lifestyles can integrate and effect 
> some positive changes to our world culture.   

Lee makes some great points here, only deleted some to help keep it from 
being too redundant and assuming you already read it.
I'd be interested in hearing from others how raving has enhanced and help 
improve your life outside of raving.  I'll understand if no one responds 
to this request because as I think about it, I realize that it is very 
difficult for me to put into words.  For me  the benifits of raving goes 
way beyond what words can express.  That is probably one on the reasons I 
rave, to express those benifits and joys without the limitations words.


peter

> 
> 
> Ummm there's been some top choons out lately, try and get hold of these.
> 
> 1 Leftism		Leftfield

If you like Leftfield, you should also check out a group called Morganistic. 
Their CD is an import and the cheapest place (and only place) I've seen it,
it cost $26 for one CD.  It's got a greyish CD cover and you'll look at it
and go AMBIENT definitely AMBIENT, but NO WAY it is aggressive trance.  Very
european if you like that.

BTW, the place I saw it was Alien Records in Austin, TX.  If anyone wantes
their number let me know.

Peace/Love/Soul

solarvibe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar  1 17:03:22 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA12676; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 17:03:22 -0800
Received: from hills.ccsf.cc.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA12670; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 17:03:17 -0800

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 17:02:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: " jessica n. bentley" <jbentl01@ccsf.cc.ca.us>
Subject: SF rave kid in NY(fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9503011616.A8313-0100000@hills.ccsf.cc.ca.us>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i'm always curious about the scenes in other cities so i'm forwarding 
this exerpt of a message from my sister, a west coast raver in new york, 
just for general interest...

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 12:29:38 -0500 (EST)
From: Rachel Louisa Bentley <rlb23@columbia.edu>
To: " jessica n. bentley" <jbentl01@hills.ccsf.cc.ca.us>
Subject: wow

So, I had the most intense experience of my life this weekend, I think.  
Of course, no way to even convey it, but you know that.  I went to the 
most HARDCORE HARDCORE party you can imagine.  I can't even believe that 
that kind of a thing is called a rave and so are the little pparties in 
SF.  They are so different.  We had to literally push and shove our way 
in to this huge castle/military-related building (HUGE), inside which 
were thousands of fucked up kids and security guards pushing you on 
through and not letting you wait for you friends who got held up in the 
"line" (more like a pulsing mob).  I walked in and could not believe my 
eyes, ears, and every other sensory detector I have.  Only slightly 
baked, I couldn't even tell if I was tripping or what.  I was already 
hearing sounds and seeing things I never thought possible.  At first I 
thought there was no way I would trip, but then decided it was so intense 
that I better see just how intense it could be.  The A was incredible 
(just 1 and we were all "GONE" :)  Lasers, lights, music.  I want to take 
you to one of these hardcore New York parties.  I went with somepeople I 
didn't know very well, and I was definitely wishing at some points that 
there were someone there I knew and loved.  But I'm also really glad I 
did it on my own.  I met a few cool people, but couldn't really socialize 
much.  See, this was the first time I REALLY tripped, you know--HARD.  
The first time I really felt restricted by my human form and stuff.  And 
felt like I was liquid.  As I sat on the filthy floor and watched the 
party, I didn't know whether to be delighted that this sort of thing goes 
on and "society" can't stop it and has no idea what it is, or to be 
digusted and sad at seeing all these dirty people, most of them really 
young, and skinny from taking too many drugs and going out every night.  
Some of Howard's friends came in for the weekend and it was their first 
rave.  They were in for a lot more than they expected.  I also "wigged" 
for the first time, but it didn't last long.  I felt bad, though, because 
I wasn't with people who knew me well.  I'm going to go.  But if you come 
visit me here sometime, I want to go to one of these with you (if you 
want).  It's just so intense, I can't even believe it.  I felt like such 
a San Francisco wimp.  Don't worry, I like the lovey-community SF parties 
better than these NY ones that just make you not be able to believe what's 
going on and feel like you're about to explode (and the bathrooms were 
grosser than you can imagine).  But it's an experience I will never forget.  


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar  1 19:06:07 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id TAA20361; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 19:06:07 -0800
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA20345; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 19:05:58 -0800

	id SAA10924; Wed, 1 Mar 1995 18:56:49 -0800
Message-Id: <199503020256.SAA10924@netcomsv.netcom.com>
Date: 1 Mar 1995 18:54:27 -0800
From: "Nathan Moser" <nathan_moser@manual3.com>
Subject: Culture vs. sub-culture (wa
To: "SFRaves list" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Reply to:   Culture vs. sub-culture (was RE>>Kids at Raves)
--------------------------------------
Date: 3/1/95 9:37 AM
To: Nathan Moser
From: Lee Fogel
Michael E. Clay:
> ( raves ) should be truly all ages - large extended families celebrating 
> together. What comes to my mind are village dances and celebrations of
> so called "primative" tribes.

Keep in mind that these village dances & celebrations are an integral
part of those cultures, i.e. they represent the spiritual and community-
building aspects that are a normal part of their everyday lives. 
 
...
Lee
---------------------------------------
I'm no anthropoligist, but I would guess many such traditional dances and 
celebrations emerge in a way similar to how raves have sprung from our 
mass/world culture. Imagine a few young members of a tribe sneaking out 
of the village after dark, "borrowing" the drums of their elders and 
dancing fervidly, with clumsy experimentation invoking the spirits 
they've always been instructed to fear, coming back in the morning 
bleary-eyed with big smiles, planning their next meeting. As they grow to 
fill the positions of their elders, could they forget the most estatic 
moments of their youth? Wouldn't some of it find its way into the 
village's rituals?

Maybe this is bourgeois white-boy glamorization, but maybe you see my 
point. 
-nate

Dear All;

	Yes; I like what people have to say about dance. What I'm curious 
about is where we men decided that it was to macho to do these 
traditional dances. Like I used to wear those bells around my leg; you 
know those bells that India womyn wear and some dead heads. These were 
worn at times of celabration, and the men traditionally performed the 
dances. What ever happened to that; and why do we(men) traditionally always 
expect the womyn to do them. What part of society or what society or time 
period was this deemed to macho to do. It really didn't become ok to 
dance by yourself until the late 70's early 80's thanks to that Gen X 
song; dancin by myself; nothin to lose, nothin to prove just dancin by 
myself. also it really hasn't been ok for men to dance with other men 
until now. Inquiring minds want to know.

Subject: SFRAVES Rave-O-Matic?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear all:

        I have been forced to live on the  east coast for about half a year
now, and have noticed a big difference in net activity between two email
groups, ne-raves and sfraves.  Now don't get me wrong, I LOVE San
Francisco.  Actually, in my opinion New York and its raves are nothing
compared to a good SF rave with some close friends.  But people here are
more informative about events.  They post weekly letters on the list
summarizing what people are going to which rave, who can give rides, and
who can drive.  There is just a lot more pre-communication of rave
information.

        The coolest thing that they have is a Rave-O-Matic on the World
Wide Web, maintained by DJ Mars(Marshall Villarosa).  This is amazing.  It
has raves lined up for the next three months going on all over the north
east coast.  It is beautiful.  I really commend him for maintaining the
page.  If you want to check it out, just to see what i mean, the address
is:

                http://www.lehigh.edu/~a176/techno.html

Just click on the rave-o-matic button and *flash*, you're connected to
hundreds of events!  It's just mind-blowing!

        I guess the point of my whole letter is that maybe we should try
and have a more informational newsgroup, and focus on meeting each other
and increasing the love of the entire rave scene.  A Rave-O-Matic for the
SF area would be great too, if someone had the time to maintain it.  I am
unable to, so i thought I'd just throw the idea out to the masses.  But  I
would be willing to help anyone who had the desire to start one up.

        I am coming back home this weekend, and am planning to go as many
raves as possible during my 2 week break.  I have a car, and would love to
give people rides if they are going where I am.  As now, I don't know
what's going on, due to my extreme geographical distance and separation
from the underground information flow in SF.  I know for sure that I am
going to Harmony on MArch 10.  the location is supposed to be beautiful,
and the people throwing it are awesome too.  DJ's are yet another reason to
go to that one!  I might go to Basics too this weekend(i think that's when
it is).  So if anyone is interested, please email me.  And if anybody else
thinks that offering rides before raves is cool, then do it =)  I have
noticed that on both newsgroups(east and west coast), people are upset with
the lack of intimacy and amiability at raves.  Well, this is a small step
back in the right direction.  I want to make a difference =)

Luv you all,

Rob McCord

mcrobt@mineva.cis.yale.edu


PS Sorry if my words and ideas are incoherent/mispelled/lame/whatever.
This was written is haste while studying for my last midterm.  Kind of a
heat-of-the-moment-thingie.....

Dear Rob;

	Your words are neither lame or incoherent; maybe misspelled but 
i'm an x -engineer and can't spell anyway; and neither can most ravers; 
and most ravers don't care about spelling. 

	Your words however show a great amount of caring and love for 
the scence and are quite inspiring; i thing you posts are just fine. 
Don't worry about what other people think; unless you want to kiss ass; 
TO THY OWN SELF BE TRUE, and the rest will take care of itself.

	People respect, trust and like me because I speak from the heart
and say what I really feel;  & think, the world needs more honesty and
less BS; there enough of the latter out there. For all the trashing I got 
last week; I got twice the letters of support; in either the public or 
private. We all have insecurites about posting; these posts go out to 
100's of people, the eyes of those people are upon our writing. But those 
are human eyes; flawwed by bad experience and environment; I will never 
trash you for a mistake; for to err is human; and I make a lot of 
mistakes every day. I/we feel we were not placed here to judge our fellow 
person; but I feel to support and help each other fight the enemy within. 
Listin to the song by the same name off the Rush CD Grace Under Pressure; 
there is much wisdom to be found in the words of Neil Peart. In fact I 
give them to you since I have the Cd right here and they were cool enough 
to give the lyrics.

	The Enemy Within;

	Things crawl in the darkness
	That imagination spins
	Needles at your nerve ends
	Crawl like spiders on your skin

	Pounding in your temples
	And a surge of adrenalin
	Every Muscle tense-
	To fence
	The enemy within...

	I'm not giving in
	To security under pressure
	I'm not missing out
	On the promise of adventure
	I'm not giving up
	On implausible dreams-
	Experience to extremes-
	Experience to extremes

	Suspicious looking stranger
	Flashes you a dangerous grin
	Shadows across your window-
	Was it only a tree in the wind?

	Every breath a static charge-
	A tongue that tastes like tin
	Steely-eyes outside-
	To hide
	The enemy within....

	To you - is it movement or is it action?
	Is it contact or just reaction?
	And you - revolution or just resistance?
	Is it living, or just existence?
	Yeah, you - it takes a little more persistence
	To get up and go the distance...

Anytime I get scared and am decideing whether or not I should share 
something with someone or do something thats a little scarey, I remember 
the words to this song. I hope that was helpful:)

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

Well I have been going though the sfraves directory, and its really sad to see
that we don't have recent pictures of sfravers on line. (BTW, thanks for the
Crunch JPEG, but you may want to consider ftping it to hyperreal.com/incoming/sfraves or incoming/images). I know that this isn't the type of group that
jumps in front of a camera and takes a million pictures (well, susie might :)),
but I'd really like to see the sfraves web pages like the other regional mailing
list pages. I'm sure it would even help if some people have their pictures on
line so others can recognize them at parties and such (since we no longer
have buttons or badges). I think the only one who wears their badge still is 
Larry Ching. Which I think it's great.

Anyway take pictures (even random ones at raves:)), scan them in, and upload them. I'm sure that a couple of years from now, it would be great to look at the E-Bee and remember all the wacky memories of Milton waving (and he will prob. still be waving) the E-Bee around. :)

Cindy

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Dear Sfraves;

	Rob's and other people private posts to me prompted me to write
this. Theres supposed to be at least 300+ people on this list and we only
hear regularly from but a small group; I'ld say less than 30%; I sit here;
at the doorway to a universe and wonder what beautiful/ugly,
inspiring/depressing, humorous/sad, intelligent/dumb words we never get to
hear from all the other people out there on this list. It makes me sad and
angry; and I do have tears in my eyes; that there are people out there
that have something meaningful to say; a feeling, a thought and are scared
that someone will trash them because they don't like, or understand what
there about or tring to say. These unheard thoughts and feeling could
change us all, start a revolution, make us all look at something in a new
and very special and wonderful way; or bore us, depress us or make us
angry. 

	I'm a raver because most of all; above all things I embrase new
experience, there are many worlds, dimensions, and universes to explore
out there, that we can touch, see, feel and be a part of. I'm not so
fragile that what you will say will crush and destory me. Today I give no
one that power. 

	But instead because of The Enemy Within(specifically fear), thoose
insecure critics of the world, the biggest and worst critic ourselves, WE
CHOSE not to do things that could propell us and the people we touch
further and farther than we've ever gone before. To push the extremes of
reality, to go where internally or externally where no human has gone
before. I know those words sound tacky; but I believe in them and carry
them with me always. 

	Maybe I was a raver before;  I was anything else; I just beleieve
in pushing the envolpe; never content to stay where I'm at for very long;
there's always something new and different to experience. I wanted to be a
jet piolet; something about going three times the speed of sound just
excites the hell out of me; to pull 5 or 10g's, god I eveny those guys;
but I'm sure even that wouldn't be enough for me, and they wouldn't let 
me because of my poor eyesight. 

	I guess the point I'm tring to make is; that I really would like
to hear from all the other people out there on the scene, whatever you
have to say is ok by me; as long as your not trashing me or anyone else. 
So if no one told you today or ever that your feelings and thoughts are
important; let me be the first. To the people on the list who never post 
I say this,
 
"your feelings and thoughts are important to me and I will always give 
them the attention they deserve, because you are a fanatsic human being 
and what you have to say is important to me; I can say this without ever 
having met you or talked with you before because mine are and your no 
different than me."

	I say this because there so many people out there saying the
opposite, that we don't count, that what we have to say isn't important or
wrong, and I what to be part of the solution not the problem I feel there
needs to be a voice of positivity out there;  we all accept the negative
so quickly; but when someones positive; the first thought for a lot of us
is oh they must want something from me;  thats so sad, but unfortuately
its true sometimes. 

	Ya know I went on a group house interview tonight, and I said to
the group of people there that I much more interested in hearing about
your feelings if I'm doing something that bothers you. As I was saying it
I looked into the eyes of the people I was talking with; and I just saw
that; its hard to explain;  but its like the lites came on inside each
person. This is why I do it; I enjoy seeing someone smile because their
humanity is recognized, accepted and appreiated. I going to sign off 
today; its late. I just hope I get to hear from more of you whether in 
private or publicly. 

	Oh one other thing, I would like to thanks Brian B at Hyperreal 
for letting the list run itself. It takes a very speicial person to have 
a lot of power and not use it; to just let things be, even if its the way 
he thought it would or wouldn't be, Thanks Brian B at Hyperreal.com your 
one of the people on the scene that make it very very special and me very 
proud to be a part of it :)

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com
		Other Internet:	algore@dkeep.com

ps I hope this makes all of you feel warm and fuzzy :), and I'm sure it 
will make some of you a little sick, thats ok, to steal a 12 step phase, 
not that I'm a part of that program, keep comin back

Brian gets to a point:
> 	I guess the point I'm tring to make is; that I really would like
> to hear from all the other people out there on the scene

I think one of the reasons a lot of people don't post is because we have
regulars here who often don't give anyone else a chance to.  By the time
someone gets the courage to contribute something, there's a good chance
that you or myself or someone other geek who happens to be sitting at a
computer all day has already beaten them to it.  I bet that if some of us
bandwidth hogs chilled out from posting so much, others would come out
of the woodwork to express their points of views a little more.  Just a 
thought.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

> Brian gets to a point:
> > 	I guess the point I'm tring to make is; that I really would like
> > to hear from all the other people out there on the scene
> 
> I think one of the reasons a lot of people don't post is because we have
> regulars here who often don't give anyone else a chance to.  

Okay, so here's a post from me, someone who doesn't that often.  The 
above statement is ONE reason why I don't post that much.  By the time I 
am able to respond to a particular subject, many times it has already 
been talked out, IMO.
Also, I'm a person of few words, and responding to a whole letter with 
"Yeah, I feel that way, too" or "Gee, that's AWFUL" is simply bad 
etiquette.  So many times everybody else says pretty much what I was 
thinking, so I wouldn't NEED to post.
Lack of time is also another reason.  By the time I read thru all the 
mail and write my personal e-mail, it's time to go to class!  Many 
students on this list, I'm sure are, in the same boat.  Incidently, I 
have the day off from school (but not work!) and that's why I have extra 
time today.  

take care everybody!
luv,
Amy

re: Lee's and Nate posts on tribes:

The key word here is integration. 

We go to these parties, and once in while, (some more than others) have an 
experience of consequential importance on our lives. We come to an 
UNDERSTANDING.  

Do we leave this experience at the party, or do we take our experience, 
our understanding, with us into our daily lives? 

I believe we all need to ask ourselves this question. For if we aren't 
integrating -learning- from our experience, then what's the point?

We integrate this energy, this understanding, into ourselves and our 
lives, and set by step, we change the manner in which we interact with 
others.

This then encourages the ones we interact with to do the same.
(y'know, give a smile and you'll usually get one back)

Get my drift?
 
We stay positive, believe in ourselves and the energy within us all, 
and I'll just bet we can straighten out this mess we call civlization.

Just gotta have faith.

Later...

-Jonas


freedom	- it's in the vibrations

Please be sure to ask for permission before putting someone's picture
on a public archive. Besides being illegal (invasion of privacy), it
could cause a lot of damage for people working for conservative
companies, teens with oppressive parents, etc.

Note that this is not a comment on Cindy (hi!). I just wanted to point
out something that could get overlooked.

Sean

DJ Smash hits SF this weekend to bring NYC's Giant Step acid jazz sound
to SF; he's scheduled for about half a dozen places this weekend. 
Saturday, it's basics vs. wicked.  Tough call, but SFR's Ethan's 
appearance at Basics may tip the scales.  

    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Friday, March 3rd - Jazid Up 
        DJ Smash  Miquel  George  Thomas  Terrence Toy (LA)
        live performance by Tommy Gurrero & Crew
        Record Release Party for Fat Jazzy Grooves #10
        278 11th St., 10p-5a, 415.905.8811

Friday, March 3rd - All Together Now
        Surge  DJ Das  Andrew Rawnsley(XLR8R)
        $5, doors at 10pm.  415.241.1585

Saturday, March 4th - Basics
        Tony  Jon Williams  Brad  Ethan  Spun  Josh
        415.522.3994  415.905.9629

Saturday, March 4th - Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

Sunday, March 5th - Root Down
        DJ Smash  Charlotte  Alex
        278 11th @ Folsom.  10pm-3am.  $3, 21+.

Thursday, March 9th - Eighth House of Zenbiance
        performances by Deep Space Time, Naked Space
        DJs Jonah Sharp, Robert Shea (Big City Orchestra), Das
        live: Kode IV (Belgium), OST (Detroit)
        $6.  1190 Folsom @ 8th.  415.487.5436

Friday, March 10th - Harmony
        DJs Tony  Simon  Doran  Trent
        visuals by Mark, ambient by Dionysus Dreams
        408.486.9591

Saturday, March 11th - Organic, 2nd year anniversary
         Simon  Graeme  Jeno  Robbie Hardkiss  DJ Dan  Andre Lucero
         $12, 10pm-7am.  415.266.8215

Saturday, March 11th - Ultrasonic
        Tracy  Ethan  Lee  Monty  Ray  Joe Rice
        Sound by SoundVision.
        $5 or $4 with a canned food donation.
        Presented by the Justice Leauge Sound System.
        (415) 281-9432

Wednesday, March 15th - Culture
        House DJs Wool, Ejyo, Chill, Brandon
        dubjazzhop DJs Laron, Keone, Mei-Lwun, Innacity
        Union Lounge, 2001 Union, SF.

Friday, March 17th - Catastrophic Planet "a journey of funky vibes"
        Gabe  Liquid  Jam N J  DJ Dan  Carlos  Q Bert  Graeme
        Chill Zone: Zee  Johnny K
        Lasers by Kevin, Visuals by Eyezmind, Sound by Fantasy Direct
        Glow Toys by Glowtech
        415.939.2468  209.991.4726

Well,   today is the day where I leave you fine and wonderful folks
and head out into the unknown,  unexplored world (At least by me).

It is VERY IMPORTANT that while I'm gone,   that all of you keep
the scene alive.   It's also important to spread as much luv and
energy as possible.    

As I leave this evening,   I will skip Friday completly,  and
arrive on a Saturday,   ready for Field of Dreams in Sydney.

I already have an internet account set up,   and I'll still be 
on the net,   instead of reporting on Bay Area raves,   I'll be
reporting on Sydney (And other cities) raves.

There will be about 20 hours (From 7 pm this evening,   until 
Friday Morning at about 3 am) when I won't be able to get on the
net.

As of about 4 pm,   I'm heading out to the airport,  in preparation
for my departure at 7 pm.   Till I return,  sometime between 1 and
3 months from now,   It's been WONDERFUL Party'ing with you fine
folks.    

Cheers

To: bpm@dhp.com
Cc: "Northwest Raver's List" <nw-raves@hyperreal.com>,
        "San FranDisco Raver's List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        I D M <idm@hyperreal.com>, breaks@xmission.com
Subject: SL1200s: The Saga Continues
Date: Thu, 02 Mar 95 16:17:51 -0700
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@selway.umt.edu>
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	OK, y'all, sorry if I'm in error in assuming that this is of
semi-general interest, but I've gotten enough replies from interested
people to think that this is worthwhile. I also think that it's
worthwhile to set up some sort of exchange for 1200s, which I'm now
volunteering to run. Please see the end of this message for my ideas
on how this will probably work.
	I've called about 10 or 12 places so far, and the news is far
from encouraging. A lot of places that used to stock 1200s do not any
longer, and those that do have jacked up the prices considerably. I
think that what's happened is that Matsushita has finally realized
that they've got a guaranteed money-making machine with no real
competition and have constricted the supply of new turntables, thus
spiking the supply & demand curve way towards the demand end. I can't
say I blame them, but it makes it a pain in the butt for those of us
on a tight budget. I guess if I was really on that tight a budget I'd
be off buying Geminis or LinearTechs, but that's neither here nor
there.
	Pro Sound & Stage considerably tightened their price-matching
procedure recently: if you quote them a competitor's price, the
competitor has to both _have_ the product and have it _in stock_ in
order for Pro Sound to match their price. This is just a small note of
warning to those who, like me, like to give Pro Sound money but don't
like to pay $439.95 for a 1200.
	Here's a list of places that actually quoted me prices, from
least to most expensive:

	Uncle's Music     (800)328-6253         $389
        Sam Ash           (800)472-6274         $429
	Pro Sound & Stage (800)945-9300         $439
        Manny's Music     (212)819-0576         $449

	I called a bunch more places, but as there is nowhere for me
to look to find phone numbers around here (no StreetSound or URB or
whatever), I'm sorta hindered. Most of the places I called just
laughed hollowly when I asked them if they had 1200s. If somebody
wanted to be really kind, they could (PLEASE! PLEASE!) type some of
the numbers for other music places in and send them to me. That would
be saintly of you. I'm also trying to find the phone number for Full
Compass music in Wisconsin, which somebody mentioned had a really good
price a few months ago.

MY IDEAS ON THE DJ EXCHANGE

	You've all seen the Internet CD/Vinyl Wantlist, haven't you (I
bet Lazlo has ;)?  It's sort of a buyer's market for rare musical
items. I was thinking that that would be a good way to administer the
buying and selling of used DJ gear -- have buyers post a price they'd
be willing to buy at, have sellers post the price they'd be willing to
sell at, and let everybody haggle it out in an intermediated forum. It
could extend to all sorts of stuff, because the market for old Numark
mixers and Sony MDRV6 and 7506 headphones is almost as tight as the
1200 market. The free market works best when it's greased a little
bit.
	I think it'd also be nice if we had a semi-up-to-date list of
what various music stores around the country are charging for things
like 1200s, 1210s, the new Vestax tables, and Sony headphones. It's a
lot easier to part with the kind of cash it takes to buy serious DJ
equipment if you know you're getting the best possible price.
	I'd be willing to set up a page on my web site to handle
this. All I would really need is information from people about price
quotes and their buying/selling prices for gear. Does this sound like
a good idea to people? I won't bother unless I get a pretty
affirmative response (like, say, more than five people). This would be
a free service for y'all, done by me mainly because I think it's
something that would be useful.
	Anyway, I've choked your mailboxes enough, so I'll depart at
this point. Remember, I need

	o Phone numbers for DJ supply stores
	o Information on where good deals might be hiding
and	o Your votes for whether or not you think a DJ service would
	  be worth having.

thank you for your time,
ozymandias

      ozymandias G desiderata AKA Forrest L Norvell AKA DJ AladdinSane

Amy R Starkey threw this into the mix:

> > Brian gets to a point:
> > > 	I guess the point I'm tring to make is; that I really would like
> > > to hear from all the other people out there on the scene
> > 
> > I think one of the reasons a lot of people don't post is because we have
> > regulars here who often don't give anyone else a chance to.  

> Okay, so here's a post from me, someone who doesn't that often.  The 
> above statement is ONE reason why I don't post that much.  By the time I 
> am able to respond to a particular subject, many times it has already 
> been talked out, IMO.
> Also, I'm a person of few words, and responding to a whole letter with 
> "Yeah, I feel that way, too" or "Gee, that's AWFUL" is simply bad 
> etiquette.  So many times everybody else says pretty much what I was 
> thinking, so I wouldn't NEED to post.

Yeah... these two reasons fit me to a T.  Also, there's the fact that although
I've been reading this list for more than a year, I never seem to make it to
any raves.  I think my life is just too busy.  Ah well, I'll be in Austin,
Texas this weekend and will be attending an all night crash worship show
while I'm there.  Not quite a rave, but probably as much fun....

I don't think there is any stigmata to being a lurker.  I'm perfectly happy
in the role.  Hopefully, though, I will eventually get out and meet a bunch
of you regulars.  While you probably don't know me at all, I somehow feel that
I know a bit of you from what y'all write, and personally, I heartily approve
of the lot of you.

- Lyle

> hearing from others how raving has enhanced and help 
> improve your life outside of raving. 

OK, here goes a little background for persepective:  went to a few 
raves with a friend a couple o' years ago (been meaning to get out 
again but combination of overwork, shyness, and life problems keeps 
me close to home...don't want to bring my downer side o' life to a 
party!)

What I got from those few experiences is a profound sense of 
connectedness with people, especially people whom I had never met 
before. I carried that feeling into my daily life _ a faith or 
emphasis on being positive, seeking the good in all things, the 
desire to seek out and celebrate the goodness in all people. Then the 
interconnectedness with nature, the world at large, all things. 
Karma-ish? yeah, kinda. Spiritual? definately. Beautiful? of course!

> raving goes > way beyond what words can express.

_like great art, great music, great _


take care,
Alissa

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 20:25:56 -0500
X-Sender: mcrobt@morpheus.cis.yale.edu
Message-Id: <v01520700ab7bd55427c5@[130.132.128.209]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
From: mcrobt@minerva.cis.yale.edu (Rob McCord)
Subject: Re: Kids at Raves
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>What I got from those few experiences is a profound sense of
>connectedness with people, especially people whom I had never met
>before. I carried that feeling into my daily life _ a faith or
>emphasis on being positive, seeking the good in all things, the
>desire to seek out and celebrate the goodness in all people. Then the
>interconnectedness with nature, the world at large, all things.
>Karma-ish? yeah, kinda. Spiritual? definately. Beautiful? of course!
>
>> raving goes > way beyond what words can express.
>
>_like great art, great music, great _
>
>
>take care,
>Alissa

That's totally what I feel!  No matter who you are, you feel a sense of
"connectedness" with all those around you.  Your energy becomes part of a
greater circle of energy and love.  You feel free to be who you have always
wanted to be, because nobody is judging you.  They're experiencing the
exact same rush of happiness =)  And when you leave the rave, you carry
that free spirit and high energy out with you.  You incorporate it into all
facets of life, making things a little bit better.

I have also gotten really close to nature.  The world around us is just so
beautiful.  The variety of plants and animals living with us blows my mind.
They are all coexisting in harmony, a feat humans have been unable to
fully achieve.  I find it really sad that congress does not share my
feelings.  Their new legislation is aimed at severely cutting back or
eliminating most of the environmental laws we have for the sake of
business. The Clean Water Act and many others are going to be toned down a
lot if they get their way, making way for lots more pollution.  All this
for the capitalistic dream of earning more profit.  IT is sad.

Well, the point is, that raves have allowed me to "touch base" with reality
and humanity.  Capitalism sucks.  People are beautiful.  People ought to
tell other people that they are beautiful more often.  The love and bonding
experienced at raves needs to be carried out into the world.  We are the
visionaries, and it isour job to slowly change society.  There was a
Women's movement, a sexual revolution, and many other giant steps made by
previous generations.  It is now time for the next revolution, the one back
to realizing the beaity of humanity.  To quote from Star Terk, Deep Space
Nine, "Greed is Dead."  There were a couple other good ones too, but i
forgot 'em.

The thing i hate about words, is that that is all they are, words.  I hate
writing about making change, because the whole time i am sitting on my
butt, doing nothing.  I better end my letter with this then.  Help extend
our experiences outside of the rave subculture.  All it takes is a smile to
start with, maybe a hug.  LOVE!!!  I'll begin by sending a warm, fuzzy,
energetic loving hug to all of you =).  Share it with others!

Luv,


Rob McCord (BR '98)
mcrobt@minerva.cis.yale.edu

> From: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
> 
> 
> What I got from those few experiences is a profound sense of 
> connectedness with people, especially people whom I had never met 
> before.

What is the connection? one may ask (well this "one" did:)

One thing I'm sure of is that we all *love* the music. Whether it's techno or
trance or house or whatever.. I personally am *addicted* to the music. 
I (and some others I have talked to) get goosebumps sometimes during a 
set or even driving down the road listening to our latest mix tape. 
One dj friend last week said that he sometimes cries..actually gets 
tears in his eyes.. when he hears some music.. or watches an awesome
dj do a superb mix. The only thing that I would have gotten this emotional
reaction heretofore was something like Beethovens 9th "Ode To Joy"...

Anyway... when I hear some great song that gives me this emotional reaction,
I sometimes look around at people and u smile and get that smile back. You
both know what ur smiling at.. then I feel the connectedness that
Alissa talks about... mebbe they feel the same "goosebumps" I do. 
And then I realize
that here we all are, from vastly diverse backgrounds, "ageless ravers" like me,
young ravers like Zack/Elf/Vladimir, people that would normally have little, if anything, in common all having the same reaction to a dj's mix...

Now thats cool :)

hugz

brian

I think the "levelling of the playing field" that is the result of E-mail and
posting to BBS's is still an alien concept to many. That is why lurkers
exist. But never underestimate the value of lurking to lurkers. We/they learn
so much, contribute if/when appropos, but otherwise stay out of the way.
We/they respond to the E-petitions when circulated, forward particularly
compelling posts to friends for their digestion, etc. Lurkers may not be
vocal, but they still are active.

And, don't worry. The day will come in the life of every lurker when it
becomes time to step out to make a point on a certain issue.

Kind of like what I just did..  ;-)

Alissa said:
> >What I got from those few experiences is a profound sense of
> >connectedness with people, especially people whom I had never met
> >before. I carried that feeling into my daily life _ a faith or
> >emphasis on being positive, seeking the good in all things, the
> >desire to seek out and celebrate the goodness in all people. Then the
> >interconnectedness with nature, the world at large, all things.
> >Karma-ish? yeah, kinda. Spiritual? definately. Beautiful? of course!
> >
> >> raving goes > way beyond what words can express.

then Rob said:

> The thing i hate about words, is that that is all they are, words.  I hate
> writing about making change, because the whole time i am sitting on my
> butt, doing nothing.  I better end my letter with this then.  Help extend
> our experiences outside of the rave subculture.  All it takes is a smile to
> start with, maybe a hug.  LOVE!!!  I'll begin by sending a warm, fuzzy,
> energetic loving hug to all of you =).  Share it with others!

I know these concepts come up a couple times a year, but I'm always glad to
see when they do.  It restores my faith that people are still doing this for
the right reasons.  Okay, we *all* love the music: that's a given.  But it
gives me renewed strength to hear from others who see this as more than a
party.  Hell yeah it's a party!  But hopefully at least some of those
emotions you feel will carry over into your everyday life.  That energy and
love is what's going to change the world, not the government.  It happens
one person at a time and if you don't think it makes a difference, you're
fooling yourself.

3 years ago I was bitter... a real cynic.  Somehow I got pulled into raving
and it changed my attitude and my whole life.  Don't tell me that most of
you weren't affected positively in some way by raving.  What changed you?
The music?  Maybe.  The people?  Most definitely.

Keep this in mind in your real life.  It takes so little to keep the
positive energy flowing and so much to fuel the negative.  More and more
people are opening their eyes everyday.  Have faith.  Have fun.  It's GOING
to happen.

vibrating at the speed of love

solarvibe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar  2 23:17:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id XAA21407; Thu, 2 Mar 1995 23:17:58 -0800

	id XAA02762; Thu, 2 Mar 1995 23:17:38 -0800

Message-Id: <199503030717.XAA02762@netcom9.netcom.com>
Subject: come/unity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 23:17:37 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1336      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had another fine time at come/unity, although I think I liked the last 
one better.  This one was a little too crowded for my taste earlier in 
the evening.  I would have went later if I knew they would stay open till 
6am.  I think its great they stayed open that long, a nice unexpected 
surprize.  Thinking the party would end soon since 4am probably kept alot 
of people on the dance floor for the last 2 hours without a rest. I know 
it did for me ,not wanting to miss the last couple of songs.   Of 
course having a water pipe burst in the chill room downstairs causing it 
to close probably got more people on the floor.  Unfortunately there was no 
water to drink near the end, being that they had to turn off the water.

On a brighter note, there were some great times sharing the vibe with 
others who I felt had a great loving vibe coming from them.  I don't know 
if its me or the people in the scene (hopefully both) but lately people 
I don't know are being really friendly.  Feel like I'm getting to know more 
and more people.  For me theres been  less of that clichess feel I've 
heard others complain about in the past.  People seem to be reaching out 
more.  I can feel the love spreading, and recycling.  I'll second what 
somebody said recently, there certainly is some kind of karma thing going 
around.


peter

Yeah, whatever Allen.  Brian is scaring everyone off the list.

Truth is, everyone does it. You do it, I do it, Milton, Peter, Lee,
Greg and Cindy, Ethan, Jayson, Zach - EVERYONE WHO POSTS adds to
the traffic and singling out Brian is a lot of shit.

The traffic on this list is not overwhelming but the decision to read it
lies within the subscriber.  The big part of that decision is whether or not
the content has value to that person.  I've seen a lot of delicious content
fly by on this list and very best of it had nothing to do with raving and
had everything to do with people.  Of course in my eyes, rave=people and its
all connected.

Now maybe it seems silly that something as dumb as techno music and a wierd
little mailing list with too much traffic might be about people.  But to
someone like me whose been rejected by the church, despised by the
government, and feared because of strangeness, this is the only community
I've got.

Rowl, ftttt,

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar  3 11:08:26 1995

Warning-warning Will Rogers Warning-

This is just a poorly written story- none of these people or places are real- 
I have not had related experiences- I just wrote this late at night about 
four years ago- Don't panic-



 I was alone again, nobody to hang with. Everybody was up north skiing they 
had a cabin and are up partying all weekend. What to do my flat is a mess the 
floor in my room is littered with invites to parties that I have been to, or 
will be going to in the future. Thumbing through invites I find a party for 
tonight CRASH it's called the invite reads " CRASH Friday March 26th with Jay 
ERIN FLIP WIG and Shon-e 410 269-0640." Right I call the number same old 
stuff the voice on the line screams "meet at the Plasma room for instructions 
from ten to two all night party no bust guarantied." I shower um warm water 
brings back thoughts of delights long past and over due again. Tonight I feel 
alone its almost refreshing to be like this. I have spent so much time with 
friends. I need to go out on my own, like I used to before I became so 
social. Time to spark a bowl and get high lately I have been getting the best 
green around it is so sweet. What to wear bright red baggy jeans no to much. 
How about baggy blue GAP one's with a dark purple hooded pullover. 
 Out the door to Plasma down Market on to Fourth I brought the E didn't I, 
best check. In my back pack is seven tabs of pure Ecstasy not the stuff you 
can buy in the clubs this is right off the chem floors clean and no speed. 
It's not like me to E alone but tonight I want to be forced to meet new 
people and not have to rely on old friends. The clock on the CD player reads 
midnight I slide the pill in my mouth as the music fills the car with it's 
pounding rhythm. Alone in the night the car and I glide softly into Orbit. 
 
 Outside, Plasma it is real crowded it's going to be a big party no doubt. 
Shit I don't want to come on to E in line here do I, to late I already took 
the pill. Oh that's the part I don't like about it. The come on is so 
explosive for me and I like to be in a place where I can kick it for the 
first twenty minutes or so. In line the people look alive the woman 
especially there outfits are so flowing with there bright orange and purple 
colors and there hair most of which is cropped in the 1920's style or long 
and straight. It's happening my heart is so soft and my body is open to all 
that surrounds me. Each pour of my skin is tingling and my vision is 
fluttering the lights are brilliant but a little to much. People are smiling 
at me like they know and I smile back like right it's smooth I am sorted and 
it shows. 
 A face I can recognize "Hi Adam" he whispers to me what's his name yea hi 
Eric " I am on the list if you have a ride I can get you in." "Right where is 
the party" I ask. " it's at the Attic 178 King ST." Yea I dig it I have been 
there before that place is a trip you have to climb about twelve flights of 
stairs just to reach it." "So can you give me a ride or what Eric says." 
  
 Ridding there in the car Eric talks a mile a minute as the vibe of the House 
music brings, takes us both on a trip through the city that appears to be so 
alive to me that I can feel each groove in the road. "So Adam can you see the 
Moon, no you can't know why cause it's blocked by dust from Nuclear bomb 
testing in Nevada." The winds blow all sorts of stuff around Adam, for 
instance the remains of all sorts of dead creatures are being blown all about 
as we drive. Think about it? Well this guy Eric is flipid what is he on about 
now. "Listen Adam if I was in my forties now I would be studying to find 
myself a new job, something completely different then what I do now." "What 
do you do now." I ask. "Oh I Rave, you know sell shit, you know stuff." 
"Yea!" I replay like a twelve year old on vacation at DisneyLand. 

CRASH:
It is good to be here the thumping of the bass has carried me on to the dance 
floor. From the moment I entered, I felt this presence like someone would be 
coming my way. I am floating with the music my arms stretched out wards to 
everyone spinning endlessly I am in perfect motion, with the sound entering 
every inch of my soul. My eyes open to find the outline of a figure dancing 
in front of me. She is long and thin with straight shoulder length black hair 
that is parted down the middle. Her eyes are as blue as the clearest sky's 
which reflect endlessly with the lasers whisking about in the background. Are 
eyes lock together, something that is not permitted in today's world eye 
contact. She brisks by my side and say's " Hooked are you". I twist to her 
side and reply " on what." She turns away from me and smiles, I look into her 
eyes again and they call me in. They tug at my heart and she walks away. What 
the fuck.

I follow her and she jesters me on with her hand. She leads me up some stairs 
to the roof of the building and we walk outside. The evening is nice and 
contrary to what Eric said earlier you can see the moon and it is near full 
at that. "What's your name, and do you have any more" She asks. "My name is 
Adam and what do you mean do I have any more." "E do you have any E your eyes 
it says it in your blue eyes your on E."  "Right I am going, and I would be 
glad to give you one but what is your name." My name is Claire." I dig into 
my backpack and pull out a tab and a bottle of Crystal Geyser a Raver's best 
friend, plus some gum cause my teeth are grinding a bit. She takes the pill 
and we go and sit on the cat walk over looking down town. Claire asks. "When 
you were young did you ever run and jump into the wind with your umbrella 
open. Do you remember that, didn't you feel like you could fly for ever in 
the wind. I have that feeling right now like I could jump off of this roof 
top and fly through out this city like a witch or something." "Um like right 
sometimes I feel like a diver swimming in an endless mass of green ocean, 
completely naked and free." "Adam, Adam I am starting to peak oh? oh! yes can 
I kiss you Adam can I." I grab her into my arms and we meet softly touching 
lips once and then parting and then slowly drawing each other in again our 
tongues glide in and out of each others. My body feels hers next to it, I can 
feel her every curve and at once can all of a sudden feel her heart beat, I 
need nothing else but to hold her next to me. I start to nibble on her neck 
and can taste drop lets of sweat the kinda sweat that the E brings, and I 
feel a closeness with her unlike I have with any of the others before her.  

We hold each other for hours it seems, feeling the cold air and talking about 
love, life, death and everything that comes between. The sun starts to rise 
and like the wind I feel a rush of life as the pounding music fills the roof 
top. A girl dances like a tap dancer in a trance all around us. She has two 
huge braids of hair flapping in the wind and is wearing Pippy long Stocking 
pants. How weird? Claire watches the girl like she is in awe of her, now that 
the sun is appearing I can see Claire's brilliance she is of light complexion 
in her mid twenties and has the most intense blue eyes with thick eyebrows 
that make her appear very smart. She has a scar on the left side of her chin 
that gives her an interesting flaw. She is very thin and could be a speed 
fiend but I don't want to pass judgment with all things considered. 

She asks me. "What do you want to do today, do you want to go to the after 
party at the bEnd Up." "Yes I reply that will be fun, it looks like it's 
going to be a sunny day and the bEnd Up will be a gas, no doubt." "Do you 
have a car Adam." "Yea I can get us there." Saturday it's noon at the bEnd Up 
and the Queens are out in force dressed in  tight shorts, with leather hats 
on, and dancing in the sunshine. I can't stop laughing at them no matter how 
hard I try. "What are you laughing at Adam." "That guy look at him in the 
dress with makeup on and fake tits, and hairy legs what's up with that? I've 
had enough Claire, I think I'm done fully cooked know what I mean." "Yea you 
want to leave then." I drive Claire home, we kiss and exchange numbers I am 
not disappointed I don't want to go in with her, really?

Riding on the hwy. I feel so high, the lights still glisten as I listen, to 
the sounds pass through me. Life surrounds me, people in there cars  only 
look straight ahead. I am beginning to feel tired and am coming down. At home 
I slide on down to bed to rest. I have not been feed at all today. Um the 
lights are fading "who are you" a soft voice from behind asks I turn and face 
a woman smoking a long cigarette she is wearing a silk black gown that goes 
down to her ankles, she has a hat on with some sort of feather in it and 
looks like someone right out of Harlem in the flapper days. Hi sunshine, I 
reply my name is Adam what are you up to."  My name is not sunshine I am a 
lady not some sort of image in your little boys mind." "Oh pardon me?" "My 
name is Claire she whispers at me" "Haven't we meet before" I ask.  She 
glares at me and then softly let's out a smile. "No I think not. Come with me 
Adam let's go to the Palace." "What's that about." She grabs my hand and we 
walk down the ally she is cold I can feel her nails tug at my skin and they 
are oh so cold. She has a very round face with dark eyes she is pretty, but 
not really my type, she is dark skinned and evil looking no doubt everything 
she has on is black, I bet her whole fucking wardrobe is black. 

Outside the Palace: People are cued up along a brick wall they all smoke and 
the men they are very fancy, I have never seen people like this ever, all in 
black each one of them. They have on long coats white shirts and ties with 
shiny dark shoes. People wave and talk to Claire as we pass on by. I can't 
even glance at the women they are way to much to look at with there fish net 
stockings and cool hats. "Let's go in Adam". 

We enter into a  room that has the feel of a fancy restaurant with waiters 
cruising around fanatically. Claire tugs at me and pulls me down the corridor 
to a stairway leading down stairs. An old guy is at the bottom of the stairs, 
he waves at Claire and smiles we rush by, and Claire say's softly "Hi 
Charles". " A night of the fullest sorts Claire", the old guy chatters. 
Claire says nothing to the guy and we head down some stairs. At the end of 
the stairs is a old looking wooden door, Claire bangs on the door three 
times. A slot in the door opens and a mans voices utters "a pear in the likes 
of order." Claire replies, "it's nice to fly so high." 

The door swings open and a rush of strange smelling smoke leaves the room as 
we enter. The basement is filled with people dancing and lounging about. They 
appear to be smoking opium pipes and the scent is very odd. The music is 
right out of the 20's, the clothes that the people are wearing are very 
flashy. The lady's hats all have feathers and there not wearing much else. 
Men and women are rolling about all over the place. Claire brings me over to 
a couch in the corner of the room. We sit down and an old Chinese man comes 
over and offers us a pipe and some opium. Claire pays the guy and fills the 
pipe. "Have you ever gotten down and done opium Adam", "no I don't think so" 
I say. "Oh you're in for some fun." 

I take a long draw off the pipe and let out a line of smoke in the air, a fast
 rush fills my mind and my body slowly let's out all it's steam. I am empty, I
 have no muscle left. The room around me is spinning and filled with laughter.
 I can see woman floating by, but I can't make out there faces everything is 
in outlines, like a coloring book that needs filling in. Claire is licking at 
my earlobe and I am getting hard? What's going on? Her tongue is racing down 
my neck, I grab at her thigh and she pulls my hand inside her dress. She 
climbs on top of me and lifts me inside her. We ride each other slowly as 
people dance and walk on by. Nobody pays us any attention, as I climax with a 
loud laughter! Claire leans far back, bending backwards toward the ground. She
 then thrusts forward in fast motion and swings at my neck. She has a razor 
blade! She pulls to the side and then slashes the blade across my neck. I can 
feel each drop of blood fall from me

I can feel Claire above me breathing down on me. I open my eyes and she is 
there next to my bed, looking at me with her crisp blue eyes. "Why did you 
leave me, you could have asked to come in. You always leave me!." "How did you
 find me" I ask. "You are listed, I just sort of let myself in." Claire lifts 
her arm from behind her back and I can see in her pale hand a bloody razor. I 
look down to the ground as droplets of my blood fall to the floor. "You never 
cared did you Adam."

from the KAREN half of this account ...


Further comment on Alissa's (?) comment on friendliness at raves!  I don't
know about the scene in sf but up here in vancouver bc I find that I can't
stand club at all any more.  Why?  TOO CLIQUEY!!!  Everyone is totally
concerned with image and getting laid.  Now I enjoy getting laid as much as
the next girl but I'd rather not have to wade through a bunch of dorks at a
club to do so...and as for image, sure it's fun to look cool but the
clothes do not make the person, neither does the hair, the tattoos, the
piercings, the brandings, or what have you.  And at a rave I find that I
feel totally relaxed and free to go talk to whoever I want about whatever I
want without worrying about being taken the wrong way.


YA ALL KNOW WHAT I MEAN???

peace

Hello, my name is Brian and I'm a lurker...

I have occasionally posted (well, ok, VERY occasionally), but mostly I lurk
because I don't really know any of the regulars on the list. I haven't
really gone out very much in the last year and a half... but as always, I
keep saying to myself that "I'll go this week." My girlfriend doesn't
really like ANY form of dance music, and doesn't really like clubs, which
is why I don't really go out much. But I've subscribed to this list for
almost a year (about the time I got e-mail), because it has good
information and a good community of users with much knowledge to share.

I used to be really into the scene, in 1992-93, before it got really
commercial and trendy (That's another reason I stopped going...). As far as
I can tell, it has gotten away from that vibe somewhat, which makes me want
to get into it again.

So that's where I'm coming from...

I will probably be at basics (if not there, wicked) this saturday, my
cousin from Ireland is in town for a while and wants to check out the
world-famous SF club scene. So, if you see a large group of people talking
with an Irish accent, go up to them and ask for Brian. Introduce yourself,
and maybe I will get to know some of the wonderful people on this list. And
then I won't lurk so much...

Respect,
Brian




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar  3 14:06:00 1995
