	id OAA16429; Fri, 3 Mar 1995 14:04:36 -0800
Date: Fri, 3 Mar 1995 14:04:36 -0800
Message-Id: <199503032204.OAA16429@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
From: KOR-IT@ix.netcom.com (Greg Sandler)
Subject: Harmony- Friday, March 10th
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello Friends,

	We would like to take another moment to tell you a little more 
about ourselves...

	About two - three years ago, a group of ravers, (our close 
personal friends from San Jose,) came to the conclusion that being a 
raver and putting in our positive energy as party goers was not enough. 
We decided that we wanted to do more for the scene. More than giving 
candy, hugs, etc. (although those things are really important!) We 
thought the most that anyone could do for the scene was not just to 
attend, but was to provide parties. 

	So, thus born, Harmony. The name harmony means so much to us. It 
signifies everything that we believe in, everything that we are about. 
In our party, there are several different people with several different 
ideas, which are used to create one idea. The idea is a place where all 
ravers, (regardless of age, race, creed, color,) are welcome. No matter 
where the parties are we vow to never exclude anyone. (a.k.a., 21+) One 
thing that annoys us, is when you look at a flyer, and say perhaps, oh, 
Justin Robertson, The Dust Bros., Doc Martin, etc. are performing, and 
you get all psyched to go, and what do you see... At the bottom of the 
flyer, in little tiny print, 21+. No one should ever be turned away from 
an event - period.

	The scene is not about classifications, it is about coming 
together as one culture to expand our awarness about eachother, to 
eachother. 

THE SCENE IS ABOUT POSITIVITY, AND THAT IS WHAT WE ARE ABOUT... 

	Friday, August 13th, 1993 was the date of our first party. 
Everything was going great until we lost our location. It turns out that 
the person that we rented land from, didn't actually own the land. You 
can figure out what happened after that. Your basic, pulling your 
hair out, going nutbar, disaster!!!! So, it was of to Santa Cruz to 
attempt to throw an outdoor party...

	We got busted at the beach, moved to a field on Swanton road, 
given to us by one of the ravers that stuck it out through the waiting 
and turmoil. The party went off! It was sooooo beautiful. People 
dancing, laughing, sharing, and smiling. Dionysus Dreams stuck it out 
and did an ambient area in the forest next to the field where Carlos 
tore it up. 

	Anyways, that was our first party, our first dream. And we have 
done three other parties since then, and with great success. Great 
success to us means that people are happy, not that we made money or 
even broke even. Come to think of it, we have lost big money at all of 
our parties. We don't care!!!!! That is why we do this, because we are 
in it for the scene, not the greed. 

	It is kinda hard not to throw another party when we have ravers 
calling us saying, "Harmony, where are you guys? When's the next one?" 
So, we are doing it again. 

	Friday, March 10th is Harmony and we encourage everyone to 
particpate in making this the best one yet! This is our first indoor 
party, ever... That means we have all the posibilities in the world! We 
have the most beautful location that we could ever dream of. We can't 
tell you where it is on sfraves, but write to us at the address on this 
posting and we will personally write you back with more info.

	Friday, March 10th - 8pm-6am

	HARMONY

	Djs: Tony, Doran, Trent, and Simon 

	Visuals by ? Mark   &  

	Ambient room next to the river of life,  by Dionysus Dreams

Subject: 278 11th Street, (Let them know!!!!)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9503032015.A29268-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Dear Sfravers;

	278 11th Street is a nice place to rave; it has real potential,
but I feel lacks a committed staff. I went there last saturday night, it
was a small but good party, ran into Peter F. 

	It has a pool table that is much more functional than the one at
1015 Folsum. An outside upstairs that would be dynamite in the warmer 
months; reminding me of Simion's in Gainesville, FL. It has a pool 
underneath the dance floor, lots a potential there for a rave pool party. 

	But the party ended at 4am sharp; which meant that 278 11th Street
threw you out into the streets. That particular night there was no were
else to go. I was stoned out of my mind on whatever. I think that if your
going to throw a party, and you're well aware that people who come to them
do party, that the party should last long enough at least 6am so people
have a chance to come down so that they can either walk home in the
twilight, or be safe enough to drive home or go to the End Up or alt. after
party. 

	It's a really cool and neat place, but come on guys; stay open
later. I see that you guys are open to 5am this time, but I will warn
ravers that go there, expect them to close it down at 5am. I don't want to
make the people throwing the party responsible for our actions inside, but
I feel in should be law that if you throw a rave, on the weekend, that the
party should go to at least 6am. I wasn't very happy and neither was Peter
F. at 4am with no place else to go, I just went to the End Up and stayed
outside until they opened, boring!!!!. Again to make it very clear the
each one of us is responsible for whatever we snort, drop, shoot, smoke,
rub into your bellies whatever, you are responsible and should only do
what you're cabable of doing and still be able to take care of your self. 

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

ps If you go let the management know how you feel about them closing, in 
my opinion early, and I feel they will listin to us, they seem like good 
people.

Dear Sfraves;

	I had one of the most mixed nights I ever had in a long time, 
maybe never. I went to All Together Now and 278 11th Street. My jourey 
starts out at final desination of All Together Now.

	WE arrive at the party location after going to one map point to 
find the police, yuk what away to start a night. So we go back to the map 
point and tell the good people of Kinetic, it looks like your busted. I 
having a truck which could assit in getting the PA out off of the bay 
jetty was asked to help and did, We arrive back at the map to find out 
the cops didn't care about the party they were looking for someone with a 
gun. Well, the people of Kinetic run back to the map point and I say and 
help do the previerbial door. Ever go to a party and get asked to work 
the door? Well, anything fo r the scene, I start checking tickets for 
about 2 hours, its about two ao'clock know. I watching these motorhead 
dudes race up and down the streets bringing the police back. The police 
say over there PA leave or will tow you cars, so I do unable to find out 
about what happened to the party.

	I go to 278 11th Street, its looking like a real suck of a night 
folks, and when I get to 278 11th Street, a club supposed to stay open 
till 5am closes at 4am, ah!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Thats all I'm going to say 
about 278 11th Street.

	In total desparation, while on the most killer E I've been on in
awhile, I return to Kinetic's location at the end of Coral Street and what
do I find, the most coolest party I've been to all year. I got there when
Bog was spinning, check him out, him and his girl friend Anie are great
people. The location had been undisturbed by the police on the 2nd
incident, yeah!!!! SFPD. Give em credit where credit due. I got to pretty
much watch the sun come up over the bay, with an aircraft carrier to by
right about .25 miles away, and a large dock crane about 200 yards to
left, the beautiful bay in the center with a killer PA basting the most
awsome Techno and Trance, I've heard in a long time, and a very warm fire
after we raided the Saveway for cardboard and Duraflame logs, yes outside.
This is why I came here, an beautiful outdoor rave at an imprompt to 
location, great works guys sorry for the sarcassum in the begining, I 
guess you guys really mean your name, ALL TOGETHER NOW!!!!!!

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

			"Tuttle Live"

Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA05628; Sun, 5 Mar 1995 00:29:07 -0800
Received: from router.mhv.net (worm.hooked.net [199.2.134.13]) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.10/8.6.9) with SMTP id AAA12126; Sun, 5 Mar 1995 00:29:06 -0800
Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 00:29:06 -0800
Message-Id: <199503050829.AAA12126@well.sf.ca.us>
X-Sender: gregm@well.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: gregm@well.com (Greg McCann)
Subject: All Together Now
Cc: davis@well.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My friend <davis> and I had a wonderful night at All Together Now.  We met at
her house which was just a few blocks from the map point.  We walked to the
map point, saw a lot of people just hanging out, and were told the party got
busted.  Anyway after about a half hour, someone came back and said no, the
party was on.  So we got our tickets and maps, and walked back to our car
together with three new friends who needed a ride.  I was delighted to see
that the location was the same as the last Sunset of 1994 - a great place 
with a wonderful view of the bay.

When we got there, things were still a little tense because of the cops who
were checking us out, but they were semi-cool and at least let us stay there.

We walked out to the point on a dark trail through the grass, past a
brightly lit factory with starkly surreal smokestacks stretching into the
night sky.  A group of happy energetic ravers were dancing to the music, 
sitting around the fire keeping warm and exploring our little peninsula.
The tide was high when we got there, so the point that I remembered being a 
couple hundred feet wide was just a narrow finger of land surrounded by dark
waves, with us in the middle dancing.

The lights of the city shone like jewels in the night, with the Bay Bridge
gleaming like a string of pearls stretching off into the distance.

As the night passed, we became aware of the gentle and powerful planetary
rhythms.  The earth, sun, and moon did their eternal dance and we danced
to our own rhythms as the waves rolled into the shore and the tide slowly
receded, exposing the wet slippery rocks that were under water at the
start of the evening.  The planet turned, the night passed, and the sun 
slowly rose in the east, painting the sky with its approach.  A fiery red
glow turned to gold as the sky grew brighter and the colors spread across
the sky welcoming us to a new day.

We cleaned up the site and gave hugs and smiles to everyone as the world
reawakened from its sleep.

As I returned to the car, I became aware of another rhythm.  The fields
which were dry and brown at the end of last summer were being renewed
again in the growing warmth of the approaching spring.  Beautiful golden
poppies reflected the golden light of the sun and the fragrant fennel
plants were sprouting new growth even as the last of last season's seeds,
dry and brown, still clung to the old stalks.

When the five of us, plus another friend who needed a ride got back to
the car, we tensed as we were approached by a cop.  "What's up?", he 
asked.  "Just watching the sunrise", I said.

greg

ps:  Hugs to everyone, especially Brian D. who I got to meet for the
first time last night, after seeing all his great posts here.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 19:36:38 -0800 (PST)

Subject: plz red Epoping frat boy?


Dear sfravers,

	This was a comment that didn't necessarily piss me off but 
inspired me to say a few things, tell a little story..
Any way the inspirational quote was from Jason Weber to  Lee Fogal that 
was carbon copied to sfraves.  The quote read,"Last time I gave my 
opinion on sfr i think i got every E-popping frat boy in california.  Well 
I am not exactly sure what Jason meant buy this but it was especially 
significant to me for a few reasons.  
	The story sees a college freshmen out on his own for the first 
time.  The freshmen (obviously that is me) goes out and rushes a 
prestigious fraternity. Lamda Chi Alpha to be exact..Now before you hit 
delete please read on...
	So during this first year I happen across a small rave in Santa 
Cruz.  It was small scale and I felt a little out of place ,although I did 
love the music very much.  My friends and I danced sober and I before I 
left I was given a mysterious phone number. The next day I called the number.
One thing lead to another and I experienced my first mind-blowing rave.
The gathering at the richmond civic center.  Needless to say it was quite 
a experience.  Ouch candy flipping is hard on the old system.  Anyway I 
returned to what I now consider cowboy land in comparison to the Bay 
Area ,San Lius Obispo. At this point in time I was still rushing the 
fraternity.  I asked a few of the brothers how they felt about those rave 
parties in San Fransisco.  A summary of a few of thier replies:
"Those people are wierd"
" They have all those earinings in their body , thier just strang and 
wacked out"
	This was obviously a major turnig point in my fraternity life.  
Fraternities tend to accept members I think that kinda think like they do.
Anyway to make a very long story short ,like I haven't talked enough, I 
ended up being dissasociated from the fratenity.  They felt like "I just 
wasn't ready to be a part of the house".  The truth is that my true 
feelings of feeling odd for not being around a group of people that 
excpted raves really really showed through and it came out in my 
interaction with the fraternity.  I don't plan to rush again because I now
know I don't really belong in the Greek Scene.  I hope that the readers 
of Sfraves will sympathiize with me on this subject very much and 
understand that the warm positive vibe ,chemically induced or not, I loved 
so much at raves is much more congruent with my inner personality than a 
Keg party.  I have to say that I have nothing against Keg parties but I 
have such a more positive fulfilling experience at rave parties.  I also 
hope that this message is accpeted as it is my debut message to the 
sfrave community.. My final question for all that I would greatly like to 
recieve feed back on is,  Is it is wrong to want to move and change my 
environment to be closer to this community that I truly love more than 
the current position.  Responses by all are extremely welcomed.  As of 
attending the Gathering I can never make it to the bay area enough to 
continually partake in these rituals of unity, acceptence, and most of all 
love.
	Universal Love and Peace to All ..Dan.

	A.K.A.  (to some)  X-rave virgin

Date: Sat, 4 Mar 95 19:15 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Trip

The Trip
========

6:21:03 AM  3/3/95 - SF time

Well,   here I am,   sitting on the plane with my laptop,   flying
across the Pacific.   I just woke up after 7 hours of sleep.   And
after learning that we are not even half way there yet...   OhMyGawd!
the realization of how long this flight is,   is just now hitting me.
Turbulance is really bad.    Very rough flight.   Hard to focus my
bleary eyes on the keyboard....

There is this neat TV monitor on the plane,  showing us our progress,
and displaying outside temperature as -43 degress BELOW ZERO outside
the plane,    so far,  we've flown about 6000 miles,  and as I'm
typing this,  we just crossed the Equator....   I'm now OFFICIALLY
in the Southern Hemisphere.   Anyway,  the stewardess just handed me
the most grotesque sandwitch I've ever seen.    I nibbled on it
until I realized that it wasn't editable.    

After partying at Come/Unity,  tweaking my brains out,   I wanted to
get as tired as possible (For me,  thats extremly difficult to do).

Anyway,   I'm powering down my laptop and going back to sleep.   At
least I'm going to try...    Got plenty of flight time left to finish
this piece of programming code later....

-------------
10:53:25 AM  3/3/95
-------------

Well,   We're getting closer now....   Still about 700 miles out,  and
I slept another 6 hours.    I feel really refreshed now,   and the
stewardess is now preparing breakfast.   We just crossed an island,
I think it's Tahiti...  (Scuse spelling).    I plug in my walkman
and hear just one FM station.  Announcer is speaking French...

Lots of clouds below me,  and the sunrise took place about 5 monutes
ago.    Hmmm!!  A very LONG sunrise...   Sun is to our left,  and
back sorta behind us.

I see no sign of land,   once we crossed this set of islands where
there appears to be a tropical reef.   For the past 8 hours,   I've
been crossing the tropics.    Really awsome blue sky.   I've never seen
it so blue.    Really deep dark blue sky.

Well,   more later,   as I'm fixing to run some code through the compiler
now and prepare to test it out.    WOW!!  I slept like a baby...  Normally
I don't sleep on planes,   but after Come/Unity I wanted to get myself
so tired that I COULD sleep.    It WORKS.   Dispite the horrible jet lag
I thought I would have,   in my brain,  it FEELS like morning.    I just
had about 5 extra hours in my evening.    Figuring out the time difference
is really easy.   Subtract 5 hours,  and ADD a day,  and you get the
Sydney time.    Cool!!    or just ADD 19 hours.

About to land in Sydney now,   the pilot announced that I have to shut
off my computer before landing...

7:50:53 PM  3/3/95 - Calif time.

Well,  I have been picked up at the airport by Martin Degroot,  i'm
currently at his place at the moment,   and I picked up a power plug 
for the mac,  and am now plugged in,   and I even have a phone adapter
to modular plug for built in modem.

I might be sending this from my apana account,  because telnet isn't
yet activated.

At 4 pm Saturday,  (my time) 9 pm your time (friday) I meet the rest
of the AusRave folks at a cafe,  then go to a pub and have a beer.

Weather here is raining,  although warm (About 75 degress F) so I brought
the rain with me.

This evening,  it's Field of Dreams...

CC

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 5 Mar 95 18:00 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sabatage report from Down Under


Sabatage report
===============

Greetings from Australia...   This is my FIRST rave report from 
Sydney,  and after learning that advance tickets for Field of 
Dreams sold out weeks ago,   and the door price was $70.   Yukk
so we went to Sabatage.    Sabatage was held in a hot and very 
sweaty night club that had little or no chill out opportunity,  ad 
because of the Mardi Gras,  was literally packed shoulder to 
shoulder,  and the only direction I could move is up and down.

Not sure who the DJ's were,   but the music was totally insane 
acid trance,  similar to Goa type of music.    My Australian hosts 
are really great wonderful people,   and it wasn't long before I
they realized the energy level I exist at.    I wasted no time,  
getting out to the dance floor,   as I was getting down to the 
serious business of raving.    The energy level here is totally 
insane,   but the music seems sorta softer at the higher BPMs.
As I was dancing around,   Phil Smart (A DJ that recently did a 
gig in San Francisco recognized me.   It blew him away,   and we 
talked for a while and meminisced the SF rave he spun at recently.

But this rave was really housey,  which surprised me.   Weather 
here still rainey,  although warm and very humid..   As the 
evening wore on,  I got more aggresive on the dance floor,  
spreading as much luv as possible,  and got lots of smiles 
returned back.   The scene here is very similar to the SF scene, 
but the people here are far more polite.   

At about 4 am,   Phil Smart went on the turntables and went 
insane,  playing about 60% of the songs so familiar to our own SF 
scene.    Then he played my all time favorite "feel so good",  and 
I upped the energy level several notches and really got down and 
wicked.    By this time,   most of the local club crowd had left,  
and I really had lots of room to really fly around.

My Australian hosts were totally amazed at my high energy level,  
as they sat outside for a while.   Phil really ripped it up big 
time,   especially after he played "Feel so good".

The rave ended at 7 am,   and we wandered around Sydney,  looking 
for a breakfast place open that early in the morning,   and took a 
cab back to Simon Rumbles place and chilled.

It's now evening,   and I'm over at Bills place,   watching TV,  
and typing in this report.    Now,  I'll post this as soon as a 
line is available.

Cheers...  Lots more to come...
C. Crunch from Down under...

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Syrian Rue is a ground seed which contains the active ingredient harmaline.
It is in the family of Harmala alkaloids. It is generally used to 
potentiate other psychedelics like LSD but can produce EXTREME nasuea and 
vomiting if you take too much. (I know this from experience).

The harmala alkaloids are MAO inhibitors and you should be careful not to 
mix them with certain substances like alcohol or amphetamines.

I highly recommend the book _The Essential Psychedelic Guide_ by D.M. 
Turner (1994, Panther Press,SF) which can give you the full story on many 
substances and the proper safety precautions. I've seen it at Ameba and 
other fine alternative establishments in the Bay Area. An added bonus is 
a beatiful cover graphic by Nick Philip.

Intelligent use of psychedelics can catalyze evolution but they must be 
understood in the right context and used with respect. Happy trips:)

peace,
ronan

Dan, thanks for the story.  To give you feedback on your story and 
question, I can't say what is wrong or right for you, but I can really 
identify with the feeling of wanting to move closer to this community.  

I attended my first major rave about 3 years ago.  It was called freedom 
harvest.  It was on a beach, and to this day is still probably my 
favorite all time rave.   I had enjoyed dancing for some time prior to 
going to that rave, but dancing at that rave with the vibe that was there 
made dancing out to be much more to me.  I can remember thinking, the 
people here aren't just dancing, they seem to be meditating together and 
the music was everyone's shared montra.  That feeling of love and 
connectedness and the discovery of this beautiful psychadelic community 
made me feel like I needed to be closer.  It already felt very homey to 
me, more than where I was living for the last 12 years.  I had already 
thought about moving to sf but after that rave I suddenly found myself 
visiting more and looking for a job here.
Welcome to sfraves Dan.



peter

i know there has been a lot of debate about or staple rave lighting 
effects helper...aka the fog machine...
ahhahahahhahahaha

this is from the examiner (sf) Feb 28, 95 page c-7

"THEATRICAL 'FOG' CAN INDUCE ASTHEMA

     Artificial fogsed in theater productions can induce asthema attacks, 
doctors said Thursday.
     Australian doctors Peter Nolan and Philip Masel warned asthmatic 
actors to be wary of exposure to the substance.
     'We recommend that amateur groups that use such devices should 
forewarn any members of the potential for such exposure to aggravate 
asthma,' they said in article in the British medical journal Lancet.
     The article cited the case of a 15-year-old-girl with mild asthma 
who sufferd an attack while rehearsingfor a school play in which 
artificial fog as used."

dan, your letter struck a very familiar feeling that i had four years 
ago. after going to toontown for the first time i hella wanted to leave 
davis, where i was attended UCD. soon i found myself in san jose and was 
a part of the family of sfravers. problem is that four years later i 
find myself thinking about having finished school there. all the peace, 
love, and harmony that sf had to offer gave way to feeling cynical, 
deppressed and angry that i allowed myself to so fully swept away. people 
will argue that this is a cynical reply and that it has no bearing 
whatsoever towards sf or raves, but i strongly feel that one has to set 
aside the lovey feelings, the drugs, and the vibes and truly think what 
he/she can get out of this before making such a strong decision. chances 
are the first feelings of all this is so fucking brilliant it leaves you 
blinded to the real world. and unfourtunatley its the real world that 
matters most of the time. i hope this doesn't bring you down any. and by 
no means is this a suggestion or warning; its just my story.
peace dj thad

ok i guess i should jump in on this one...

as a high schooler i knew alot about acid house parties and techno 
culture..i then went to a few parties and shipped myself off to dc to go 
to The American University...there i found the net and raves/ravers...i 
became an active ne-raver and still having ties to sf..an sfraver...also 
i helped co found the dc-raves list...i am a member of a global community of 
net-ravers...infact i still remeber when i was first given an sfraves pin 
or neraves badge and welcomed to the "family" or the first time i logged 
on to vrave...

after a while i started questioning why i was in dc so i moved back to 
sf...during that summer before i moved back to sf i traveled around the 
east coast...never staying in a hotel...always with a net-raver...(and 
finally ended up near nyc at laura's house) 

finally getting back to sf...i went on a binge partying spree...i like to 
go out a few times a week...this proved productive when i met a lot of 
people from all over (especially what i like to call the thursday night 
crowd or the your sisters house/(what was the name of that party that 
jonah used to have on thursdays at the troc with the trance music ...the 
name has slipped my mind temporarily..ahhh) but now the novelty of 
partying every night has warn off and i go out occasionally...

i have made quite a few good friends (shouting over loud music or chatting 
away with on the list or vrave) and got back into school (sfsu)...and have 
mellowed out quite a bit...slowly i am becomming a net.geek...

I learned one thing along the way...don't let raving take over your 
life...sure it can be part of your identity but certianly not all of 
it..cuz (gosh i am full of cliche's) what you put into raving (bringing 
stuff to share, diy parties, hugs, whatever) you will get back in ways 
you don't expect...(hell, i never realized i wanted to be an information 
arts and conceptual design artist)

i have found my involvement with the net-raver community positive...it 
lead me to many things i may never have known about or done...but only you 
can know what is best for you...

(infact sfraver old-timers might remember a certian closing of mine..ehheheh)

partyon...susie (:

p.s. no fair saving this and sending it to my grandkids...heheheh

Hiya,

	I aint from San Fransico, but I come down there ocassionally and 
I enjoy reading the posts....I particulary like this thread so i think 
ill add my two cents......I will never forget my first taste of a real 
rave (well if I go on partying like some of these crystal smoking drug 
dumpsters I might), I went apeshit....this was what I had been searching 
for all my life (sounds pretty fucking dramatic but pretty true) and the 
music blew me away....and then I was given a little pill that blew me out 
of the galaxy...it made the music sound so fucking heavenly...I had been 
reading NME and the like about Acid house parties and Raves from England, 
thinking to myself I need to be at this shit....there had only been a 
handfull of records that blew my mind (Meat Beat Manifesto, 808 
State-Newbuild, RSW-In Dub......) and then all of the sudden I was 
hearing all types of shit that was so wicked....holy shit, i thought....I 
remember being psyched for weeks when I saw a new flyer for a killer 
rave....but while all this shit was going on I was stuck in Eugene Oregon 
at the University of Oregon....no one I knew down there even knew about 
these "Raves" and the music and I was going stir crazy....friends would 
call me from Portland to tell me about the warehouse party they were at 
last night while I was sitting in a dorm room with a bunch of dorks 
drinking as many beers as I possibly could....I needed to be beamed up 
back to Portland, so I dropped out of U of O and moved back....and now 
three years later many freinds from U of O have graduated, while I have 
been booted from Portland State University still just barely a Junior, 
working in a restaurant with a bunch of people who have made some wrong 
turns in their life too......I am not saying I regret my moves I just 
want to get thru school now (or pretty soon) while still following the 
music and the raves.....I don't think everyone has to become a suit to be 
"successful", I just don't want to end up like the guy I work with who 
tonight was saying "I should make it out of here in a few years" from our 
shitty job, and this guy is 34 years old, and he is bussing tables with 
me (he got fucked up on cocaine during his twentys)...
I have seen friends get into crystal meth and fuck themselves up 
hardcore...and I have seen others that raved real hard for a year and a 
half and got out of it...and others who have been raving for 4-5 years 
while still keeping their shit together....the only person who can keep 
you from going where you want to go is yourself....it is good to have 
some goals and to keep yourself in check....that is all for my Sunday 
Sermon....
Derek
moses@teleport.com

>It's just not the same without the Crunch bouncing around. 

Hey!!  I'm there dude,  in spirit of course....

Just curious,  where was Wicked this time?    Also,   where was
Basics?

Sorta non rave related material follows,   but today I put in
a good days work for my boss on the E. Coast.   I sat at my friends
table,   hacked out a considerable amount of code and even kept
the compiler from gagging.   Now I got a well fed compiler...:-)

Took my first walk around Sydney... Currently am in the Darlinghurst
area,  and walked around the botanical gardens,  gawking on all the
beautiful birds,  and strange animals.   No Kangeroos yet,  as those
are found in the bush,  far from the city.    I found a great gym
only a block away from where I'm staying.

At night,  they have huge bats flying overhead.   Wing spans about
same as eagles.    Strange!!   There are so many tiney little
differences...   But the one that really throws me is they
drive on the LEFT side of the road.   I just got to remember to
look RIGHT when I cross the street  :-)

Weather here is same as Hawaii...  Rains a lot,  humid,  very
warm nights.    This last sunday,  they just got off of Daylight
savings time.  Now,  they are 18 hours AHEAD of Calif time.
That means,  I go out raving 18 hours sooner....  Drool drool!! :-)

I met Simon Rumble,  who is a great person.   Him and Michael Dagn
are really dedicated AusRavers,  and remind me of Brian Behlendorf
and the other SFRavers.    People here are so polite...  Very layed
back.    There is a very large Gay scene here,  and it's definately
MAINSTREAM and very acceptable by almost everyone.   Even the 
mainstream TV commercials depict Gay lifestyles...

Food here is absolutly great.    Lots of Italian restaurants around
here,  foccacia very popular and inexpensive.   Also,  there are many
coffee shops.   Slight differences... Radio shack = Tandy,   
Burger king = Hungry Jacks...

After my workout tommorrow,  I plan on exploring the Kings Cross area
to check things out over there.   It's a short walk from here.

TV here sux just like American TV,  but more British programs.   A
british program "Bottom" is quite popular here.

One other thing,  my best friend Aaron and Craig are now on internet
but have problems joining sfraves,  although just before I left,
I mailed my request to majordomo@hyperreal.com to subscribe,  but
no sfrave mail at this time.   The address is:  nebula@netcom.com
and I telnetted in to see if they got it,  but none yet.   Would
whoever maintains this list check into this?   I did get mail
back,  saying that the request was sucessful,

Telnetting here is Slow...  So I'm having all mail forwarded to
crunch@sysx.apana.org.au so I won't have to telnet.  Probably
helps reduce net bandwidth anyway.

As soon as I get payed,  I might sign up with a commercial provider
for a backup.

Tommorrow (Tues),  I'm to be interviewed on a radio show.  Then
on Wednesday I'll be meeting the Clan Analogue crew.   I'll report
on them after I meet them at the Bently pub on Wednesday.

Anyway Enuff for now,   just tell me how Basics was pleeze... Where
was it?

Hmmm!  It'll be interesting to recieve the sfraves calander on Fridays
instead of Thursday.

Anyway,  nuff from Down Under...

Cheers,  73's and other types of goodbys...

Crunchman

     Hello Folks,
     
     Well, another --greeeatt-- Wicked passed us by this last weekend, and 
     here IMHO is the report card:
     
     VENUE:C+           To me the basement of DV8 just doesnt do it! Its a  
                        tad too crowded and the low ceiling isnt as       
                        conducive to the great open air feel of warehouses 
                        or the other clubs. Security seemed to be nice 
                        though.
     
     ORGANISATION:A+    Very clear instructions on the Wicked line.. as 
                        well as a very cool DV8 dude who kept telling 
                        everyone, " This line is for Wicked only!" This 
                        kind of stuff helps, as my worst nightmare wouldve 
                        been ending up at Release....
      
     MUSIC:A+           WoW! Ive been to better overall Wickeds, but this 
                        Saturday's had the BEST (wOWzOWIEzOKNKERS) and very 
                        consistent music sets from all the dj's. Markie got 
                        it pumped up early, and then Jeno and Garth kept if 
                        flyin'!!! And of course only as Thomas can, bump 
                        and grind funk, house, and jeez .. even reggae      
                        closed out the musical extravaganza at 7:30.... 
                        Definitely a great dancing night!
     
     VIBE:A             Ive been to Wickeds with a better vibe.. but then 
                        this is totally comparative, because even a Wicked 
                        with a good vibe is AMAZING! Overall, the smiley 
                        happy people were again in great abundance! 
     
     All in all, it was just another great Wicked! As always, YMMHV ( your 
     mileage may have varied.. :) ). Rave on folks! Hope Basics was fun 
     too...
     
     (: blinky blinky off :)
     
     Sy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar  6 11:49:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA08569; Mon, 6 Mar 1995 11:49:42 -0800
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA08561; Mon, 6 Mar 1995 11:49:39 -0800
Received: from xinet.COM by xinet.COM via SMTP (940715.SGI.405/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for sfraves@hyperreal.com id AA04502; Mon, 6 Mar 95 11:46:01 -0800

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 11:46:10 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Brief non-music review of Wicked; and then some
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A bunch of SF Ravers gathered at Hamberger Mary's prior to Wicked.  It was
a great way to start bringing this really special community feeling outside
the clubs and into the world.  The best part was seeing the same people
later at Wicked and sharing a special smile and hug that says "I like you
even when we aren't dancing with Evelyn."  ;^)  It's something we all
agreed should be done more often, maybe for F&F Equinox,,,

Wicked seems to attract great people and this time was no exception.  Lots
of smiles and unsolicited hugs being spread around.  The music was just as
great, but I'll pass the baton onto to a more exprienced critic for that
review.

The only negative was, as Sy posted:

VENUE:C+           To me the basement of DV8 just doesn't do it! It's a  
                        tad too crowded and the low ceiling isnt as       
                        conducive to the great open air feel of warehouses 
                        or the other clubs. Security seemed to be nice 
                        though.

I agree.  To add to the crowdiness, the military-style mesh netting
hindered movement around the floor even more.  Not to cap on the promoters
and/or set designers, but in a limited space, the netting only limited it
even more.

Remember people: tip your DJs with a smile, a hug, a tip of the hat, a wink
or a primal scream.

Thanks all!

Tony@Xinet

P.S. Bonus question of the night (10 pts.):  Who was the freak dancing in
the cow-pattern pajamas?  "I'll have what he ordered..."

P.P.S.  To Dan who wants to move here to be part of the scene:  Strike a
decision based upon equal parts emotion, logic, feasability, and reckless
abandon.

P.P.S.  Fog machines only make a stuffy room stuffier; I'm willing to
sacrifice enhanced visuals for breathable air.

I'm done.  (Whew!)

I couldn't drag myself way out to Basics on Saturday, but I did 
manage to get to Wicked.  I would agree with the previous posts 
about the location.... too low a ceiling in the basement of DV8 
makes it stuffy.  That space also attracts a very "clubby" crowd.  
Despite these two negative points (I guess the second one might be positive 
for some people) I had a great time.  The music was much more 
house than the acid/trance I've been hearing lately.... good for a 
change, but I'll be looking foreward to hearing Carlos rip it up 
again.   									

Peace and love,
Andrew

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar  6 13:15:25 1995

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Date: Mon, 6 Mar 95 13:15:08 PST
Message-Id: <9503062115.AA07970@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: basics review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I'll preface my review with the obvious for you peace and love
folks ... this is All my opinion


basics
why the hell did I drive to Vallejo? (ethan)
was this the most boring party I've ever been to?

Drugs - I was offered drugs a dozen + times.  Out near the parking
lot I was flyered and offered E.  When I ignored him.  IN A RAISED VOICE
he offered me the drugs again AS I WAS WALKING AWAY.  This ridiculous
kind of indiscretion Only happens to me at 18 and over or all age 
parties.  This is the same party that had the cops at their map
point in the fall??

Beggars - Some guy was begging for his charity near the ticket window.
He gives me a sticker with some clever slogan like "looking for the eternal
buzz" (I ran home a slapped that witty refrain on my fridge ...) and
then this clueless guy Doesn't Take NO NO NO NO NO for an answer.  
Salvation army santas and sf homeless are universally more
polite than this joker was.

Chairs - there were no chairs.  no carpets.  no benches.  only cold
cement floors.  for $15 fucking dollars they could have thrown some patio
furniture into a little cafe-like lounge area.  how about umbrellas, candles,
ashtrays, or maybe some flowers?  This was not a damn warehouse breakin
or outside summer freebie.  This was a big budget basics.  My weary
fucking ass no longer considers cement a fun place to chill.

Space - I wanted room and a change of pace from the city clubs.  It
was a great big fairground exhibition hall.  Maybe 2/3's of it was
partitioned into the dance area.  Lots of Generic Uninspired Cliched
visuals.  A laser.  Too many black lights.  The only places to dance and
at the same time escape from the boring/annoying (blck lights) visual effects
were way off near the Bathrooms or equally high traffic spots.

People - were really into Sitting Down in the middle of the dance floor.
there were cool beautiful clever fun people at this party.  they were 
out-numbered 10 to 1 by surburban kids.  Further annoying moment -  
some guy comes up and shines two flashlights in my eyes.  i plead
guilty to thinking this was fun in third grade.  he coulda asked
first.  i don't blow smoke into people's faces just to get there
reaction ...

NO SUSTAINED ENERGY or DANCING
spun threw on a few rave anthems that got everyone cheering like
a rock concert encore - i have no problem with excitement over a song
you really like - the excitement, unfortunately, lasted only as long
as the song.

Dave

Sounds like Matt Mau.

> And finally, can anyone tell me how I can get myself one of Brad's tapes up
> here?

Assuming you're referring to Brad of Mother Earth Sound System, you can 
get his latest, "Basstrip Gaia" as well as any other MESS DJ tapes by 
contacting me, Scottie, and arranging for me to mail it to you.  We 
haven't really done any mail order stuff before, and prices are 
definitely negotiable...$8 for one and $14 for two, we'll take care 
of postage.  If you'd like to send a check straight off, my mailing 
address is 2545 Hillegass Ave. #33, Berkeley, CA 94704.

While speaking of Brad, props are in order for his rockin' set at Basics 
last Saturday...ditto that for Ethan...and much respect and "thank you" to 
Martin for giving this local talent the exposure it deserves!!!  Keep it 
fresh!

mother EARTH sound system

Hi,
Just a quck note [to fulfil a promise,actually:)] to say that
the dj Jeff from sacremento  at the party last friday at 
16th and folsom was really cool, and enthusiastic and made us
dance like crazy. It was a very good feeling, since there werent
a lot of people around, and so there was ample space. It
was very nice of him to continue playing, although it seemed
as though the organizers were waiting to close down. 
He kept playing, almost for an hour after that and enthusiastically; 
and although I am not well versed in the genres of music, 
and the titles of the albums, the beat was something that I 
enjoyed dancing to, and i think he deserves a larger audience.
So if you see him listed again, check him out.:)
and with that,
thats the end of this praise letter:)
regards,
-harsh

Subject: Basics...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Although some of the previously mentioned things were true,
there were too many people sitting in the middle of the floor,
there wasn't a real ambient room, a few other things maybe that
weren't perfect, I have to say that I didn't really care.
I had one of the most amazing experiences of my life at this party.
The lighting and sound system was perfect for creating a mood of
simply exploring the music and your friends without so much of the crap 
that goes around at most raves.  The music was almost all beautiful,
and I found certain pockets of energy in the room where we were really 
dancing harder and with more intensity than I ever have before.
I never stopped dancing and kept meeting people and getting such
smiles out of them the likes you see once on a blue moon.
So, if you were looking for entertainment, maybe this rave wasn't
all that entertaining.  But if you were looking to dance and
take yourself to new heights through the beauty of the music and
people's energy... well this party did that for me much more than
any has for a long while.

still grinning like you wouldn't beleive...
-john.

See everyone at Harmony next friday.

Hi Brian

I liked your setup.  I'll just guess your financial situation is
similar to mine so maybe you are limited in what you can bring but
here is what I imagine - 

a nice big carpet
a chair or two (confortable ones)
a small table with a lamp on it
maybe some magazines
some kind of standing doctor's office looking curtain
wall behind ya - does that one make sense?
a nice frame for your certificate (try thrift store)

REally go for broke.  Make it a full "set".  A trippy space that'll
draw people to watch and hang out.  More of this is desperately needed
at big parties like Basics.  Of course, it wouldn't really work too well
at some of the clubbier city parties.

I'll definitely havta disagree with the previous post about Basics.  
Basics, although not absolutely spectacular, waz really good.  It was in 
this huge indoor space in Vallejo which was quite a drive from San jose.  
The decorations were pretty cool (the banners) but were all really close 
together which left most of the area in emptiness.  The muzik was 
awesome!! especially Tony's set.  Tony just ripped everything apart.  
Although most of the people I saw were dancing constantly through the 
whole party, everyone seemed to go completely wild when Tony was on.  
when he played Rythm Construction even people who had been sitting down 
jumped up and went crazy.  The vibe was really good.  Lots, and lots of 
friendly people.  Free Water!!  
	right, behind the dj, there were these red lights that made a 
verical line but if you shook your head from side to side, these lights 
would make different picture! Wow!  how do they do that??
overall, i had a really good time at basics (because of the vibe, and the 
incredible muzik!) but I do agree that they could have spent some $$ on 
making the space look better or to bring us something new and unexpected.
laters

HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly                          
vekatz@ucdavis.edu

Subject: Political Correctness Revisited

The Electronic Telegraph 6 March 1995

Getting to grips with the Politically Correct hug

By Sean O'Neill

THE "non-threatening hug" was demonstrated yesterday at a workshop at
the Green Party conference. Instead of the full frontal embrace, which the
party regards as menacing and sexually predatory, the Green hug is altogether
more gentle and supportive. A how-to-hug leaflet will follow for those who
could not attend the Weston-super-Mare workshop.

The initial touch should be applied to the shoulders or the middle of the back
- definitely not to the waist (too sexual) or the head (too patronising).

Next, an arm is placed around the shoulders, applied only from the side. It may
be enhanced by a light yet affectionate squeeze. The final phase is the embrace
from the front without the bodies touching. Arms should be placed around
shoulders "rather like a pair of Greek dancers".

Mr David Taylor, 37, the Greens' principal speaker, said: "We Greens are quite
touchy-feely types. But because you go to a Green Party conference it doesn't
mean you want to be hugged all the time. The idea was to deal in a somewhat
light-hearted way with quite a serious issue: one related to sexual
harassment."

Mr Taylor, director of an adult education centre, said: "There is nothing more
threatening to a woman than when a strange man leans over while she's sitting
down, kisses her, pats her on the head and touches her hand in her lap.

"Even a conventional hug can be seen as an invasion or sexually oppressive."

Mr Taylor, one of 70 Green men now instructed in correct hugging methods, said
the training would come in useful in an increasingly physical Britain.

"The English are becoming more tactile generally. There's a lot more kissing
going on."

The politically correct hug was choreographed by Ms Miriam Kennet, 35, an
engineer and member of the party's executive.

She said: "Hugs are meant to be compassionate, not passionate. Basically, it's
not right-on to invade another person's space during a hug. Many men are
totally oblivious to the fact that women are being threatening by what they
simply see as a greeting."

Ms Kennet said the bear hug favoured by world leaders was "uncomfortable and
overbearing", while the traditional handshake was far too formal.

"If the hug is done correctly it's the most incredible feeling. A Green hug is
saying: 'We are working together and I want to support you and I want you to
support me'." Ms Kennet added that men who hugged incorrectly could end up
feeling "lonely, confused and rejected" if a woman reacted negatively to their
embrace.


Reply to The Electronic Telegraph - et@telegraph.co.uk

The Electronic Telegraph is a Registered Service Mark of The Telegraph plc

On Mon, 6 Mar 1995, John Draper wrote:

> 
> >It's just not the same without the Crunch bouncing around. 
> 
> Hey!!  I'm there dude,  in spirit of course....
> 
> Just curious,  where was Wicked this time?    Also,   where was
> Basics?
>(DELETED) 
> Anyway Enuff for now,   just tell me how Basics was pleeze... Where
> was it?
> 

Basics was, well passable.... 
It was held at the Vallejo Fairgrounds. It was $15 and there was one 
room, which immediately dissapointed me. Anything $10 and over and I 
think you deserve a chill space. For the most part it was hard, cold 
cement, although they did have one section of carpet and some pillows. 
The sound was not too hot, being too boomy(space not conducive to sound 
quality) and in my opinion, slightly underpowered. Visuals get an A+ 
however, as they had a laser setup in addition to a few screens with 
stuff running. I was also not impressed with the DJ'ing(man I am sounding 
down on this....) There seemed to be a lot of cut mixing, letting a song 
run it's course, before putting something else on. This made for a choppy 
vibe as nothing really flowed much. They did have free water, and 
inexpensive juice. About the biggest plus there was, was the availability 
and quality of the party accoutremount.... :)

All in all I have been to better BASICS, and feel that maybe I shouldn't 
have been so lazy and drove the extra 30 min to Wicked. 

                                                  Black Adder

        I think that when it comes to a choice as big as this one you must
follow your own intuition and everything will work out alright.  I had a
very similar experience in my life. In fact it is a tremendous coincidence.
I to was part of a fraternity, in fact it was Lamda Chi Alpha.  I was
going to school in Ft. Collins, co. which is about two hours north of
Denver.  Anyways, I visited the East Bay and realized I was living in a
fantasy world. I just decided to move, to get away and allow a change in
myself.  That was about two years ago and since that time I have
experienced much change and personal growth. I think you were quite lucky
to have discovered raves before you ended up in the emotional wasteland of
a Fraternity.
        As far as measuring how your decision will affect you in the "real
world" I think that you must decide what is real, the love you feel at a
rave or getting a job.  Don't let your fears dictate your choice. I know
this is a bit fragmented, but I hope you are able to understand it.
Love,
GABE

---------------------------- Forwarded  ---------------------------
From: mw-raves-owner@hyperreal.com at SMTPGATE
Date: 3/6/95 8:16AM
*To: mw-raves@taz.hyperreal.com at SMTPGATE
*cc: 313@taz.hyperreal.com at SMTPGATE
Subject: Detroit PD wants to abolish Detroit Parties (please read)
-------------------------------------------------------------------

I still haven't gotten all the details yet, but Saturday night's party at
1515 Broadway (originally scheduled for 1315) was busted _hard_.  Everyone
there was ticketed: adults for "loitering", minors for violating curfew.
The cops apparently forced everyone to the floor, searched everyone, asked
for ID, the whole third world police state trip.

We weren't there -- having read the silly scare piece in the Detroit News
the week before, we figured that the PD would pick this weekend to make a
big "show of force", and unfortunately we were right.

Channel 7 cameras were there as the bust took place, which indicates to me
that the PD had this planned as a media event from the very beginning.
The clip I saw showed officers with _guns drawn_ ordering people to the
floor.  The report on the 11PM news of course followed the city's party
line to the letter: "this was an unsafe, overcrowded building, we found
drugs there", etc.  They _did_ mention however, that no alcohol was found,
which makes the idea that they busted it because it was an illegal "blind
pig" very suspect.  The cop on the news said "This organization is very
mobile -- they moved the party from another location down the street
earlier in the day to avoid us, but we found them anyway."  Ha -- this
organization, as if party goers and organizers are some sort of sinister
Mafia-like cabal with a planning hierarchy and structure...  whatever.

The other comments by the cops only confirmed how truly clueless they are
about the whole thing: how the parties were a "new phenomenon" they were
going to put a stop to, and how they were something for "out of towners"
(neglecting to mention, of course, how many of the DJ's and musicians
live and work in the city.

In a nutshell, thanks to a rash of sensational press coverage, the city
is coming down with both jackboots on _your right_ to freely assemble and
dance to the music of your choice outside of a club environment.  I'm
going to get contact information later for officials at city hall and
police headquarters so that we can all make our views heard.  If you've
ever attended a party in Detroit, or enjoyed music from a Detroit artist,
you need to speak up to preserve what we've built here.

Show them that there's more to life than busting parties and scarfing down
jelly donuts.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
dave walker, detroit art services                             _
marmoset@msen.com                       absolutely sweat, marie

<A HREF="http://www.msen.com/~marmoset/">Dave Walker</A>

I got a EP from Solid Grooves recently that I really like. The artist
is Wallstar ( Bates/Twichett ) , on the Immortal Records label. The
title is "Shadow Overture E.P.". The cut I really like on it is 
"Shadow Overture" , and the other cuts are good , although with 
different moods. 

 "Shadow Overture" has an ostensibly slow , dubby beat , but the ragin' 
conga/tabla percussion bubbling away over the bass beat kicks the actual
dancing rythmn way up in the BPMs! Add a grand yet simple melodic line and
atmospheric twitterings that sound like a gossipy audio oscillator on
speed. 

 So - can the musically knowlegible out there recommend similar 
tribal/trancey/trippy tunes I could hunt for? 

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From: nrg@ultima.org (ethan miller)
Subject: Basics
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings!

First off, many thanks to all of you came to hear me, I *really* appreciate
the support; helped out a lot too...  I played one of my better sets ever.
I'm remastering the tape and adding some material to the back side (it's
110 minutes :), so look for it at ameba and primal soon :)

All in all I have to confess to being fairly disappointed in the party as
well. My main gripe was the sound; it was totally insufficient for the
space and, while passable standing directly in front of the dj, was
absolutely atrocious throughout the bulk of the building. And yes, I have
to agree, $15 with no chill space is really a bit much especially when most
areas sounded as bad as they did.

Really I think the space was just too big (spacially and fiscally) for a
basics and hence got skimped on a bit. When the gathering was there they
used a *much* bigger sound system (plenty :) and had a chill space, but
then again that night, the whole place (everywhere) was packed...

However, after spending every day since December 17th trying to find the
right space for Friends & Family, and only having just done so, I'm
prepared to be a little bit more forgiving than I might otherwise be;
finding spaces, especailly 18+ spaces (let alone all ages!), is an absolute
fucking nightmare these days... and, when it comes right down to it, few
people are really willing to take on the risk and the effort associated
with trying to pull this shit off... which doesn't mean we shouldn't hold
them to the highest of standards and judge them, harshly if need be, on
their merits but, all that aside, I'm glad people are at least throwing
parties; many people did have a great time; I saw the smiles on their faces
:)

I would also encourage everyone to let promoters know how you feel about
their parties. Give em a call... rant, rave, call it like it is. Honest
feedback is *really* important; I certainly welcome it, and I'm sure martin
does as well.

take it easy
ethan

Well after 2 hours of contract negotiations last night, we do have a deal,
though I gotta tell ya, I'm really fucking tired of arguing with people
that want to sell water; this deal almost fell through on that issue.

So, as it stands, they will sell "premium" chilled water, juices etc. *and*
we will provide free water at tables immediately adjacent to their "bars"
one upstairs, one downstairs...

Bust-wise, if we were to get shut down before midnight we'd pay $500,
by 2am, $1000, after 2:30 am the whole amount; to quote Lamont, "I'm not
renting you the space by the hour..."

Though really I'm not too worried about getting shut down.

On the good side, they are hoping to have the all the junk downstairs
cleared for us and maybe even a new paint job; they're moving the gallery
to that room :)

So, that's the news... I hope it's palatable enough to everyone; I did the
absolute best I could.

take it easy
ethan

"D. Ronan Hallowell" writes:

 > Syrian Rue is a ground seed which contains the active ingredient harmaline.
 > It is in the family of Harmala alkaloids. It is generally used to 
 > potentiate other psychedelics like LSD but can produce EXTREME nasuea and 
 > vomiting if you take too much. (I know this from experience).

Take heed of his warning. I know of one person who was just a bit
careless on the dosage, and ended up having a horrible 7 hour out of
control terror trip. Not only can too much induce nausea, it can
qualititavely modify the experience in very bad ways.

Read about it. Start slow, with conservative dosages.

Sean

karen & lauren writes:
 > Gawd, that report doesn't surprise me at all ... and why do people think
 > it's so cool to choke a club or whatever up with apricot smog?

Apricot? I guess that would suck.

Artificial fog is cool, especially when laser beams go through it :).
Glycerine based fog isn't too bad as long as it's used lightly, and
with breaks. And of course it can exacerbate an allergy attack, like
cigarette smoke and 100,000 other things.  I feel that (a) that's
tough; if you don't like it, leave, and (2) venues with fog machines
should have that fact posted ahead of the cashier.

Sean


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  7 12:06:05 1995

From: Jeremy Rhoten <mazlo@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Ravography
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9503071146.A14126-0100000@am.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi, I'm a student at the University of California at Santa Cruz.  I'm an 
anthropology/psychology major and the opportunity has come up for me to 
do an ethnography on the culture (or sub-culture) of my choice.  I 
figured what better choice than rave culture.  It's got music, it's got 
dancing, its got ecstacic trance, it's got community, all the makings of 
a tribal culture with a few technological twists.  Most of all though, it 
sends some of the most positive messages you can find in today's world.  
With that in mind I was wondering if a few sfravers (especially those who 
rave for the reasons above) might answer a few of the following questions 
(as briefly as you want) and e-mail them to me.  

1. A few general statements about why you like to rave.

2. Comments on the relationship between rave culture and technology.

3. Is the music the most important aspect of the culture?  What do you 
like about techno and other electronic music?

4. How important are the drugs for promoting the rave vibe?

5. The rave culture is very different from the hippie culture of the 60s 
(though many philosophies are the same).  Any contrasts/comparisons 
(especially the apolitical nature of rave culture).

6. What changes has the movement gone through since you've been part of 
it?  What are the effects of commercialization?

7. Do some raves have more of an ego vibe than others?  Is there a sharp 
distinction between the underground movement and the popular/commercial 
scene?

8. Where is the movement heading?  Will it survive or will it die when 
the music and fashion inevitably changes (like the hippies)?

9. Anything else you'd like to add?


Thanx and blessings  in advance to all any/all who reply.  I'm 
mazlo@cats.ucsc.edu

Unity is the key,

mazlo

I have some experience with safety issues concerning disco fog because of a
stage production I did.  We wanted to put a person in a large burlap sack
with a fog machine (picture a large amoeba shape wandering around the stage
emitting plumes of smoke).  A safety mask was required because of the
concentration levels of the stuff within the sack...

I don't think that the concentration levels of disco fog at a club are going
to be a health concern, unless of course you go right up to the spigot and
take a huge disco fog bong hit.  I haven't tried this yet.  I guess though
that there are probably some people out there who would be naturally
allergic to it.

Remember, don't hog that spigot, mango. Pass it around.

Paul

Sean Casey writes:

>Artificial fog is cool, especially when laser beams go through it :).
>Glycerine based fog isn't too bad as long as it's used lightly, and
>with breaks. And of course it can exacerbate an allergy attack, like
>cigarette smoke and 100,000 other things.  I feel that (a) that's
>tough; if you don't like it, leave, and (2) venues with fog machines
>should have that fact posted ahead of the cashier.
>

>
>

Geez Sean, that seems a little harsh considering fog is just to enhance
visuals.  To say, "that's tough; if you don't like it, leave..." just
doesn't seem very conducive to the culture we're trying to promote.  In
fact it sounds like something a bouncer might say upstairs at DV8, or maybe
the Sound Factory.  I mean, without the people, Sean, you're standing alone
in an empty room with no music...think about it...

Wondering if maybe the fog machines can be turned off after a certain point
in the night, like when the place gets packed,

Tony @ Xinet





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  7 16:41:23 1995

Received: from bsd.iccse.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA27663; Tue, 7 Mar 1995 16:41:19 -0800
From: soundgod@iccse.com
Received: from iccse.com (uucp@localhost) by bsd.iccse.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with UUCP id QAA06106 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 7 Mar 1995 16:43:22 -0800

Subject: frog machines(rrrribbitt)
Date: Tue, 07 Mar 95 16:39:05 EST
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I sell fog machines and used to have asthma problems.

I probably use a fog machine as much in an 8 hour day of work as they
did at the three year gathering at the armoury in three hours(mind you,
I work five days a week.)

I'm no worse for the wear, but the only thing you have to be concerned
about is the old oil based foggers. they suck. the new alcohol and
glycerin based ones are safe with a minimum amount of clean DRY air.
they make different size foggers for different size occasions. If
promoters or the visual personell heed to this specifications, then no
one should suffer from these machines.

my comment about dry air was that the fog produced be machines will
condense water at a lower temp than normal. This condensation will enter
the lungs and cause a simular reaction to a mild asthma attack. The
problem can be solved simply by drinking some water and holding your
breath for 15 seconds or so(this will cause the water in your lungs to
heat to body temperature and evaporate when you exhale).

UNITY THROUGH THE SENSES
SOUNDGOD@iccse.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  7 16:55:10 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id QAA28651; Tue, 7 Mar 1995 16:55:10 -0800
Received: from relay1.UU.NET by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA28644; Tue, 7 Mar 1995 16:55:06 -0800
Received: from sco.sco.COM by relay1.UU.NET with SMTP 
	id QQygch28336; Tue, 7 Mar 1995 19:55:02 -0500
Received: from tehama.pdev.sco.COM by sco.sco.COM
	id aa24895; Tue, 7 Mar 95 16:40:47 PST
Received: from moscow.pdev.sco.COM by tehama.sco.com id aa09311;
          7 Mar 95 16:55 PST
From: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>
To: mazlo@cats.ucsc.edu
Subject: Ravography
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: SCO Portfolio 2.0
Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 16:54:37 -0800 (PST)
Message-ID:  <9503071654.aa01523@moscow.sco.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


        If I answer do I get a copy of your paper?  I'm sure you'll get 
answers from other people more into the scene, but it really interests me...

> 1. A few general statements about why you like to rave.

        intense experience, positive vibe, good music

> 2. Comments on the relationship between rave culture and technology.

        acceptance...  sometimes even love.  I don't think it goes as far
into worship as rock&roll though.

> 3. Is the music the most important aspect of the culture?  What do you 
> like about techno and other electronic music?

        the music is the focus but there is much more to the culture.
Take away the PLUR (peave love unity respect) and the culture would be
gone.

        I like the music because it explores new ground, and is more
purely musical than most other modern music.  and of course the rhythms
are good for you.  Also the relationship between the DJ and the crowd
can really amplify the energy (the best techno is mixed live).

> 4. How important are the drugs for promoting the rave vibe?

        drugs are a form of technology, and are accepted just like
the music, visuals and environment/space.  moderate use of alcohol is
pretty important though I think.  Also I think there are many other
drugs which reduce the vibe (the harsh ones and the other downers).
We all know which ones enhance the experience (used properly).

> 5. The rave culture is very different from the hippie culture of the 60s 
> (though many philosophies are the same).  Any contrasts/comparisons 
> (especially the apolitical nature of rave culture).

        I think the fundamental idea of personal freedom is the same.
I don't think all hippies were/are political; on the contrary most reject
politics per se (is rejecting politics a political act?).  Another hippie
stereotype is rejection of technology; even thats not so straightforward
though -- I think the "hippie ideal" involves "appropriate technology".

        Check into the evolving relationship between the Rainbow tribe
and the ravers.  Also, the Deadheads.  Look for ravers in tie-die.

> 6. What changes has the movement gone through since you've been part of 
> it?  What are the effects of commercialization?

        I havent been in it long or deeply but it does have to deal with
more commercialism now.  It's being handled well elsewhere in the world
though...  its almost mainstream in Europe for example, and the music is
popular in latin america.  I'd even say the primary (native) culture in
many parts of the world is rave-like.  the USA's puritanism still causes
problems, especially combined with greed (unscrupulous promoters).

> 7. Do some raves have more of an ego vibe than others?  Is there a sharp 
> distinction between the underground movement and the popular/commercial 
> scene?

        the club/bar scene is different from the rave scene.  more trendiness,
less freedom in club types.  no two parties are alike though, and some clubs
can be cool.  This is obvious, right???

> 8. Where is the movement heading?  Will it survive or will it die when 
> the music and fashion inevitably changes (like the hippies)?

        hippies are still alive (rainbow for instance, also look around santa
cruz).  ecstatic dance has been around for millennia.  part of the rave
is pagan, or at least not fundamental "christian" (I think the original
christianity was co-opted by power-hungry assholes)....  so I'd say there
has been a little fad in some parts of the world for the last 2000 years
which has devalued ecstatic dance, but we're getting over it.
Civilization can survive without oppressive religions...

        I can't wait to party off-planet (in orbit, not with the aliens
necessarily), and I'll bet most people who choose to go "up there" will
accept technology, and lots will believe in freedom...

Andrew

PS I was going to send this personally, but after typing it all in I thought
        I'd "de-lurk" for a moment...
AK
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RE: susan's report on fog machines (clarification)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I said:

>Glycerine based fog isn't too bad as long as it's used lightly, and
>with breaks. And of course it can exacerbate an allergy attack, like
>cigarette smoke and 100,000 other things.  I feel that (a) that's
>tough; if you don't like it, leave, and (2) venues with fog machines
>should have that fact posted ahead of the cashier.

That wasn't written very well. Let me try and restate:

Venues that use fog machines (or even those that tend to be thick with
cigarette smoke) should be required to state so somewhere before
patrons pay to get in.

At the same time, I don't think all those people who love laser shows
(which need some fog), and industrial shows, which sometimes use tons
of it, should be deprived of it because some people can't tolerate it.
Perhaps a compromise could be worked out so that people who *love* fog
and those who hate it can both get a chance.

Sean

Dear Sfraves;

	I read many fine comments on effects machines, and here's my 2 cents 
worth. I promise to keep it short, and do the doctoral disertation stuff 
that I 'm used to.

	Laser's need fog, people who want to have sex at raves need fog, 
fog doesn't need anything, it works just fine by itself.

	A low wattage laser, the type used in effects, target
aqusition/guildance, super market check lines  ..etc, will if a direct hit 
does occur with the human eye, place a permanet microscopic mark on the 
retina. All milarty(MIL) personnel are required to wear expense gogles to 
either elimiate or minize this undesirable effect of low wattage lasers. 
No one know's whether or not this is harmful to the long term health of 
the eye, it depends on which experts you talk with and they even 
disagree. I'm not advocating going out and staring into one of these 
devices, I suggest you follow your mothers immortal words of wisdom; god 
only gave you two eyes, don't mess with them.

	If you've ever had a direct hit, believe me you are very aware of 
this. You see the brightest thing in your eye next to a nuclear exposion, 
or the second coming of christ.

	As far as fog machines  go, I think these devices are great. I 
don't have any respitory problems though. They provide great cover if you 
are ahhh involved with someone you care about for that moment. Someone 
mentioned the alcohol type, and yes these devices are much easier to use 
than the dry ice machines, what a pain in the ass thoose things are, and 
big and heavy to. 

	So there my 2 cents worth. To save bandwidth yes I used to design
guildance and target aqusition stuff for our goverment. After desert storm
I really couldn't justify what I was doing. We did a great job, keeping
the American death toll down, but destoried over two million of another
race of human beings. I would never tell anyone not to do what I did. But 
for myself I chose not do be a part of that anymore. Saddam deserved 
everything anything he could get, not his people, I just wish he could have 
felt, just a small % of all that firepower.

	I'm for life today, that proably why I'm a raver!!!!!!!

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

			"Tuttle Lives"

From: SHall@ix.netcom.com (Sean Hall)
Subject: new SFRaver, please read  - it might remind you of something important! 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello you beautiful people - 

	This is my first time posting so I thought I'd start by saying hi and 
telling you a bit about myself.  My first party was a toon town in March of '92, but I
didn't feel as if I was a part of the scene until a few  months later.  All I remember
was being blissed out dancing freely with not even a trace of my consciousness being
directed at myself (for the first time since I was a child I'm sure).  Suddenly I 
stopped, noticed humdreds of people around me seemingly in a similar state, noticed the 
morning sun and moisture in the air, noticed the water surrounding us (we were on a
peninsula - it was almost an island), noticed an exquisite man with blue hair freaking
out beautifully to the beat, oh yeah the beat... then the music came back into my
reality I began dancing again, looked around one more time, realized I loved everyone 
and suddenly understood that the rave experience was much more than I ever hoped it 
could be.  I left that party feeling as if I was part of something, part of something
more beautiful than I had ever hoped for.  A few months later at Vision (remember this
one?  humongous warehouse, the best music ever, drum circles, thousands of people, 
probably the most amazing vibe I can rememeber) I had another profound, timeless, 
ecstatic, seemingly divine experience.  I won't try to explain this one it was 
completely ineffable, let me say this: I emerged a completely new person and the 2 1/2
years since then have been spent attempting to integrate into my life what was learned
in those few seconds.  This scene has been extremely influential in shaping the person
I am always becoming.  I'd like to thank everyone for making it what it is.  Thanks for      
the memories and I look forward to what the future has in store for us... plenty I'm 
sure.  I mean our scene is looking pretty damn good, don't you think?  It's had it's 
ups n  downs, but here we still are, strong as ever.  And the vibe? yeah the vibes still
here, maybe not as breathtaking and electric as it used to be, but definitely more 
constant, more mature, ya know?  And in this sense it's even more powerful than it used 
to be.  
	Anyway, although I've been a part of the scene for 3 years and have 
had a modem for a year, I've only been on the net for a couple weeks (kinda silly 
huh?).  Maybe you know me.  My name's Sean, I'm from Sac, have long blond hair, fair 
skin, glasses, sideburns, goatee, septum ring, hopefully a smile but you know these
things can't be forced.  Just thought I'd say hi.  I'll be on SFRaves for about 2 weeks
then I'm off to drift around the country for 6 months before returning in September to 
transfer to UCSC.

		Take care, love you, thank you, BE STRONG (it's your choice)
 					
						Sean,	   


P.S. - I'm listening to Break It Down (Garth) and I still get chills!!!!!

Maybe I wrongly took offence to this but on a post about basics Dave wrote:
"there were cool beautiful clever fun people at this party.  they were
outnumbered 10-1 by suburban kids."

I'm a suburban kid, I know many other "beautiful clever fun people" who are
also from the suburbs.
What I'm getting at is if raving is about peace love unity and respect,
stereotyping people is hardly respect.  Stereotyping is were bad things
begin, which lead to the erosion on unity and peace.  Without those there is
no love, and therefore no philosophy of raving, in other words raves are
useless.
I'm sure Dave didn't mean to insult anyone though.

By the way, thanks to all who gave suggestions for my party.  I'll keep you
all updated :)  See you all at Harmony.
Love Always,
The Elf Queen

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar  8 12:16:59 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: 1015/Basics/Gardening
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Checked out 1015 on Fri., curious as to how 4 clubs in one would feel. Hmm,
feels kinda oogy. =)  You gotta walk through the disco death chamber to get
to the housier parts and the crowd was a dressed up, feel up kinda crowd.
There was some good music both in the main room and downstairs (until the
water pipe broke). Mostly house, fairly commercial, although Jeno played
some decent stuff. Left before Tracy went on, but heard good things about
her set.

Got to Basics at about 2am on Saturday. First impression - nice visuals,
nice crowd, uh, but about that music, now....Evidently Spun forgot his funk
credentials at home, and I wasn't into what he was playing. Half the crowd
was sitting down in the midst of the dancefloor - looks like some massive
e-wave caused everyone to drop to the floor spontaneously. =) Tony went on
and totally hyped the energy about 300% - you could feel it. He played a
ridiculous acid set. Jon Williams did a good job of keeping everyone going
and Josh finished it up with some decent house. Most surreal moment: Tony
walking by and patting me on the stomach.

It wasn't stupendous, but it was a nice party.

Joe

America as well as the personal mistakes and random chaos that shadowed
some of the Zippy Events. But the mote in your eye phrase keeps coming to
mind. What I would really like to know is this: are you really arguing that
this is all just an attempt at manipulation, an evil conspiracy?

 David Dei 007 on her raverness' service?? Cloak and Dagger video here we
go hee hee.
