From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9503090052.AA25415@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, megatrip@best.com
Subject: Re: Chemica Sutra
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dave Dei wrote:
The plan is to use this [the advertsied Chemica Sutra event] 
as a petridish for growing wider community support for fulblown rave 
orientated Megatripolis Events in May.

I responded:
This is not a flame, but I find the above statement a bit presumptuous
considering that Fraser & friends so far haven't been able to generate
much support for their rave vision from the current rave community here.
 
To which David replied:
> Really? Which community are you talking about  the rave-elite?
> Fraser is one of the few voices arguing for a broader rave culture.

I'm talking about the SF Bay Area ravers, the people who actully go to 
raves and to varying degrees perpetuate the so called rave culture.  Most 
ravers that I know ended up not supporting supporting whatever it was 
that the Zippies claimed to represent.  After the 1st freebee, 
Megatripolis failed to attract Bay Area ravers to their party.  Other
attempts by the Zippies to promote their ideas were met with derision
in this and other forums, for whatever reasons.

Personally, I like a lot of what Fraser Clark has to say.  But ultimately,
what good are words if you can't get people to act on them?  He couldn't
promote harmony amongst his own Zippies, Megatripolis flopped, and
now you tell us that he's going to entice our parents with sex to get
them to attend upcoming Megatripolis parties with us.  As cynical as I
am sounding here, I really do like many of the ideals that Fraser spews.  
I even think (perhaps in ignorance) that he is sincere and not just on an
ongoing self-promotional campaign.  But he just doesn't seem to know how to
get in touch with the actual, living, breathing rave culture that already 
exists here.  

Raving isn't about helping subculture celebrities sell their books 
(though I find nothing wrong that).  It's about coming out of yourself
to share and connect through music and dance.  Fraser promotes himself
as "zippy extraordinaire", but I have found that most of the people
who really understand what our community is all about are all the 
*ordinary* folks who have managed to generate an amazingly unambiguous 
vibe for quite a few years now.

Apologies to SFRaves for resurrecting this debate.  Hopefully, Megetripolis
will get it right when they come back in May.  In the meantime, Janie & I 
are looking forward to dancing with some of you at Ultrasonic, and of 
course, at Family & Friends on the 18th.

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (   ( ((truth-love-energy))  )   )   lee@hyperreal.com

Cc: lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Excuse me pardon me -- and I'm sure Robert can defend his point much better
than I -- but I was talking with Robert right after the conversation he
mentioned and we were both shaking our heads about the unwillingness to
even consider arrangements to bring in the very people who basically
invented the sonic tools that have evolved into the hard-trance and
faster techno styles.  I mean, we're talkin' *Detroit* here, right?

And certainly there would be logistical and monetary issues involved 
with booking the people Robert knows.  But let's face it, they virtually
never make it to the West Coast except for Richie Hawtin once in a great
while, and we're less rounded musically because of that, I think.  And
after my brief visit to Detroit last summer I'm determined to help 
support what the Detroit DJs and musicians and producers are doing
because many of them really are still truly devoted to the music,
wherever it takes them stylistically. 

But even all this is beside the point.  I want to avoid undue flamage,
but let me make this one point and then get out.  I'm all for diversity
and different types of events, like Chemica Sutra.  There's a pressing
need to develop beyond the two-turntables-mixer-amp-sound-system-and-a-
couple-of-lights type of party.  But I am not interested in buying into
the hype, and ultimately the ego-worship, demanded by Fraser and David
Dei and the other self-proclaimed Zippies.  

As one of my current favorite tracks makes clear, this is about going
*beyond* the ego.

c u in the future
phred

One more thing.  Lest there be any misunderstanding, I am not at all
upset or alarmed that Chemica Sutra and the Friends & Family events
are on the same evening.  Instead, I would encourage those who can
to check them both out.  There was some concern that the December 17
F&F would conflict with the Gathering and Stompy events the same night,
but it turned out fine, all three parties were happenin'.  There is
more than enough room to grow in the SF scene.

I can't speak for anyone else involved in F&F but I rather suspect this
view is widely shared.

thanks
phred

At  5:39 PM 8/3/95 -0800, Fred Heutte wrote:
>One more thing.  Lest there be any misunderstanding, I am not at all
>upset or alarmed that Chemica Sutra and the Friends & Family events
>are on the same evening.  Instead, I would encourage those who can
>to check them both out.  There was some concern that the December 17
>F&F would conflict with the Gathering and Stompy events the same night,
>but it turned out fine, all three parties were happenin'.  There is
>more than enough room to grow in the SF scene.
>
>I can't speak for anyone else involved in F&F but I rather suspect this
>view is widely shared.
>
>thanks
>phred

thanks for the plug

The thing to remember is that the Parallel University is conceived as an
educational/experimentational/expeditionary  and intimate event  which we
hope to replicate around the bay and geared towards different age and
financial groups - so we anticipate a bigger lower cost event at a later
stage, along with other great topics like Dancing down the System - Theory
to Praxis 101 etc. This is a modular concept that can easily be
incorporated into other events or a Megatripolis Full Blown Rave situation.
Basically we want to push the educational aspect of raving. So I would
reccomend F&F for those who want a full rave, and our event for those
wanting an introduction to Sex Chemicals and other nutrients and so on - I
do'nt see why we cant increase the scene this way, by bringing the
underground into the overground in a way that maintains the essential
life-affirming information.

Lets not get into a flame war over this, but rather concentrate on the
synergy of new angles on a long running theme.

- david dei

( I'll keep & loose my ego as many times as I want, thanks )

On Wed, 8 Mar 1995, David Dei wrote:
> If you were trying to achieve a group trance dance with limited space and
> trying to introduce a music form that had not received much coverage
> wouldn't your priority be to get the appropriate music onto the dance floor
> first. THEN tackle the question of whether or not to have ambient, gabber,
> jungle etc areas ie in an expanding  party?

No, because that implies that "hard trance" is superior, or at least 
"more appropriate" than the others, which is silly.  The question is: 
which garners more "respect" and partygoer loyalty - a reliable constant 
dollar for dollar groove or an experimental-yet-always-more-or-less-high
quality party?  Ie., does Fraser see a possibility for ambient nights, or 
for even varying the type of music over the course of the night?  
Robert's quote would tend to indicate not, though one could also say that 
was hearsay.

> Good news is that Fraser should be online soon to answer all these
> intriguing questions

He's been on the Well for a few months making, er, acquaintences.  He's 
welcome to join this list if he wishes.

> If sfravers will allow him to voice his point of view without dumping
> parental-rebellion shit all over him first?? lets expand rave rights to the
> very young (as a recent long thread concluded )as well as the very old or
> are the over-30 year olds still the Enemy? lets ask Bob Dylon to answer
> this one.

Basically last summer both he and his ex-compadre Zippies arrived in San 
Francisco amid much fanfare and hope and open minds, and many of the 
people on this were underwhelmed.  If you weren't on SFRaves then, you 
can check the archives at http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/archives/ (now 
set up with continual updating) for a historical note.  Basically I don't 
think anyone is taking away Fraser's right to say what he wants and plan 
parties and such, but his words haven't quite been translated into action
as effectively as we all had hoped.

	Brian

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar  8 22:28:44 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id WAA10349; Wed, 8 Mar 1995 22:28:44 -0800
Received: from sysx.apana.org.au by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA10287; Wed, 8 Mar 1995 22:27:36 -0800
Message-Id: <m0rmakQ-000IVuC@sysx.apana.org.au>
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 95 16:26 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Frazer, Zippies,  and other things...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ahh!!  Here I am,  Keeping track of TWO rave scenes, 12,000 KM apart
from each other --  Neato...  

And I have a few comments to make Re: Zippies/ Frazer and the lot...

It may sound like I may be defending Frazer,   but let me speak my
peace....  Here we have a group of British dudz,  supossedly making
a tour to the USA,  and they're no doubt not that familiar with the
American scene,  let alone the SF Scene.    I'm experiencing this
right now,  here in Australia.   Although I'm taking a somewhat
different approach with my entry into the Australian scene.

When Frazer and crew left for the USA,   there probably was little
effort on their part to try and understand our scene before they made
their trek...  Probably due to the lack of Internet connectivity they
had before they left.   For instance,  Frazer didn't subscribe to
SFRaves 6 months before coming to USA to get a flavor of our scene.

I cannot emphasize the importance of trying to understand a local
scene before making an entry into it.    For me,  it was a godscend..

I found out about the Australian scene through alt.rave,  and I've
always wanted to learn more about Australia,  so I joined the AusRaves
mailing list 6 months BEFORE coming over here.    At first,  I studied
their calander of events,   and read with such relish their rave reports
to get a flavor of what it's like.   After that,  I started asking questions
about the scene,  and got to know the promenent people like Simon Rumble,
Michael Dagn (Maintainer of the Ausraves calander) etc.

Never hearing a single note of the types of music until Grant brought
over a tape of Green Achrs,  did I ever know what their music was all about.

Now I do....ONLY after actually coming over here to exerience a real Australian
rave for the very first time.   I got to say,  I like the music over here
MUCH BETTER than in the SF scene.   There is FAR MORE variaty in music,
and the format for the music is very logcally layed out to promote
really good vibe and dancing environment

First,  they usually start off with medium speed (140 -150  bpm trance), for
several hours,  then up the energy level with Happy Hard core (160 - 180 bpm)
range.   Then around 5 am or so,  they slow things down to Housey sounds and
the more familiar tunes the SFRavers are used to.    This kind of variaty
is really great....  It serves all types of ravers,  from the slower housey
types to the faster harder types.  I think it's long overdue for the SF Scene
to start doing something like that,  but not necessarily copying the Aussies.

Then,  along comes Frazer...  and Jupiter bash...   with the faster harder
trance from Goa Gil and others.....   At first,  I didn't really like the
faster stuff,  and wasn't really secure about dancing to it.   But being
a little new to dancing,  I ADAPTED by experimenting with newer dance
movements to keep up with the faster pace.  As a result,  I feel comfortable
with anything from Acid Jazz (Remember Boogie Buffet?) all the way up to
Gabber (240+ BPM).

SF mainstram scene has aways been sorta housey..  Now this year,  we're
finding a LOT more variaty,  check out Atomicon!!   They are really great!
Lots of variaty,  but I think their format could use some improvement.
For instance,  my first Atomicon ended with Gabber...  I think they should
either start off with Gabber and work into Hard trance,  and end with House..

These are my opinions,   but it makes sense.   After 5 - 8 hours of dancing
the faster stuff,   lowering the BPMs towards the end,  keeps the people
on the dance floor,  because people are tired by that time and prefer the
Fatter and slower housy stuff.

When Megatripolus opened up at the Troc,   one of the things I really
dug was the variaty...   At first,  it was housey,  then acid trance from
Goa,  followed by Hardcore,  then back to house.   I think it was very well
formatted, and the decision to have the first Megatripolus be FREE,  
certainly throws away ANY ideas I had that Frazer was into greed and
commercialism.  After that,  they charged a reasonable $10 door charge.  

And now....  remember Santa Cruz...   By about that time,  Angus/Pinkus
crew sort of had a falling out with Frazer.  Don't know the details,
but things for the Zippies really started to fall apart.   Remember 
Pinkus's speach "By definition..  blah blah!!".   I really was'nt
that happy to hear him ranting and raving about such drival shit...
where he literally took the microphone away from Fraser.   There was much
disagreement among them,   and their un-familiarity with our scene AND
anti-commercialism we ALL have,  has marked the zippies as highly commercial
and self serving.   But,  the publicity of their coming to the Bay area
has turned off a lot of SFRavers,  mostly in part to this publicity
and apparent commercialism.

The other thing was the interruption of the dancing,  which is typical
for UK events.    Here,  thats just not done.   Again,  it was his
unfamiliarity with how we do things here.    For me,  I find it quite
annoying to have the music interrupted when my head space is into dancing.

I met Frazer at the Wyoming Rainbow gathering for the very first time.  He
didn't know me from diddly squat... But it became very clear how dedicated
to the scene I was,  as I pumped an amazing amount of energy into my
dancing (Mostly to keep warm in the below freezing evening).

   As we sat by the fire in the freezing cold Wyoming morning and I 
briefed frazer on our scene here in the SF area.    He had already 
chosen SF as one of his points on the tour,  so I did my very best to 
brief him on our scene.   I told him about the SfRavers,  Friends
and Family parties,  and briefed him in on our mainstream events
like Wicked,   and Martin O' Brian productions like BASICS,  VISION,
etc.    Unfortunately,  Fraser had little control over Angus and 
Pinkus and the others.  At least these were my impressions.   We 
really clicked with each other.  We are essentially the same age (51),  
renigades from the 60's and the "Love generation" but seperated by 
8000 miles.

Dispite the closeness of our modern global society,  distances STILL play
a large part in making differences in our respective scenes.  I'm finding
this out here in Australia.   I find MANY similarities,  but there 
are also many differences.

At any rate,   lets give Frazer a fair shake and as soon as he gets on the
nets,  invite him into OUR scene,  and let him know in no uncertain terms
what *WE* like (Luv,  togetherness,  and happyness) and dislike (greed,
commercialism, and bad press).  That way,  we can all get along together.

Re:  sex on the internet....  C'm on you people,  lets not give our
legislators any more reasons to put tighter controls on our freedom
of speech...  We are already getting more than we bargained for with
this Exon crap....!!

Nuff said...   (As he places the asbestus flame barrior in anticiption
for the inevitable flamage...)

One other thing.... I know that F&F is coming up soon,  and it may be
too late to get him to spin,   but I highly recommend DJ Mars to be placed
in the lineup.   I think that David Minuk (davidmin@crl.com) knows the
person that knows Mars.  Mars spun at Atomicon,  and his energy is highly
worthey of F&F and vice versa.

Crunchman (From down under)
G' day mate.

Subject: Re: Frazer, Zippies,  and other things...
To: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 23:23:13 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <m0rmakQ-000IVuC@sysx.apana.org.au> from "John Draper" at Mar 9, 95 04:26:00 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 7580      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> 
> Ahh!!  Here I am,  Keeping track of TWO rave scenes, 12,000 KM apart
> from each other --  Neato...  
> 
> And I have a few comments to make Re: Zippies/ Frazer and the lot...
> 
> It may sound like I may be defending Frazer,   but let me speak my
> peace....  Here we have a group of British dudz,  supossedly making
> a tour to the USA,  and they're no doubt not that familiar with the
> American scene,  let alone the SF Scene.    I'm experiencing this
> right now,  here in Australia.   Although I'm taking a somewhat
> different approach with my entry into the Australian scene.
> 
> When Frazer and crew left for the USA,   there probably was little
> effort on their part to try and understand our scene before they made
> their trek...  Probably due to the lack of Internet connectivity they
> had before they left.   For instance,  Frazer didn't subscribe to
> SFRaves 6 months before coming to USA to get a flavor of our scene.
> 
> I cannot emphasize the importance of trying to understand a local
> scene before making an entry into it.    For me,  it was a godscend..
> 
> I found out about the Australian scene through alt.rave,  and I've
> always wanted to learn more about Australia,  so I joined the AusRaves
> mailing list 6 months BEFORE coming over here.    At first,  I studied
> their calander of events,   and read with such relish their rave reports
> to get a flavor of what it's like.   After that,  I started asking questions
> about the scene,  and got to know the promenent people like Simon Rumble,
> Michael Dagn (Maintainer of the Ausraves calander) etc.
> 
> Never hearing a single note of the types of music until Grant brought
> over a tape of Green Achrs,  did I ever know what their music was all about.
> 
> Now I do....ONLY after actually coming over here to exerience a real Australian
> rave for the very first time.   I got to say,  I like the music over here
> MUCH BETTER than in the SF scene.   There is FAR MORE variaty in music,
> and the format for the music is very logcally layed out to promote
> really good vibe and dancing environment
> 
> First,  they usually start off with medium speed (140 -150  bpm trance), for
> several hours,  then up the energy level with Happy Hard core (160 - 180 bpm)
> range.   Then around 5 am or so,  they slow things down to Housey sounds and
> the more familiar tunes the SFRavers are used to.    This kind of variaty
> is really great....  It serves all types of ravers,  from the slower housey
> types to the faster harder types.  I think it's long overdue for the SF Scene
> to start doing something like that,  but not necessarily copying the Aussies.
> 
> Then,  along comes Frazer...  and Jupiter bash...   with the faster harder
> trance from Goa Gil and others.....   At first,  I didn't really like the
> faster stuff,  and wasn't really secure about dancing to it.   But being
> a little new to dancing,  I ADAPTED by experimenting with newer dance
> movements to keep up with the faster pace.  As a result,  I feel comfortable
> with anything from Acid Jazz (Remember Boogie Buffet?) all the way up to
> Gabber (240+ BPM).
> 
> SF mainstram scene has aways been sorta housey..  Now this year,  we're
> finding a LOT more variaty,  check out Atomicon!!   They are really great!
> Lots of variaty,  but I think their format could use some improvement.
> For instance,  my first Atomicon ended with Gabber...  I think they should
> either start off with Gabber and work into Hard trance,  and end with House..
> 
> These are my opinions,   but it makes sense.   After 5 - 8 hours of dancing
> the faster stuff,   lowering the BPMs towards the end,  keeps the people
> on the dance floor,  because people are tired by that time and prefer the
> Fatter and slower housy stuff.
> 
> When Megatripolus opened up at the Troc,   one of the things I really
> dug was the variaty...   At first,  it was housey,  then acid trance from
> Goa,  followed by Hardcore,  then back to house.   I think it was very well
> formatted, and the decision to have the first Megatripolus be FREE,  
> certainly throws away ANY ideas I had that Frazer was into greed and
> commercialism.  After that,  they charged a reasonable $10 door charge.  
> 
> And now....  remember Santa Cruz...   By about that time,  Angus/Pinkus
> crew sort of had a falling out with Frazer.  Don't know the details,
> but things for the Zippies really started to fall apart.   Remember 
> Pinkus's speach "By definition..  blah blah!!".   I really was'nt
> that happy to hear him ranting and raving about such drival shit...
> where he literally took the microphone away from Fraser.   There was much
> disagreement among them,   and their un-familiarity with our scene AND
> anti-commercialism we ALL have,  has marked the zippies as highly commercial
> and self serving.   But,  the publicity of their coming to the Bay area
> has turned off a lot of SFRavers,  mostly in part to this publicity
> and apparent commercialism.
> 
> The other thing was the interruption of the dancing,  which is typical
> for UK events.    Here,  thats just not done.   Again,  it was his
> unfamiliarity with how we do things here.    For me,  I find it quite
> annoying to have the music interrupted when my head space is into dancing.
> 
> I met Frazer at the Wyoming Rainbow gathering for the very first time.  He
> didn't know me from diddly squat... But it became very clear how dedicated
> to the scene I was,  as I pumped an amazing amount of energy into my
> dancing (Mostly to keep warm in the below freezing evening).
> 
>    As we sat by the fire in the freezing cold Wyoming morning and I 
> briefed frazer on our scene here in the SF area.    He had already 
> chosen SF as one of his points on the tour,  so I did my very best to 
> brief him on our scene.   I told him about the SfRavers,  Friends
> and Family parties,  and briefed him in on our mainstream events
> like Wicked,   and Martin O' Brian productions like BASICS,  VISION,
> etc.    Unfortunately,  Fraser had little control over Angus and 
> Pinkus and the others.  At least these were my impressions.   We 
> really clicked with each other.  We are essentially the same age (51),  
> renigades from the 60's and the "Love generation" but seperated by 
> 8000 miles.
> 
> Dispite the closeness of our modern global society,  distances STILL play
> a large part in making differences in our respective scenes.  I'm finding
> this out here in Australia.   I find MANY similarities,  but there 
> are also many differences.
> 
> At any rate,   lets give Frazer a fair shake and as soon as he gets on the
> nets,  invite him into OUR scene,  and let him know in no uncertain terms
> what *WE* like (Luv,  togetherness,  and happyness) and dislike (greed,
> commercialism, and bad press).  That way,  we can all get along together.
> 
> Re:  sex on the internet....  C'm on you people,  lets not give our
> legislators any more reasons to put tighter controls on our freedom
> of speech...  We are already getting more than we bargained for with
> this Exon crap....!!
> 
> Nuff said...   (As he places the asbestus flame barrior in anticiption
> for the inevitable flamage...)
> 
> One other thing.... I know that F&F is coming up soon,  and it may be
> too late to get him to spin,   but I highly recommend DJ Mars to be placed
> in the lineup.   I think that David Minuk (davidmin@crl.com) knows the
> person that knows Mars.  Mars spun at Atomicon,  and his energy is highly
> worthey of F&F and vice versa.
> 
> Crunchman (From down under)
> G' day mate.
>

About a year before his death Abe Lincoln wrote in a D.C. newspaper


"A hypocrite nevr learns respect, especially of ones self. If he
hypocrisizes about the most important fundamentals of our new
America(ie: freedom of speech, freedom of opinion((especially the
freedom to let OTHERS voice their opinion)) right to bear arms, freedom
of ASSEMBLY) he becomes worse then those who oppress us, because he
himself doesn't beleive in those fudamentals. If all of those who see
his hypocracy can show him truth, then the hypocrite becomes an
American. Americans are no better in any form but to that wich they can
honestly say they beleive in their own heart"

I had this quote here in my computer when I did an english paper in
college.

What I'm trying to say is that sometimes we uorselves can easily become
this hypocrite because we ourselves sometimes feel like the world is
against us.

I think that Mega-Tripolis sounds great in any respective if it can
allow one of those hypocrites(boomers) to see truth in a rave culture.
Everyone here talks about unity, but as someone mentioned earlier in
another message,"is that a stereo-type"
                                       (ie:BOOMER,SUB-BURB KIDS)
Remember that we don't care about stereo types. Ask Amy Starkey. She
knows me and she knows that I don't care if there are ten "GANG-BANGERS"
walking around the GATHERING. I go right up to them and introduce myself
to them. I want everyone to be part of this so called rave culture. I
wouldn't worry about getting mugged at the ATM, or dodging bullets while
in the inner city. I would be more concerned about how I'm gonna set up
sound this friday at common ground here in Sac.

Let's not loose grips on why we started raving. If you beleive it was to
dance or to do drugs in mass quanities, why even metion love, peace,
unity, togetherness, or VIBE. I've only been in the seen for a little
over a year. Don't see this message as a new kid on the block thing.
Because I do sound for 90% of the gigs here in Sac. I've talked to a lot
of the old timers, and they all say the same thing,"It's all about the
people."


IT'S ALL ABOUT THE PEOPLE

aka: Andrew Dressler

my reference to "shit" or your reference to "fuckers"?

Well.. my humble apologies David in not taking your sensitivities into account.
Please allow me to rephrase the "line of shit" sentence more succinctly:

Do *you* really believe that this is an attempt to get ravers` "parents"
into the rave scene? Or..are you just brainwashed?

Please let us "call a spade a spade". This is a commercial venture. And,
believe me, I have no problem with that. I wish it success. However, 
it is indeed a far stretch of the imagination to state that this is an
attempt to involve parents in the rave scene. Naturally, I have the greatest
admiration for *your* ability to make that stretch, being that I, personally,
am not that competent.

 On March 8th, David Dei wrote:

If sfravers will allow him to voice his point of view without dumping
parental-rebellion shit all over him first?? lets expand rave rights to the
very young (as a recent long thread concluded )as well as the very old or
are the over-30 year olds still the Enemy? lets ask Bob Dylon to answer
this one.

Well, I'm not Bob Dylon but I am 30 and I can tell you that I've gotten strange looks from the "average" raver.  They look at my friends and I as if we're strange for being at a rave.  The  EXPECTATION of younger ravers is that people over 25 or 26 SHOULD be conservative.  It seems that it is their EXPECTATION that we should be the enemy.  But I can tell you from personal experience that the over 25 crowd is almost without exception the one group at a rave that is there for the SOLE purpose of being with friends, dancing, and promoting a sense of community.  I don't know about you, but I havn'
t seen too many over 25vers posturing or scamming or walking around with "fuck-you" attitudes.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying that anyone under 25 is doing the above, but it is from that group that the negative elements spring.

Every once and a while, a "kid" between the ages of 16-19 comes up to me and asks me my age. When I tell them they are surprised thinking I was old but not that old.  Then they smile and say, "Man, when I'm your age I hope I'm still raving."
Me too.

Stamp out prejudice of EVERY kind.

Love and Peace

--
Jorge Montoya
fx277@kanga.ins.cwru.edu

> On March 8th, Jorge Montoya wrote
>
>Well, I'm not Bob Dylon but I am 30 and I can tell you that I've gotten
strange >looks from the "average" raver.

I'm glad to see I'm not the only geriatric raver out there.  I'm 36 and I'm
definitely in the upper age range of most of the events I go to.  But this
is what I would have been doing if they had these 10-15 years ago.  Back
then, if you wanted to get out and dance, the only thing available was the
vibeless meat-market club scene.  The closest thing I had was when all my
buddies and I would skip school and go out and build a fire in the woods 
and sit around partying and watching out for cops.

Kids today don't know how lucky they are.  Why when I was a kid we had to
walk 10 miles in the snow, barefoot, uphill both ways to go to a rave.

:)

greg


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar  9 12:20:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id MAA24271; Thu, 9 Mar 1995 12:20:57 -0800

The Zippies could have been one of many perspectives in S.F. , a city in 
which all things live forever.Unfortunately conquering S.F. as part of a 
grand sceme to conquer all of rave/hippydom backfired. 
Our city sometimes seems behind the times to outside visitors, but the truth is, 
we are not desperate for the next big thing. Better Luck next time.

Greg McCann wrote:

Kids today don't know how lucky they are.  Why when I was a kid we had to

Dear Greg;

	Your not alone, I'm 32, age is only a statement of the mind. 
Captain Crunch is 51, so don't feel bad. Every scene needs wisdom, this 
is were we come in, I know so much more than I did when I was in my 20's.
Am aslo able to deal and look at things with not so urgent of a 
perspective. Everything takes caree of itself in the long run. I don't 
miss those days of desparation, coupled without my wisdom that I have 
today. I chose to still live on the edge today, but today I wear a 
parachute :)!!!!!!!. Also to quote Judas Priest's "you don't have to be 
old to be wise", just to be fair.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

			"Tuttle Lives"

Harmony on Friday is getting a lot of people's attention, so it looks
like the place to be that night; on Saturday, Organic should be a
pretty good big party (expect it to be crowded though), and Ultrasonic
should be a good smaller party.

As always, directions for svbscribing and unsvbscribing are at the end.

    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Thursday, March 9th - Eighth House of Zenbiance
        performances by Deep Space Time, Naked Space
        DJs Jonah Sharp, Robert Shea (Big City Orchestra), Das
        live: Kode IV (Belgium), OST (Detroit)
        $6.  1190 Folsom @ 8th.  415.487.5436

Thursday, March 9th - The Ambience 2 year celebration: The Terrible Twos
        hosted by Michael Hayes, David X and special guest dj Eddie Edul
        with live performances by: RED FLAG  SEVEN RED SEVEN  MACHINE IN MOTION
        at the Rage 1890 Arden Way, Sacramento  916.929.0232 
        18+.  tix $15.00 under 21/$12.00 over 21

Friday, March 10th - Harmony
        DJs Tony  Simon  Doran  Trent
        visuals by Mark, ambient by Dionysus Dreams
        408.486.9591

Friday, March 10th - Passion
        Deep Soul/House w/DJs Miquel, Henry, Life
        590 Valencia St @ 17th.  $3

Saturday, March 11th - Organic, 2nd year anniversary
         Simon  Graeme  Jeno  Robbie Hardkiss  DJ Dan  Andre Lucero
         $12, 10pm-7am.  415.266.8215

Saturday, March 11th - Ultrasonic
        Tracy  Ethan  Lee  Monty  Ray  Joe Rice
        Sound by SoundVision.
        $5 or $4 with a canned food donation.
        Presented by the Justice League Sound System.
        (415) 281-9432

Saturday, March 11th - Funky Groove Nation
        Simon  Gil  Carlos  Love  Spinner  Greed  Georgie Porgie 
             Jeffrey  Phil  Travis  Bliss  Chach
        Visuals by Pure   Sound System by God II
        Addmission $10        (510) 945-9885

Wednesday, March 15th - Culture
        House DJs Wool, Ejyo, Chill, Brandon
        dubjazzhop DJs Laron, Keone, Mei-Lwun, Innacity
        Union Lounge, 2001 Union, SF.

Wednesday, March 15th - Smorgasbord
        Spun  Miquel  Josh  Galen
        21+, 278 11th St.  415.773.8841
        FREE!

Friday, March 17th - Catastrophic Planet "a journey of funky vibes"
        Gabe  Liquid  Jam N J  DJ Dan  Carlos  Q Bert  Graeme
        Chill Zone: Zee  Johnny K
        Lasers by Kevin, Visuals by Eyezmind, Sound by Fantasy Direct
        Glow Toys by Glowtech
        415.939.2468  209.991.4726

Friday, March 17th - Reflective Records and Clear Records present
        Black Dog, Velocette, Spacetime Continuum, Single Cell Orchestra
        + DJs Mark Broom, Jonah, Thomas
        415-241-1560

Friday, March 17th - Xogenix
        something new, something dangerous [ROT 13] hyperparty-cybertrance
        "prepare to move all night towards tek armageddon"
        415.541.5019

        Mark Lewis  Taylor  Michael Cook  Barry Weaver  Fabian  Chris Flores
        415.522.3881

                Cyberlab7, Ameba, and The Cloud Factory
        invite you to join us as we celebrate spring and 1 year of F&F
        all ages, all night, $5+ sliding scale
        benefits 2 very worthy causes       415.985.5244

        Jazz-Funk: Manny Rosa  Miquel  Julius Papp
        Deep House: Aaron O  Ruben
        top floor: ambient, dub, experiment
        Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk, SF.  415.441.4007.  10pm, 21+, $5.

        Live set by The Darwin Chamber

        415.512.5713

        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.

        KZSU 90.1 Stanford

        ambient w/Galaxy Girl and guests, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

        w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)

        Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)

        Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz and noise
        KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

You know what the most amusing and peeving thing anyone ever said to me was?

Early last year we were at Warehouse Jam here in van. b.c. and for some
reason the subject of age came up.  I said something about not wanting to
turn 25 and this guy asked "well how old are you?"  I said "24" and he said
"wow, it's so cool that you're still partying at your age."

ERCKLE!!!!!!!

oh well . . . now i'm turning 26 on the 15th and that all seems so long ago
. . .

interview - my preferred attire was blue jeans and flannel shirts.

Not really jumping to conclusions just posing some serious questions
(IMHO).  I might add that I think you are confusing Tribal Funk and Tribal
Future that same weekend.  I got no hint that the Tribal Funk party would
last for more than one night from the post or the calendar while it was
clear that Tribal Future will go on for two days.  I just have some pretty
strong feelings about people in our scene saying one thing and then
changing their mind under the same guise, I feel it is kind of like false
advertising...if someone doesn't find out it's $20 after 12am and they go
with $15 thinking that Tribal Funk doesn't charge $20 for a rave then they
are screwed...I'm not upset but I think we need to make people accountable
for what they say.

peace and love drenalin

ps it would be great if someone from Tribal Funk would stand up and speak
for themselves if they are on this list, in fact I would expect it if they
are reading.

yeah, 20 iz a bit much for a party but it iz *only* after midnite.  why 
not arrive early??  also, TF has always been cool about their time. last 
time at the cow palace, they stamped peoples hands in line so even if ya 
got to the casheir after, the said time, ya could still get a discount.  
Also, i wouldn't say that TF iz goin' back on their word. over time TF 
has been throwin' lots of parties. this iz the fourth big one but most of 
them have been small and extremely inexpensive events. in fact, a whole 
lot of them were free. unfortunately, TF iz not yet big enuff to draw the 
*huge* crowds (like funky techno, gathering etc,) so they can't afford to 
have really low prices at their big events.  when TF throws one of their 
big parties, they put * a lot* into it.  in fact, they've managed to lose 
money (lots of money) at all of their big parties.  basically, i'm just 
tryin' to say that if ya wanna provide people with a big quality party, 
ya gotta get the money from somewhere.

Received: from harp.aix.calpoly.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id CAA17686; Fri, 10 Mar 1995 02:20:53 -0800

          id AA190385; Fri, 10 Mar 1995 02:20:51 -0800
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 02:20:50 -0800 (PST)
From: Daniel Alexander Robinson <drobinso@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: mazlo@cats.ucsc.edu
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: to Jeremy about survey
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.950310002729.44023A-100000@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

To those of you that complain about not having enough in your mail box to 
read here is my response to Jeremy Rhoten's survey.  Enjoy!

Hi jeremy, here you go-_

>1. A few general statements about why you like to rave.

1.  I like to rave to hear the original music, meet a wide variety of 
people and most of all to expand my mind.  Its also a great form of 
entertainment.  I especially like raves because they are so far from the 
idea of Keg parties which I never have really liked.  Sure you find 
people with attitudes but the majority of true genuine ravers are 
extremely cool people.  They don't judge you on looks, mannerisms, the 
way you dance, the way you were your hair.  I imagine some people judge 
others at raves but generally anything goes.  At first I felt really out 
of place at raves but soon realized that I wasn't.  Anybody can attend, I 
mean anybody, the important thing to realize is what they are about.  They 
are not about finding some member of the opposite sex to have sex with, 
as some of my friends seem to think, they are not about doing a shit load 
of drugs, as many parents, including my father think, they are about 
getting back to the basics, to reaching that astral plane, chemically 
induced or not, that allows you to see people, that are also in the search 
for a feeling of connectedness with either the universe, other people, or 
themselves.

>2. Comments on the relationship between rave culture and technology.

2.  First of all let me tell you that there is an extremely good book 
that talks specifically abou this.  It is called "Cyberia" I forgot who 
it was by but if you are interested it has some very very very very 
relative stuff to say about technology in regards to rave culture.
The rave culture has virtually been around since the beginnig or 
civilization if you look at from the perspective of what it hopes to 
achieve.  Rave culture is in essance a religion.  Once you commit 
yourself to the ideals that raves perpetuate you can't forget about 
them.  The drugs are a part of the technology just like the music.  The 
Technology allows us to reach a "temporary" state of euphoria.  the 
lights, the defeaning music, the smoke, are all ways to physically create 
this artificial euphoria.  And it is "artificial" and "temporary" 
if it is viewed as lasting only as long as the party lasts and the music 
keeps pumping and the peolple still have any physical energy left.

>3. Is the music the most important aspect of the culture?  What do you 
>like about techno and other electronic music?

3. I have a very interesting view on electronic music.  Hear let me give 
you an example that will put it into better perspective for you. My friends 
and I were getting pretty high one night and I decided to play some 
decent european stuff.  A little ambient and some faster stuff.  They had 
never been to a rave and had no reference for what the music was supposed 
to do for them.  They complained that it was created with artificial 
instruments,i.e., synthizers, sequencers, turntables, etc.. They said 
they wanted to hear stuff made with natural instrumrents.  You know 
instruments like guitars, drums, etc.  Well I told them that was fine 
because I knew they had never experienced what true techno induced.  It 
is a mantra.  A way of shutting out the world.  The volume, the hard 
hitting repetitive beat doesn't allow room to really sing or think about 
anything.  When I listen to techno ,house, any of that stuff, My body 
moves, my mind doesn't get filled with images.  I feel emotions but I 
don't feel sad or happy just there at that moment much like what any good 
yogi attempts to achieve.
The only thing that I think about when I am really into the music and not 
at rave is being at that rave and dancing with all those people.  it 
brings me back to that feeling of unity but emptimindedness that I 
experienc there.  Just look at a raver in serious dance.  That's what he 
is doing. Dancing, he not thinking about his the fight he had with his 
girlfriend or the job that controls his life.  
	My friends didn't understand the music.  The instruments are 
nature.  We as humans are a part of nature just like any other aspect of 
nature.  Our  consciousness about ourselves as beings on earth balances all 
the beings,ie plants animals on the 
planet, universe, whatever, that are not conscious of thier own exixtence. 
	Techno only manipulates music to take us to higher states. Just 
as the instruments have been a manipulation of technology to create 
advanced sounds and rythm, "real" authentic techno, not club muscic, 
allows us to relate to higher states of mind that take us back to that 
part of us inside that needs no satisfaction, confirmation, or 
possession, it just lets us be there now at that moment in time alive and 
living, a celebration of life at a higher level.  This can be 
accomplished with or without the drugs. I have done it with both.  They 
are equally as cool.
>4. How are important are the drugs for promoting the vibe?

4.  The drugs can do a number of things.  It depends on what you take.  
If you are talking about MDMA I will relate my experience.  This drugs 
closes off that part of my brain that says, hey that person is wierd, hey 
that person is ugly, hey that person is a dork, hey that person is 
stupid. It silences that prejudice that is inherent in the pysical 
manifestation of the human brain.  They don't call it exctasy for 
nothing.  If you truly understand the experience that it can induce you 
see that this state of mind is possible to be achieved.  Its just that 
since the time we where born we have been trained to have all these labels 
and 
attach them to people as we see them with our eyes not with our spirit.  
some people take X and don't change, they virtually stay the same way 
when they are sober.  They haven't taped into that part of them that 
loves unconditionally.  
	The very bad side of X is the dependancy factor that I believe 
can result and you end up needing the drug to feel this way all the time.
Just a serious reminder.......These are purly my opinions, they are 
obviously not facts that I know of or that have been researched and proven.
>5.The rave culture is very different from the hippie culture of the 60s
>(though many philosophies are the same). Any contrasts/comparisons
>(especially the apolitical nature of rave culture).

5.  Rave Culture like the 60's
	People are on a search for happiness and connectedness to 
something higher than what is possible in day to day society, at least in 
Western Society.  Different drugs but same idea,  free love, respect, 
freedom from presumed athority, e.g. the government their bosses, the 
realities of life.
 
Differences...
The music, dancing by yourself and not being considered wierd, more advanced 
equipment for simulating euphoria, Ie lazers, some cool electronic 
visuals , ambient music, although the sixties did have some trippy shit!   
>What changes has the movement gone through since you've been part of it? 
>What are the effects of commercialization? 
6.  Have not been part of the 
movement long enough to really see an 
evolution occur in the rave scene.  Although I do have one thing to say
I saw an article on "Christian Raves".  This is kinda of a strang idea 
because the rave was ofcourse drug free. which is good but I'm not sure 
exactly what kind of music was played.  I do think that this also was a 
little out of the true rave ideal in that it established a theme to the 
dance.  The religion Christianity has a lot associated both good and bad.
But raves are a place where nothing matters in context to preconcieved 
ideas.  Raves allow you become primordal.  Like I said to get back to 
that emptiness and find whatever you want. I really don't think they 
should have any connection to any one type of association.  Be it racial, 
ethiical, religious etc, you just dance....

>7.  Do some raves have more of an ego vibe than others? Is there a sharp 
>distintiction between the underground movement and the popular/commercial 
>scene?  
	I can't say that I know that much about the commercial scene 
because I am not old enough.  I do know that I went to tiajuanna one time 
with some friends to some discotechs.  I am not knocking that scene or 
any thing but I really hated it. I honsestly don't think that the have 
even heard of a "vibe" in many commercial esatblishments.........I dunno, 
thats my assesment....

>8.  Where is the movement heading? Will it Survive or will it die when 
>the music and fashion inevitably changes (like the hippies)?

Well as far as I can tell many fashions are established at raves.  It 
will probably evolve just like any other fashion.
As far as the music goes aren't Jimi hendrix, The Doors, 
still listened to and followed to day in a certain respect.  If those 
guys were still around people would go to their concerts.  I don't see 
the entire population of the rave culture disappearing so someone will be 
making music and someone will be listening to it.  People will stay in 
the scene for life and many will be involved in the rave scene as a part 
of their life cycle only being envolved for a while.

>9.Anything else you'd like to add?
	That's  all folks!

Peace Dan :)

I just got into my office from the lab,
what a miserable day it is out there,
and much to my surprise,
a message awaited me on the phone,
I surely thought it yet another request to do more work,
but instead it was an injection of high energy house
music.

Thanks to that lovely individual who was thoughtful
enough to think of me this AM.

Ron.

Hello - Larry Ching here ....
Recently, Greg McCann replied to Jorge's posting --
> Subject: Geriatric Ravers
> 
> I'm glad to see I'm not the only geriatric raver out there.  I'm 36 and I'm
> definitely in the upper age range of most of the events I go to.  But this
> is what I would have been doing if they had these 10-15 years ago.  Back
> then, if you wanted to get out and dance, the only thing available was the
> vibeless meat-market club scene.
> 
 I'm 40 , and I know exactly what you mean! I did my freedom dancing at rock
shows , and singles bars were a poor alternative if there wasn't a good
group playing. I was in my teens and low twenties during the first disco 
age , but I didn't like it - I was a "rockist" then , and was disdainful of
disco *. I still hate stupid brainless metronome beats , unless they're 
accompanied with some mindbending harmony/atmospherics. Hard tribal and
acid trance is my preference now ( at least that's what I think the music
styles are called (!) ).. 

 ( * On the other hand , I did like Donna Summer's "I Feel Love" )

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

gonna be a killer oarty despite the gloom outside!!
see ya all there!!!  I hope ta meet all ya sfravers out there who i 
haven't seen b4!! i'll be wearin a blue journees shirt that says 
"journees control your destiny"  say hi!!!!

HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly

The following storm information has been posted to assist you with commute

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar 10 21:46:23 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id VAA01291; Fri, 10 Mar 1995 21:46:23 -0800
Received: from itsa.ucsf.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA01283; Fri, 10 Mar 1995 21:46:19 -0800

	id VAA120917; Fri, 10 Mar 1995 21:45:00 -0800
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 21:45:00 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: Re: Frazer, Zippies, and other things...
To: Monica and Tom <litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org>
cc: John Draper <crunch@sysx.apana.org.au>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <m0rmcYz-000IKvC@priscilla.ultima.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9503102132.C90471-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just because a bunch of Acid heads can run a few good parties in England, 
that glorious land where money and skill of organization comes second 
place to having a good time.  And that was the problem was it not?  They 
all made loads of money and thought: "We are much more ahead musiccally 
then those pesky yanks; lets go over their and we will go down really 
well.  Wrong!  Once the novilty wore off the cold hard facts was that 
they had not got what it takes to keep it going.  What ever one might say 
about Wicked or Community these were paerties started by and still run by 
British people and they are still going strong.  In England, the music 
played at raves here would send your average British raver to sleep so 
the scene here is very different to how it is here.  Britisah people who 
come over here liek the scene because it is different to London.  But the 
Zippies thought that they could just replicate the scene from London to 
SF and they were wrong.
As regurards Frazer he is a totally cool person who has never done of 
said anything more then he has lived up to.  His integrety and respect 
that he deserves is boundless.  It was all the other people on the 
original Zippy tour that fucked it all up.  That's what happens if you go 
on the road with dope fiends!  I hope that Frazer can continue to do what 
he was doing in London: bringing forward the philosophical side of rave 
culture to the fore-ground.  He is in a good position to do this too 
because un-like other's he has not lossed it mentally and, as he is 
intouch with young people on a daily basis, he has not lost touch with 
reality or forgotton the main purpose behind his mission.  I whish him 
all the luck in the future.

On Wed, 8 Mar 1995, Monica and Tom wrote:

> > 
> > 
> > Ahh!!  Here I am,  Keeping track of TWO rave scenes, 12,000 KM apart
> > from each other --  Neato...  
> > 
> > And I have a few comments to make Re: Zippies/ Frazer and the lot...
> > 
> > It may sound like I may be defending Frazer,   but let me speak my
> > peace....  Here we have a group of British dudz,  supossedly making
> > a tour to the USA,  and they're no doubt not that familiar with the
> > American scene,  let alone the SF Scene.    I'm experiencing this
> > right now,  here in Australia.   Although I'm taking a somewhat
> > different approach with my entry into the Australian scene.
> > 
> > When Frazer and crew left for the USA,   there probably was little
> > effort on their part to try and understand our scene before they made
> > their trek...  Probably due to the lack of Internet connectivity they
> > had before they left.   For instance,  Frazer didn't subscribe to
> > SFRaves 6 months before coming to USA to get a flavor of our scene.
> > 
> > I cannot emphasize the importance of trying to understand a local
> > scene before making an entry into it.    For me,  it was a godscend..
> > 
> > I found out about the Australian scene through alt.rave,  and I've
> > always wanted to learn more about Australia,  so I joined the AusRaves
> > mailing list 6 months BEFORE coming over here.    At first,  I studied
> > their calander of events,   and read with such relish their rave reports
> > to get a flavor of what it's like.   After that,  I started asking questions
> > about the scene,  and got to know the promenent people like Simon Rumble,
> > Michael Dagn (Maintainer of the Ausraves calander) etc.
> > 
> > Never hearing a single note of the types of music until Grant brought
> > over a tape of Green Achrs,  did I ever know what their music was all about.
> > 
> > Now I do....ONLY after actually coming over here to exerience a real Australian
> > rave for the very first time.   I got to say,  I like the music over here
> > MUCH BETTER than in the SF scene.   There is FAR MORE variaty in music,
> > and the format for the music is very logcally layed out to promote
> > really good vibe and dancing environment
> > 
> > First,  they usually start off with medium speed (140 -150  bpm trance), for
> > several hours,  then up the energy level with Happy Hard core (160 - 180 bpm)
> > range.   Then around 5 am or so,  they slow things down to Housey sounds and
> > the more familiar tunes the SFRavers are used to.    This kind of variaty
> > is really great....  It serves all types of ravers,  from the slower housey
> > types to the faster harder types.  I think it's long overdue for the SF Scene
> > to start doing something like that,  but not necessarily copying the Aussies.
> > 
> > Then,  along comes Frazer...  and Jupiter bash...   with the faster harder
> > trance from Goa Gil and others.....   At first,  I didn't really like the
> > faster stuff,  and wasn't really secure about dancing to it.   But being
> > a little new to dancing,  I ADAPTED by experimenting with newer dance
> > movements to keep up with the faster pace.  As a result,  I feel comfortable
> > with anything from Acid Jazz (Remember Boogie Buffet?) all the way up to
> > Gabber (240+ BPM).
> > 
> > SF mainstram scene has aways been sorta housey..  Now this year,  we're
> > finding a LOT more variaty,  check out Atomicon!!   They are really great!
> > Lots of variaty,  but I think their format could use some improvement.
> > For instance,  my first Atomicon ended with Gabber...  I think they should
> > either start off with Gabber and work into Hard trance,  and end with House..
> > 
> > These are my opinions,   but it makes sense.   After 5 - 8 hours of dancing
> > the faster stuff,   lowering the BPMs towards the end,  keeps the people
> > on the dance floor,  because people are tired by that time and prefer the
> > Fatter and slower housy stuff.
> > 
> > When Megatripolus opened up at the Troc,   one of the things I really
> > dug was the variaty...   At first,  it was housey,  then acid trance from
> > Goa,  followed by Hardcore,  then back to house.   I think it was very well
> > formatted, and the decision to have the first Megatripolus be FREE,  
> > certainly throws away ANY ideas I had that Frazer was into greed and
> > commercialism.  After that,  they charged a reasonable $10 door charge.  
> > 
> > And now....  remember Santa Cruz...   By about that time,  Angus/Pinkus
> > crew sort of had a falling out with Frazer.  Don't know the details,
> > but things for the Zippies really started to fall apart.   Remember 
> > Pinkus's speach "By definition..  blah blah!!".   I really was'nt
> > that happy to hear him ranting and raving about such drival shit...
> > where he literally took the microphone away from Fraser.   There was much
> > disagreement among them,   and their un-familiarity with our scene AND
> > anti-commercialism we ALL have,  has marked the zippies as highly commercial
> > and self serving.   But,  the publicity of their coming to the Bay area
> > has turned off a lot of SFRavers,  mostly in part to this publicity
> > and apparent commercialism.
> > 
> > The other thing was the interruption of the dancing,  which is typical
> > for UK events.    Here,  thats just not done.   Again,  it was his
> > unfamiliarity with how we do things here.    For me,  I find it quite
> > annoying to have the music interrupted when my head space is into dancing.
> > 
> > I met Frazer at the Wyoming Rainbow gathering for the very first time.  He
> > didn't know me from diddly squat... But it became very clear how dedicated
> > to the scene I was,  as I pumped an amazing amount of energy into my
> > dancing (Mostly to keep warm in the below freezing evening).
> > 
> >    As we sat by the fire in the freezing cold Wyoming morning and I 
> > briefed frazer on our scene here in the SF area.    He had already 
> > chosen SF as one of his points on the tour,  so I did my very best to 
> > brief him on our scene.   I told him about the SfRavers,  Friends
> > and Family parties,  and briefed him in on our mainstream events
> > like Wicked,   and Martin O' Brian productions like BASICS,  VISION,
> > etc.    Unfortunately,  Fraser had little control over Angus and 
> > Pinkus and the others.  At least these were my impressions.   We 
> > really clicked with each other.  We are essentially the same age (51),  
> > renigades from the 60's and the "Love generation" but seperated by 
> > 8000 miles.
> > 
> > Dispite the closeness of our modern global society,  distances STILL play
> > a large part in making differences in our respective scenes.  I'm finding
> > this out here in Australia.   I find MANY similarities,  but there 
> > are also many differences.
> > 
> > At any rate,   lets give Frazer a fair shake and as soon as he gets on the
> > nets,  invite him into OUR scene,  and let him know in no uncertain terms
> > what *WE* like (Luv,  togetherness,  and happyness) and dislike (greed,
> > commercialism, and bad press).  That way,  we can all get along together.
> > 
> > Re:  sex on the internet....  C'm on you people,  lets not give our
> > legislators any more reasons to put tighter controls on our freedom
> > of speech...  We are already getting more than we bargained for with
> > this Exon crap....!!
> > 
> > Nuff said...   (As he places the asbestus flame barrior in anticiption
> > for the inevitable flamage...)
> > 
> > One other thing.... I know that F&F is coming up soon,  and it may be
> > too late to get him to spin,   but I highly recommend DJ Mars to be placed
> > in the lineup.   I think that David Minuk (davidmin@crl.com) knows the
> > person that knows Mars.  Mars spun at Atomicon,  and his energy is highly
> > worthey of F&F and vice versa.
> > 
> > Crunchman (From down under)
> > G' day mate.
> > 
> 
>

my entree into the august forum of sfraves shall be by way of a general
confession and attonement before you all.  and it's thanks to kevin that
I'm here and now free to admit that maybe I/we *did* somewhat overexactly
focus on a particular london form of a Thing (the Rave Spirit?) that in
fact has an infintie number of possible forms within it, all of which we
shall see over the last years of this millennium..
in other words, that I *did* try too hard to repeat what we were doing over
there in megatripolis.london without enough attention and sensitivity to
adapting it to the local conditions.

but there's no sense being too smarmy. for I fear that my mission for at
least the next few months will be to play the intitially unpopular raver
conspirator / cheerleader -coach and ancient marinerto help you see the
Mote in Thine Own Eye and the sheer throobing aching need for you to
ACCELERATE NOW BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE,  so I'd better move on sharpish to
any of a hundred other opinions on this subject, this comparison of the
cultures, that you won't at first like nearly so much.

like, for example, and offered purely as a possible Talking P0oint for
everyone, I'd generalise that, nevertheless, Sf goes for party (AND THERES
NOTHING WRONG WITH THAT)  but the zippytrance evnt is more like a group
conspiracy to apply certain scientific shamanic technologies (repetitive
beats, synched lights, UV future strangeness etc) to bootstrap the whole
group to the next evolutionary level.  DISCUSS.

As a general answer to some of kevins post, the zippy meme, as actually
evolved and currently being lived by real people (many long before I ever
verbalised the re-paradigmed lifestyle) was not and is not a quickbrew
instant fad whipped together by me and a few mates to make a fast buck over
the summer and then disapear.  that's how it's supposed to work over here
and it does except that , ONCE OR TWICE in a generation's lifetime a new
wave comes along that smashes all those habitual patterns aside.

the zippy thing started a good half dozen years ago and definitely does not
dissipate with a few early blows, or a certain level of criticism.  by the
time this sumer gets rolling most people will rightly remember the things
that *were* achieved last year and can become the markers for starting this
year, and will start to forget what *didn't happen*

and thanks, kevin, for the vote of confidence.  all I can add is this:  I
AIN:T NO SAINT - you have been legally warned.

and, finally for now, my first apperance before you all, I must correct the
impression kevin gives that "all the others" fucked it all up.  there were
very honorable exceptions,  and we just were not in a numerical majority
after I decided to make the pronia zippy tour a collective.

exceptions are ZANA, a great spirit and heart and back for now in england
with her brood of 3 daughters.  RONNIE, who filmed the whole crazy tour
from megatripolis london to the end of megatripolis west.  MICHAEL JOHN of
the american rainbow family who worked with me in megalondon and on the
tour from start to finish and through into mega west.  and KATE.  and GABE

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: One Ravers Night
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Dear Sfraves;

	I went to Harmony lastnight unfortuately before all the bad news 
appeared on the internet. Yes I ran into a 2 mile long backup due to 17 
being closed at 9. So I then tried 9 to attempt to get to this event, am 
I a die hard or what.

	I'm from the East Coast and things like mud slides and nonstop
rain, well we don't have those things back east. Well here I am, me, my
Cherokee, 808 State on da box pumpin, and this mountain on 9(a place were
I've never been before), where I'm now stuck both ways due to these
wonderful and exciting mud slides you guys have out here. But it was
really cool, I was moving and so was the mountain, so we were in Harmony
together pun intented.

	Well I finally got off the mountain and made it to Harmony only to
find the electricty out and no one around, argh!!!!!. So I paged Greg and
he told me the unfortuate news. So here I am wired on the most non-drug
energy I've ever been wired on, a mountain coming down around my ears,
with nothing else to do, and what do I do. I go to Greg's house party that
he just invited me to in San Jose, who said theirs no god. 

	I then loaded up the Jeep with some party stuff left at the 
place, and went on my way to San Jose, through more mud slides and fallen 
trees. Well anyone who said that the people in San Jose don't have a good 
vibe and a lot of love are full of shit!!!! I had been on some of the 
worst road conditions I've ever seen, and I'm coming from ice storm land 
folks, and by the time I reached the party I had been on the road for 6 
hours. I was welcomed with a couple of great hugs, warm smiles, and that 
beautiful love vibe that pur-me-ates this bay area. After I decompressed 
from da road, I setup my massage table on an exchange basis, you give me 
10 and I'll give you 10, and had a great time the rest of da night, with 
pleasent raver dreams......

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

		"It doesn't get much better than this!!!!"

ps It was pretty cool talkin with you Vekatz see ya :)!!!!!!

On Tue, 7 Mar 1995, Jeremy Rhoten wrote:

> 1. A few general statements about why you like to rave.
  Simply put...it's the funnest thing to do. The people, the music, and 
the real reason we're here...the people make the party, those humble 
servants or cosmic guides who partake in the vibe are dreaming and working 
at the same time. Bliss is capable at many levels. Positivity. Some of 
my  real friends were, for the first time in their lives , happy and 
accepted completely as individuals. As simple as  agreeing on the 
changing textures of the cliffside, something to build on.  

 
> 2. Comments on the relationship between rave culture and technology.

An intriguing prop...global unity in that that common vibe happening all 
over the planet in synch, channeled with enough focus to deconstruct any 
divisiveness left in this human being..."a divided house is just that 
divided" K. Gabril {sic .}.

 
> 3. Is the music the most important aspect of the culture?  What do you 
> like about techno and other electronic music?
> 
  Not the most important, the people make the party, but the driving 
force is the ethno correcto the souloo therapy, (maybe?)
Smiles everyone for many more safe journeys. The music is the shit, as 
long as its off and not close to being slighty sick. 


> 4. How important are the drugs for promoting the rave vibe?

  I saw it in a cartoon...person hears the bass and investigates, trys a 
pos htunknut
peace of teknology,
And smiles in what is called ecstatic deep trance dance expression.
> 

> 5. The rave culture is very different from the hippie culture of the 60s 

  As cycles reverberate, try to build onto good sound reality by the down 
2 Earth
predecessors. Mucho respect to those that lived B4...
> 

> 6. What changes has the movement gone through since you've been part of 
> it?  What are the effects of commercialization?

 The truth transcends til the now. Attitude goes and may return fore it 
easy to cop to weak B.S. Flashin the skillet does not cut for long.

> 
> 7. Do some raves have more of an ego vibe than others?  Is there a sharp 
> distinction between the underground movement and the popular/commercial 
> scene?
> 
 
 Anybody could say there first party was a CoolWorld...It was in this 
case , however, different facets of the party experience are paid 
attention to at differing rates, aptitudes and learning styles.


> 8. Where is the movement heading?  Will it survive or will it die when 
> the music and fashion inevitably changes (like the hippies)?

 The scene, no matter where evolves according to multiple major set of 
actions. I only know the San Francisco. Sharing can hurt at times but we 
learn, and try to give an example for the next group of swing tings.

> To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>,
>         Monica and Tom <litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org>
> From: fraser@megatripolis.org (fraser clark)
> Subject: Re: Frazer, Zippies, and other things...
> Cc: John Draper <crunch@sysx.apana.org.au>, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
>         megatrip@best.com
> 
> like, for example, and offered purely as a possible Talking P0oint for
> everyone, I'd generalise that, nevertheless, Sf goes for party (AND THERES
> NOTHING WRONG WITH THAT)  but the zippytrance evnt is more like a group
> conspiracy to apply certain scientific shamanic technologies (repetitive
> beats, synched lights, UV future strangeness etc) to bootstrap the whole
> group to the next evolutionary level.  DISCUSS.

I think the idea of any one person or group saying they are attempting to 
"bootstrap..."  is rubbish. In order to move "a group to the next 
evolutionary level" you are claiming knowledge of what that level is, which
has a tendancy to make one sound very self-important. Any scenes "level"
is created by the members of it. It is not the other way around, and I for
one bristle at the idea that anyone claims knowledge of what particular
direction it should go, and that I need to be spoon-fed that direction.
Personally, I don't think the "scene" is, or has ever been about sex. It 
is about love, and/or friendship with people from a variety of different 
backgrounds, without regards to sex,age,color, the way you dress, etc... The 
truly equal opportunity "scene." If this were not the case, the "underground
" would have degenerated into a bunch of gangbangers looking for chicks 
on E to fuck, which I have seen happen to much of the "commericial" or easily
accessible scene.
> As a general answer to some of kevins post, the zippy meme, as actually
> evolved and currently being lived by real people (many long before I ever
> verbalised the re-paradigmed lifestyle) was not and is not a quickbrew
> instant fad whipped together by me and a few mates to make a fast buck over
> the summer and then disapear.  that's how it's supposed to work over here
> and it does except that , ONCE OR TWICE in a generation's lifetime a new
> wave comes along that smashes all those habitual patterns aside.

Again, that is your lifestyle. Live it and relish in it if it works for 
you. I don't think anyone has a problem with that. Do your own thing, but 
I don't think it appropriate for anyone to say that this is the lifestyle 
we should all live. I am not looking for a philosophy or the politics for 
my life, especially from a source of so much enjoyment. Rather be with 
friends and dance than learn what the proper things to do become a card 
carrying "zippie." 

> 
> the zippy thing started a good half dozen years ago and definitely does not
> dissipate with a few early blows, or a certain level of criticism.  by the
> time this sumer gets rolling most people will rightly remember the things
> that *were* achieved last year and can become the markers for starting this
> year, and will start to forget what *didn't happen*
> 
> and thanks, kevin, for the vote of confidence.  all I can add is this:  I
> AIN:T NO SAINT - you have been legally warned.
> 
> and, finally for now, my first apperance before you all, I must correct the
> impression kevin gives that "all the others" fucked it all up.  there were
> very honorable exceptions,  and we just were not in a numerical majority
> after I decided to make the pronia zippy tour a collective.

This is a prime example of the group creating the vibe, philosophy, or 
actions, and not the other way around. The tour was a result of who was 
attracted to you and or your "cause." If it didn't follow your utopian 
vision, then thems the breaks and welcome to the real world.

> 
> exceptions are ZANA, a great spirit and heart and back for now in england
> with her brood of 3 daughters.  RONNIE, who filmed the whole crazy tour
> from megatripolis london to the end of megatripolis west.  MICHAEL JOHN of
> the american rainbow family who worked with me in megalondon and on the
> tour from start to finish and through into mega west.  and KATE.  and GABE

I don't understand the necessity of raising any one person to a higher 
status in the group.  It sounds way too cultish, which again is not my 
view of the scene. And if the tour or your project flop(s)(ed) then it 
because not enough people share your views, or feel they need to be 
shown. The impression I get, at least of the San Francisco people, is that 
we are not together to push any one way of life. We get togther to share 
the company of others that love the music and know the rush of a "good 
vibe." Politics , lifestyles and views of "proper" rave culture aside. I, 
and most the people I have come into contact with already know where 
they're at and where there going. Thanks anyways, but I have a philosophy 
for living my life.

                                                   Peace,
                                                    Black Adder

Hey All,

My friend Poppy needs some help with something she stumbled across. I 
hope you can help her out. Please disseminate. Thanks!

Here's what she's got:

WHO'S REALLY RUNNING OUR WORLD?
A campaign organized by the Earth Island Institute

1994 marked the 50th anniversary of the founding of the World Bank and 
the International Monetary Fund, global financial institutions which have 
failed miserably in their goals of promoting global prosperity and 
stability.  

They have needlessly fostered environmental degradation, and 
through their economic "adjustment" programs, have pushed societies to 
cut spending on health care and education in order to repay impossibly 
large debts.  For example, from a UNICEF estimate: "about 500,000 
children die each year from austere conditions (in part imposed by the 
IMF and World Bank)."

Definitely of concern is that our U.S. tax dolllars are going to support 
institutions not open to public scrutiny or citizen input.  We, the 
undersigned, call for a moratorium on funding for the World Bank and the 
IMF until these institutions become democratic and accountable,  and 
promote sustainable and equitable people-centered development.

Instructions for signing this petition:
Signing isn't hard if you just please follow this example:

Foward this message to:	wb50years@igc.apc.org

Place the following at the end of this message:

SIGNED <Internet e-mailaddress><Fullname><U.S. CITIZEN>

You need not include the < or >

If you want more information regarding the U.S. Campaign, please mention 
so after your signature.

!!!!PLEASE RESPOND BY MARCH 15th!!!!

-Thanks for letting me use this forum as a vehicle for change. 

 PLUR,

 Poppy :)


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 12 01:25:24 1995

Message-Id: <m0rnjsK-000IKvC@priscilla.ultima.org>
From: litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org (Monica and Tom)
Subject: 8th House, yohimbe
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 01:23:48 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2795      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

well, my night at the 8th House turned into quite a tragedy, thanks in 
part to the promoter, the maker of the "funny punch," and a "friend" who 
stupidly od'ed on various substances...

8th House was held at the cat's alley bar & grill, a bar space with a 
dance room in back.  first complaint: not enuf seating in front when we 
got there, and the back room was still closed, and they were showing 
really gory (sp?) films with annoying industrial music.  

i had heard there would be some "funny punch" at the party so i went to 
check it out.  the server estimated that about a cup would be ok to 
drink, and my friends and i stupidly believed him.  
let's just say we got more than we bargained for, so 
we left and took a taxi home.

however, my "friend" had bought a shot of yohimbe from the bar girl, who 
HAD NO CLUE WHAT IT WAS AND THOUGHT IT WAS A SMART DRINK.  not good.  
yohimbe is an MAO-inhibitor, which means that it SHOULD NEVER BE COMBINED 
WITH ANY AMPHETAMINE-TYPE DRUG, or food with aged protein, which includes 
mdma, cheese, beer, wine, pickled herrings, snails, chicken livers, yeast 
products, figs, raisins, pickles, sauerkraut, coffee, chocolate, soy 
sauce, cream and yogurt, not to mention speed, acid (i guess), etc.  our 
friend had had two ephedras and a chocolate chip cookie, as well as 
punch.  yikes.

(btw, asevereoverdose heightens the blood pressure and can lead to 
pulmonary edema, circulatory collapse, or intracranial hemorrhage.  info. 
from *Psychedelic Shamanism*, by Jim De Korne.)

so we got home and he began sweating, getting the chills, babbling 
incoherently and twitching.  he then started freaking out, becoming 
paranoid, overly sexual (yohimbe is an aphrodisiac), and violent.  we 
called a friend to help, but b4 he arrived our od-man stripped naked and 
tried to run out into the street several times and we had to restrain 
him, and at one point he trampled on my foot and broke a bone.  we calmed 
him down and got him lots of water and bananas, which helped and he is 
ok.  HOWEVER,  i am hobbling around with a cane and in pain and i don't 
know when i'll be able to dance again or even walk very far.  

so, the moral of the story is: don't take funny punch at parties, even if 
you know the person serving it, unless you are sure of how much of 
whatever is in it;  do not take yohimbe unless you have researched it, 
and never serve yohimbe at parties.  philip infinity (the promoter of 8th 
House) was totally irresponsible to have served it without any warning or 
instructions, and he will be called on it.  

i really believe that more damage could have been done (for instance, had 
he been a violent person he could have attempted to rape me), and in a 
way i'm "lucky" to have escaped with "only" a broken foot.


monicat
