	id CAA112678; Sun, 12 Mar 1995 02:35:16 -0800
Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 02:35:15 -0800 (PST)
From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: Re: Frazer, Zippies, and other things... [fraser@megatripolis.org (fraser , clark)] (fwd)
To: "P. Greenwell" <blkadder@community.net>
cc: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9503111949.A9834-0100000@odin.community.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9503120238.A76065-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Okay okay; point taken about the fact that raves over here are muxh more 
concerned with making fast buck then they are in England.  But explain 
some thing to me.  I was envolved, for two years, with a sound system 
that nobody had ever heard of yet we would a minum of 1500 people on a 
week end and we were the prime catalysts in organizing the Castle MOrton 
festival which was, with out a doubt, the biggest free rave in te 
histotry of the planet.  It was, of course, all free some we made up from 
it from selling sweeties: enough to be able to expand the sound system, 
sought every one out, and have a lot of money left over for ourselves.  
Was it not the same for Megatripolis?  Remember, your speaking to an acid 
dealer from way back (fnaar, fnaar, fnaar!).  I hope so because that is 
the way it should be.
Incidently, have you not noticed the fact that their are very few 
Scottish people over here compared to English or Londoner's?  "Every where 
you go, always take the weather with you."(?)
But if only you had been their, on that beautiful sunny day in a quiet 
area of our equivilent of Golden Gate Park.  And their were people of all 
ages, all colours, workers and dossers; beauty and love all around 
hanging out, playing drums, talking; friends who had not seen each other 
for a while were re-united.  ANd while their were only about 100 people 
every knew each other realy well and for quite some time.  We were at an 
important rest stop on our journey through life.  Us against the world, 
the State, the grown-ups.  And at one point their was a cool breeze and 
all noiticed it; and we were all high and felt so happy in ourselves and 
with each other and this wind had come to relieve us in the heat.  I felt 
like crying feeling so lucky to have friends and be around people that 
felt the same way that I did.  And that, my friends, is, in a nutshell, 
the Zippy vibe.  Anrt't you sad that you will never experience it?  
("England, oh my England.")  Ah well, at least we have Sunset (hopefully)
And that is the main difference.  In England everybody, like Frazer and 
Tom, is family.  All for one and one for all.  But here anybody can stab 
you in the back at a momments notice and the result is everybody is very 
edgey and nobody trusts eachother.  Result: people work against eachother 
rather with each other; there are to many crossed signals.  I mean, just 
from the time that I have subscribed to this network I have seen bitching 
and ego trips going on that would make a bunch of new york queens 
jeolous.  You know what I mean?  "Your so vain, you probably think this 
song is about you!"  All the great dj's like each other, it's just these 
bastard promoter, club owners and secruity personel that are the 
problem.  Soloution?  Need to think about it.
Said my poeace now.  I love Frazer, and I love the whole ethic of the 
entire Zippy movement.  I was theiright from the start when we were 
having raves of fifty people in houses that were condemed and everybody 
thoiught we were mad.  I would not be the person that I am with out the 
influence they have had, for overwheming positive good, on my whole being.
But not I, like the Zippy's must move on and take it to te level.
Much love and respect T.

On Sat, 11 Mar 1995, P. Greenwell wrote:

> > To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>,
> >         Monica and Tom <litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org>
> > From: fraser@megatripolis.org (fraser clark)
> > Subject: Re: Frazer, Zippies, and other things...
> > Cc: John Draper <crunch@sysx.apana.org.au>, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
> >         megatrip@best.com
> > 
> > like, for example, and offered purely as a possible Talking P0oint for
> > everyone, I'd generalise that, nevertheless, Sf goes for party (AND THERES
> > NOTHING WRONG WITH THAT)  but the zippytrance evnt is more like a group
> > conspiracy to apply certain scientific shamanic technologies (repetitive
> > beats, synched lights, UV future strangeness etc) to bootstrap the whole
> > group to the next evolutionary level.  DISCUSS.
> 
> I think the idea of any one person or group saying they are attempting to 
> "bootstrap..."  is rubbish. In order to move "a group to the next 
> evolutionary level" you are claiming knowledge of what that level is, which
> has a tendancy to make one sound very self-important. Any scenes "level"
> is created by the members of it. It is not the other way around, and I for
> one bristle at the idea that anyone claims knowledge of what particular
> direction it should go, and that I need to be spoon-fed that direction.
> Personally, I don't think the "scene" is, or has ever been about sex. It 
> is about love, and/or friendship with people from a variety of different 
> backgrounds, without regards to sex,age,color, the way you dress, etc... The 
> truly equal opportunity "scene." If this were not the case, the "underground
> " would have degenerated into a bunch of gangbangers looking for chicks 
> on E to fuck, which I have seen happen to much of the "commericial" or easily
> accessible scene.
> > As a general answer to some of kevins post, the zippy meme, as actually
> > evolved and currently being lived by real people (many long before I ever
> > verbalised the re-paradigmed lifestyle) was not and is not a quickbrew
> > instant fad whipped together by me and a few mates to make a fast buck over
> > the summer and then disapear.  that's how it's supposed to work over here
> > and it does except that , ONCE OR TWICE in a generation's lifetime a new
> > wave comes along that smashes all those habitual patterns aside.
> 
> Again, that is your lifestyle. Live it and relish in it if it works for 
> you. I don't think anyone has a problem with that. Do your own thing, but 
> I don't think it appropriate for anyone to say that this is the lifestyle 
> we should all live. I am not looking for a philosophy or the politics for 
> my life, especially from a source of so much enjoyment. Rather be with 
> friends and dance than learn what the proper things to do become a card 
> carrying "zippie." 
> 
> > 
> > the zippy thing started a good half dozen years ago and definitely does not
> > dissipate with a few early blows, or a certain level of criticism.  by the
> > time this sumer gets rolling most people will rightly remember the things
> > that *were* achieved last year and can become the markers for starting this
> > year, and will start to forget what *didn't happen*
> > 
> > and thanks, kevin, for the vote of confidence.  all I can add is this:  I
> > AIN:T NO SAINT - you have been legally warned.
> > 
> > and, finally for now, my first apperance before you all, I must correct the
> > impression kevin gives that "all the others" fucked it all up.  there were
> > very honorable exceptions,  and we just were not in a numerical majority
> > after I decided to make the pronia zippy tour a collective.
> 
> This is a prime example of the group creating the vibe, philosophy, or 
> actions, and not the other way around. The tour was a result of who was 
> attracted to you and or your "cause." If it didn't follow your utopian 
> vision, then thems the breaks and welcome to the real world.
> 
> > 
> > exceptions are ZANA, a great spirit and heart and back for now in england
> > with her brood of 3 daughters.  RONNIE, who filmed the whole crazy tour
> > from megatripolis london to the end of megatripolis west.  MICHAEL JOHN of
> > the american rainbow family who worked with me in megalondon and on the
> > tour from start to finish and through into mega west.  and KATE.  and GABE
> 
> I don't understand the necessity of raising any one person to a higher 
> status in the group.  It sounds way too cultish, which again is not my 
> view of the scene. And if the tour or your project flop(s)(ed) then it 
> because not enough people share your views, or feel they need to be 
> shown. The impression I get, at least of the San Francisco people, is that 
> we are not together to push any one way of life. We get togther to share 
> the company of others that love the music and know the rush of a "good 
> vibe." Politics , lifestyles and views of "proper" rave culture aside. I, 
> and most the people I have come into contact with already know where 
> they're at and where there going. Thanks anyways, but I have a philosophy 
> for living my life.
> 
>                                                    Peace,
>                                                     Black Adder
>  
>

Subject: Looking for individual to share house and network link
To: csua@csua.berkeley.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com, snoop@leri.net,
        ba.market.housing.USENET@c2.org, ucb.market.housing.USENET@c2.org
Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 15:16:33 -0800 (PST)
From: sameer <sameer@c2.org>
PGP-Strong-Print: 3C AE E4 00 C2 6A 81 FF  49 4E EE 0C CD CD 1D 80
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL20]
MIME-Version: 1.0

        My friend/business-partner and I are planning on expanding the
28.8 kbps network link into our small community-based ISP to a 56k
link sometime this summer and hope to move the system into a more
permanent location before we actually get a digital line to the house.
        We are looking for someone who would like to sublet a room in
a 4BR (or a 3BR + 1 office) house that we plan on finding to move into
in May. Whoever is subletting the room would be allowed to hook up
their computer(s) to the ethernet connecting to our netlink. (We
-hope- it will be a 56k digital line this summer but we can't
guarantee it. At this point we have a fulltime dedicated 28kbps link
into the net. As we continue to expand our net will increase to
fractional-T1 and eventually full T1.)
        We realized that it would be a good idea to look for someone
to rent a room to because we would like a place sufficiently large to
look professional and even hold some small parties in and don't really
have the money to just find a large enough place with only two
people. We are also interested in finding a location which we'll stay
in for quite some time (given that installing a dedicated digital
circuit is expensive and timeconsuming we don't want to move often..)
and hope that once whoever move in decides to move out another of our
friends who would like to join the project but doesn't have the
resources at this time will be able to join with us and move into the
location.
        (You would pay 1/4 of rent and utilities..)

Thanks,
-- 
sameer                                          Voice:   510-841-2014
Network Administrator                           Pager:   510-321-1014
Community ConneXion: The NEXUS-Berkeley         Dialin:  510-549-1383
http://www.c2.org (or login as "guest")                 sameer@c2.org

Dear Sfravers;

	Just a follow up to my last post. If you know anyone stable, and
kind I'm still lookin for a new home. I don't have to rush out of my
current situation so I have time and want to find da right place, and
people. 

	My current situation isn't working because of operating hours
conflicts, in other words I keep odd hours typically 11am to 2am weekdays
and later on weekends, and this is a low keyed boarder type house where
I'm a high energy positive person. Also, theres no sense of community or
household here, and people aren't very positive or polite, I mean not even
a please or thanks, just demands. But it is a friendly parting and I get
all of my security deposit back, and a good reference. 

	I don't smoke cig's; but don't care if you do. I have two male
siamese cats that are very friendly and loving; they are litter trained
and declawed and nuetered. I keep odd hours; like most ravers do; I have
an upper limit of $550/month with utillites included.  I'm very quiet,
considerate and communicative; you can see that from my posts. 

	I love people and always do things to try and help out a roommate; 
80% of the time I'm never to busy to help, talk with, do bodywork on a
fellow housemate, or do whatever.  I'm a licensed massage therapist, have 
a BS in Electrical Engineering, and am a Certified Electronic Technican. I
really don't have a geographical preference as long as its close to San
Francisco. I have a computer and spend a lot of time logging. I don't have
a problem keeping my cats in my room; as long as its big enough.  I will 
need to get a separtate phone line for my computer, and can install it 
myself.

	I like chores to be scheduled and devided up in the house, food
can either be communal or separtate, no meat ok. I'm neat, I put the
toilet seat down, and rinse the shower out after I use it. I like things 
to be tidey, but am not the type of person to get down on their hansd and 
knees with a tooth blush to clean the floor. Unless thats the only way to 
get it clean. I would hope my fellow housemates would do their chores 
within 72 hours of its scheduled date.

	I'm open to trading work whether it be massage or engineering
((appliance/computer repair, house wiring(telephone or power), car work
...etc)) for rent and do it very cheaply. For example a licensed electrican
gets about $75/hr, on a trade I will only charge $25/hr and it most cases
I exceed housing specifications, without added or unnecessary cost. As 
far as house wiring goes I can do everything from PG&E point of entry, 
top of mettercan pole, through main circuit breaker panel to the rest of the 
house.

	I don't like mean, rude, excessively drunk, selfish, dishonest,
inconsiderate, violent, illresponsible people. I expect that the rent I 
pay is and even derivative of the total rent; unless my room is either 
bigger or smaller; I'm not willing to sublet and pay for someone elses 
rent just because they hold the lease. 

	I like to have everything on the table, if you need references
from me, to see id ...etc no problem just ask. I feel that trust must be
built not just given, and this is acomplished I feel through being honest,
open, verifiable and accoutable. I expect to see a copy of the lease and
the utillity bills each month. If I move in and things can't be resolved 
though discussion than I would have no problem moving out, it is my 
believe that if I move into your household, and am causing friction to 
the point where we both can't resolve it without major lifestyle changes 
then its me that has to go.

	As housemates I'm much more interested in how you feel about 
something that I may be doing thats bothering you, rather than shouting, 
character assination, or expectations that I'm suppose to change.

	I have some living room furiture; most kitchen appliences,
blender, microwave, toaster ..etc. A great stereo 100watt+, with 150+
CD's; a great computer 486DX2-66 with 500megs of harddrive space. Lots of
artwork everything from fine $$$ to stuff I found on the street. I also
have my own car.

510-254-0933 Ct Active or e-mail me at the addresses list below; placing 
the word roommate in the header to get my prompt attention.

Subject: outdoor party yesterday
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

After hearing about a party on the beach by sloat, I decided to take a 
motorcycle ride down the coast to check it out and meet some friends.  At 
first I had some doubts about whether this rave on the beach would 
actually happen, and if it did, how long would it last.  The last party 
on the beach I went to got busted in less then an hour.  I rode up about 
1:30 into the parking lot.  Found some ravers, but no music.  One of the 
ravers said music would be there in about half an hour.  So I rode around 
for awhile.  When I came back, the rave on the beach was cranking out 
some music that instantly drew me to it and got me dancing right away.  
There wasn't alot of people dancing, but that didn't matter much to me, 
being able to dance in the outdoors and with the ocean.  

Other raves I've been to there have been alittle further down the beach 
away from sloat, a little more secluded.  It was great to see people 
walking by some stopping to check it out, some dancing a little as they 
did so.  

There was also a group of people who were cleaning up the beach.  
Initially I thought they came for the rave.  I found out later from a couple of 
fellow ravers who decided to help them out, that they were suppose to 
meet some kids there, but the kids never showed up.  One of the fellow 
ravers told them that there are some big kids here that might be willing 
to help.  With that they came over and danced with us and got some of us 
to help clean up alittle. 

I danced for about 3-4 hours before I unfortunately pooped out.  It was 
now 6pm with the party still going, a fire was being made and Galen was 
supposedly due to come on if people were able to withstand the cold.  
Having had my fill, I rode home feeling great riding down the beach with 
the vibe of the still running through me.  My motorcycle sounded like 
some techno base and beats as I cruised home.


peter

Subject: Correction: Yohimbine is not an MAOI
In-Reply-To: <m0rnjEO-000IKvC@priscilla.ultima.org>
References: <m0rnjEO-000IKvC@priscilla.ultima.org>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A small correction here:

Yohimbine is not a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI).  It is a CNS
stimulant, a selective antagonist for alpha 2-andrenergic receptors,
and is associated with increased norepinephrine release. It has been
studied in the laboratory in combination with MAOIs, which inhibit
norepinephrine degradation.

It could, given a large dose, or given with an MAOI, exacerbate the
effects of other drugs to an unknown degree.

If your friend was given an MAOI, it was likely harmaline, a potent
MAOI of about 5-8 hours duration which is easily extracted from
locally growable harmala seeds. Yohimbine must be brewed (extracted)
from yohimbe bark, which must be imported and is fairly expensive.  I
would expect an effective dose of genuine yohimbine to cost at least
several dollars.

All the other caveats apply. For the general public, I'd say that if
you can't recite off the top of your head what an MAOI does, what it
is contraindicated with, and how it synergizes with various other
substances, then you'd best stay away from it until you can.

Sean

PS. MDMA is a short-term selective MAOI to which the above precautions
do not apply.

1. Biaggioni I; Robertson RM; Robertson D.
     Manipulation of norepinephrine metabolism with yohimbine in the treatment
     of autonomic failure.
   Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 1994 May, 34(5):418-23.
     (UI:  94375607)
     Pub type:  Journal Article; Review; Review, Tutorial.

> 
> A small correction here:
> 
> Yohimbine is not a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI).  It is a CNS

I cannot refute what you are saying here if it indeed is quoted from a
reputable source.  I have however read several books that speak of yohimbe
as being an MAOI.  Your quoted article is perhaps more recent though.  Was
Yohimbe just recently found to *not* be an MAOI?  I have read many places
that say it is, including the package of yohimbe bark sitting in front of me.

> from yohimbe bark, which must be imported and is fairly expensive.  I

Actually, I can buy yohimbe bark here in Texas (legally) for a few dollars
an ounce which is more than enough for at least a dozen doses.  It is
clearly labeled as an MAOI on the package by the people who import it and
package it.  Again, perhaps this information has only recently been refuted,
but I'm not about to go mixing yohimbe with anything, whether it's an actual
MAOI or not and I still tend to think that it is.  You are the first of many
sources I've heard to say that it isn't, you understand my skepticism. 
Thank you very much for the info though.

> All the other caveats apply. For the general public, I'd say that if
> you can't recite off the top of your head what an MAOI does, what it
> is contraindicated with, and how it synergizes with various other
> substances, then you'd best stay away from it until you can.

That's good advice certainly.  I'd just generally stay away from MAOI's
period though unless you really know what you're doing.  I have no idea why
anyone would serve and MAOI at a bar anyway.  That's the stupidist thing
I've ever heard.  Did they not think people would be drinking or taking
anything?  That's just plain idiotic.  My 2 cents.

vibrating at the speed of love solarvibe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 13 17:14:06 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA25239; Mon, 13 Mar 1995 17:14:06 -0800
Received: from sysx.apana.org.au by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA25207; Mon, 13 Mar 1995 17:13:37 -0800
Message-Id: <m0roKF9-000IVoC@sysx.apana.org.au>
Date: Tue, 14 Mar 95 11:13 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Jeremy Rhoten's questionair...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> 1. A few general statements about why you like to rave.
Well,  for one,  it's great exercise!!   and not only do I get an awsome
workout dancing,  but I get to socialize as well.   Before I was seriously
raving,  I was not that social,  nor did I ever go out much.   Partly
because I was a little self conscous about dancing.

> 2. Comments on the relationship between rave culture and technology.
When I started going to the first Toon Town raves,   there was a lot of
technology present.   Computer graphics,  electronic music,  and other
electronic and computer thingies.    I think these things spun off
from all the parties put on by large companies at computer trade shows.
Early on,  when these parties first started,   they were funded by 
large companies,  who hired the DJ's,   negotiated for venues,  etc.
Eventually,  these evolved into the later Toon Town parties.

> 3. Is the music the most important aspect of the culture?  What do you 
> like about techno and other electronic music?

Well,  the music certainly plays a large part of it,  and tends to be
the fundimental tribal vehicle that carries one along through the trance
state of mind.

> 4. How important are the drugs for promoting the rave vibe?

Drugs are certainly something that can help promote the trance state,
but it's important that people use the drugs wizely and not abuse them
or use them for the wrong purposes,  or take them in wrong combinations.
It also depends on the specific drug,  it's potency and purity.
It also depends on the specific drugs one indulges in.   

> 5. The rave culture is very different from the hippie culture of the 60s 
That is certainly true.... The music is different,  the drugs are also
different.   In the 60's  MDMA wasn't around then,  but acid was also a
lot stronger then todays standards.

> 6. What changes has the movement gone through since you've been part of 
> it?  What are the effects of commercialization?

Well,  for one... it's getting harder and harder to locate good venues,
mostly in part due to the authorities cracking down on good parties.
Also,  events are over commercialized in a very big way,  as promoters
are getting more greedy,  charging far more then they have to.

> 7. Do some raves have more of an ego vibe than others?  Is there a sharp 
> distinction between the underground movement and the popular/commercial 
> scene?

Certainly they do.  But the people who are really dedicated to the scene
often can tune out the ego factor and cancel out the bad ego facter. 

> 8. Where is the movement heading?  Will it survive or will it die when 
> the music and fashion inevitably changes (like the hippies)?

Well, I certainly hope the movement continues,  as this to me is the
best thing that came my way since the "coolaid acid test of the 60's"
and has been a wonderful remedy to my social problems in the past.

Cheers
CC

Dear Sfraves;

	Hi all!!!, hope you are all well & content. Due to the
nonfinancial sucess of myself professionally practicing massage therapy at
raves, the number of events uncovered, the number of people desiring
therapy, my limitations as a human provider, that I'm currently looking 
to organize other therapists out there on and off the scene, so that we 
can bring qualified, diversified, ethical, loving, respectful, responsible, 
massage/touch therapy to the people at raves, for an affordable cost. 

	I would like at this time to invite other ethical massage/touch,
and other alternative healing/art professionals to contact me so that we
can organize & network togther, in cooperation not competition, so to
provide a wonderful generation, with quality, affordable, touch &
alternative therapy/art at raves. To make our parties not just a place to
burn brain cells, but to celabrate life, heal & love one another in a way
thats both affirming and respectful of each others self. So that raves can
go further down the path to becoming a true festival of life, diversity,
healing energy and love. Jimi Hendrix believed that music would eventually
be a healing art, that it would penatrate the body like rays and heal. I
believe we can do this though, touch, dance, art and music. 

	Just the mear act of you reaching out and placing your hand on
some elses body, brings pressure, heat, and energy to that area. The
pressure pushes clogged lymph, and waste products into the drainage system
of the body of the person being touched. The heat makes the connective
tissue which surrounds our entire body more liquidifed, meaning the layers
of muscle tissue side across each other more easially. Also making our
bodies celluar matrix more liquidifed, which means immune cells can move
around the body easier, requiring less energy to do their healing &
regenerative functions. With removal of the touch/pressure fresh blood and
nutrients come into to that area and feed the tissue and the cells. As far
as energy goes, no one really knows what happens when the energy fields
that surround each of us, uniquely characterize and polarized by our own
individuality, state of being and genetics, comes in contact with
anothers. All I know is that when someone with a loving, respectful, kind
intent reachs out and touchs me, I get the warm fuzzies and feel great,
ENERGY!!!!. 

	To become one with ourselves and the people around us, though 
respectful affirming touch, dance, music, astrology, art, science, 
technology, food, drink, and alternative substance ...etc

	I really want this to become part of our celabrations, I see a 
need and a desire for it. To provide people at our events with quality, 
responsible, certified first aid care, drug overdose or bad trip care, 
and of course good reventative & feel good therapy as well. We deserve to do 
this for ourselves, and I feel we can make it happen, As long as greed 
doesn't get in our way!!!!!!

	I do massage at raves for the love of doing massage at raves, to
be a part of the scene, to touch and provide people with a little bit of
love and care. Yes I charge a very small fee for these services, that fee
is at a rate of 65% less than what I normally charge. If I were to do it
for free, and I do give a lot of massage away, I would have a line out the
door, and would be exhausted both mentally and physically in an hour. 
What I do for people who can't afford to pay the $5.00 is I do 10 minutes
for 10 minutes, in others words you rub me for 10 minutes and I'll rub you
for 10 minutes. I don't care about the precision of your strokes, all I
care about is whether your hearts in the right place, whether you care
about the person your hands are on, thats what does it for me. 

	So if you are a promoter, or a massage/touch/alternative healing
arts person and are interested in either having or joining me and my
partners respectively please contact me at 510-254-0933. I'm available for
most benefit work, any AIDS or environmental benefits get 120% of my
proceeds, 120% not a typo. But only do it for the love of raving, the scene, 
yourself, and the beautiful people of this area. 

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

			The message is love!!!!

From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler)
Subject: Harmony...(Take #2 March 31st)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello all you beautiful sfravers,

	I'll start by saying it's wonderful to be back on line! Thanx to 
Brian Darkness for posting that little announcement about my netcom 
account problem! 

	First things first! Harmony last friday was postponed as some of 
you know, because of the horrible storms that rocked california last 
weekend! We had the hardest time trying to figure out what to do. But, 
in the long run, (at about 5pm.) we decided to postpone the party 
because it was not safe for people to drive up to the location. We did 
not want people getting stuck overnight if the roads got blocked again 
after the party would have started. (By the way, the roads did get 
blocked again overnight!.) We did not want to run off generators, (the 
location lost all power until sunday afternoon!) But most of all we did 
not want anyone getting hurt! So it was a unanimous decision... We are 
truly sorry...

	So to make it up to you, we are planning the best make-up party 
that we are capable of! It is going to be in the same beautful location. 
(No, the river didn't wash the building away!) We are now able to put in 
more time to make the party even better than what we planned for march 
10th! We are also working more harmoniously with Craig Larson to set up 
a spectacular visual light show! Randy and the crew from Dionysus Dreams 
are setting up a bigger and better ambient area. (Before we were only 
using a small portion of one of the rooms for an ambient area, now we 
have the whole thing! Reconstruction was taking place that week of march 
10th.) We are making more props for the party, (some got destroyed at 
Trent's house party!) We are using different dj's this time! So far we 
have Trent, Ethan, and Galen! More are to be announced...Pretty cool...

	This party is planned for march 31st. Three weeks away, I can't 
wait! 

	I wanted to say a great thanx to all of you who made it to 
Trent's house on friday. That was a pretty bad ass party! Trent kicked 
serious butt! And, we recorded it on DAT, so he might get it on tapes 
or something.) I had a great time, and loved meeting all of you! I thank 
you for supporting us and understanding our situation...

Peace, love, and harmony to all,

Shroomy


Ps. I want to say in our world today, we all need to live together, work 
together, and exist together. In times of crisis, (Loma Prieta, 
Hurricane Andrew, floods, etc.) we all come together as one. A society 
with one purpose, to help the misfortuned. We all come together in 
harmony to get things done. Those times are the most destructive times 
in the world, but then they are also the most beautiful times. To be 
able to see hundreds and thousands of people working together to help 
eachother is the most beautiful occurance in time. Participating is even 
better! So remeber that in order to survive as a culture, as a world, we 
must work together and help eachother as much as possible, not just in 
times of crisis! Living together, in harmony, is the key... Spread the 
love!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

C-YA @ F & F!!

Shroomy


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 14 04:05:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id EAA25317; Tue, 14 Mar 1995 04:05:57 -0800
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id EAA25310; Tue, 14 Mar 1995 04:05:54 -0800
Received: by netcom.netcom.com (8.6.10/Netcom)
	id EAA01692; Tue, 14 Mar 1995 04:04:47 -0800
Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 04:04:47 -0800
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199503141204.EAA01692@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: First report from Australia
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Latest info from RAVE HEAVEN!!

Well,  It's now Wednesday here in Australia,  and Tuesday in the USA,,
and this is yet another wakey rave report on an interesting weekly
happening in Sydney,  Australia.

In the Darlinghurst district in Sydney which is similar to the Castro
in San Francisco,  there exists this pub called Bently's
on Crown St.   And every Wed evening,  a group of very interesting
musicians called Clan Analogue,  which is a collective of talented
musicians,  hold a "get together/ dance party" with DJ'd music,  and
live acts.

I'm not sure of the DJ's name,  but he started off with hi-nrg house,
slightly faster than the normal pace of the SF scene.   About an hour
later,   the most insane hi-energy acid trance started to fill up the
dance floor.    I decided to do this one sober - And as usual,  the
music pumped in just as much awsome energy into my body that L and E
could have done.   And at the prices of "E",   doing it sober was
really neat,  and absolutly necessary.

All around me,   I was pumping in energy into the dance crowd,  and to
be honest,   they just aren't used to seeing a old 52 yr old dude from
America dancing like a maniac.    It seems that the club scene here has
a really interesting vibe.   One thing I noticed missing are the Gangsta
types.   They just don't exist here.   Or if they do,   they are doing
a good job of hiding.   Very few Black people here.

I've come to the conclusion,  Sydney is RAVE HEAVEN!!  And I encourage every
self respecting raver to get down,  Down under...   These guys really know
how to party...   And I'm being deluged with people asking me about the
SF scene.    When I say it's Housey,  they say "Cool,  but we like more
variaty".   House music takes a 2nd stage over here,  but in the club
scene,  it's mostly house.

Almost everywhere I go,  I hear techno...  in the shops,  on people's car
radios,  in the clubs,  and on the radio.   Especially on the radio.   

There are no stations that dedicate ALL their time to techno,   but it's not
that hard to find it on the dial perhaps about 50% of the time.   For instance,
on 2SER FM,  they have it from 2 - 4 pm every day.

They also got community stations here,  and one in particular is 
Radio Skid Row...   A low power station,  serving the center of Sydney
with about 60% techno and alternate programming.

On thursday evening at 1 am,  I was invited to be interviewed on the radio
and talked about the SF scene.   It was recieved very well,  had many people
call in and ask me questions,  as well as give messages out to listeners.

Vic Zitser,  a DJ,  hosted the program,   and before the radio show,  we
sat behind his turntables at his pad and I got a chance to spin some
Happy Hardcore,  and Acid trance,  and he showed me how to gradually "up"
the tempo from 130 bpm to 180 bpm in a totally seamless way.   A very
interesting DJ trick.   I wish OUR DJ's would do things like that.

I also met Bernie,  the dude putting on this birthday bash,  and he
reminds me of Frazer Clark...  

It appears to be very common for DJ's to start off relativly slow,  say
around 140 BPM,  and gradually increase the tempo to 190 BPM in a single
2 hour set.  

Happy hardcore,  totally absent from the SF scene,  primarily due to it's
faster BPM range of 160 - 180,  is just not yet accepted in the SF scene,
at least in the mainstream.

I have to say,  it's really neat,  and incredably ennergetic.

On the air,  we talked and plugged "Bernie's Birthday Bash" a party thats
to take place tonight at "The Pavilion".    Other parties scheduled tonight
are....

        -Symbiotic by Vibe Tribe
         DJs Nick (Prana U.K.), Eon (U.K.),
             Zeitgeist, Bass Bitch, Sub Bass Snarl
         Live: Squish, Non Bossy PossE
         + Chillamental Zone with Chin Bindi Bombasha Percussion,
           Cianamaya & guests.  Chai, Juice, Munchies Cyberdelic Video
         Info: 0055 22746  or 88.9 FM        $10
         --------------------------------------------
        -Restoration
         Arena 1 - Ming D, Pee Wee, John Ferris, Hype,
                   Nik Fish, Jumping Jack
         Arena 2 - Martyn Allen, Dave Kirkpatrick, Andrew James,
                   Freestyle, Milo, Eden
         Lounge Bar - Sasha, Dion & Guests.
         1 Angel Place City (mear Martin Place)   9pm-8am
         Tickets:$15+bf from Reach'n Records, BPM Records,
         Central Station Records, Folkways, Parade Music,
         Spit Records, Music Zone, Mall Music
         --------------------------------------------
        -Revolt   at the Hyde Park Barracks.  10pm-7am
         DJs: Sheen, Dave Kirpatrick, Pee Wee, Nick Field, Mal Russel,
              Louise, Martyn Allen, Tim McGee + Guests.
         --------------------------------------------
        -Aurora
         DJs: Fenix, Spellbound, Reaver, Jumping Jack, Georgy Porgy
         info: 0055 16171   Tickets: $20+bf adv.
         
As you all can see,  there are just too many parties for this one heavy
raver dude to swallow in one evening.   But I was able to manage to get
on Bernies,  and Symbiotic's guest list,  so will probably check out
at least these two.

Almost all the parties take place in Sydney city center,  and are all
within the 1 km area.

There is one thing thats really annoying...  It's those "0055" numbers
given out on the flyers.  They are similar to our "900" numbers,  but
when you call them,  you can get soaked for about $5 per call,  and
it's really annoying when they have a 3 minute entro of just music
and another 5 minutes of narration before the directions are given
to the venue.

Last night,  I got a hotel in Kings Cross,  and WOW!!  Whatta trip Kings Cross
is on a Friday evening.   There are strip tease joints and barkers constantly
pulling people into their venues.  Cover ranges from $25 for strip acts,  and
of course dancing.   Most of these play house in the 120 BPM range.   Boring!!

I dosed up a tab,  and the "Cross" as it's called is really something to behold.
First off,   establishments can sell booze 24 hours a day.   There is NO 2 am
closing time.   The ALL stay open all night long,  at least until 6 am,  and
mostly till 8 am.   Drinking age here is 18 and over,   and ID checking is
lax at best.

After leaving my hotel,  I decided to go back to Club-77 to hear Phil Smart,
Sugar Ray,  Jumping jack,  and Nick Fish.   When I arrived,  Jumping jack was
spinning house,  and I heard all the familiar songs heard in SF.    It was
like I ever left.   Later on,  Phil smart got on,   and guess what...  I heard
the laughing song...  So it's played here as well.   :-)   The name of this
weekly is 'LOADED",  and behind the turntables are a really cool Mural showing
a loaded gun with a smile on it's side and a bullet coming out (Also with
smile).    For a club,  the vibe was totally insane.   I got tons of smiles,
and people coming up and dancing next to me.

I think the Aussies are starting to get a feel for the absolute dedication to
the scene that I represent.   Although I've been nursing a cold when I arrived,
it hung on for almost a week,  and I felt like my energy level was at an all
time low.   

Jumping Jack finally went on,  and spun the most awsome acid trance I've heard
since Goa Gil....  Yow!!  I went totally insane and almost completly forgot that
I really wanted to try and get some sleep.    But as it always turns out,
sleep is something I always sacrafice when I have such a good time.   One dude
who calls himself "Stickey" came up to me and gave me a big smile and thumbs
up.   The dancing energy though was rather low for Calif standards but when
Sugar Ray went on,   WOW!!  What a increase in energy....  Everyone was cheering
and yelling just like back home.

The Club 77 is a rather small venue,  and it can get hot and stuffy in there
but I managed to find the air conditioner vent and a great spot to dance
and stay cool.

Later on,   Sugar Ray came up to me and asked me who I was,  and where I came
from.   I filled him in on the details,  and after I told him I was writing
about the rave scene,  he consented to an interview.   Sometime soon,  I'm
going to sit down and talk to him about the Australian scene in detail and
write up more stuff and publish it in SFRaves, alt.rave,  and AusRaves.

So,  later this afternoon,  I'm going to interview him at BPM records.
YEA!!  They got a BPM record store HERE as well.    I don't think they
are affiliated with the BPM store in SF.

I'm sitting here in an American Cafe in the Cross,   where I discovered they
serve American Pancakes (A rarity here in Australia).

Well,   I gotta prepare some Email to upload later,  when I can find a phone,
so I'll break off here...  It may be as late as Wednesday before I'll get
the chance to upload this.

---------

WELL,  I wasn't able to scarf up a freebie and get into Restoration,  but
bought a ticket anyway.   When I arrived,  they had two arenas set up,
one playing house which I avoided,  because coming from SF scene,  we
get all the house and garage anyone would ever want.   So I headed directly
for the Hard Core arena and loosened my body up a tad with some pretty insane
breakbeat with Sasha behind the turntables.   I was practically the only
one dancing,   so I decided to go down George St about 5 blocks to check
out Bernies Birthday Bash.   I then learned that the Vibe tribe party was
to be in Alexandria's Graffitti hall of fame,   which was way too far to
make it on foot.    So I called Mike Dagn to tell him that I couldn't
make it,  unless someone was to give me a ride.

Unfortunately,  I didn't recieve Addey's message until long after the
party.    Sorry about that!!   But I don't have access to a home phone
anymore so I was only able to check my Mail a few days later...

As I was looking for the Pavilion entrance,  I asked a few young Aussie
dudz where "the Bash" was,  and they said "You go to raves?"   I said
"Yup!  I live to rave...."  they asked how old I was,  and after telling
them,  they said "Far out...  We need older people here in our scene".

I then told them I came from Restoration,  and it waas just starting up,
and they said that they were planning to go over and check it out.

When I arrived at the Pavilion,   things were just getting set up,  and
their dress code didn't allow shorts,  but luckily I popped over to Bill's
pad and changed,  then came back..

Bernies party was a real slow starter,  but I met this dude who was to
be heading over to Vibe tribe at about 4 am,   but was unable to connect
as I explain later...

Bernies bash provided me with some wonderful Happy Hardcore which is
totally non-existant in the SF scene (whotta drag),  and now I know
why they call it that.    I was bopping around the dance floor with
this huge smile on my face,  groovin to the insane pace of 170 - 180
BPM's just getting off big time.    My Aussie friends must have thought
I was totally insane,  as I was chasing the lazer beams all over the
dance floor like a total insane idiot.   Sorta like a dog chasing
a flashlight beam  :-)

I had been partying the evening before at the Loaded bash at Club 77,
but my energy level for the 2nd allnigher was really cranked up and
was totally peaking all evening until the end.    Ahhh!!  These double
all nighters really get me going.... 

The Lazer show was really cool,   and the fog machine provided my eyes
with superb eye Kandy....

After a while,   I wanted to walk around Sydney for a while and head back
to Restoration,  and by the time I arrived,  things were going in full
swing.   I imediately wasted no time and got down to the most insane
acid trance I've heard since hearing Goa spin.   I met those same Aussie
Dudz I met at the Pavilion on the dance floor,  and they couldn't believe
the energy I had.   

I was certainly the oldest dude out there,   as almost everyone was younger
than 25.   But I didn't let that stop me from really getting on and groovin
big time.   People around me were totally blown away as I poured on the
energy and good vibe.   WOW!!  My cheeks still hurt from all the smiling
I've done.

I headed back to Bernies Birthday bash so I could catch my ride to the Vibe
tribe,   but for some reason,  Bernie's bash ended early, and there were
rumours that Vibe tribe might get busted.    This scared off my ride,  so
my opportinuty for a ride to Vibe tribe was reluctantly removed,  and
I had no choice to either head back to Restoration,   or do this special
workshop that involved watching the sun rise at the beach.

Not having an opportunity to go to a Sydney beach,  we head out to Bondai
Beach and watch the sunrise experimenting with a massive dose of "A".

The sunrise was awsome,   and after that,  we walked around the many coves
and inlets as well as gawked at the beautiful homes,  and jogging pathways
along the beach.   The cliffs were totally amazing....  The water was
amazingly clear,   very clean and sanitary beaches here.   I haven't
seen such clean water since I visited the tropics.  The brown cliffs,
carved by ions of years appeared to be sculpted by some insane artist.

After the sunrise,  we ate breakfast,  and took a bus back to the 
inner city.

--------

After returning,  I chilled in the Botonical gardens and went swimming
in a local salt water pool.    As I was lying on the grass,  this Ibis
bird was poking it's long curved bill into the ground barley 6 inches
from my face as I was lying there.   One thing thats really startling
is the abundance of exotic birds,  and how close you can get to them
without them flying away.

In 2 weeks,  I plan to take a trek up into the Blue mountains,  and
this upcoming Friday,  an outdoors rave is scheduled.

>On Mon, 13 Mar 1995 SCRUTON@PAELE.dnet.hac.com wrote:

>>
>> then you're torching the environment, whether you know it or not.
>>
>> the la times today mentioned that the EPA has to be called in to
>>   clean up meth labs when they bust them, because of the amatuerish
>>     and haphazard way in which toxins are handled.  in most cases,
>>       they just get dumped.
>>
>> ...can you say "poison the neighborhood"?
>>
>> Dave Scruton
>>
>
>Ummm Where do you think the MA comes from in MDMA? Or is this a blanket
>censure of any related substance?
>
>                                                    Black Adder

Even though the two substances aren't unrelated, the methods used to
produce them are different, so MDMA manufacture is not necessarily as
damaging. In addition meth is much easier to produce, therefore it's more
likely that amateurs and others not familiar with proper chemical safety
procedures are involved in its synthesis.

Joe

Brian & Greg comment:

hey all,
this is completely off the subject of sfr, but i 
just *had* to share the great experience i had in introducing raves to 
some of my friends out here in cow-ville Davis:
last weekend i brought 8 die-hard dead-head friends to their first rave 
(it was in sacramento). the vibe was not going on, most people left by 
3am, and it was over-priced. but, if i've learned anything since moving 
up north and getting "into" the sf rave scene, it's that you can't 
just expect a positive vibe to just happen, you gotta help create the 
magic--so i brought lots of fun stuff to share and tried to make some smiles.
at any rate, it was really great seeing my friends really turning onto 
this rave (despite its flaws) and going *nuts* dancing to Dj Dan and 
curiously looking at Dubtribe, with their equipment strewn all over the 
floor, and asking, "jason, how do they *make* this trippy music?!?!" it 
was so wonderful seeing them smiling and playing/meditating in the chill
room...
all i have to say is THANK YOU sf ravers for showing me that raving 
is all about a good vibe! my experiences at the "best" L.A. and S.D. raves 
are nothing compared to even the *worst* party up here. the vibe is the seller!
here's a tid-bit from one of my friends:

> It was definately an unforgetable 
> night.  I have never experienced anything like it. RAD RAD RAD!! I wanna 
> go again soon. I have a whole new appreciation for techno.  It becomes a 
> part of your whole being. It enters every facet and vein in your body. 
> AMAZING!

peace n' stuff
jase
ps see ya @ FF (even though ph-ph is only 15min away. sorry, i'm addicted)

Monty Python/terry Gilliam?), Priscilla, Queen of the Dessert ("I will 
survive!" in Vegas in space style drag in the outback honey!), 
Orlando, Marlon Rigg's "Anthem"- black gay male defiant Chicago house and 
snap diva's short video rallying cry), Satyricon, The Wiz (Dorothy and 
company again, souled up-?), Latcho Drom (gypsy wail and romance), Harold 
and Maude (no dancing, but the vibe!), Female Trouble (or is John 
Waters too much?), City of Women, La Dolce Vita (or too decadent and 
too much Marcello Mastioni/bachelor ego?), someone said 2001, right?, 
Planet of the Apes!, Breakfast at Tiffany's (go Holly Go Lightly, party 
girl and "screaming reds/blues" moods woman!), Rocky Horror Picture 
Show...the list goes on and on...

(and i'm sorry if most of these belong on a house queen and club kid or 
gay favorites list, we just find em carnivalesque, not very "faceless 
techno bollocks" at all)    ;)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 14 18:14:44 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id SAA19687; Tue, 14 Mar 1995 18:14:44 -0800
Received: from liberty.liberty.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id SAA19680; Tue, 14 Mar 1995 18:14:38 -0800
Received: by liberty.liberty.com (Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #10)
	id m0roi65-002qmhC; Tue, 14 Mar 95 17:42 PST
Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 17:41:59 -48000
From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Reply-To: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Gangbangers NOT!!!!!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9503141645.C6097-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear Sfraves;

	I read something recently that bothered be greatly, and am now I 
think emotionally clear enough to write about it coherently. Someone 
mentioned that at times there have been groups of men/boys going around 
raves, with the intention of gang raping womyn on E.

	When I read this I cannot express in words the level of outrage, 
shame as a man, and anger I felt. As men we cannot allow behaviour such as 
this continue in our time. We as men must put a stop to this senseless 
destruction and violation of our fellow womyn/sisters. I remember cring 
when I read about the mass raping of womyn over in Bosina.

	I've seem the end results of such horrible behaviour, a life 
still living but utterly destoried. I just cannot understand, and will 
not except behaviour from another man, and will fight them anyway I know how.

	If you know someone who has particpated in such acts please turn 
them into the authorites, because they will do it again. We must stop 
these sick people before they destory another life.

	Yes, I do understand that people who do this have often been 
abused themselves, and often by womyn. Their belief systems are so 
perverted from the hurt and pain that they are it, that they feel 
justified in their actions. As men they are also often not able to access 
the emotional safety valves that normal healthy people have available to 
them, for coping with extreme trauma.

	But this is still no excuse to go out and do the same thing to
other beautiful innocent human being. I as a man & as a human being say
that this must stop and that we as men can put a end to rape in all its
forms in our time.  But to do this we must not tolerate it from our
contemporaies, and must report it to the authorites, insist that our
legislators make strong effective punishments, provide preventative and
after the fact consuling for both victums and perpetrators, and education 
in our schools.

	I remember talking with a freind of mine who was recently date
raped, she was such a beautiful care free person who loved and trusted
everyone. After she was raped, when she wasn't in a disassoicated state,
she was just afraid, afraid of men, people, and what hurt the most, even
me. We sat their and cried together. I hope I never have to do that again.
As a male massage therapist I have to deal with this fear a lot. A lot of
my womyn friends say they walk around in fear. When I first started
becoming aware of the level and severity of this I almost couldn't believe
it. I would encourage men to ask womyn about this, encourage men to become
more aware that are sisters live in a state of rape fear. 

	On the other hand I would encourage parents to teach both genders
of their children how to fight and defend themselves, not just the boys. 
I would encourage womyn to learn how to defend themselves if no one has
ever taught them to. Of course I would always stress violence as a last
resort to saving ones life or self. 

	I'm sorry I realize this isn't totally rave related, I feel its 
important to talk about these things, To make people more aware, for this 
is all I can do as a fellow human being, is make people more aware. I 
feel if you bring awareness into people's lives the rest will take care 
of its self. I hope this made you think & feel, I hope that you feel just as 
outraged as I did when I first read about Gangbangers. I hope as men, that 
we put a stop to this in our life times. Thanks.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace

i dream of castrati...standing sweetly at a party, gang-bangers never 
more, just sweet screeching-along-with-the-diva castrted boy/men!...

Diamanda Galas, her wild women with steak knives routine, at a rave
(well almost, a few years ago at Fusion club at the Oasis, Niki Rivera i 
think it was spun some gigantic Galas-like voice booming something about 
waking up, possible life on Mars, and desires unbound- briefly, between 
house/techno/high energy). Fabulous!

Brian, my in the haze of emotion response to your eloquent horror, you 
said it! (Rorgive me for invoking Lorena Bobbit notions for raves, but 
that's how i feel toward gun, violence, hate pain spewing  freaking 
idiots of any sex, especially male, at parties...watching this stuff 
happen in a utopian peace aspiring scene is really hard to take...
"oh yes mum, it can really be as fucked up as any other crummy scene, 
PLUR shattered by a few testosterone ridden neanderthal freaks, ok 
mum."
	I don't know the L.A. or local rave-turned-riot nightmare 
stories, but i remember the horror of M.E.S.S.'s tiny Candlestick Park 
water front party disruption- being surrounded for a few minutes by 
rival gangs ponding on eachother and beating the faces of some of us 
merry partyers who kindly asked them to either stop harrassing the women, 
stay and dance with us, or else leave.  No gunshots from these packed 
guys, we were relieved, but still, the fear.
	Wrong turf, bad luck, no matter how happy the house being 
spun at the time, oh well.

re: gangrapes of women at/after raves

scary shit!  i'm curious - where did you read this?  a small part of me 
is skeptical, wondering if it came from a conservative source, but 
of course it's just the same old "fratboy" sexist 
shit, different drugs.

it sucks, but people carry all their nasty baggage with them to parties, 
of course.  i wish raves were a complete escape from capitalist 
hetero-patriarchy (to use bell hooks' term), and sometimes they are, but 
most often not.  i know, i know, there's no overnight revolutions, in 
consciousness or otherwise, but it still totally sucks to have to deal 
with abuse anytime, esp. at a rave, and i'm really saddened to hear about 
that.

monicat

> > The flyer is advertised as "The black dog", not "Black Dog Productions".

> > Any comments?  I'd like to not show support for somebody trying to cash in
> > on another band's name, but I'd really like to see Spacetime, Single Cell
> > Orchestra, and Velocette anyways.  Ethical dilemma, hmmm.

> Looks to me like the Black Dog are having a little fun with us. Plaid is 
> merely the name under which two of the 3 (4?) members record. Look at 'Bytes.' 
> See all the Plaid tracks?

Actually, Black Dog is 'The Black Dog.' Check out just about any release 
except Bytes. It'll say 'Black Dog.' Far as I unnahstood it, Black Dog 
Productions is the umbrella name for BD and all their related/spinoff 
groups. Bytes was more-or-less a compilation (a very nepotistic one, but 
a compilation nonetheless). BDP includes Plaid, but doesn't necessarily 
mean that they're the true Black Dog. 

If it's fake, then I certainly wouldn't figure Black Dog themselves to 
be behind it. Would you want to lug your gear 5000 miles to play a show 
you've scared everyone away from? And since the Spacetimers got a danka 
on Bytes (if it *was* for them), I figure they'd know the difference.

*late news flash*

I heard from Miguel (single cell orch) that there was some problem or 
confusion with getting Ken Downie into the US. He didn't know if he was 
actually here or not, but said that someone would be posting a message 
(or apology as the case may be) to the net shortly.

Either way, I'm still going. SpaceTime, Velocette and SCO are well worth 
the admission. I tend to believe that this is more of a miscommunication
or accident rather than a scam. And I certainly can't say I'm not a Plaid 
fan either.

jmar. woof.

The Chemica  Sutra Technoerotic Expedition is a Megatripolis Parallel
University Event. Space
 is extremely limited with only room for 150 people so all those
considering attending - come early to avoid disappointment.  For those
unable to make it  Chemica Sutra will be followed in April by  a second
Parallel Univeristy Event featuring Dan Mapes'  and the Cyberlab 7 Safari
Across V.R.  Zen & Now. More details will follow. The Parallel University
for those who don't know, organises Infinity Treks, using ancient & modern
visionary technologies, to the points where seemingly parallel universes
meet. We claim to do this in as human and subversively edutaining a manner
possible. Intelligent Raving, in a nutshell. See you there!
Love,
        Fraser   x  x

I enjoy expressing my opinions, but I have no illusions about the
importance of my words.  What we say, like the propaganda on rave flyers,
means little compared to our actions.  Ultimately, it is our behavior
towards one another, the way in which our intentions are executed and
*felt* by others that will determine whether our "meme" or ideas propagate. 

And speaking of successful propagation, this is quite a symbolic weekend 
we have coming up.  

- We have the 4-year anniversary of the Full Moon Rave thanks to the 
Wicked crew who came over here from the UK to help mold and establish the 
SF scene and have continued to perpetuate a tradition of insanity and
transcendence through music and dance.  

- The one year anniversary of Friends And Family will celebrate the heart 
and soul of the kind of renegade raving that Ethan, Bryce and others have 
been quietly sharing with us (for 2 years actually) out of their love for 
people and for the ideals of individual freedom.

- Another free Organic Party in Golden Gate Park thanking us, the 
house/rave community, for helping them perpetuate the joyful vibe that
has continued to make their parties a success over the years.

- And in 2 weeks we'll have the first Sunset party of the year from
relative newcomers, the Pacific crew, who melted our hearts last year
with their selflessness and caring intuition about what it means to
make good intentions a reality.

I won't be able to go to all of these events, but will continue to
support these people in my own small way, whenever I can.  I am confident
that the SF Bay Area rave scene will continue to grow and evolve, with or
without my (or anyone's) words.  Promoters/sound systems/clubs/philosphers 
will continue to come and go for a variety of reasons.  The ones that 
contribute positively to our scene, promoting unity and love, or whatever
it is that people want and need, will succeed through the actions that do 
just that.  It's that simple.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

P. Greenwell said:
> 
> On Tue, 14 Mar 1995, Joe Rice wrote:
> 
> > At 22:13 3/13/95, P. Greenwell wrote:

[stuff about meth labs poisoning the environment deleted]

> > >Ummm Where do you think the MA comes from in MDMA? Or is this a blanket
> > >censure of any related substance?
> > >
> > >                                                    Black Adder
> > 
> > Even though the two substances aren't unrelated, the methods used to
> > produce them are different, so MDMA manufacture is not necessarily as
> > damaging. In addition meth is much easier to produce, therefore it's more
> > likely that amateurs and others not familiar with proper chemical safety
> > procedures are involved in its synthesis.
> > 
> > Joe

> My point is that quite a few of the same highly toxic and corrosive 
> chemicals are involved, and are just as easily mis-handled. I think it is 
> silly that people put themselves on a pedestal in regards to their drug 
> usage. 
>  
>                                                    Black Adder

Joe's point was that although the molecules are nearly identical,
the manufacturing process is not really that close.
Which means that different chemicals are used and in a different manner.

The point about meth labs is that they are all over the place.
In a ten minute drive through a local neighborhood
i probably pass a good 10 to 20 (or more?) meth production places
mostly being done in hotel rooms where the disposal of things is 
done by dumping fumes up the faucet in the sink and the rest
down the drain of the bathtub

MDMA production obviously doesnt happen like this
or i would know a lot more E dealers and producers
than i do speed dealers and producers.

MDMA is usually being made by people who know what they are doing
because it is a much more complicated process.  People
who arent doing it in hotel rooms and therefore are
more careful about what they do with their waste so they dont get caught.

 ,
dana

"He doesn't need an ID, he's got a tattoo across 
his forehead that says 'Metropolis'."

This may seem a little off the subject of SF Raves, but I think that I is 
entirely within the realm of what we are all talking about.  Developing a new 
community which transcends the problems of our current hierarchial, dominator 
culture.  I am working on my senior thesis and I am focusing on our end of the 
millinea culture.  Specifically, I am examining the writings and prophecies of 
Terence McKenna and Timothy Leary, the development of a new language, and the 
'end of history'; cyberspace, VR and the culture developing in the rave 
scenes.  If anyone has read McKenna or Leary's most recent works, has any 
comments, opinions or just wants to discuss these ideas, I'd appreciate the 
help. 

Thank You!!!

please e-mail me (Love Anais) at bliss@rain.org

We are recovering "the lost jewel at the beginning of time", together.

by stating that he would prefer that ALL nasty chemicals stay in 
industrial areas, and not in peoples' back yards. The only reason I 
griped was the title of the message. I was just pointing out that 
another substance that is widely used, uses many of the same 
ingredients. And many of the same chemicals are used. 


>

facility(nice metal one?)

>

> because it is a much more complicated process.  People
> who arent doing it in hotel rooms and therefore are
> more careful about what they do with their waste so they dont get caught.
>

I don't believe you do either.

Again, my point is simply that chemicals can and probably are disposed of 
improperly by some makers of chemicals besides Methamphetamines. I doubt 
every happy e-lab spends the money on taking their waste to a toxic 
disposal facility. Or acid lab, or whatever......

                                             Black Adder

>There are a lot of us out here who have been going to Grateful Dead concerts
>for years.  Most of us weren't around for the Acid Tests, but wish we had been.
>
>We love to dance.  We NEED to dance.
>
>We Are Everywhere.

And besides, a real live going-off rave is about a million times more
fun and perhaps even more "spiritual" (if that's your cup of meat) than
any recent dead show. Thought I can't say, since I haven't been to any
ones recently (i usually just dance in the parking lot) because every
time I go, I ask myself why I bothered. Hell, nowadays I'd probably get
more vibe whiffing the toxic hair-goo from de lady-in-front-of-me's
bouffant at the Neal Diamond show...

Lately I feel that Jerry has become one of those disneyland
audioanimatrinic-lincoln-speaks characters and the overall show is
dragging and lagging. On the other hand, I've been to some screamingly
headmelting epiphanies/shows in the early '80's e.g. Greek Theater at
Berkeley, Frost Amphitheater @ Stanford, H.J.Kaiser in Oakland, etc.
and of course my first dead show (10/92 @ Frost) where I caught a real
nice "vibe" from a relatively small crowd of 10,000 partiers ...
sometimes I haul out a soundboard tape or two to remind me of the
intensity they were capable of.  (Please bind, gag, and hog-tie me
before I start soundin' like yer grampa, ok?)

Today, I'll take raving, thank you very much.

PS: If you want to check out a Rock/Jazz/Blues/Funk/R&B-oriented group
that completely blows the Dead away (and from whom the Dead
took/popularized many a song/sound) check out "The funky Meters" on Sat
March 25 at the Fillmore. They are truly incredible, and I'll never
forget the funky stanky booty wagglin' communal vibe (to say nothing
about the amazing amount of spleefs being passed between strangers in
the audience) of  the Meters shows at the Covered Wagon in '89, or
their shows in New Orleans at the Jazz fest, etc. I can't promise this
will be the same, because they're missing original members from the
original "The Meters", e.g. guitarist Leo Nocentelli and original
drummer Joseph "Ziggy" Modeliste (one of the great new orleans
drummers). Fortunately Russell Batiste (from a great new orleans
drumming family, and it shows) is an incredibly funky beatmaker, and
Art Neville (keyboards, also a key player in the Neville Brothers) and
George Porter Jr (Bass) will do just fine, if they're feeling "on" and
haven't partied too much. Hell, these guys were on their way up up and 
up until they started partying too much during their first big break
opening up for the rolling stones US tour in '74. ... Now they're back,
older, wiser, and funkier...  These guys pretty much define funk,
especially of the down-south new orleans, stylee so if yer into it,
Niels-bob sez check it out (and play "name the Meters sample used in a
lot of modern funk/dance/rap oriented music").

PPS: I'm unfortunately going to be out of town for both F&F this
weekend and the Meters show I talked about above...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Not to diss the many cool australians out there, but far too many of
the australians that I have met while travelling have come off as
complete racists. To say nothing about the way australia treats/talks
about the aborigines, or the low social status of aborigines in
Australia. (I'm not saying amerikkka treats it's american indians,
eskimo, or black population any better, really...)

W/r/t the message below, perhaps there's not a lot of blacks at raves
because they're economically locked out, or wouldn't be welcome by the
average austrialian? Or perhaps the aborigines are sick of all those
damn digeridoo samples :-) and prefer their own communal/ancestral
dancing rituals to raves??

FYI, the movie "Romper Stomper" (produced by my cousin D.Sharf in
Australia) is an interesting, though grittily **disturbing** and
**realistic** examination of racism in Australia, though the racism is
perpetrated mostly on asians via the nazi skinheads that "star" in this
movie. It is available on video tape in the US, though they actually
edited out some of the Sex & Violence for the US video release (???). I
guess some censor got confused between the concepts of "cinema verite"
and "dangerous ideas" -- then again, perhaps too many morons in the US
would take this movie at face value, as an avocation of the nazi
skinhead lifestyle. THis movie does not glorify violence and racism....
It deglamorizes, and magnifies the stupidity of people caught in that
trap....

I'll just shut up now, because reality doesn't have anything to do with
movies, no matter what that mo-ron Newt Gingrich has to say about it.
(Hey amerikkka -- you all should watch "Soilent Green" to learn about
why de-regulation of food products is a good idea -- think of the profits
man! the prophets!). :-)

Great comments, Niels.  I tend to agree about the Dead, though I still
go quite a lot.  There have been some excellent Dead shows over the
last year; I think Sunday at Vegas (despite the heat) and Sunday at
Eugene were the real standouts for me last year.  But though I still
like the scene and have many friends, the shows and the scene are very
same-y these days, and the outdoor parking lot scene has totally
deteriorated into a messy, ugly, depressing thing as anyone who wandered
around the lot during the Atomic Pig this time could see.  The lift 
I got after leaving the show and walking through the lot and getting
back to our little sound system scene there was palpable.  (On the other
hand, here in Portland we expect that at least for one glorious weekend
at the end of May we can make the old vending/hangout Dead scene work
like it should, of course with the addition of suitable sound system
and DJ enhancements :)

I'm pleased to hear the Meters are playing around again, and bummed
seriously that I'll probably be up on the Russian River for Tribal Future
that weekend.  

Niels talks about sounding like yer grampa, well, maybe I'm *in* that
category.  The second record I ever bought was in 1969 and it was
the 45 single "Cissy Strut" by the Meters which is still totally cool.
It was sampled -- hell, practically copied completely -- by the Stone
Roses for "Fools Gold," and you know how cool that is (although it's
getting so old-fashioned I saw someone dissing one of the Hardkisses
for playing it at a party on the east coast recently!).

As an aside, the *first* record I ever bought, right before the Meters,
was "Time Is Tight" by Booker T and the MGs.  They were the house band
for the Stax label in Memphis and put out a bunch of very popular
instrumentals under that name too.  And here's where it all comes
full circle.  Just about my most recent purchase is a 12" called
"Love Is The Key" by Blind Truth on Platinum Records (a UK label, and
I bought it at Platinum Records, the Portland DJ store :), with remixes
by DJ Camacho and Coke, the ubiquitous Danny Tenaglia and . . . Booker T!

c u in the future
phred

On Wed, 15 Mar 1995, Robert Smith wrote:
> fault.  WHAT DID YOU DO ABOUT IT?  Don't ever put blame on someone else
> when you did nothing yourself.

I wouldn't go off so hard okn the boy now...maybe you are a big guy.  But 
if you are timid or little or non-violent it is not always your first 
thought to jump in and do something...Vlad didn't say that he didn't do 
anything...in his case <i would say that it seemed he thought the 
security were going to be responsible and do something about it.  To 
relate a similar incident about three years ago <i was in Carl's Jr. on 
Market after a concert.  Being about 17 (i think) and in high school you 
are a little less mature and experienced than some people.  We were in 
teh restaurant when this guy starts harassing a bum and gets more and 
mkore aggressive.  In the end he assaulted the man who was the victim 
while my friends and myself watched not wanting to get involved.  It was 
obvious who was the victim, being he was somewhat helpless and very 
timid...but in the end you find yourself thinking what you could have 
done, but will it make things worse or better you'll never know, would 
two or t hree people have gotten beat up instead of one...maybe the 
rapist pulls a gun and shoots you...people do think of these things.  
This message isn't really meant to tell anyone wheteher to act or not too 
but you can't blame someone for also trying to take care f themselves.  
<it's a tough choice <i'd like to see what you would do if the same 
situation came upon you.  Ah the world what a nice place?  

love drenalin\

point.  why the fuck shouldn't i blame security?  don't you think that if 
it's your fuckin job to provide *security* then you should maybe do your 
job instead of just being a jerk??  i sure do.  i think 100% that 
security should be waaaayy more responsible in this type of situation 
than small little raver kid.  sorry that i'm not superman and shit.
later.


HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly                          
vekatz@ucdavis.edu

Hello SFRAVERS!
 
I'm new to E-mail and decided to join this discussion group.  I LOVE
high energy dance music of all sorts.  I'm from Chicago (the Inner
City) and I do lean a little more towards House music.  But Techno,
Trance, and especially Hardcore really does it for me.
 
Right now I'm at St. Norbet College in De Pere, WI.  I'm going crazy up
here.  Looking to leave real soon.  A couple of years ago, I went to
San Fransisco.  I luved it!  Right now I am thinking about finding some
way to san fran.  Next to Chicago, San Fransisco is where I want to be.
 The music lives in these cities.  Maybe in June, we will see.
 
 Hope to here from some cool people real soon!

Subject: more trippy rave images
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I just thought of a show I haven't seen since I was about 6 - it was called
Les Contes de la Rive (stories of the riverbank) and it was all live action
rodents!!!!!  There was a hamster named Hammy, a guinea pig named Grandpere
and a white rat named Moustache and they all lived together in a waterwheel
house.  Grandpere had a plane, Moustache had a diving bell ...  does anyone
else remember this?  Or was it just some weird Canadian thing I grew up
with?

peace

karen

**************************************************

*       Insula locus non ideona adultero.        *
*                                                *
**************************************************

  Xogenix wins my vote for worst timed techno-party of the month -- head to
head with Black Dog on Friday.  Could be real cool, though.  The
lighting/video/decor is going to be intense -- very focused and
techno-fetishistic.  The dj lineup should be:
     Minor (me) 9-11
     Graeme LaPaix 11-12
     Tim 12-2?
     Mars 2-4?
  I'm planning on playing my favorite blend of dark growling trance.  Tim &
Mars have got a bunch of really fast (150-160bpm) psychedelic hard techno.
 Hope there are enough technoheads in town to pack both of these parties.
 Xogenix, like Black Dog, though, is 21+.  The voicemail # is 415-541-5019,
the flyers are worth finding -- circuit boards, vacuum tubes, & capacitors
labeled with the number.  We'll see ...

Actually, I just remembered one of the trippiest movies ever, that had me 
rolling on the floor laughing... 

		The Frog Prince

		with Kermit the Frog

There's this one scene where all these frogs are singing, except they're 
puppets, and they're moving around in this strange fashion, kinda 
in-your-face-I'm-a-frog... well... you have to see it for yourself...

Oh... and what about for trippy TV, I don't know why I didn't think of 
this before...

		The Banana Splits

I mean come on... the original Trip TV Show.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nrg@ultima.org (ethan miller)
Subject: F&F Notes...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings Friends!

I wanted to take this opportunity to share a few, important, last minute
thoughts with you on the upcoming party :)

Please remember that this is an *underground* event; hanging out on in
front, playing car stereos loud, running naked up the street ;) etc. can
really kill stuff like this, so please, please, please consider the
environemnt and your actions carefully... we really need everyone's help in
pulling this off.

Also, we will be using a map point, so even if for some reason you know
where the party is, *please* use the map point :)

We do have a limited capacity of around 750 including crew, so please get
to the map point early, it will open at 9:30 and be shut down when we reach
capacity.

As many of you know it has alway been a primary goal of F&F to be ultra low
cost. The cost of this party is from $5 to whatever you can afford and/or
feel like contributing, however no-one will be turned away (from the map
point) for an honest lack of funds.

On the other hand, F&Fs are *always* benefits, and *everyone* involved --
djs, musicians, artists, staff -- all work for free. In this case we are
benefitting two very worthy causes (info on them will be available on-site)
so if you can contribute more than $5, please do.

So nice that the sun has come out to add a little support to the spring
theme :) Looking very forward to seing you all saturday!

:)

take it easy
ethan

        415.995.4699

        950 Geary @ Polk

>about the aborigines, or the low social status of aborigines in
>Australia. (I'm not saying amerikkka treats it's american indians,
>eskimo, or black population any better, really...)
>

>because they're economically locked out, or wouldn't be welcome by the
>average austrialian? Or perhaps the aborigines are sick of all those
>damn digeridoo samples :-) and prefer their own communal/ancestral
>dancing rituals to raves??
>
>FYI, the movie "Romper Stomper" (produced by my cousin D.Sharf in
>Australia) is an interesting, though grittily **disturbing** and
>**realistic** examination of racism in Australia, though the racism is
>perpetrated mostly on asians via the nazi skinheads that "star" in this
>movie. It is available on video tape in the US, though they actually
>edited out some of the Sex & Violence for the US video release (???). I
>guess some censor got confused between the concepts of "cinema verite"
>and "dangerous ideas" -- then again, perhaps too many morons in the US
>would take this movie at face value, as an avocation of the nazi
>skinhead lifestyle. THis movie does not glorify violence and racism....
>It deglamorizes, and magnifies the stupidity of people caught in that
>trap....
>

>movies, no matter what that mo-ron Newt Gingrich has to say about it.

>why de-regulation of food products is a good idea -- think of the profits
>man! the prophets!). :-)
