Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 12:00 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Happiest people in the world
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The Happiest people in the World
================================

Well,   this is to be my first Mainstream Rave in Sydney,  and thanx to
Steve Bancroft,   I got on the guest list.

On thursday,  I learn the rave was to take place about 45 km south/west
of Sydney,   way out in the suburbs.   I was supposed to meet the bus that
was to leave the Central terminal at 9 pm.

On the bus,   I meet one of the ravers that heard my radio program on
Skid Row radio.  This kid was blown away that he actually met me in person.

There is no doubt,  I am the OLDEST raver in Australia...  according to
most people I met.

The bus pulls into an industrial complex,  with scattered homes nearby,
and I though that it was going to get busted for sure,  because of the
close priximity of homes in the area.

As I leave the bus,  I could barely hear the music inside as the first DJ
was spinning Happy Hardcore.    Remember,  here in australia,  Happy Hardcore
is MAINSTREAM!!   but that not ALL you get.    There were 3 other parties
going on in Sydney this Sat evening.    One thats not more then 100 meters
from my doorstep in "the Cross",  held at "Le Girls" nightclub,   but got
word is was mostly house.

The Fridays Green acres was cancelled,  due to the outside area being flooded
due to recent rains.

Anyway,  back to the "Happiest People".   I saved my E's and A's for this
party,   and wanted to be especially happy to insure the party lives up
to its name.

This was a Kiddie rave,  as named by the AusRavers,   and I can certainly see
why.    Age ranges from 18 - 24,   and few people with the exception of me,
were much older.

I could hear the kiddie girls giggle when I walked by as these people aren't 
used to seeing older people at these gigs.

The venue,  is a warehouse,  with a chill out tent in the front parking lot,
and clothing and shirt sales Kiosk and hot dog booth set up.    Inside,  the
area was all the dance area,  with the speaker system in the back,  although
they could use some additional speakers in the front,   I suspect they were
concerned with noise,  as it got visited by the police several times,  which
resulted in the noise getting turned down several times.

After midnight,  they allowed ins-and-outs,  and people were congregating
outside in great numbers.   I saw a few police cruisers drive by,   but
no serious problems.

Inside,  I was getting off big time,  groovin to the insane 180+ BPM pace
of Happy Hardcore.  Gack!  One song they played in particular was played
3 times that evening.   It was a cool song,   but VERY POPULAR when it
was played.   It even gets a lot of Air play on the radio.

I went to this rave alone,   but was almost immediatly approached by people
saying "You were at Restitution,  weren't you?"  I said Yup!  "Better get
used to seeing me here for a while!"  he gave a thumbs up and said,  "It's
really great to see older people here".   At first,  people were somewhat
suspicious of me,   but once they saw me out on the dance floor,  groovin
and hoppin around like a mad Kangarooo,   they really dug it.

Eventually,  they got the lazers fired up,   and WOW!  What visuals.   Almost
all large mainstream raves have really great Lazer effects that really make
the visuals really insane.

All throughout the evening,  the music stayed ABOVE 170 BPM range,  and as
the pace quickened,   it got as high as 250 BPMs and at that stage its all
arms and little leg work....   As a new DJ went on,   it would start at about
170 BPM,  and gradually would increase during the DJ's set.

All DJ's did a wonderful job of seamlessly mixing the Hardcore songs,  but
there must not be that many Happy Hardcore songs out there,  as several got
played several times throughout the evening.

I have to say one thing about (HHC - Happy Hard core),   it's Happy,  and 
while on E,   it's really blissful,  trancey and you just can't help but keep
a big fat smile on your face.    Oh Yea!!  people here also use pacifiers  :-)
Tee hee!

As the evening wore on,   I really stepped up my energy,   as I ussually do,
to the amazement of my Aussie friends.   They just dan't get used to seeing
an older person having so much fun.

Later on,  I met this other older person,  perhaps in his upper 30's,  and
he thought that HE was the oldest until he met me.

This rave was to end at 10 am  (WOW!!  14 hours of continious dancing)  -
Now we're talkin a REAL RAVE....  Tee hee!!

At one time,   someone said,   lets go up and dance on stage,   but I was 
having a really trancey time where I was,   Eventually, I grabbed him and
pointed to the stage,  and headed towards it.

People I passed,  literally pulled me up there,   but one of the staff told
me to leave,   as I left,  others were ragging on the staff guy,  saying
"Bring this guy back up there!",   so  headed back and danced the entire
set until there was a break.

At that time the girl was behind the turntables,  playing some insane hard
acid trance with little or no breaks in the beat.    I literally WENT OFF!
and everyone hopped up on the dance floor.  I've never seen so many smiles
from so many people in one place.

I would estimate about 1500+ people attended,  if you include about 100 or
so hanging around outside.

At about 10 minutes before the party ended,   I started walking along the
side,  pulling people up to the dance floor....  "C'm on you slackers,   get
up and dance  - this is the last song!"   Most people were too tired to get 
up and stand,  let alonne dancing.    I even pulled up this one dude that
ribbed me when I went to chill,  earlier he said "Chilling already?"   I said
Yup!   Gotta cool down...   The heat and humidity rivaled Friends and Family,
but climate here is awfully hot and humid to my standards anyway.

Then,  towards the end,  I saw him sitting down,  so I grabbed him and said
"Lets go... slacker!  time to get up and dance yo ass off!"  He shook his
head in bewilderment,  as I had been up there solid for more than an hour,
but couldn't possibly even think of not dancing to this insane acid trance.

He finally got up,   and several more complied,  and I think I got about
15 - 20 more people up and dancing towards the end.    Everyone really
dug it...   Towards the end,  thie youg girl came up to me and said
"Aren't you tired?"   I said "I don't know the meaning of 'tired'".

At one point,  about an hour before the rave was to end,   someone was
sufferig from an overdose,  and mentioned that he had mixed speed with acid.

Unfortunately,  speed is used here,  all too often,  probably because of the
high cost of A and E.

When the rave finally did end,  the music stopped and everyone cheered the
DJ,.  and the promoter came up and announced the names of the DJ's.

Finally,  one more song was played,  and yup!  You guessed it,   it was that
HHC (Happy Hard core) song tha was played earlier.

As people were filing out,   many were coming up to me,  asking where I was
from.....  I told them that I was from SF,  and many asked how long
I've been raving....   I said...   I'm from Old School!!  WOW!  I haven't
seen or experienced such great respect and appreciation for me being there
grooving with these fine people.    

More next time...

Crunchman

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 19 19:18:57 1995

Subject: NON-RAVE/LOOKING FOR SUPPORT :)
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9503191846.A27484-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Dear Sfraves;

	Hello, I'm going to be going in for some very serious elective 
maxillofacial surgery in about a month. The surgery will take place at 
Doctors hospital in Pinole, were I will be for several days recovering. 
The procedure I'm having done is a maxillary os-de-otto-me & a 
mandible sagital spit. In lay terms, their going to cut and move up 
and back my upper(superior) jaw(maxilla), and cut and move forward my 
lower(inferior) jaw(mandible). I will also be in braces by the middle of 
next month. This will correct a long time severe over bite and a source 
of both physical and emotional pain.

	The bone structure and of course the way I appear to people will
change from the nose down. So I will look like a different person, and
hopefully for the better. I'm very scared, but its the only way to correct
it. My rotten family is "too busy" to come out here and spend time with me
and help me though this. This hurts & angers me greatly, but I will not
let their lack of love stop me, from what I need to do for myself. 

	The risks of the surgery are some degree of sensation lost to my
face. There's a nerve called the mandibular nerve which is responsible for
sensation in your face, especially around the mouth. It runs down the
lower jaw and enters into your chin through a little hole called a
foramen. This nerve needs to be stretched a little bit, and hopefully
won't break or tear. 

	The biggest concern is how I'm going to look afterward, will I 
like what I see ..etc. My jaw/face as a child was a source of tremendous 
emotional pain, being called names like beaver ..etc. Also, if something 
were to happen to me while I was on the table, there are still things in 
this life I haven't tried yet or done.

	But on the positive side I could end up looking better, I will be 
able to eat food properly, and stop doing damage to my esophagus & 
stomach. Of course I will also end up having a great smile.

	So once again I ask for your support when its time for me to have 
my surgery, My doctor wants me to have a partner to help me though it. I 
would be willing to pay this person for some of their time. I image I 
would need someone to work closely with me for a week or so, and you would 
have access to my car. The person shouldn't be very screemish as far as 
being around someone in a lot of pain, or being around a man crying or 
expressing strong emotion, or alergic to pussy cats, meow. My jaw will be 
wired shut for about 2 weeks and I'm told possibly longer.

	So anyone interested in supporting me through this please contact 
me at my email address listed below or call me at 510-254-0933. I'm 
moving to Berkeley this week so me number going to be changin, the old 
number will having a forwarding message on it. Support can also be a 
card, e-mail or a visit in the hospital, any and all are always 
appreiated, very deeply heart felt, and never forgotten :)

	   Peace, Love & Thanks From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

			"The message is love"

Lagging and lollygagging as usual I got to the map point way too late and 
just found a bunch of people wandering around thinking the same thing and 
wondering what to do now.  Oh there is a little note - another party at 
the Begin Again location! Now what was the address??  thinking thinking 
what did I read about so many good reviews... bryant something... almost 
the troc but not quite  is all I remembered.  After a brief wander I 
heard the music!  No I didn't see the light, I heard the music!
"Is this the party?"
"Yeah it's upstairs and a left and a left"
"Whoa!" (joey lawrence style)
Nice office space!  (whoa!)
computers everyehwere! (whoa!)
huge comfy ambient area (whoa!)
free! (whoa!)

techno?  trance?  what was it? I don't know.  It wasn't F&F  but this 
was a very interesting party.  vibe?  this may have been one of those 
examples of DJ controlling the atmosphere - people are dancing to some 
solid grooves at a steady pace, nothing spectacular ,but enough bass to 
fill your soul.  Dj handoff - the big screeching halt... silence... intro 
to some voices muttering something backed by muzak. was this somoe kind 
of joke?  I dunno.  "bye bye crowd!  bye bye thanks for dancing, scurry 
along now!" and that they did.  People wanted to love the moment, I could 
tell there were just enough smileys but the music was robbing our 
momentum. 

otherwise it was a pleasant party.
A suitable shinding.

Walrus
o.O
( )
 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 20 02:03:38 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id CAA26911; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 02:03:38 -0800

From: soundgod@iccse.com
Received: from iccse.com (uucp@localhost) by bsd.iccse.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with UUCP id CAA08085 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 02:05:56 -0800

	id D2627OD Mon, Mar 20, 1995 02:00:20 EST
Message-Id: <9503200200.D2627OD@iccse.com>
X-Mailer: UUPlus Mail 1.51
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: F & F Experience (PLEASE READ)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 02:00:20 EST
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear SF-Ravers,

     I'd like to start by saying thank you to Ethan. You have my support. Not
many people would be willing to take the risk you did.

     To others out there, most of them not on the net, I would like to
apolagize for some actions(and lack of) at F&F.(personal apologies will
follow). I'm guilty of making my personal feelings more important than
others.

Now for the important part.

     Although I personally went to F&F with at least 6 friends from Sac, I
drove alone with the intention of crashing at MILTON's. I was totally looking
foward to the whole night. When I pulled up to the map point, things started
out great. My friends Chris, Lalomi, and Blanka were right behind me. Wendy
and Rohnda were already in line and the I bump into some friends from the
city. I was already an hour behind the schedule I wanted to be but no probs.

When I arrived the party was bumpin in a big way. Although the ambient room
was a little to be desired the layout seemed to be nice and cosey. I decided
to go sober(lotsa reasons) and glad I did. I couldn't stop dancing. I kept
going up and down between the two floors, trying to decide wich one I like
beter.

At about 2:15 in the morning when I started to release all my energy on
dancing(That guy upstairs was tearing it up soooooo good), the system turns
off.

This is the start of my worst time ever. I go outside and find everyone.
Wendy's friend Rhonda turned up missing. We found her by the dumpster. She
was afraid of being arrested. Wendy took Rhonda home so that left me with 3
friends. still good in my book. We tried that party on howard. Some guy tried
to sell me crack in front, and they were charging $5. Since we had no money
for either(just kiddin) the only other thing was dream. Since 2 of the three
friends were frying(and were under 21) they went back home.

It was already 3:20 but I knew my friends Peter and Jen would be at dream for
sure and milton wouldn't be home before 6 or so. I went to Dream and found
out it was $10. The bouncer wouldn't let me get my friend to borrow five more
bucks to get in, so I went atm searching. I spent almost an hour trying to
find an atm machine that worked. I went as far as fell before turning back.
I decided to go back to dream to leave a message with my friends. I tried the
door one more time. The guy beleived me and used my ID as coll. against the
other 5 bucks. After taking care of that I relized I should have gone home at
3. The vibe had a score of 0. only about 30 or so people. 2 really drunk
girls hit on me(I was def. in no mood for people drinking).

Because I was sober I really needed to talk to someone(I like to talk alot
when i'm sober(ask anyone)). But none of these people would suffice. I called
Milton at 4:45 and he wasn't home. I left dream at 5:30 and decided to go to
golden gate park and rest for a few before driving to his house.

Here is where it gets really bad. I parked and leaned my chair back. I must
have fallen asleep right away because a half an hour later a cop was knockin'
on my window. He asked me step out of the car. He ask if I was sober but he
didn't believe me because my eyes were droopy. He put me in the back of his
car(were it was freezing) and began searching my car. He found two NOVA's in
my ashtray(NOVA is like herbal x)and he then arrested me for possion of an
illegal substance and for under the influence(both bull)we stayed there
and waited for another cop. I protested both counts to the second cop and
told him that it was a bullsh*t search. After about an hour and fifteen
minutes of waiting a third officer let me go because he also felt the search
was illegal. I was sooooo tired and needed to sleep. But the cops told me to
go back to Sac. right away. I didn't argue.

I almost fell asleep on the road. I forgot all about milton and went driving
home. I went real slow and stopped at denny's for food and coffee. It's funny
how you realize you ignored someone only when you feel incredibly lonley
yourself. I didn't get home till 10:30 or so. I slept until 8. I blame the
bad night only on myself.

Thanx for reading this message. I know a lot of you skipped it. If just one
person reads it. I'll know because I'll feel it.
Thanx again ethan.

Time to smile again.

OOOO                        O      Man is a wonderful machine,
O                           O        the only machine capable
OOOOO  OOOO  O  O  OOOO  OOOO        of controlling it's own destiny.
    O  O  O  O  O  O  O  O  O                      -Unknown-
OOOOO  OOOO  OOOO  O  O  OOOO
       OOOOOOO            O        The most complicated things
       O                  O            in life can't be calculated.
       O   OOOO  OOOO  OOOO        The most simple things in life
       O      O  O  O  O  O            are still taken for granted.
       OOOOOOOO  OOOO  OOOO                        -Unknown-

SOUNDGOD@iccse.com

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> good drugs that you would have had a good time in a concentration camp!

many tickets were sold for the venue size, the vibe in the place was out 
of this world. You can't even get into a movie for $5 bucks these days.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 20 10:47:33 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id KAA25071; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 10:47:33 -0800

	id AA04679; Mon, 20 Mar 95 10:47:24 PST
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 10:47:24 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9503201847.AA04679@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: wknd rpt - GG,FF,C7
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

To celebrate the theft of my motorcycle last thursday I decided to skip
Organic's Saturday GG Park party and work on my taxes instead.  After
a few hours of trying to comprehend my net economic worth to society,
I suddenly noticed that the sun had come out.  Screw it; off to
the park.  

This was the first band shell party to be set up in the renovated
band shell, and it was fun dancing up on the stage.  I didn't find the
raised DJ setup to be a problem, i.e the separation between us and our
shamans seemed minimal.  Jeno was typically engaging and Graeme followed 
with a good set as well.  Another beautiful day in the park.  I hear that 
we can look forward to celebrations there every other week once the summer
starts.

* * *

Janie & I arrived at F&F early and were impressed by the setup.  Tasty 
visuals everywhere, water, candy, murals, literature, eucalyptus trees, 
blinking lights... Was this a labor of love, or what?  I really liked 
the various philisophical slogans that were put up "Underneath 
everything we are all connected (paraphrased)" and the like.  Basic 
fundamental stuff that helps remind us why raves are more than just 
excercises in hedonism.  The 2 main sound systems - SoundVision 
dowstairs and  Pacific's up - have never sounded better to me, like 
they were tuned perfectly for this space.  The ventilation was also 
quite good - as crowed as it got, it never seemed too hot.  

Like all F&Fs, the party got going early, reaching critical mass before
11.  Bryce started things out downstairs with some intense hard trance.
And who was the first DJ upstairs?  A little funkier, and quite 
excellent.  By 12, the party was packed.  This cramped our ability to 
dance freely but the incredible vibe compensated for that.  Everyone 
seemed totally into the music, shouting, clapping, raised hands.  And 
people pretty much stayed put, not a lot of the constant shoving and
unfocused moving about that often destroys the sense unity at many large
crowded commercial parties I've attended.  

Yes, the venue was oversold; the only real flaw in the equation.  With
a crowd stuck ouside (and very visible from the street) I had 
premonitions of a bust.  But by around 2, things had started to thin out
just enough to allow easy in&outs.  I had no trouble finding room to 
dance downstairs by the DJ where Ethan was going off like a madman.  I
really felt like this event was a historic moment for the underground
scene.

Then a small army of policepeople joined us and just didn't seem to be
able to get into the spirit of things.  They seemed cordial enough
once it became clear that we weren't going to be any trouble for them.  
The firemarshalls sure didn't look  happy.  Maybe having this party across 
the street from the firehouse had something to do with that.  Have to admit
though, this *was* a firetrap - but there's little that can be done about 
that.  People of all ages are *desperate* for the chance to come together 
and share their love of music & life with each other.  Until our society 
provides safe and caring environments for that to happen in, we will do 
what we can to fill the need.  We're not just talking about the need for 
some cheap fun.  Raving is quite spiritual for many of us; a (dis)organized
religion to some.

I stuck around with a few others to help clean up, break things down, 
load, etc.  Ethan was calm and cool about everthing.   In my book he's 
a fucking hero.  Bryce chatted with the police, explaining to them
our side of things, building bridges...  There is some hope that Ethan
won't get slammed too hard, thanks to our cooperation and the lack of
any violence, destruction, or major hassles.  All we can do is wait
and see.  

It was 4ish and I still had some energy in me, so I went over to the 
Cyberlab7 party.  It was laid back and uncrowded,  a great place to 
dance off excess energy and wind down.  I really enjoyed the DJs in the 
main room and danced quite a bit. There were a few F&F refugees who 
were also fortunate enough to have gotten the word on this.  

Upon reflection, I also thought about the FMR i missed this week.  The 
demand for good equal-oppurtunity vibeful parties far outstrips the 
supply in this town.  If your try to accomadate everybody, things get out 
of hand.  If you try to go further underground, people get left out.  It's
hard to always guess at the best workable balance.  For those who got 
bummed out by the unfortunate turn of events - there was at least 
something to be learned:  Shit happens and a backup plan is your friend. 

Anyway, thanks to the entire F&F crew for a great 4 hours.  Ethan - you 
know you've got friends who are prepared to help.  If the $ situation is 
really bad, perhaps a killer benefit party might be in order. :)

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (   ( ((truth-love-energy))  )   )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Kevin writes:
Clearly you either went to different rave thren me...the most badly
organized party organized in SF...To many people, to smal a venue;
pathetic!
This is sad because a lot of people come from far and wide for this 
event because it is all agaes.  Hopefully next time they'll know not to

this even if it is for a good cause.

REMEMBER: WANTING TO HAVE A GOOD TIME AND ACTUALLY HAVING A GOOD TIME ARE 
TWO COMPLETELY DIFFERENT THING'S.

Dear Kevin:

Well, my friend, it is apparent from your post that you did not have a good
time at Friends & Family.  Gee, that's too bad.  You see, if you have a bad
time at a rave that people truly put their hearts into -- in organizing,
producing, and spreading a good vibe (I mean, come on, boxes of Blow-pops,
free fruit, water!!) and taking the wrap when it gets busted -- then I fear
that you may never enjoy a rave again.  I agree it was hot, it was crowded
and it was not close in proximity to everyone who came, but tell me Kevin,
how many raves have you been to (good raves that is) that have not been
hot, crowded and right next door to everyone who went?  And you cap on the
five dollar cover?!  I won't even acknowledge that...

In short, I know the people who worked on this event.  They did it out of
the goodness of their hearts, for three months, for *YOU*.  I will not
tolerate you bashing them unjustly.  You speak for yourself, Kevin, not the
whole.  Sounds like you were an island in an ocean of good vibes.  You are
right, there is a diffence between wanting to have a good time and actually
having one, and there's also a diffence between having something
constructive to say about an event and being a complete and obtuse asshole!

Now as for my take on F&F:

Thank you, thank you, thank you...Ethan a group of us spoke later and
agreed that we will fight this with you to the end.  It goes beyond this
one bust.  It bites at the core of our existance as an alternative social
scene, our cohesive group, our family.  

It was clearly evident that the organizers were in this wholeheartedly. 
Yes there were limitations to the space, but every means available was made
to work around them.  The chill-room especially had a nice, warm glow to
it. Which is why I wanted every one to "appreciate this!"  Great visuals by
Michael Clay, great set by Lee An...

Unfortunately it was busted.  Your higher spiritual power only knows what
would have happened if it had gone on all night.  :^}

Having warmed up the Blue Cube prior to the event, Greg was only too kind
to let me run around and tell people to go there to work off their
respective buzzes.  And it turned out great, for a spontaneaous event. 
Thanks to everyone who showed up.  We were proud to provide the
opportunity.  And "thanks!" to Greg (and his sleeping roommate) who let us
invade his place. We didn't have a DJ spin, but Kenneth Paul stepped up to
the tape deck and soaked us all in some really great ambient stuff while
the masses lounged around and enjoyed the memories of "the good ole' hours"
at F&F.  I must publicaly thank Ofra for the massage of my life!  I'm sure
others had equally stimulating experiences...  ;^} ;^}

All in all, we had over 100 people spend some quality time in the Cube,
which, for those history buffs, was the site of Friends & Family #2.  We
felt it only fitting that the evening should end up there.

Thanks again, everyone, for making it a night to remember...Oh, and Kevin,
please share the site of the next event that *YOU* organize, because I will
certainly be the first in line for a non-crowded, air conditioned, close to
everyone's home, all ages, less than five dollar for a good cause, free
fruit/water/candy, cool set-up, great sound, great line-up, great
chill-room rave any day of the week!


Tony

P.S. Hey Amy the English major, ("word of the day is hyperbole") send me a line.

P.S. Ob: history 

Geoff said: You must realize also that history is the story of 
            the "ones who win."

from Salman Rushdie's Shame:

"The ancient Greeks," he said out of the blue, making her spill the ash 
of her cigarette-tip, "kept, in the Olympic games, no records of 
runners-up." 

Then he dresses quickly, but with the meticulous dandyism that she 
had always loved, and left her for good; that sentence was the 
only explanation she ever got. 

But in the years of her isolation she worked it out, she knew that 
history had been waiting for him to notice her, and a man who 
catches history's eye is thereafter bound to a mistress from whom he 
will never escape. History is natural selection. Mutant versions of 
the past struggle for dominance; new species of fact arise, and old, 
saurian truths go to the wall, blindfolded and smoking last cigarettes. 
Only the mutations of the strong survive. The weak, the anonymous, the 
defeated leave few marks: field-patterns, axe-heads, folk-tales, broken 
pitchers, burial mounds, the fading memory of their youthful beauty. 
History loves only those who dominate her: it is a realtionship of 
mutual enslavement."

He says it better than I could.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 20 13:36:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA08888; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 13:36:00 -0800
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA08879; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 13:35:53 -0800
Received: from ultima.org by ultima.org; Mon, 20 Mar 95 13:20 PST
Message-Id: <v0211013eab9368c14e53@[140.174.184.129]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Length: 6436
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 13:09:17 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nrg@ultima.org (ethan miller)
Subject: Friends & Family
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings Friends!

Well, I'm not sure quite where to start...

I guess first off my sincerest and most heartfelt apologies to any of you
that had a negative or less than positive experience saturday night.

Perhaps a review of what happened (as best we can ascertain) followed by
some interpretation and conclusions may help to clarify the nights events
and at least my position on them...

The short version is: A number of things some within our control and some
beyond our control resulted in crowds of people that *way* exceeded our
expectations and, unfortunately, our ability to manage them effectively.

*We* did not, however, oversell our stated capacity. 740 tickets were
produced, 20 were sold in advance, 50 were held at the door to handle
people that skipped the map point and 670 were sold at the map point. The
crew present totalled approximately 30 people. Thus, but for the events I
will discuss in a moment we should have had 770 people which we as a group
had decided would fit in that space albeit tightly.

However, as noted above, hundreds and hundreds more -- anywhere form
250 - 500 found out where it was and showed up with a variety of stories
both true and false that our overwhelmed door people then had to attempt to
decipher.

This was the result of a few things the details of which we're still trying
to sort out. We do know one thing though: I personally, in a fit of total
madness forgot a stack of prolly 100 maps (but *not* tickets!) at the map
point which was shut down and locked at that point. That door should have
never opened again but it did. There was a band recording inside that got
sick of people continually banging on the door and opened it. What happened
next is still a bit vague however one thing is certain: that stack of maps
went out the door somewhere around midnight. At around 12:30 one of our
staff showed up at the map point and someone very definitely not part of
our group was giving out those maps and may have been selling them. Our
staff person took that stack from them at that point. So it apears that
there was about a half hour window in which those maps were either given
away or sold. By our estimate about 30 people showed up at the site
claiming that they had been sold a map.

In addition to this there were reports of people at kinkos counterfeiting
maps, tickets and/or fliers. As you might also imagine loads of people were
observed trying to transfer stamps from one hand to another. Very sweaty
conditions inside were making valid stamps extremely difficult to verify,
let alone fakes.

So, between roughly 12 and 2, there were was a huge crowd of people outside
the door unable to get in. Some of these were people that had been inside
and decided to go out; some of these were people hoping to buy a ticket at
the door, some may have been sold fake "tickets" and some were clearly
bullshit artists with a variety of stories. I personally saw *no one* that
had a real ticket and was unable to get in.

At about 2:40, most everyone was inside. Unfortunatley the real (and mostly
white ;) gangstas, responding to a tripped burgalry alarm next door, then
arrived not at all expecting what they found. The party was then shut down.
Had that alarrm not been tripped, I (and many others) feel we would have
made it.

But it was, and one of our doormen at the time, Jeff, was put in a choke
hold, handcuffed and arrested. He has been charged with "Obstructing an
Officer", and "Assault and Battery on a Police Officer". I was issued five
misdemeanor citations:

 o No Dancehall Keeper Permit
 o No Place of Entertainment Permit
 o No Cabaret Permit
 o Exceeding The Stated Capacity of the Building
 o Blocked Fire Exit

So, those are the facts as best we can determine so far. I'd like to start
by responding to Tristan's (the kevin keiper account) post cos I think it
frames the main issues fairly well. (Tristan I suggest you start signing
your posts, lest people mistake your sentiments for kevin's).

Yes, we made mistakes but I think you're still missing the point. F&F has
always been an *attempt* to make raves (or whatever) something other than
products to be payed for and consumed. F&Fs have always been ultra low
cost; they have always been benefits at which everyone always works for
free, and *no one* has ever been turned away cos they didn't have the
money. We are trying to *facilitate* NOT FOR PROFIT *community*
celebrations.

Yes, the space was too small for the 1000+ people that showed up. Yes we
were unprepared to deal with 1000+ people. Yes, it was fucking hard do get
in during peak hours. And yes, I understand your frustration and your
anger, and yes, I am sorry.

BUT, YOU had the opportunity to *not* view the whole situation as a bad
product that you were having a hard time consuming. YOU had the opportunity
to see that we were having a hard time. And so my friend, YOU also had the
opportunity to *help us*, had you cared to. Lord knows we could have used
it.

Time and time again life presents us with situations where what is *is*
never mind whose fault it is, and pointing fingers at that point simply
does no good. With a little help and a little patience we could have pulled
this one out.

Nevertheless it brings me great joy that lots of you and others did have a
very good time. So, many, many thanks to all of you for your love, support
and energy.

As I'm sure many of you are curious, here's what happened fiscally: luckily
all of our expenses were covered and, depending on the final disposition of
our security deposit there will be somewhere between $1500 and $1900 left.
This will hopefully cover any fines that Jeff and I are liable for in
addition to benefititing the two groups we intended to benefit.

So once again thank you for your support fiscally and otherwise. I hope you
felt your contribution was well placed. If not, then my apologies once
again. There will be more parties, should you object to or be unable to
afford the donation at any of them, we will (as always) happily let you in
free.

I'll keep the list up to date on our legal proceedings. When and if we need
it, Jeff and I would certainly appreciate your support should you feel so
inclined.

And last but not least, many, many thanks to everyone that helped try and
pull this one off. There are truly too many to list. You all know who you
are. If we're not gonna try it who is? Right Fucking On. Nice job everyone.

lost of love
ethan

I was at last Saturday.  The one I was at was WAY to small for the venue 
in comparrrison to the number of tickets they sold.  The dj line-up, 
while immpressive, was blighted by the fact that, while it lasted, they 
had all decided to play the worst set of their lives.

underground in recent years.  This was a shame because a lot of people 
had travvelled a fair distance and had been looking forward to the party 
for a long time.  Let me give them a word of advice: NEXT TIME DON'T BOTHER!
And that goes to all the organizer's (sorry Ethen) and the people who 
went their.

NOT THE SAME THING!

held Saturday day.  Now that's what a party should hbe like.

Date: 3/20/95 7:26 AM
To: Nathan Moser
From: Kevin Keiper
Clearly you either went to different rave thren me or you were on so many 
good drugs that you would have had a good time in a concentration camp!
F&F was, with out a doubt, the most badly organized party organized in SF 
in recent months...
------------------
As far as the  the overcrowding, my (our) sincerest apologies. It was 
rumored early on that someone had taken the B&W ticket 
to Kinko's and run off 300 counterfeit copies - a pretty significant 
number when you consider only 750 were originally printed. This was 
confirmed when the tickets taken at the door were counted. Now that we 
know that there's people out there sad enough to counterfeit $5 tickets to 
a benefit party, we can take preventative steps in the future. Again, sorry 
if you were held at the door or if the population inside was 
uncomfortable. It was not our intention.

Other than the crowding, however, everyone else (including myself!) 
seems to agree that this party >went off<! Fucking amazing sets by so 
many of the DJs! People showed up with a vibe that brought it all 
together, "let go, and took the next step," and reminded you why people 
throw these parties in the first place. 

Also... Kevin, your comment about "good drugs" shows a real lack of 
understanding of what this scene is about. Deaks and many others carried 
the vibe to its full effect with good old water and positive attitude. And 
(even though this may be as cheap a shot as your original comment) if you 
think drugs make a bad party good, then you've probably never tried any.

Ironic side note... while the SFPD was committing the resources of eight 
officers and a van to breaking up our party, someone a couple blocks 
away was busting the window of my car to get the stereo.

-nate, member of the F&F luv patrol

Friends and Family was awesome before its untimely shutdown. For 
atmosphere it surpassed any rave I've been to over here and in England as 
well. We introduced a couple of our friends to a rave and we couldn't 
have picked a better one to start them off at, they had the night of 
their lives they said. Deaks played a great set which got the place going 
really nicely, and then Tim Mcknew took it up a gear and played a 
fantastic set which luckily the cops didn't interrupt until the very last 
tune. Mcknew set the upstairs on fire and I think that the cops may have 
arrived because his set was Too Good. Anyway it was a tragedy that it got 
busted but while it lasted it was amazing despite the fact there may have 
been a couple too many people in there. Well done to all those who put so 
much effort into it and I cant wait until next time, and I hope it comes 
around before the middle of June because I shall be returning to the U.K. 
and I would love to get one more Friends and Family in before I go.
             Cheers
             Dan Wilson
p.s. Friends and Family tour of England to come in the future? No busts 
guaranteed.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 20 17:06:07 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA25800; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 17:06:07 -0800
Received: from mail02.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA25793; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 17:06:04 -0800
From: RobertJ308@aol.com
Received: by mail02.mail.aol.com
	(1.37.109.11/16.2) id AA259667934; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 20:05:34 -0500
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 20:05:34 -0500
Message-Id: <950320200324_55605448@aol.com>
To: Sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: RobertJ308@aol.com
Subject: F&F: Flight of the Bumble Bee or Oops!!!!.........
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


.......................back to the drawing board............


(Scene)......

Imagine, if you will, a little hive (Kommotion), and little a half-mad,
swarming party of bees can't get a ticket sweest, ambrosia, or rave-honey (to
which they are addicted) is being served for $5.OO.

In their increasing agitiation, they swarm about the location, getting
increasing louder and angrier..."buzz,buzz...Where's the party?....buzz,
buzz,"Got an extra ticket?".....buzz, buzz,..."Who can get me
in?"....buzz,buzz,.."I'll make some clone-tickets," thinks one enterprizing
party-bee......

Meanwhile........back at the Big Hive......a large swarm of honey-hungry
raver-bees are seething and jostling about the entrance to the hive, whose
walls are already thud-shuderring, humming, and pulsing with rave
energy!!!!!!

!Buzz, Buzz, "Let me in" they cry, wail, and cajole at the door
bees....zzzzz......zzzzzz....zzzzz.......zzzzz....

Inside, the raver-bees who made it, seem to be willing to put up with any
slight, minor, trivial, or unimportant aspect of a party; room to dance,
places to chill, places to piss, ventilation, security or escape in case of a
fire.......

The buzzing desire for rave, or transcendence via drugs and dance suppresses
any notion or safety for themselves and others......

* A powerful scene.....Yes.......One in which this party-bee was also
campletely taken up in......no excuses.........But, give consideration,
thoughtfulness, and  wisdom it's due......*

...... "What came first?  The fire laws or the fires?......

Without sounding heavyhanded, there are thousands of dead garment
workers, and operators of sweatshops or thought "I won't happen here,

it won't happen this time..." who would answer from the grave.

.....back inside the throbbing beehive....an underage raver passes out in an
aisle way from too much alcohol. (It could have been any drug, he could have
been dead...) Other rave-hungry bees are beginning to step over, and on him
to get into the next room. 

His friends drag him on top of them because there is no room...could they
have gotten him out of the building in a hurry if necessary?

But, the music.....yes, the music.....so powerful, enthralling, sweeping
everyone up into a pandemonium, and (I'll say it)  an ecstacy of emotion
through dance.......Yes, that music could have brought the house down....and
that's what scared me.

......(IMHO) there has been too much criticism, and not enough wisdom,
knowledge, and self-reflection....recently. I'm for a

"Friends, Family and Not Flames...." campaign........

 Is the sheer greatness, or magnetism of the music enough to justify so great
a risk?

 Here @ Sfraves, we have often installed themselves selves as the great
experts or "arbitors of taste," when it comes to raves. We have shredded,
dismantled, dismembered, and second-guessed, other parties or promoters;
i.e., Cool World, for failing to provide adequate security, a safe
envirnoment, etc......

..For the ocean of criticism we have dumped on others, I think that a drop of
self-criticism is due here.....

"One is never so generous with criticism when it comes to one's self......"

I do regret what that party might have been. It will probably enter the
annals of legendary parties for the brief 4 hours anyway....which says even
more about how great it was......

Moral of the Flight of the Bumble Bee: The Pleasure Principle meets the
Reality Principle--The SF Law and Police

 (In hindsight only)...I think we should have had the balls to shut the party
down ourselves!!!!!!!

That certainly would have been Sf rave historic if we had closed it down...
Backed everyone out...Cause we promised on the tape we would close the party
at 650 people, and we didn't do that..........But's it's what we promised on
the phone tape message....

In future, I think we should have the REAL  friends and family buy the
tickets in ADVANCE, take pre-cautions with the tickets, Count people at the
door, and keep our integrity......

The fact that the party is a regenegade seems to me a flimsy excuse to risk
lives and damage our reputation.......

As a disclaimer, this is not a finger-pointing for what people did, it is
only a reminder of what the "sins of omission" could result in. The party was
legendary in my mind, and in my experience of it. We should condider
ourselves lucky. The people at the recording studio would have been right to
call the cops and bust the party. We were interfering with their legal right
to make music......(But, I think if they had heard ours, they would have
joined the party too!!!!!)

If we don't put in correction  for the next party, (I forget who said it to
me)..

we should change the name to "Friends & Family and Everybody Else and His
Brother."

 .      ....Forever in Flames...

                                          I am, ...as always,....... your
humble 
                                           servant,

                                           robertj...........monterey

Sorry that Mark and I weren't there for the party.  We've heard some 
interesting tales though.

Being that I was scheduled to dj at 4:15 am, We were at home trying to get 
some sleep, which we did.  I set my alarm for 11pm but it failed to go off 
resulting in my not waking up till around 2:30 am.

We hopped a cab and arrived at the party around 3 am.
The party had been shut down (bummer, I had a special set planned for this 
one).  I hope that there will be a future F&F and the possibility of getting to 
play.  After this Mark and I got another cab and went to grab a bite.  It was
so beautiful out that we decided to walk home from the castro.

I hope that everyone had a good time regardless.

For those of you that would like to hear Galen and I, We will be playing at
Brothers and Sisters @ 1015 Folsom on Friday the 24th.  For anyone who is 
interested, Mark and I will have Free Passes for anyone that wants to come 
down and catch a groove with us.  The Passes should be available by 
Wednesday.

Subject: Re: Have YOU heard this dj ?
To: ymir-e@centrum.is, sfraves@hyperreal.com

>Hi
>I need comments on dj Doc Martin from L.A.

>Has anyone on this list heard him spin ?

>How is he and what kind of music does he play ?

>Thanks in advance

>E-mix

I first heard Doc Martin spin in 1989 when I lived in OC and he was playing 
New Beat at LA wharehouse parties.  LA ravers have elevated him to diety 
status.  I heard him in SF a few years ago at "Mr Rogers Neighborhood" and he 
played the classic "Wicked" style trancy house that we all know and love.  It 
was a good set but not the mind boggling noise that one would expect 
considering his reputation. I heard him spin again at Sound Factory when he 
opened for Sasha. Sasha was late and Doc spun for a good 5 hours (thats 
endurance), but again nothing truly special.

I think that he is suffering from severe DJ burnout.  There is no Art to his 
sets, its like he just goes through the motions.  Great music but no vibe.  He 
has a mix CD out that he did for Urb magazine.  I haven't heard it, it might 
be pretty good.  The playlist has alot of good classic stuff on it like 
"Spirit" by phuture (good stuff!).  I've seen the CD at housewares, they would 
probably play it for you if you ask.  

Better that you be the judge, after all, one man's e is another man's etc, 
etc.


See Ya.
Bliss


        "Mmmmmmmmmmmm biddle biddle biddle biddle..."   :)

                              say it, it's fun!!!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 20 21:53:50 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id VAA14544; Mon, 20 Mar 1995 21:53:50 -0800

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199503210553.VAA08670@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: f&f, again
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


well, too bad f&f did not last all night.  *sigh*  a lot of planning
and heart went into it, but due to overcrowding unfortunately things
did not go as planned.

in my mind, it will always be what someone (philip, maybe?) dubbed it
the night of:  the Japanese bullet train party.  i have never in my
life seen so many people jammed so tight into a place before.  it was
absolutely terrifying at first, but then i started to kind of like it.
i guess you all remember the orginal complaints about the kommotion
parties?  that they were too crowded!  do you remember the anonymous
complaint to the fire marshall about this particular thing?  whew!

a very weird dynamic was operating that night:  even though people were
crammed in like sardines, it seemed like nobody wanted to leave.  people
kept advising eachother:  better not go out or you won't get back in!
also, once i got used to the press and the heat, i started kind of liking
the vibe of being part of the bullet train, rocketing at the speed of
light to goddess-knows-where.

the music i heard that night was infused with insane energy..the dj's
were responding to the crowding, i bet.  and the ambient room was outa-
sight.  thank you new moon!  (i didn't help set up so i am not being
a narcissist here)

all that said, i thank our lucky stars that the worst that happened was
that the party got shut down.  like i said, i was terrified that any
second somebody was going to start freaking out.  but the vibe held,
thank you thank you thank you.

here's my suggestions for the future..i hope they help:

(1) raise the price, but let people who want to help set up, break
down, get in for free.  $5 (was that the price?) is too little.

(2) don't encourage people to get there early anymore.  

(3) make sure you have experienced door people working the door...
(or at least folks with thick skins who can keep smiling no matter what)

(4) sell half as many tickets as you think the space will hold and
get ready to take people's money at the door.  because the night of, the
location WILL get out!

well, i know many of you of course disagree with my suggestions, (i'm
betting the price one will rankle) but they are just one girl's ideas
so please don't be offended.  all in all, i thought it was an absolutely
incredible party while it lasted, despite the various problems.

oh yes, one more thing:  i think it's time to move ff to the richmond
civic center.  (hee hee!)

seeya!

anthrax

Subject: Every Sunday ...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 22:06:12 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Hey all,

Checked out a new weekly last night @Il Pirata (16th&Utah).
Kudos to Ann for explaining to me that I needed to go out ;)

I heard this one referred to variously as "Every Sunday" or 
"Every Fuckin' Sunday"; take your pick.

We got there about 11pm? I really wasn't paying attention. Very mellow
crowd; old and new faces. Got to hook up with a few people I haven't seen
for months, yay! We left b4 closing, but it was supposed to go until ~3:30.

The space is a small bar/restaurant, it looked like there were maybe 50 of
us there at most; a little less than full and much less than crowded.
The front was well lit without being over-powering; think family bar instead
of chill room. Mona tripped it out a bit, though. The effect was nice; there's
supposed to be a different twist on it every week. Harlan did his visual magic
in the dance room; it went down smoothly with the audio.

Spent most of my time talking but caught some of the music; lots of slow and
slower hip-hop beats as the evening wore on. Markie dropped the needle on 
something I've never heard before, but I'm not out often, so maybe someone on
the list has. *Real* slow back-beat, mostly bass and drum w/o cymbals, 
occasional soft offbeat kicks from a high register glass-bell like synth and 
some light use of what sounded like highly processed (wah and echo) 
reggae samples. Is this ambient dub? Someone point me at a suitable record 
store bin if you can tell me what it is! This is nice to dance to, especially 
when you're tired. It provides alot of room to move around in.

Sorry to hear about F&F, didn't make this one, but every one of them I've been
to in the past was a blast. At least now you know you can fill a bigger space!

Random past and present thought connection from the list:

	Getting a suitable space is the number one problem for everything.
Rising rent costs force people onto the street (you could flop in a downtown
hotel for $50 a month or less as recently as 15 years ago). Most of us spend 
most of our $$$ on rent, probably. We need space for parties... <segue to
the effect of technology on rave culture thread> ... in the future every place
of business will be used for something 24hrs/day. Offices in downtown high
rises will become dance floors as portable computers/phones and foldable
partitions are tucked away... floor 24, crash out, floor 25, chill room,
floor 26, hard-trance... every bedroom will have sound proofed walls as a
matter of course... no more noise complaints ... someone pinch me, ok?

-Dave


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 20 22:58:18 1995

In-Reply-To: <v0211013eab9368c14e53@[140.174.184.129]>

POint well taken but don't forget Ethen that I was part of the biggest 
underground sound system in London for 21/2 years.  We did illegal 
parties every week where we would get at least 1,000 (and sometimes up 
to five thousend) people a week and we never made the mistake of having 
to small a venue.  Not to sound patronizing but maybe you should talk to 
a British sound system about throwing break-in's because you clearly need 
a few pointer's (or, more to the point, is it the people you were working 
with?) in how to do it.  Firstly, never have the map point at a well 
known place: always have it in a very obscure location.  Secondly, once 
you at capacity shut the doors and only let people out through the exit 
door which should never be the same as the entrance door.  Thirdly, 
always have a lawayer present at the rave so that when babylon come you 
have some one their who know's if what they are doing is illegal.  There 
Are other rules but these are the main one's.
Look at the Rock Against Reagen tour of the early eighties which was also 
a totally illgal tour that never got busted once mainly because they 
obeyed the above rules.  It worked very for us too.  So please bear this 
in mind so that you can start playing at parties that are worthy of your 
considerable talents and dedication to the SF scene.
Yours, Tristan

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, ethan miller wrote:

> Greetings Friends!
> 
> Well, I'm not sure quite where to start...
> 
> I guess first off my sincerest and most heartfelt apologies to any of you
> that had a negative or less than positive experience saturday night.
> 
> Perhaps a review of what happened (as best we can ascertain) followed by
> some interpretation and conclusions may help to clarify the nights events
> and at least my position on them...
> 
> The short version is: A number of things some within our control and some
> beyond our control resulted in crowds of people that *way* exceeded our
> expectations and, unfortunately, our ability to manage them effectively.
> 
> *We* did not, however, oversell our stated capacity. 740 tickets were
> produced, 20 were sold in advance, 50 were held at the door to handle
> people that skipped the map point and 670 were sold at the map point. The
> crew present totalled approximately 30 people. Thus, but for the events I
> will discuss in a moment we should have had 770 people which we as a group
> had decided would fit in that space albeit tightly.
> 
> However, as noted above, hundreds and hundreds more -- anywhere form
> 250 - 500 found out where it was and showed up with a variety of stories
> both true and false that our overwhelmed door people then had to attempt to
> decipher.
> 
> This was the result of a few things the details of which we're still trying
> to sort out. We do know one thing though: I personally, in a fit of total
> madness forgot a stack of prolly 100 maps (but *not* tickets!) at the map
> point which was shut down and locked at that point. That door should have
> never opened again but it did. There was a band recording inside that got
> sick of people continually banging on the door and opened it. What happened
> next is still a bit vague however one thing is certain: that stack of maps
> went out the door somewhere around midnight. At around 12:30 one of our
> staff showed up at the map point and someone very definitely not part of
> our group was giving out those maps and may have been selling them. Our
> staff person took that stack from them at that point. So it apears that
> there was about a half hour window in which those maps were either given
> away or sold. By our estimate about 30 people showed up at the site
> claiming that they had been sold a map.
> 
> In addition to this there were reports of people at kinkos counterfeiting
> maps, tickets and/or fliers. As you might also imagine loads of people were
> observed trying to transfer stamps from one hand to another. Very sweaty
> conditions inside were making valid stamps extremely difficult to verify,
> let alone fakes.
> 
> So, between roughly 12 and 2, there were was a huge crowd of people outside
> the door unable to get in. Some of these were people that had been inside
> and decided to go out; some of these were people hoping to buy a ticket at
> the door, some may have been sold fake "tickets" and some were clearly
> bullshit artists with a variety of stories. I personally saw *no one* that
> had a real ticket and was unable to get in.
> 
> At about 2:40, most everyone was inside. Unfortunatley the real (and mostly
> white ;) gangstas, responding to a tripped burgalry alarm next door, then
> arrived not at all expecting what they found. The party was then shut down.
> Had that alarrm not been tripped, I (and many others) feel we would have
> made it.
> 
> But it was, and one of our doormen at the time, Jeff, was put in a choke
> hold, handcuffed and arrested. He has been charged with "Obstructing an
> Officer", and "Assault and Battery on a Police Officer". I was issued five
> misdemeanor citations:
> 
>  o No Dancehall Keeper Permit
>  o No Place of Entertainment Permit
>  o No Cabaret Permit
>  o Exceeding The Stated Capacity of the Building
>  o Blocked Fire Exit
> 
> So, those are the facts as best we can determine so far. I'd like to start
> by responding to Tristan's (the kevin keiper account) post cos I think it
> frames the main issues fairly well. (Tristan I suggest you start signing
> your posts, lest people mistake your sentiments for kevin's).
> 
> Yes, we made mistakes but I think you're still missing the point. F&F has
> always been an *attempt* to make raves (or whatever) something other than
> products to be payed for and consumed. F&Fs have always been ultra low
> cost; they have always been benefits at which everyone always works for
> free, and *no one* has ever been turned away cos they didn't have the
> money. We are trying to *facilitate* NOT FOR PROFIT *community*
> celebrations.
> 
> Yes, the space was too small for the 1000+ people that showed up. Yes we
> were unprepared to deal with 1000+ people. Yes, it was fucking hard do get
> in during peak hours. And yes, I understand your frustration and your
> anger, and yes, I am sorry.
> 
> BUT, YOU had the opportunity to *not* view the whole situation as a bad
> product that you were having a hard time consuming. YOU had the opportunity
> to see that we were having a hard time. And so my friend, YOU also had the
> opportunity to *help us*, had you cared to. Lord knows we could have used
> it.
> 
> Time and time again life presents us with situations where what is *is*
> never mind whose fault it is, and pointing fingers at that point simply
> does no good. With a little help and a little patience we could have pulled
> this one out.
> 
> Nevertheless it brings me great joy that lots of you and others did have a
> very good time. So, many, many thanks to all of you for your love, support
> and energy.
> 
> As I'm sure many of you are curious, here's what happened fiscally: luckily
> all of our expenses were covered and, depending on the final disposition of
> our security deposit there will be somewhere between $1500 and $1900 left.
> This will hopefully cover any fines that Jeff and I are liable for in
> addition to benefititing the two groups we intended to benefit.
> 
> So once again thank you for your support fiscally and otherwise. I hope you
> felt your contribution was well placed. If not, then my apologies once
> again. There will be more parties, should you object to or be unable to
> afford the donation at any of them, we will (as always) happily let you in
> free.
> 
> I'll keep the list up to date on our legal proceedings. When and if we need
> it, Jeff and I would certainly appreciate your support should you feel so
> inclined.
> 
> And last but not least, many, many thanks to everyone that helped try and
> pull this one off. There are truly too many to list. You all know who you
> are. If we're not gonna try it who is? Right Fucking On. Nice job everyone.
> 
> lost of love
> ethan
> 
> 
> 
>

having been on sfraves for the past month, i've been truly inspired by 
the way everyone helps each other out. the support that everybody gives 
to each other is second to none, considering noone has to even care at all.
this os my chance to ask for help. about a week ago i loaned my 
turntables and my skillz to my 'friends' for a house party. i figured no 
problem, since they're my tables i can just relax and have a good time. 
right.you see, i happen to love jungle; the drum n bass. been into it for years 
now. well my 'friends' didn't take so kindly to the music. after i got 
kicked off my OWN tables, i wuz told i wuz lucky i didn't get my ass 
kicked. i took it all in stride, altho i was so pissed at these closed 
minded fuks. my 'freinds' started telling me that jungle isn't music, its 
a bunch of noise, and that everyone hates it.
this angers me so, cause i know people will love this if they are just 
given a chance to hear it. 
this is where sfraves come in. if you are a promoter, or know a promoter,
 
email me and i can hook you up with my mix tape. 

peace, dj thad

Dear Robert J;


	If defense of the promoters, Ethan M., the F&F staff, and myself, but
I'm just curious. Did you not see the fire extingushers, did you not see
me, maning the first aid station, certifed by the american red cross?

	I don't know to many events that have first aid available from a
qualified person. The only time first aid seems to be available at events
is when I show up, not to blow my own horn, but its true. 
	
	F&F's was the first event where an actual first aid area was
provided for. WHich included a full first aid kit, bendine, gause,
banages, blood pressure cuff, thermometer(with cover), saline solution(eye
injury), latex gloves, and don't laugh, super glue(because it bonds skin
instanly, and in a life threating situation it can save you),...etc 

	I take offense to say that we weren't prepared and ready for
accidents, some people just aren't tuned in. We had more stuff there than
most big corporations provide in their messly little first aid kits, I
know I worked for several, and couldn't even get a bandaid. If you gonna
make comments like that make sure you first ask the people who were
responsible for providing those services, and also open your eyes, if you
saw the massage table you found the first aid station, with a working fire
extingusher next to it. The F7F staff knew where everything was, and who 
to go to in the event of an emergency, and I never left my massage table 
once the night started, not even to dance!!!!

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

> 	I take offense to say that we weren't prepared and ready for
> accidents, some people just aren't tuned in. We had more stuff there than
> most big corporations provide in their messly little first aid kits, I

> saw the massage table you found the first aid station, with a working fire
> extingusher next to it. The F7F staff knew where everything was, and who 
> to go to in the event of an emergency, and I never left my massage table 
> once the night started, not even to dance!!!!

None of this would have done any good if anything serious had happened.
Normaly I don't realy care for fire codes, but there was a very dangerous
situation going on in that building. I'd estimate that there were 600+
people crammed upstairs with the only exit being the already crowded
stairs. It was very obviously completely out of their control & although I
was very pissed about getting stuck outside for an 1 1/2hr breath of air
it was a very good call by them, even though having 200 people hanging out
outside is not very inconspicuous. The thing that realy got me was that it
was a limited capacity party, which IMHO realy sucks, most hardcore people
don't show up before 2am let alone 11:30, I think they should have found
a bigger & safer venue. There were alot of unfamiliar faces & most of my
friends slacked to hard to get there on time. On a good note there was alot
of energy, they did a very good job decerating the place & it was only $5.
Thanks to all the people that *atleast tried* to put on a good cheap party.

		Josh

Dear Josh;

	I must admit I never saw the upstairs, but downstairs didn't seem
that crowded, and yeah I told you I never left my massage table. So when
you say crowded, do you mean the first 25 rows at a Grateful Dead Concert,
or Metallicca, or do you mean crowded like any given Wicked.

	I agree a building colaspe, no we couldn't handle, but multiple
cases of dehydration, or heat prostration, a bad trip or two,
lasserations, bruses, yes, especially if I had someone steady to count on
tranfering people to a hospital ER.  It requires some really dedicated,
clear, responsible people. Even though I'm trained to be able to deal with
everything up to and including a heart attack(CPR), I don't want to ever
have to be that clear and responsible.

	As far as what I think of the building, I us to be a Test Engineer
and I really don't know that much about structural stuff. But in human
factors engineering the average human is considered to weigh 150lbs(if any
one has an ISO Standard Handbook on that I would appreiate the exact
fiqure)(I'm such a geek):), whether or not the building could safety
withstand:

	(150 * the number of people upstairs * modified by the fact that
	their moving * modified inversely by the short duty cycle of the
	load on the structure * modifeid inversely by the fact that the 
	load is spread out)/2000 = the number of tons on the 2nd floor. 

Who's really to say but a Structual Engineer whether it was really safe or
not. It was one of the old buildings, the kind that they don't make
anymore, its withstood a few earthquakes, I image we weren't in danger of
what we call in the test eng. biss, a catastrophic failure, but this is
California were I've decided anything can happen. And besides if it 
wasn't dangerous it wouldn't be any fun. :)

	If any thing I thing people had a better chance of getting killed
due to the fact they had to drive a car before they were ready. Just my
clammer thoughts. The fact is no one got hurt, at least no one came to see
me for first aid. I think its great that we can put 750 of us together and
have fun, and love and respect each other.  That even though some people
tried to destory a good time, most had one any way. Thats whats important
and no matter what happen-ed/s I hope we never lose sight of that. 

		Peace & Love Fromn Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		ALt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

main not have been able to get there in time considering the crowd
and ensuing panic that might have occured.  Despite the no smoking
signs, we witnessed people smoking and flicking their ashes on the
mattresses they were sitting on. =:-O

This problem is not unique to F&F.  Current laws make it nearly
impossible to find cheap, safe, all nite, all age indoor venues.  
Another reason why outdoor renegades are preferable.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

I don't know if the F&F crew are up for hearing suggestions, but I'm 
going to take my chance.  
A major problem of the night was the copying of tickets.  When I went to 
Basics last November, they had a special stamp on the back of the 
ticket.  Maybe if all the tickets were numbered on the back - up to, what 
was it, 750? - then no one could get in without a numbered ticket.  Add 
to that maybe a mark with one of those invisible ink markers that you can 
only see under a black light, so that if anybody trying to forge numbers 
on the back of the ticket will get yet another surprise.  The only 
problem with doing all that is that it takes alot of time to do, but I 
think it could work.  Just my 2 cents worth for the day.....


luv,
Amy

In the mist of a somewhat of a tragidy with the cops breaking up the 
party, it was really nice to see the way all the ravers dealt with the 
police.  As I helped clean up and the cops walked around taking pictures, 
conficating evidence, I was appreciative of the reactions of all those 
present.
Things could have been much worse, if people decided to meet the cops 
with attitude.  They looked plenty prepared with a van and the number of 
them to really have made the shutdown real ugly.  Those that were present 
stayed cool, continued with a peaceful vibe despite the disappointment.  
Thanks to everyone's peacefulness, I think helped nuturalize an intitial 
aggressiveness from the cops.  I don't think it would have taken much, 
for things to escalate into a much worse situation.  
As dissappointing as it is for me to see the cops show up at our raves, 
its nice to see some good relations take place with them, hoping it will 
help cut down on future hassles.


peter

Please don't be angry. Yeah, it's a pretty awful thing to counterfeit
tickets for--a benefit for two such worthy causes--but please don't
let anger dominate your feelings over it. Remember it for all the good
it served, for the wonderful times had, and, should things work out for
the best, that it will still benefit these causes.

We're not about resentment. At worst, we learned a lesson, and we'll
do better next time. At best, we've seen how our community pulls
together in times of trouble, and it really warms my heart to see it.

I talked with Ethan in person last night, and (sorry if I embarrass
you) his impish grin is as impish as ever, and his enthusiasm is
still, well, very catching :).

So _smile_ when you think of F&F :) :) :). Karma will take care of the
people who do bad things; we want to focus on doing some good things.

:)

Sean

PS - Think a bunch of computer technodweebs can work solutions to
things like queueing and ticket counterfeiting? Mmmmm... could be... :)

I just got to my e-mail, and was curious to see what the response would be
to the party...

I just had to add my two cents.

GREAT FUCKING PARTY, even in spite of the shutdown. Even though I don't go
out all that much anymore, I haven't seen a vibe like that in years
(obviously this was my first FNF), since before the days of Toontown...

I don't really understand the point of criticizing the people who so
obviously put a lot of heart and soul into it, the overcrowding situation
was clearly out of anyone's control. It's a shame that there are those
willing to take advantage of good intentions.

Though I doubt anyone who counterfeited tickets is on this list, a message
to you: you don't get it, try something like the DV8 next time you can't
get in somewhere... It was made abundantly clear that the map point would
be sold out early, that the party would be crowded so get there early.
Those words weren't just for show or to try to get people to come out a
little earlier.

And another thing... standing outside a party waiting to get in is no fun,
especially if you've already bought your ticket. It's a frustrating
situation to be sure, BUT IT HELPS NO ONE to clamor and try to force your
way into the door. Most especially when the only point of access was in
such a crowded spot to begin with.


Now that I've vented, I'm really bummed that I didn't get to meet anyone
from the list Saturday. It was just to damned crowded. I still had a great
time though, maybe we can meet another time.


A BIG THANKS and kudos to those involved with making it happen.



-Brian Benitez

Subject: Friends and Family Collective Statement
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 12:29:48 -0800 (PST)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Content-Length: 1460

Precedence: bulk

I am posting the message below on behalf of the entire group of people
who produced Friends and Family.  Thank you for your patience.



============================================================================

Greetings, friends and family!

As many of you know, the Friends and Family anniversary went off in San
Francisco last weekend.  You probably also know that we were shut down
by the police.  The event had much going right, and some things went
wrong.  The Friends and Family collective will be making a statement
about the party in the next few days.  Since we are a diverse group of
people, we ask for your patience while we collectively prepare our
statement.

In the meantime, we thank everyone who participated in the event.  We apologize
to all who were inconvenienced or turned away.  We also request that anyone
who has any information or was a witness to the behavior of the police at the
event to please contact us at the address ( fandf@ultima.org ). If
you'd like to make a comment to the Friends and Family collective, please
send us email at that address.

Thank you very much.

The Friends and Family crew

-- 
---- Bryce Ryan ------- Site Admin ----------- e-dress: brycer@ultima.org -----
---- Internet services, education, and Toaster Net construction :-) -----------


-- 
=== Bryce Ryan ===== AMBIANCE ========= e-dress: brycer@ultima.org =========
=== Internet services, education, and Toaster Net construction :-) =========

To all,

After reading many of the reviews, I have concluded that much of what I would
say here has already been said.  I would like to add a few words, however, to
let those involved in the planning of it that *yet another person* (me) thought
it was one of the best events they've seen.  I brought 9 people along; for many
of them it was their first rave.  They all thought it was truly an amazing
thing.  To quote a friend of mine, who looked on wide-eyed across the dance
floor: "I never knew something like this was possible!"

For those of you who made it to the BLUE CUBE (my home) for the post-bust,
ad-lib after-party, I thank you all for coming and relaxing with us.  It truly
was a peaceful gathering, even though the space was crowded and entropy
abounded.  We managed to support over 100 people in a two person house!
  
Special thanks to Melissa ('ello, me love) for excavating the downstairs with
me.  Props to Tony and Ed for being crowd control and general, all-around cool
folks.  (and yes Tony, I "appreciate this!")  Hello to Sy, Eva, Brian M., Brian
T., Gaby & Bill, Amy & Paul (great tape!), Ken Pau ('nother cool tape!), , Rob
L., Scott & Sarahjane, Mark & Char, Mike "Spydah!" B., Brian H., Katie, Dan, Rob
O., Cindy, Rocky, Peter ("Chairs as currency... think about it!") and ESPECIALLY
those at the helm, Ethan & Bryce, who have *the vision*.

Let's do it again!

Greg Harrison

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: gregm@well.com (Greg McCann)
Subject: Global Solar Ceremonies 3/21/95
Cc: davis@well.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thanks to Dan Trocha for posting the information on the Global Solar
Ceremonies.

Two of my friends and I decided last night to get up at 5 am and
go out to the Baylands Nature Preserve in Palo Alto to greet the 
sun as it rose.  We were afraid it would be raining or overcast, 
so we were glad to see some patches of blue sky when we looked
outside at about 5:30.

We brought drums, a flute, other miscellaneous instruments, and
some sage to burn.  We offered prayers of thanksgiving and peace,
then began drumming as the sky slowly grew lighter and the waking 
birds flew around us singing.  Another person came as we were 
drumming and joined us in welcoming spring to the earth.

As we stood drumming and looking across the bay to the green 
mountains, the sun burst through the clouds and filled our eyes
and hearts with its fresh morning light.

We stopped drumming and turned around to see a rainbow forming 
over the foothills.  It seemed to begin at the Stanford radio-
telescope and ended on the shore near the bay.  As we watched,
it slowly grew larger, arching across the sky, turning into a
double and then triple rainbow!

We were filled with its beauty and took it as a sign that our 
prayers were heard.

peace,

greg

I've done it, a lot of us have done it before, so no scolding.  But *don't
do it!*  "Just say no" to buying anything at a rave.  You will get 100% pure
SHIT everytime first of all.  Second, the more selling that goes on at
raves, the more undercover cops there will be, the more busts there will be,
the more this stigma of raves being drug parties will grow, the more parties
like F&F will get shut down due to "probable cause".  NOT that this was the
case this time.  But you see what can happen.  It's a good idea to take care
of business before hand.  Be careful... have fun.

solarvibe
