On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:

> 
> well, too bad f&f did not last all night.  *sigh*  a lot of planning
> and heart went into it, but due to overcrowding unfortunately things
> did not go as planned.
> 
> in my mind, it will always be what someone (philip, maybe?) dubbed it
> the night of:  the Japanese bullet train party.  i have never in my
> life seen so many people jammed so tight into a place before.  it was
> absolutely terrifying at first, but then i started to kind of like it.
> i guess you all remember the orginal complaints about the kommotion
> parties?  that they were too crowded!  do you remember the anonymous
> complaint to the fire marshall about this particular thing?  whew!
> 
> a very weird dynamic was operating that night:  even though people were
> crammed in like sardines, it seemed like nobody wanted to leave.  people
> kept advising eachother:  better not go out or you won't get back in!
> also, once i got used to the press and the heat, i started kind of liking
> the vibe of being part of the bullet train, rocketing at the speed of
> light to goddess-knows-where.
> 
> the music i heard that night was infused with insane energy..the dj's
> were responding to the crowding, i bet.  and the ambient room was outa-
> sight.  thank you new moon!  (i didn't help set up so i am not being
> a narcissist here)
> 
> all that said, i thank our lucky stars that the worst that happened was
> that the party got shut down.  like i said, i was terrified that any
> second somebody was going to start freaking out.  but the vibe held,
> thank you thank you thank you.
> 
> here's my suggestions for the future..i hope they help:
> 
> (1) raise the price, but let people who want to help set up, break
> down, get in for free.  $5 (was that the price?) is too little.
> 
> (2) don't encourage people to get there early anymore.  
> 
> (3) make sure you have experienced door people working the door...
> (or at least folks with thick skins who can keep smiling no matter what)
> 
> (4) sell half as many tickets as you think the space will hold and
> get ready to take people's money at the door.  because the night of, the
> location WILL get out!
> 
> well, i know many of you of course disagree with my suggestions, (i'm
> betting the price one will rankle) but they are just one girl's ideas
> so please don't be offended.  all in all, i thought it was an absolutely
> incredible party while it lasted, despite the various problems.
> 
> oh yes, one more thing:  i think it's time to move ff to the richmond
> civic center.  (hee hee!)
> 
> seeya!
> 
> anthrax
>

mean about the reputation of raves and their association with drugs; my

   I was wondering who else out there got the biggest, phattest contact 
high ever at F&F?  This includes people who were not sober and were taken 
to the next level by the energy.

   After I finished my set, I could barely walk down the stairs to do 
security because my body was so elated from everyones energy.  It was 
also a very pure energy.  All the effort put in to the party was sincere 
and honest and done purely out of love.  This left a trail of beauty, not 
only in tangible things like the music/visuals etc., but on an emotional 
plane as well.  
 
   Even though this party was busted and overcrowded, I think the amount 
of energy that was there tells us we should continue expanding.  I think 
1000 people is the perfect number for a micro-massive party.  I think we 
are going to experience an amazing summer.  I think there will be some 
massive outdoor parties, we should try and fill the bandshell!  I also 
think the need for spaces will be taken care of with wherehouse 
locations outside of SF.

   I've gotta stop rambiln now, it's time for crass... :/

   Peace
   Love,

There was a vibe there that you personally didn't get. That was your
problem .. not the party's. Hundreds of others did get it.

I'm sure you've experienced great parties in the past. And this,
in your opinion, was not even close. Fine..we've all been to parties
that just didn't click.. and we've probably all been to parties where
we didn't like the music.

But your ego is getting in the way of your brain, Tristan.
You still think that you're right and everyone else must be wrong,
because they don't agree with you. Face it man, most people had a great time
there. People that have as much/more party experience as you, as well as 
people who were at their first party. 
 
Now you've added a little constructive criticism (not much) in the 
last 2 days.. but a little modesty would go a long way in getting 
your point across. And judging from your posts.. you probably have
a lot to be modest about.  (to quote a churchill)

chance to hear him.  San Francisco you are spoiled!

happen to be a cop, to take notice and start looking for something that
_is_ probable cause. There are undercovers at raves - you're now doing

rather not know any more...

dealers at raves...

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Peter Fogel wrote:

> As dissappointing as it is for me to see the cops show up at our raves, 
> its nice to see some good relations take place with them, hoping it will 
> help cut down on future hassles.

	I would not call the relations with the cops nice. I have a 
friend who is sporting a well smart bruise to illustrate the point, and 
two friends that sat in front of the police station grumbling while we 
got stoned-walled as to what had happened to him. A cop creating a 
situation in which a s/he can claim assault creates reason, in my mind, 
to believe the relations were not so good....
	I will admit I do not take too well to American police; from most 
of my experience, they have been beefed up bullies who live upon the 
pedstal that the title of Peace Officer gives them (with a few 
exceptions. I most say I have met a few who were laid back and did what 
they were supposed to do and no more, didn't try to bully or harrass, 
some have been helpful, but those have been the exception in my 
experience). Granted, I did not receive such an ornament of affection 
when their flashlights shone in my eyes and their sneers lept out from 
their faces as I made my way to the stairs to leave, but that same kind 
of glint, that, just one fuckin dodgey move boy, and I will beat you to a 
pulp look was there (which of course made me giggle, which brought more 
sneers, which brought quickness to my feet)....

dave

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Brian McGonigle wrote:

> Man, u just don't understand Friends and Family.
> There was a vibe there that you personally didn't get. That was your
> problem .. not the party's. Hundreds of others did get it.
> 
> I'm sure you've experienced great parties in the past. And this,
> in your opinion, was not even close. 

	Och, good glimpse of sanity here. I thought Tristan's first post
did catch something of what I had felt when I got to F&F, in that while
people were yelling and hotting and having a gooding time, there was
something kind of missing, that was a slight artificalness to it as the
swarms of walking people would invade the area of those trying to dance. 
Sure there were a lot of "smiling faces" and the such, but there was a
good amount smiling-faces-who-do-not-make-eye-contact as well. And I tend
to look at smiling faces off in their own universe or harboring the fear
of looking at the people with whom they are partying, at least somewhat
superficial. What I noticed later was it was a just a different vibe then
the stomping parties that go off in the far away UK. They are based on a
slightly different vibe even. And going between the two can be difficult, 
especially when everyone around you is going, fuck yeah, it doesn't get 
any better than that... Right.
	Fraser got ridiculed for trying to bring that here and when he
tried to defend it a little, people labled him as a profitteer. Tristan
came out really confrontationally in my opinion, and got a wave of critism
in his face.  That might be all well and fine, but the type of critism
that was uttered was often followed by a "I feel sorry for YOU" speech
which I will admit, I think have nothing to do with feeling sorry for
someone, but instead feeling slightly better about oneself; when there is
no place for such egotism when one is a criticizing another for being
"egotisical".
	I read something in XLR8R, a bit back about SF being a closed 
mind place. There is a set style, and anything different will get the 
piss taken out of it (or soething to that effect) beyond the point where 
it is just fun and games. I think Megatropolis was a demonstration ground 
of that. I seem to remember a lot of Tristan-like comments being flung in 
Fraser's general direction (like the price thing, the venue... even the 
sound and music being shite - far too fast...) If you happened to think 
Megatropalis was a load of shite and flung words at the list expressing 
your disdain, Tristan may be a mirror you should like at for a bit. 
Especially in an openminded community.

dave

The story goes that during some interview or other with Niels Bohr 
(one of the quantum mechanics guys) the reporter happened to notice
a horseshoe hanging over the doorway of the Bohr Barn (turned upright,
so the good luck wouldn't fall out, naturally). When asked if he believed
in such things, Mr. Bohr replied, "No, of course not, but I'm told it
works whether you believe in it or not." 

Is there such a thing as a contact high? "No, of course not, but I'm told it
works whether you believe in it or not." 

-Dave we are making magic whether you know it or not Ilstrup

feelings, just a healthy expression of something I thing we're all 
feeling to varing degrees about the alledged anti-event people. I feel I 
had to express it on the net, it was a rotten thing for them to do, but 
its behind us now. I can only look forward to the next, new & improved, and 
better than ever F&F. 

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Sean Casey wrote:

> Please don't be angry. Yeah, it's a pretty awful thing to counterfeit
> tickets for--a benefit for two such worthy causes--but please don't
> let anger dominate your feelings over it. Remember it for all the good
> it served, for the wonderful times had, and, should things work out for
> the best, that it will still benefit these causes.
> 
> We're not about resentment. At worst, we learned a lesson, and we'll
> do better next time. At best, we've seen how our community pulls
> together in times of trouble, and it really warms my heart to see it.
> 
> I talked with Ethan in person last night, and (sorry if I embarrass
> you) his impish grin is as impish as ever, and his enthusiasm is
> still, well, very catching :).
> 
> So _smile_ when you think of F&F :) :) :). Karma will take care of the
> people who do bad things; we want to focus on doing some good things.
> 
> :)
> 
> Sean
>

come, come, brian, u "humbly" suggest that tristan's acting "like an 
arrogant little kid"?!  stop it!  whether we agree with tristan or not, he 
has made it clear that he is xtremely experienced in these matters and 
knows what he's talking about.  I was having a totally glorious time at 
the Chemica Sutra that night so I can't comment, but this is no childish 
opinion by someone who doesn't know any better, that's been made entirely 
clear.  stop this bitching, ok?
one of the problems we all share together is that society forces us 
out on the edge and then we get forced into blaming each other.  let's 
put most of the blame where it deserves to be - on the repressive kind 
of society we live in, and ;let's not turn against each other.

the word is coming down from on high (and I DO mean a hell of a lot 
higher than just the mayor of this little city) to stomp down hard on the

so fast that the authorties are realising that ignoring it (phase i) is not 
going to stop it, so now we're into phase 2.

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Greg McCann wrote:

> Thanks to Dan Trocha for posting the information on the Global Solar
> Ceremonies.
> 
> Two of my friends and I decided last night to get up at 5 am and
> go out to the Baylands Nature Preserve in Palo Alto to greet the 
> sun as it rose.  We were afraid it would be raining or overcast, 
> so we were glad to see some patches of blue sky when we looked
> outside at about 5:30.
> 
> We brought drums, a flute, other miscellaneous instruments, and
> some sage to burn.  We offered prayers of thanksgiving and peace,
> then began drumming as the sky slowly grew lighter and the waking 
> birds flew around us singing.  Another person came as we were 
> drumming and joined us in welcoming spring to the earth.
> 
> As we stood drumming and looking across the bay to the green 
> mountains, the sun burst through the clouds and filled our eyes
> and hearts with its fresh morning light.
> 
> We stopped drumming and turned around to see a rainbow forming 
> over the foothills.  It seemed to begin at the Stanford radio-
> telescope and ended on the shore near the bay.  As we watched,
> it slowly grew larger, arching across the sky, turning into a
> double and then triple rainbow!
> 
> We were filled with its beauty and took it as a sign that our 
> prayers were heard.
> 
> peace,
> 
> greg
> 
> 
thanks to dan and now thanks to greg.  my own vision of this summer 
happened at the sunday bandshell event in golden gate park about a month 
ago.  when I saw all those lovely people from age 12 to 80, mixed ravers, 
hippies and punks, I had a vision of this summer as Summer of Love Part 
Two/Rave style.  a message will go out to the planet from SF this summer 
that will have global effects.  could say more but fear being flamed for it.
fraser

If there's one consistantly subversive soundsystem around, its got to be
SPAZ. Popped in for a dance last night - and the Equinox, and found an
intimate, free (donations -only) intimate event that gave me that shiver up
the spine feeling of participating in a real "underground" experiment.
Whoever was DJing was kickin out the hardest fastest trance/aboriginal
druming rythmns I've heard in a long while. With  free water and
subversively entertaining literature to boot - puts some of the bigger
operators to shame.

Here are some people who have definitely got the message of what it is that
we are doing - WE ARE RAVING TO DANCE THE SYSTEM UNDER. THERE IS NO OTHER
REASON WE ARE DOING IT, THIS IS OUR WAY OF SAYING I LOVE THE WORLD AND I
DEMAND AN ALTERED STATE.

Folks, its time to get out there an into every concievable venue possible -
a whole bunch of mustard seed small events undetectable, alive fertile,
places, we need to be free. Soon we will have to demand the same rights
that were extended to rock 'n roll in the fifties. BUT right now, we are
under attack. Like those who listened to the rolling stones once upon a
time long ago, WE TOO are fighting for our very survival as a generation of
love. We must awaken to our mission, to our FUNDEMENTAL RIGHTS to Dance
wherever, and whenever the whim takes us.

FOR IF WE CANNOT DO THIS, WE CANNOT BE FREE.  AND I FOR ONE WOULD RATHER
DIE than have my very humanity stripped from me, for if I cannot dance, I
cannot consider myself to be human.  Lets open our eyes to what is
happening  - the emporer wears no clothes, the state is conducting a
concerted campaign to strip our freedoms basic ones like

DANCING ON THE GRASS
DRINKING FRESH WATER
FROLIKING AMONGST THE PLANTS
WORSHIPPING NATURES BOUNTIFUL FERTILITY

If we are willing to defend a basic right, one which is fundemental to
being in tune with nature, then we can have no doubt as to our
rightiousness, and the universe will surely look upon our fight with pride,
and assist us. OPEN OUR HEARTS AND EMPTY DOUBT.

IT IS NOT A CRIME TO BE A VISIONARY, NOT IS IT A CRIME TO LOVE NATURE
WE DANCE TO MUSIC, WE DANCE TO THE BASIC RYTHMNS OF NATURE, TO NINETIES
DRUMMING BEATBOX RITUALS
AND WE DO THIS BECAUSE WE ARE HUMAN

love

david dei

Dear Lee;

	Agreed, I meant to talk about that but forgot. Anything that 
would have paniced people would have definately bin a disaster. But I 
think that could happened at a number of common rave locations, for 
example 1015 Folsum has steep stairs, leaving up and downstairs one level, 
and poor lights.

	I keep hearing all these stories of indivual stupidity at F&F, Ya
know Lee sometimes I wonder about people, I would hate to be the heavy and
have to tell people at parties not to do things like smoke on a mattress,
people need to be more responsible when there out at an event such as F&F,
and not so self centered. Its all together, because one person's 
illresponsible actions can ruin it for us all.

	Although I think when the cops came 750 people kept their cool and
didn't panic or riot. I think thats the most positive statement that we 
can make about our scene, and I do think the authories will see that and 
acknowledge it. I would hope Ethan would make that point at the hearing, 
because I thing its a valuable one.

	Anyway, I do agree with you, the possibilty of a very dangerous 
situation did exsist, and it seems that some people weren't helping make 
it any better. But I can only speak for myself when I say, I would do it 
again in a second. :) Hope you and yours are happy and well, good night 
and have pleasent raver dreams.

B. Darkness

forget it, daniel. I have to agree with Tristan on this one. I've been to
one F&F event (PLEASE DON'T MISUNDERSTAND WHAT I AM ABOUT TO SAY BECAUSE I
AM ONLY TRYING TO BE HONEST) and I thought it was absolutely lovely,
wonderful people-friendly vibe, with a great sense in the atmosphere of a
potential shared idealism ... and it melted my heart because it reminded
me of the rave scene in Britain 3 or 4 years ago.  unless you took 400 SF
ravers with you most people just wouldn't see the point.  the scene there
has moved on massively - remember that the whole thing has got gigantic,
political and socially idealistic over there.  seems to me your time is
now coming and some SERIOUS FUN is coming all our ways as RC goes beyond 
party mode. 

just where in Britain have you been staying? Megatripolis (while I was
there anyway) had 1500 people EVERY WEEK with this kind of vibe PLUS lots
of older Hippy & New Age people too, and a huge ambient room where
everybody lay around on cushions and played with computers, massaged each
other etc etc, PLUS a huge hippy market that made it all look like a
Magickal Palace PLUS a room with serious lectures on everything radical
under the sun PLUS therapy workshops PLUS tons of political/social fliers
and stalls PLUS, oh I could go on. 

I am not knocking anyone, F&F has the best vibe of any rave I've been to 
in the US, and the people involved are clearly going to be very important 
socially and politically over the next year or two, the very heart and 
mind of the scene .. but it's important you guys keep some kind of 
perspective, that's all.

I am/we are NOT dissing you, but what should we do?  keep mum?  surely 
you want information, specially now with so many important issues 
beginning to raise their heads.  love you all,  fraser.

Hey you guys, 

	I just want to take a minute here to personally tell you 
	that I think you are a stupid jerk.  Regardless of whether you
	got burned or not, outting someone on a public network is 
	_really_ stupid.  Just think, if someone did that to you and
	you were pulled over and even though you don't deal or anything
	and the cop found something on you that could send you to PRISON.

	Come on guys! Think, this is NOT funny and you are doing no one
	here a service!  I personally have been paid a visit by police
	at my home at 4 am because a stupid fuck like you reported that 
	there was drug activity going on in my house (there was another tall
	large black man that lived directly under me who I believe they
	mistook me for) fortunately all of my neighbors and my landlady
	(whose office is near by) could vouch for my integrity, Being accused
	of drug dealing is a SERIOUS MATTER, you can cause a person to
	loose everything they own and not even be found guilty.

	Why don't you get a clue and think before you put your hands on the
	keys the next time.

when we kicked off Megatripolis/West last year (only 6 months ago) I said
to Mark Heley, my partner at the time, that, if it worked, we should lok
at the Richmond Ctre as a jumping point.  he looked at me like I was mad
or a megalomaniac.  I went to Funky Techno there a month ago and was
re-convinced.  I think F&F AT THE RICHMOND is a great idea.  and don't
argue that the place is a big impersonal confeence centre - what was the
venue of this last F&F event?  WE make the place what WE want it to be. 
what SF needs IMHO is a big regular gathering point of ALL the tribes,
that's when things start to seriously come together and change. fraser.

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> so muched promised so little delivery!
> 
> On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:
> 
> > 
> > well, too bad f&f did not last all night.  *sigh*  a lot of planning
> > and heart went into it, but due to overcrowding unfortunately things
> > did not go as planned.
> > 
> > in my mind, it will always be what someone (philip, maybe?) dubbed it
> > the night of:  the Japanese bullet train party.  i have never in my
> > life seen so many people jammed so tight into a place before.  it was
> > absolutely terrifying at first, but then i started to kind of like it.
> > i guess you all remember the orginal complaints about the kommotion
> > parties?  that they were too crowded!  do you remember the anonymous
> > complaint to the fire marshall about this particular thing?  whew!
> > 
> > a very weird dynamic was operating that night:  even though people were
> > crammed in like sardines, it seemed like nobody wanted to leave.  people
> > kept advising eachother:  better not go out or you won't get back in!
> > also, once i got used to the press and the heat, i started kind of liking
> > the vibe of being part of the bullet train, rocketing at the speed of
> > light to goddess-knows-where.
> > 
> > the music i heard that night was infused with insane energy..the dj's
> > were responding to the crowding, i bet.  and the ambient room was outa-
> > sight.  thank you new moon!  (i didn't help set up so i am not being
> > a narcissist here)
> > 
> > all that said, i thank our lucky stars that the worst that happened was
> > that the party got shut down.  like i said, i was terrified that any
> > second somebody was going to start freaking out.  but the vibe held,
> > thank you thank you thank you.
> > 
> > here's my suggestions for the future..i hope they help:
> > 
> > (1) raise the price, but let people who want to help set up, break
> > down, get in for free.  $5 (was that the price?) is too little.
> > 
> > (2) don't encourage people to get there early anymore.  
> > 
> > (3) make sure you have experienced door people working the door...
> > (or at least folks with thick skins who can keep smiling no matter what)
> > 
> > (4) sell half as many tickets as you think the space will hold and
> > get ready to take people's money at the door.  because the night of, the
> > location WILL get out!
> > 
> > well, i know many of you of course disagree with my suggestions, (i'm
> > betting the price one will rankle) but they are just one girl's ideas
> > so please don't be offended.  all in all, i thought it was an absolutely
> > incredible party while it lasted, despite the various problems.
> > 
> > oh yes, one more thing:  i think it's time to move ff to the richmond
> > civic center.  (hee hee!)
> > 
> > seeya!
> > 
> > anthrax
> >

Maybe Fraser has a point here, even though maybe F & F shouldn't be the focal
name, it might be a good jumping off point.  The Richmond Civic center has
been used for large "gathering of the tribes" type events, the most successful
and awsome one being the First benefit for Malachy (Unity).  It was one of the
few times that most of the promoters in the city co-operated :) for one
good cause.  Don't know if the climate is ripe to do it again, it was really
hard top get everyone to co-operate before, could be even harder now.
But still if you want to try your luck it might be a good interface point,
the police are right across the way, and they are use to these types of
events.  The last Area-51 was a really nice party,  It's sorta hard to
generate a steady "Vibe" in such a large space and goddess knows we 
San Franciscians MUST have our Vibe :) 

but hey... maybe with a 50 kilowatt Luv Phaser...



				G

Dear Sfraves;

	With all this talk about them and us, I just have to go out on a 
limb and share a personal experience with you all.

	After Black Dog last Friday night I found myself in a house with a 
bunch of English DJ's and friends. I was the only one with a different 
accent and felt really out of place. At that point this thought darted 
into the front of my mind, if I feel out of place here with these 
beautiful people, god they must feel even more out of place than I do, 
being in a country of non-orgin, so I just sat their and took in the 
feeling. Tring to image how I would feel if I was over in England going 
to raves. I imaged after a while that I would really desire something that 
reminded me of home, and if I had the opportunity would try and change the 
scene, if I were involved to fit my tastes a little better.

	This isn't England, I think thats obvious, we here in SF do 
things are own wonderfully unique way. I'm most recently from Gainesville 
Florida where the scene is strong, but as different as SF is to England ..etc

	One thing that is SF is I feel that we do try and embrace 
diversity in all its forms. Diversity by its nature is different, most 
people are uncomfortable with change and something that's different. Even 
the most seasoned raver I image can fall into a rut of rave man-nag-omy, 
(sorry my dictionary packed).

	The point is, (Lee always likes it when I get here), I think we
all know what are differences are. I would really like sfravers, and the
english ravers on this list to take the time and express how we are all
the same, I think this is much more a worth wide effort, than whats been
going on, just my 2 cens worth. I know how I would feel if I was in a
strange place/country, thanks for your time, and pleasant raver dreams to 
you all. :)

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

		"the message is as always love"


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 22 00:12:31 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id AAA09234; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 00:12:31 -0800
Received: from priscilla.ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id AAA09227; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 00:12:25 -0800
Received: by priscilla.ultima.org  (Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #8) id m0rrL6y-000IL6C; Tue, 21 Mar 95 23:45 PST
Message-Id: <m0rrL6y-000IL6C@priscilla.ultima.org>
From: litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org (Monica and Tom)
Subject: police brutality/misconduct (long)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 23:45:48 -0800 (PST)
Cc: ff-planners@priscilla.ultima.org
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 4646      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

as you may have heard, there was yet another wrongful arrest and 
brutalizing (brutalization?) of a party staffer at a rave this past 
weekend - this time at friends and family.  it comes as no surprise, 
considering the way the cops treated partygoers and organizers at the 938 
harrison street new years ball/Visual Aid benefit earlier this year 
(beating/brutalizing people, levying false charges, confiscating 
equipment and money...)  

these are not isolated incidents, but are simply more attacks in a 
crusade by mayor jordan, along with Southern Station and moneyed 
interests, to quelch soma parties in order to proceed with gentrifying 
the neighborhood, as well as to put an end to, or at least exert more 
control over, our underground and subversive gatherings.  prior to the 
two above examples, there have been raids on DV8 and gay male "underwear 
parties," as well as new enforcement of anti-nudity laws at the folsom 
street and dore alley fairs.  clearly, these are related, and are 
attempts to enforce a hegemonic anti-sex, anti-youth (and anti-fun!) agenda.

the police break up our parties and brutalize us because they can get 
away with it.  in terms of brutality, the only way a citizen can get any 
compensation or justice is thru a civil lawsuit, and even then the money 
comes out of the city's general fund (for hospitals, etc.), NOT out of 
the police budget.  in addition, officers who are found to have committed 
acts of brutality are still promoted!  the Office of Citizen Complaints 
(OCC), is a sham, made up mainly of ex-cops and ex-DA office employees 
who can only make suggestions to the police chief as to dealing with 
abuse of power - brutality is treated as a managerial problem and then 
swept under the rug.  

we need to organize to fight this and make changes.  i am sick of seeing 
my friends attacked, i am sick of fearing for myself and basically being 
treated as a second-class citizen if i am at a party, and i am sick of 
worrying if my party is going to get busted.  i think it is time that we 
as "ravers" and people with progressive/radical visions make links with 
other communitites under attack by the police in this city.  

i am working with a group right now called Action for Police 
Accountability (APA), formed by some of us who were present at the New 
Years Raid, and consisting of a range of individuals active in 
Streetwatch/Empty the Shelters, public housing tenants organizing, the 
IWW (Industrial Workers of the World) and the Gray Panthers.  we are 
small now, but full of energy and ideas.  i encourage anyone interested 
in APA to please email me for more information. 

 in addition, i'm 
interested in connecting with other people to form a loose group/network 
of "ravers" to organize specifically against the south of market (and 
city-wide) anti-rave/anti-sex, etc. crackdown.  if you are interested, 
please please please email me.  ideas of what we can do include (but are 
most definitely not limited to!) spreading info. among a larger group of 
ravers on what to do in dealing with police, getting terrance hallinan 
(supervisor) to actually do something substantial to support us, making 
our RIGHT TO DANCE AND CELEBRATE LIFE an issue politically (and i do not 
just mean electoral politics here), having creative protests/raves, 
participating in the upcoming Food Not Bombs festival/encampment in U.N. 
Plaza during the U.N. celebrating, having fun (always a priority!) and 
whatever else we think of and can implement.  

i know that one of the most subversive things we can do is to continue to 
organize underground parties, but the more we get pushed around the 
greater our need to react publicly as well in an organized, nonviolent 
manner.  

next tuesday, march 28, the Board of Supervisors, with support from APA, 
is holding a hearing on police brutality and what we can do to make 
changes (legislatively) in terms of police dept. procedure and civilian 
oversight.  this will also be a forum for people who have experienced or 
witnessed police brutality to speak out.  i am planning to make a short 
statement about the soma crackdown and recent events.  the hearings are 
at 10:00, and we are holding a rally beforehand at 9:00, and i am 
encouraging everyone who can to attend.  (oh, BTW, they're at 401 Van 
Ness, the War Memorial Bldg.)     in the future, APA will be holding 
town hall mtg speakouts and rallies as well.  

again, i really think that what with all the publicity around the 938 
harrison raid that this is our opportunity to make our right to dance an 
issue.  

in love and @,
monicat

litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org

Dear monicat

	You know I'll be there, and will fight them with the tools
available to us technology, computers, the internet, and what the cops
fear most the VIDEO camera, I would like to suggest to all door crews in
the city running raves to have a VHS video camera in arms reach of every
main door, a VHS camcorder is such a small investment that makes such a
powerful statement. Or do the citzens watch thing only make a VHS 
camcorder standard equipment, they can't lie when its all other CNN, and 
the other networks. DO it  DO it DO it

B. Darkness

>as you may have heard, there was yet another wrongful arrest and
>brutalizing (brutalization?) of a party staffer at a rave this past
>weekend - this time at friends and family.  it comes as no surprise,

>(OCC), is a sham, made up mainly of ex-cops and ex-DA office employees
>who can only make suggestions to the police chief as to dealing with

>swept under the rug.

>my friends attacked, i am sick of fearing for myself and basically being

>worrying if my party is going to get busted.  i think it is time that we
>as "ravers" and people with progressive/radical visions make links with
>other communitites under attack by the police in this city.

I think that when Tristan commented on needing a lawyer at raves, he hit a
valid point.  I know that we as a group can change laws if we voice
ourselves loud enough, but sometimes you need a little something extra to
get your foot in the door of change.  Having a well-known lawyer at a rave,
and maybe a video camera, would allow us to fight the system using the
system to its fullest extent.  You need somebody fluent in the lingo of the
law that can address all problems that might arise.

Also, from the way that raving is portrayed on television nowadays, many
people are brainwashed into thinking that it is a bad element in society.
Ravers might be considered as druggies and idiots in the eyes of the court
if they were to testify without a really good lawyer.  Having that lawyer
at the rave, paid to take notes on any disruption in the flow of the night,
would give us the edge we need by having a player in their game seeing
things from our perspective.

I know money would be the big setback in this idea, so I leave it to
somebody else to figure that out.  Perhaps if instead of charging $5 at the
rave they charged $7-10, the rest going to pay the attorney.  It would work
if someone tried.  With the increase in busts by police, I see less and
less options to deal with them except by playing the game.  Play it for all
it's worth, and get them caught in their own traps.  Rent two lawyers,
three, whatever it takes to get police to step back and say, "wait a
second....this is not as easy as it used to be". Just like what happened
after Rodney King(although this is a lame example).  Police abused their
power until they were placed in check.  We must place them in check here.
We all have rights to.  It's time we began to try and secure them.

Luv ya =)



Rob McCord (BR '98)
mcrobt@minerva.cis.yale.edu

I would just like to suggest that we not over-react to Fraser Clark
lecturing us about how to do things.  There are always plenty of people
telling us "how they do it in the UK."  I think we know perfectly well
about all that.  We are doing things as they ought to be done in
San Francisco.  We are learning from our mistakes, we are being honest
about them, but we are also being appreciative of each other.

Grant slack, and it shall be granted thou a thousand times over.

c u in the future
phred

it would be EASY to get the right vibe there.  when I attended the Funky
Techno event (DIGITARIA) I "saw" all those boring corridors FILLED with
hipy markets and every social/political stalls (including blanket stalls)
to overflowing and all these thousands of rainbow ravers (what we call
zippis) flowing through them, communing and then back to the dncing. 
EASY. and right. "we" are MUCH bigger than the old Richmond Centre.  I've 
actually been thinking (and talking a bit) bout how there should be, 
during the UN celebrations, a United Raver Nations Gathering (URN) either 
there or, if the strike is on, why not have it at Candlestick - I bet 
they could use the bread!  If we invited teams from other countries it 
could even last all week.
just a thought (but thoughts at the right time have wings)
fraser

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Geoff White wrote:

> >

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 22 08:43:24 1995

	id AA01621; Wed, 22 Mar 95 08:43:09 PST
Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 08:43:09 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9503221643.AA01621@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Politics of Raving
Cc: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I totally understand the us vs. them attitude with respect to ravers
and the police/government and our need to demand our right to celebrate 
life in any way that we choose.  Just a few points though:

At F&F, we were breaking the law.  The police were responding to a
burgular alarm.  People often die at crime scenes.  Cops had no way of
knowing what exactly was going on; someone at the scene of a crime
who is slowing them down even slightly could be contributing to a life
threatening situation.

Humans are flawed.  Just as cops can be unjustly brutal and often abuse
their authority, we've seen ravers destroy property and nature, even
steal from each other.  Most cops I've spoken too see us as relatively
harmless - but a major nuisance nonetheless.  Most cops that have busted
parties that I've been at (and that's a lot) have not been brutal at all.
They are usually responding to a complaint.  There is good and bad on both
sides.  And a lot of misunderstanding.  And very different perspectives.

One theory about raving that I've respected is founded on Hakim Bey's
concept of Temporary Autonomous Zones (TAZs); events that spring up in
the cracks of society (like during the night in an abandoned warehouse),
and then disappear without a trace.  A  TAZ can be a selfgoverning and 
does not have to obey society's laws or follow the norms dictated by the
power brokers at large.  The purpose of a TAZ is not to overthrow the
status quo, but to exist in spite of the status quo.  Peacefully.  A TAZ
doesn't battle the environment, it exists in harmony with it.  

Until that burgular alarm got triggered, F&F was in harmony with
the world.  Once the TAZ nature of the party was compromised, it was 
over... Until next time that is - because fortunately there are still 
cracks we can exploit.

If you want raving to be a part of the sociopolitical process, then you
have to start playing along with the existing sociopolitical games.  That 
means following the laws and/or changing the laws.  That means becoming 
visible and attracting even more attention.  That means trying to win
friends and creating more enemies.  That means defining who we are and what
we are trying to do and fighting among ourselves to reach a consensus and
getting people to act as a group which usually means having leaders to
follow and establishing our own authority structure and becoming a lot
like "them".

Our ideals are valid, but I personally feel that the less confrontational
method of spreading our vibe in the cracks of the power fabric will 
ultimately (perhaps not in our lifetime) be more effective, while better 
preserving the ideals we claim to represent.

I'm all for fighting police brutality aboveground and trying to get unjust
laws changed, but I'd prefer that the rave scene not be the main impetus 
for it.

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (  ( (Everything is Possible) )  )   lee@hyperreal.com

> On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Peter Fogel wrote:
> 
> > As dissappointing as it is for me to see the cops show up at our raves, 
> > its nice to see some good relations take place with them, hoping it will 
> > help cut down on future hassles.
> 
> 	I would not call the relations with the cops nice. I have a 
> friend who is sporting a well smart bruise to illustrate the point, and 
> two friends that sat in front of the police station grumbling while we 
> got stoned-walled as to what had happened to him. A cop creating a 
> situation in which a s/he can claim assault creates reason, in my mind, 
> to believe the relations were not so good....
> 	 
 
Dave, Fraser,
I do agree that initially our relations were not good, resulting in a 
ruffed up arrest.  After that things got better.
Just being angry and despising those in authority and seeing them only as 
opponents, I don't think will help.  I do see them as being obstacles and 
opponents at times myself.  There is much more than that here.

This is where the power of the vibe comes in.  The one that nutrualized 
the initial response from the police.  For that vibe, that unconditional 
love goes deep.  It goes to a place that connects us all, brings us 
together, lets us feel its great to be alive, and gives us a sense of 
harmony amongst all the chaos.

That love can be powerful.  Look at the impact it has had on most if not 
all of our lives.  I know I feel fortunate to have been exposed to it as 
we all have to some degree.  Something that creates changes is sometimes 
feared by those that don't understand the beauty behind it.  It is our 
differences and the threat of changes that the authourities fear and try 
to contol.  The love underneath is not.
 
The love that runs through all of us when truley and unconditionally 
shared can help reduce that fear.  For in that experience of love the 
fear of what one has to lose, deminishes as so much is gained.  It is 
that unconditional love and vibe when expressed and shared will help us 
all.  

For some people raving is a great party, for others raving is a great 
party and much more.  Through raving some of us find a vibe which 
connects us to a core within, which is a shared core.  Through this 
shared core a sence of harmony can spread, and we will feel more free to 
dance.


peter

Having been reading all the messages zipping around the net about the bust
of F&F, I thought I'd sneak in my 2=A2 worth ...

At Dreamscape here on the 18th we saw LOTS of cops floating around outside
in their cars, but they seemed to realize that security had things under
control and left us all alone.  I think the secret is to have the
organizers & security guys (or girls) work together with the cops instead
of having everyone give a bad attitude.

I don't know if Canadian cops are more laid back than US cops or what but
if they haven't busted the party by 4:30 they're not gonna bust it at all!
We've been trying to figure out this phenomenon for ages ...

ANYWAYS - I seem to be rambling around here so I better go get back to
work.  I hope to meet some of you at Wicked in Portland if yer going (HEY
TONY!!! COME ANYWAYS!!!!), I'll have my nw-raves badge on ...

peace

karen

e-mail - fuck its like getting post from another planet of postive vibe.

>
>SOUTH AFRICA-POLITICS: Harmony Breaks Out Over Constitution
>
>   By Chris Louw
>
>PRETORIA, Mar 22 (IPS) - Peace and understanding appears to have
>beset South Africa's political parties as they thrash o
>ut the latest version in a series of constitutions for the
>country.
>
>   The lack of acrimony and the level of agreement at the
>Consitutional Assembly (CA) in Cape Town has surprised a publi
>c accustomed to heated debates during the pre-democracy
>constitutional talks at Kempton Park.
>
>   It is even more remarkable when the level of public
>participation is considered. More than 3,000 submissions have
>alr
>eady been received as inputs from various individuals and
>interest groups.
>
>   A fair amount of progress has been made, according to CA
>officials, particularly as far as the acceptance of broad de
>mocratic principles is concerned.
>
>   For instance, everyone in the CA already agrees that South
>Africa should be a constitutional state, that the state sh
>ould be sovereign, that there should be a Bill of Fundamental
>Rights which is entrenched and enforcible, and that there
>should be general franchise for adults over 18.
>
>   But political observers caution that the real test will only
>come after the first draft of the new constitution has b
>een published. This is scheduled to happen in June.
>
>   ''Expect the sparks to begin to fly in July,'' says one
>observer. ''Once the theme committees' draft is committed to
>paper, the present harmony will be shown up for what it really
>is -- little more than the calm that precipitates the sto
>rm.''
>
>   Why does South Africa need a new constitution so shortly
>after its democratic elections last April?
>
>   During the multi-party negotiations at the World Trade Centre
>in Kempton Park, most of the minority parties -- includ
>ing the National Party (NP) -- wanted the negotiated
>constitution to be final. But the African National Congress
>(ANC) a
>rgued that the support enjoyed by the negotiating parties had
>never been tested at the poll.
>
>   The NP then insisted that a set of 34 constitutional
>principles be drawn up to guide any future constitution-writing.
> These principles were ''written in stone'', and all future
>legislation would have to be tested against them. It was als
>o agreed that parliament would lose its supremacy in favour of a
>Constitutional Court which would have the final say on
>whether legislation complies with the constitutional principles.
>
>   In the event, the ANC was prepared to compromise
>significantly in order to facilitate the process. Its
>strategists we
>re happy enough that they would be afforded a second chance to
>write a more durable constitution after the elections.
>
>   A time frame was agreed upon for drawing up the final
>constitution. Six ''theme committees'', representing all the pa
>rties in parliament, have to complete their work on June 30.
>Their reports then have to be considered and evaluated by t
>he CA, which consists of joint sittings of the national assembly
>and the senate.
>
>   On July 14, all reports must be approved by a constitutional
>committee, and the text of the constitution be drafted a
>nd referred to the Constitutional Court to rule whether it is in
>accordance with the constitutional principles.
>
>   On October 31, the full text of the constitution has to be
>completed and ''placed before the public for scrutiny''. A
> full six months is allowed for public reaction to the text. The
>ANC, in particular, is adamant that the final constitut
>ion must be  acceptable to the vast majority of South Africans.
>
>   Says CA chairman Cyril Ramaphosa: ''If an issue is handled in
>a way that engenders massive public protest and unhappi
>ness, the public should be given the opportunity of venting
>their views and their frustrations... That would further enh
>ance the legitimacy of what we are doing.''
>
>   The full text of the new constitution is slated to be debated
>and adopted by the CA in May next year, before final ce
>rtification has to be sought from the Constitutional Court.
>
>   The biggest difference between the present process and
>earlier ones, according to insiders, is in the transformation
>of the roles assumed by the various parties.
>
>   Political observers agree that while the NP government was
>under pressure during the pre-democracy round of negotiati
>ons to see that the process continued and succeeded, the ANC as
>the majority party now finds itself in the role of facil
>itator which has to compromise to accommodate renegade parties.
>
>   It is in the ANC's interest to ensure that the process
>succeeds. The smaller parties' only concern is to look after t
>heir own interests. This entails that the NP, the Freedom Front
>(FF) and the IFP can afford to be ''difficult''.
>
>   These parties' aims to a large degree centre on the highly
>contested issue of federalism, to which all the minor part
>ies (including the liberal Democratic Party) subscribe to a
>great or lesser degree.
>
>   Various mechanisms are in place to slow down the process if
>these parties so wish. Parties disagreeing with clauses i
>n the constitutional draft, for instance, will be able to take
>their objections to the Constitutional Court to decide wh
>ether they comply with the constitutional principles.
>
>   This can significantly delay the process.
>
>   But much of the debate is still obscured by the fact that the
>major parties have as yet been unable to come up with f
>irm policy proposals because of disagreements in their own
>ranks.
>
>   The ANC has up till now only tabled brief proposals at the
>CA, accompanied by warnings that these would be supplement
>ed later -- after the party's constitutional conference
>scheduled for March 31.
>
>   Populists in the ANC are pushing for a strong central state,
>while provincial leaders, having tasted power, are insis
>ting on greater autonomy for the provincial governments.
>
>   The exact functions and roles of traditional leaders is also
>still a contentious issue within the ANC. While modernis
>ts insist on ''pure democracy'', traditionalists want to see a
>special dispensation worked out to accommodate tribal ins
>titutions.
>
>   The NP, on the other hand, is still divided on the issue of
>power-sharing in the executive -- rejected out of hand by
> the ANC -- and on the electoral system best suited for the
>country.
>
>   ''It is too early to have a fixed view on what we want,''
>says NP Executive Director Fanus Schoeman. ''We are conside
>ring a dual system of proportional representation as well as
>constituencies to reflect proportionality and retain the li
>ne between the electorate and their representatives.''
>
>   The transitional constitution stipulates that the new
>constitution has to be passed within two years. If it fails to
>gain the necessary 67 percent support, but is backed by a
>majority in the CA, it will be referred to a panel of constitu
>tional experts to make recommendations which may secure its
>approval.
>
>   If this fails, the president may put the draft to a national
>referendum, needing the support of 60 percent of the ele
>ctorate to get it passed. Inability to secure two-thirds obliges
>the president to dissolve parliament and call a new ele
>ction. The CA that emerges from this election needs only a 60
>percent majority to pass a new constitution and must do it
> within a year. (end/ips/cl/mn/oa/95)
>
>

-----------------------------------------------
                           Megatripolis Parallel University
                                     megatrip@best.com

     INFORMATION, INSPIRATION & SERVICES TO THE NATION
-----------------------------------------------

aggressive posturing, etc. etc...

It's such a slam in our faces - they interrupt an evening of
exuberance, sharing, joy, the thrills of music and dance and closeness
with other human beings, with their annihilating intolerance.
I've felt so bruised each time this happens, but I've
always wimped out in regards to taking any type of *action* -
the style/tactics of the police's type of oppression taps quite
easily into my oh-too-accessible feelings of despair, of being
"too small to count" against a "them" that seems to be so dang LARGE.

However - Monica's post on this issue reminded me that one of the
most important things I have learned (and am still learning)
from raving is how to feel *brave* - to root out my fears and expose them,
balancing their pain with thoughts of clarity, letting my heart relax
& fill with love. Then - to try to speak, and act, and *be*
within the space of honesty and calm that this creates....

My first thought upon writing this last sentence is Embarrassment -
I feel corny, and sort of cringingly ashamed, like I'm doing something
wrong, voicing something so obvious. But this is fear! - me policing
myself with my own thoughts.

"Fear" and "police" are so linked, I think - police intolerance
fills me with sadness because it feels all too familiar - an external
manifestation, or mirror of my own internal paranoia, dis-ease,
uncertainty whirling off past measured and rational doubt to some dark
black-hole vaccum, sucking me away - sucking the TRUST in me away...

Scarier when it's cops, maybe, because it's a social sanction of control.

I'm going off, I know, forgive me - it's my first letter to you
guys and I must feel like I have to say *everything*  :)
I do know that these sentiments have been expressed before.
I wanted to voice my approval for Monica's words & ideas,
and to connect -
and to share -

(Thanks)
  Rhea

Groovy!
I don't care for punk or Rancid, but it's funny how both adverse in some 
ways, but what kindred spirits punk and dance scenes can be.
I used to try and imagine how many of us were punkers once, or how many 
of had never been part of a "scene" till house stuff; how many peopel are 
are eclecticists, into a lot of things, or exclusive, feeling that this 
and that don't mix, unless you're a watered down vegetable, who 
knows...i'm no pop sociologist

Ska, groovy, but will it be considered watered down, fake jungle, by 
jungle purists, whether of the happy house, reggae vibe type jungle 
enthusiasts, or the more "gangsta rap"/ego m.c. aggro type jungle- just 
two crowds who have different notions about what jungle 
means or could be?
(more fuzzy music questions, i'm sorry, can't help it)

A music press recently commented upon the tiredness of a Dee-Lite 
concert in January and their futile attempts to remain contemporary by 
"going jungle" for a song or two.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 22 14:34:52 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id OAA02386; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 14:34:52 -0800
Received: from pilot.njin.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA02378; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 14:34:48 -0800
Received: (from csc@localhost) by pilot.njin.net (8.6.10+bestmx+oldruq+newsunq+grosshack/8.6.10) id RAA24836; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 17:34:45 -0500
Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 17:34:45 -0500
From: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>
Message-Id: <199503222234.RAA24836@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Taping the Police with Video Cameras, Damn Lawyers, etc.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The San Francisco Police, especially during SOMA busts, will routinely
seize videotapes and film, and will beat and/or arrest the one doing
the filming.  Although these seizures are almost always illegal, no
one is held accountable. In addition, recordings that may convict the
police are routinely erased or otherwise destroyed, while those that
support the police are kept and used as evidence.

These are the facts of life. So if you record a bust in progress, be
prepared to physically beaten and possibly arrested, have your
equipment confiscated, and to have your film or tape destroyed if it
shows the police in the wrong. We are talking gang violence, and this
gang doesn't have to follow their own rules.

My advice is: Unless you are beaming the video signal to a remote tape
machine, or unless you have small army of damn lawyers to defend you
right there, don't bother taping the police. You'll likely be beaten
and arrested on a fake charge, your tape erased or lost, and even if
the charges are dropped, you may not get your gear back for a while.
At worst, your tape might be used in court against the promoters or
some of the guests. Best thing to do is immediately stop recording,
and deliberately but not hurriedly box the camera and secure any
tapes you have made so far.

The future may hold some hope, though.  At the raid of Terrance's AIDS
benefit, police illegally seized at least one camera and film. This
caused enough protest that the police chief said that officers would
be briefed on the rules regarding seizing recording devices. While I
don't expect this briefing to even happen, much less that it would
make a difference, the incident and protest does at least draw public
attention to the issue.  Further *loud* public protestations (like
perhaps picketing the police office) after further incidents may draw
more news media attention, and actually result in some change.

Sean

anyone personally so don't unsult him back on a prsonal level.  disgree
with his statement, sure, but he never questioned anyone's happiness.  his
point has been all along that there is a geographic and historical
situation that he wants to point out.  his closest to a criticism is that
a lot of really good people really loving each other does not necessarily
mean that the rave was well organised, that' s all - argue with that is
all.  :-)

Um, Fraser, you may want to peruse exactly what Tristan wrote, for I think
you might change your mind about blindly defending him.  I'll pull just one
passage of wisdom that wasn't (cough, coough) criticism:

> Date: 3/20/95 7:26 AM
> To: Nathan Moser
> From: Kevin Keiper
> Clearly you either went to different rave thren me or you were on so many
> good drugs that you would have had a good time in a concentration camp!
> F&F was, with out a doubt, the most badly organized party organized in SF
> in recent months...

I would say that his statement was not only criticism of both Nathan and
the organizers of F&F, it was a tasteless metaphor...

It is obnoxious, insulting material such as the above that leads generally
peaceful people to get upset;  especially considering that was the tip of
the flameburg.

Tony

        Reply to:   Nathan comments on RE>Nathan's comment
Geez, I don't check my email in fourteen hours and suddenly there's no 
less than six posts w/my name in the title! Fraser, is this a 
manifestation of pronoia? How does pronoia reconcile with ego-death in 
Zippie philosophy, anyway (seriously)?

BTW, I was at the first SF Megatripolis, and I liked it - lack of 
ventilation, less than perfect sound, weird water policy, and all! I didn't 
agree with all of what was put forth in the lectures (stopping the music 
in the middle was an adjustment, at first I thought it was a bust!). I didn't 
like all of the music. But in addition to the ideas and music I did like, I 
appreciated the effort and the strive to experiment. F&F, though very 
different, embodies those same qualities for me.

I think there's a culture clash going on here (as if that's not the obvious), 
but larger than SF rave vs UK rave. Rave in america is capturing the 
hearts and minds of those who want to be a part of but not be lead. There 
are plenty of protestant envangilists here to pick up the leftovers. 

Bootstrap us in? OK! Fall in line? Never!

Look at our politics - we tend to hate our leaders. Look at our favorite 
college professors - through the museum of ideas, they gently push from 
behind, never lead from the front without looking back. Like a kid with a 
chemistry set, we like to think we're discovering, even if we know plenty 
of people have already been there.

I'm not saying it's good/bad, advanced/behind, it's just there.

My favorite rave? The DJ's the interface, not the brain, he can't help it 
any more than you can stop dancing. The floor's crowded, no start, no end, 
no middle. An amorphous blob absorbing energy as it travels along. Starts 
at the bottom of the spine and builds and whoosh! up through your head! 
Sorry if that's already passe. Hell, I still buy baggy jeans!

We all have positive contributions to make. Fraser, even you! :-> 

love to all!
-nate

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 22 16:54:08 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id QAA12827; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 16:54:08 -0800
Received: from pilot.njin.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA12818; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 16:54:03 -0800
Received: (from csc@localhost) by pilot.njin.net (8.6.10+bestmx+oldruq+newsunq+grosshack/8.6.10) id TAA01654; Wed, 22 Mar 1995 19:54:02 -0500
Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 19:54:02 -0500
From: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>
Message-Id: <199503230054.TAA01654@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: How to deal with the Police
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last revised: 3/22/95

I've been to many many parties where the police showed up. Some were
busted, and some were left totally alone. This posting is based on my
first-hand observations both as a guest and as promoter, from talking
with other guests and promoters, and from talking with the police.

This advice is not designed to maximize the expression of one's
constitutional rights. The police can stomp on these at will, and
unless you have a _lot_ of money, you have no chance of successfully
fighting for these rights. Instead, this advice is designed to
maximize the chances of a good interaction with the police, and to
minimize the chances of getting shut down or arrested.

- Assign an ambassador.

  Decide who will talk to the police if they show. Ideally, this
  person should look at least 25, be friendly, cooperative, a fast
  thinker, and should not be intoxicated in any way. Get this person
  as soon as you see any police at all. They should meet the police
  outside and be the first person they talk to.

  Someone else should go inside and immediately check around and let
  people know the police are there, but that things are cool.


- Cooperate fully.

  Always do what the police tell you, and do it as quickly as
  possible.  If it will take a minute or more, tell them you are
  starting on it _right_now_, and that it should take X minutes to get
  done. Show a genuine willingness to carry out their orders. There is
  a certain amount of uncertainty in every situation they deal with;
  if you show them competent, immediate cooperation, their stress
  level will reduce dramatically.

  If they ask to come inside and look around, tell them "Sure, no
  problem at all." If you don't, then they will find some reason to
  shut the party down. Go with them if you can, and reassure guests
  and party workers that it's cool. The more relaxed you and everyone
  else is, the more relaxed the police will be. For all they know,
  they're walking into a riot. Show them a peaceful celebration.


- Be friendly to the police.

  Be absolutely friendly. The police have to deal with aggressive
  drunks, idiots, people who shouldn't drive, angry people, etc. all
  the time. They won't know what they're dealing with when they pull
  up, but if you are friendly and reasonable, they will love it.

  Introduce yourself. Ask them if everything is okay. If they ask
  what's going on, just say it's a big party you and your friends are
  having. If they ask who's responsible, say you are. If you want, you
  might explain that it's a cooperative effort, but still maintain
  responsibility. The police don't want to talk to 20 people. They
  want to talk to one.

  Treat them as guests.  They came by to check up on things, or maybe
  you screwed up and let it get too loud.  You didn't *think* you were
  doing anything wrong, but if they say you are then be genuinely
  regretful.


- Be truthful.

  Tell the truth as much as you possibly can. Nothing pisses off the
  police like a liar, and they can spot lies easily. And to them no
  one is as pathetic as someone who takes the easy bait they often
  hand out. The truth is often a point of view: One person's concert
  is another's punk drug fest. We're having a party, a celebration. If
  they ask if it's a rave, say something like: "It's not a rave; it's
  a house party, raves are much bigger and crazier." Or something like
  that.

  DON'T admit to illegal acts, or admit the blatant knowledge thereof.
  The answer to this is "No."


- Agree.

  Agree with the police as much as you can. Police have monster egos;
  if the average person hates to be wrong, imagine how much the police
  hate it. If they call you on something, fess up, and be regretful.
  If they say it's too loud, say "Damn! I was really hoping we
  wouldn't bother anyone." Or if you're on the wrong public land,
  "Yeah, we figured it might be risky coming here; it's just that this
  small group can't afford the permits." You get the idea.
  

- Negotiate.

  Once the police understand that things are under control, that your
  party is peaceful (if chaotic), don't be afraid to ask for lenience.
  Would it be okay if we turned it down and had someone check outside
  every so often to make sure it doesn't get too loud again? Can we go
  for just another couple of hours? Is there anything we can do so
  that the party can continue? Don't insist, just ask (or plead). It's
  sometimes surprising what they'll grant you.


- NEVER CONFRONT THE POLICE.

  Never ever try to block their way or stop anything they are doing.
  Don't lose your cool, grumble, or even look the slightest bit
  annoyed. You will lose. Give them any attitude at all, and they will
  beat you, arrest you, and charge you with assault on a police
  officer and obstructing a police officer. Then they will then shut
  the party down no matter what, even if it has all the proper
  permits. More people may be roughed up, and they will issue as many
  citations as they can possibly think of.


- SEARCHES

  Always grant police permission to look around the party space. Never
  grant permission for a personal search or a car search. "I'd rather
  you didn't. I really don't like other people touching my property."


- ARRESTS

  If you are arrested or otherwise restrained, don't answer any
  questions except your name. Say "My lawyer told me to never ever
  talk to the police unless I talk with him first." Stick with that no
  matter what. At that point, you can probably only hurt your legal
  stance by talking. It may also improve your chances of being simply
  let go. When in doubt, be silent.

Sean

To: SCRUTON@PAELE.dnet.hac.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: if you like meth...
In-Reply-To: <01HO3BBLWKW200LH9Y@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
References: <01HO3BBLWKW200LH9Y@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

SCRUTON@PAELE.dnet.hac.com writes:
 > 
 > then you're torching the environment, whether you know it or not.
 > 
 > the la times today mentioned that the EPA has to be called in to
 >   clean up meth labs when they bust them, because of the amatuerish
 >     and haphazard way in which toxins are handled.  in most cases,
 >       they just get dumped.
 > 
 > ...can you say "poison the neighborhood"?

Of course they have to call the EPA; the police can't just throw a
container of thionyl chloride, sodium borohydride, or many of the
other corrosive, poisonous, and water-reactive reagents into the trunk
of the police cruiser. They have to be put into proper containers and
shipped carefully.

Whether any of these would be poisonous after being "dumped down the
sink" is another issue entirely. Most of them you wouldn't pour down
the sink unreacted because they would explode or start fires or
produce clouds of deadly gas (like chlorine).  What gets washed down
the sink is mostly by-products.  Whether or not these are toxic has
not been stated, though I imagine an adventurous chemist could figure
what they are.

If you're interested in the Material Safety and Data Sheets for a lot
of chemicals, visit <gopher://atlas.chem.utah.edu/11/MSDS>.

The real villian is the FDA and our legislators, who create the
illegal market in the first place. Legal commercial production would
(probably) be less messy and risky.

Sean

> > On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:

> > > 
> > > well, too bad f&f did not last all night.  *sigh*  a lot of planning
> > > and heart went into it, but due to overcrowding unfortunately things
> > > did not go as planned.
> > > 
> > > in my mind, it will always be what someone (philip, maybe?) dubbed it
> > > the night of:  the Japanese bullet train party.  i have never in my
> > > life seen so many people jammed so tight into a place before.  it was
> > > absolutely terrifying at first, but then i started to kind of like it.
> > > i guess you all remember the orginal complaints about the kommotion
> > > parties?  that they were too crowded!  do you remember the anonymous
> > > complaint to the fire marshall about this particular thing?  whew!
> > > 
> > > a very weird dynamic was operating that night:  even though people were
> > > crammed in like sardines, it seemed like nobody wanted to leave.  people
> > > kept advising eachother:  better not go out or you won't get back in!
> > > also, once i got used to the press and the heat, i started kind of liking
> > > the vibe of being part of the bullet train, rocketing at the speed of
> > > light to goddess-knows-where.
> > > 
> > > the music i heard that night was infused with insane energy..the dj's
> > > were responding to the crowding, i bet.  and the ambient room was outa-
> > > sight.  thank you new moon!  (i didn't help set up so i am not being
> > > a narcissist here)
> > > 
> > > all that said, i thank our lucky stars that the worst that happened was
> > > that the party got shut down.  like i said, i was terrified that any
> > > second somebody was going to start freaking out.  but the vibe held,
> > > thank you thank you thank you.
> > > 
> > > here's my suggestions for the future..i hope they help:
> > > 
> > > (1) raise the price, but let people who want to help set up, break
> > > down, get in for free.  $5 (was that the price?) is too little.
> > > 
> > > (2) don't encourage people to get there early anymore.  
> > > 
> > > (3) make sure you have experienced door people working the door...
> > > (or at least folks with thick skins who can keep smiling no matter what)
> > > 
> > > (4) sell half as many tickets as you think the space will hold and
> > > get ready to take people's money at the door.  because the night of, the
> > > location WILL get out!
> > > 
> > > well, i know many of you of course disagree with my suggestions, (i'm
> > > betting the price one will rankle) but they are just one girl's ideas
> > > so please don't be offended.  all in all, i thought it was an absolutely
> > > incredible party while it lasted, despite the various problems.
> > > 
> > > oh yes, one more thing:  i think it's time to move ff to the richmond
> > > civic center.  (hee hee!)

this.

there with POSTITIVITY, and lots of it!!!!!!!! You may bring toys,

( sung to a fire and brimstone repent repent dirge)

In a perfect world of divine justice, every american would have a "my
country consumes 75% of the worlds resources" tattooed on their forehead.

You should all be ashamed of yourselves. Its like one week, this list is
tallking about harmony and the next week its dissing any target it can lay
its hands on. YOU ARE ALL AN EXAMPLE of the schizofrenic society you live
in, which is one of those  in where we see " this is my brain as a human,
this is my brain when I channel surf."

I am quite prepared to unsubsribe from this list, and continue my activites
elsewhere if this methamphetamine enduced tirade goes on longer.

Quite frankly I have a hard time just finding an argument why the entire
American Continent should not be wiped off the face of this earth, so lets
just forget this little episode of unbridled xenophobia.

While we go about examining the mote in each others eye, let remind
ourselves that there are none more guilty than ourselves, so lets all drop
this shit and get on with changing the world and RAVING or are we just
another brand of rock n roll?

david dei

Dear David,
   Just because you're a little mad from the recent flamage must you
insult the ENTIRE list with the tired old UK is better and you are
all on meth bullshit flamebait. It is probably clear to most on SFR that
things will be fine here without your input as self-appointed
visionary/legend in your own mind. It has nothing to do with xenophobia,
only this tactless, self-important attitude which IMO is rubbing the list the
wrong way. Note that you don't hear anyone flaming other (big) UK contibutors
to our scene.
   What in the hell does group flaming all americans have to do with
pronoia?  What makes you think that the members of this list are
stereotypically american? (heavy consumers, TV watchers, etc). Please 
return from the land of the clueless.

peaceout,

Lurker Lane

On Wed, 22 Mar 1995 deluxe@slip.net wrote:

> >kevin is responding to the feedback.  what is wrong with that?  it is
> >called communication.  we don't always expect to agree.  god knows *I*
> >have been accused often enough of expecting everyone to agree with us
> >zippies. anyone notice me complaining?   fraser
> >
> 
> 
> I have no problems with communication, but "beating a dead horse" only
> wastes bandwidth....
> 
> 
> Brian


surely in this case it's Kevin who's the horse that's getting beaten but
refuses to be dead.  ?:-) 
and I do grant and have already that he hasn't been the coolest and most
"polite" of people.  actually I think the old anglo saxon is causing a lot
of these cultural problems.  are the pagan Brits just too foulmouthed
maybe, given to just a bit more unkempt colorful speech? we're used to it
and don't notice.  
that's probably worth a thread all to itself, might unravel soem of these
kinds of problems, but it's not the thread I'm going to get into now. 
however, just to expand this thread one more inch, I'd like to quote what
an american buddy of mine in europe once told me: "ya know why there's
this bit of an anti-yank thing over here?  it's because our fathers bought
your mothers for a night for a pair of nylon stockings after the war." 
>:-) (smiley raver in hat)

the point I *would* like to develop a litle further is about "cool" becuse
that's really kevin's problem here.  "cool" is probably the most populr
saying in US culture right now.  now the last time the word "cool" was 
the in-thing was in the mid sixties just before "Hippy" burst upon the 
scene.  at parties everybody used to
stand around posed and "cool" and then suddenly one day the door burst
open and the hippy stumbled in, promptly fell flat on hir face while
mumbling some cosmic theory, got up, and babbled about Life and the
Evolution.  the Hippy was *hot*. it was all too real for him to be "cool".
that is what I think is happening to american culture right now.  RC (Rave
Culture) is the leading edge of that.  the cool thing for kevin to do
would be to withdraw.  but he feels too *hot* about this stuff, it's too
important to him to pretend he doesn't care any more. a couple of years
ago I heard a zippy raver protesting to an older New Age type:  "I'm
talking about saving the fucking planet and you're wasting bandwidth
complaining about me swearing!!!?" 
(not true about "bandwidth") 
fraser.

On Wed, 22 Mar 1995 medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU wrote:

> I missed a group reaction to"coming up yer ass." > > Now I'm pissed. I
love that song. It sounds friggin' awesome on acid. > > That people can't
take it, well, I guess that applies to anal sex!:) > > Allen, keep doing
that voodoo that you do so well! > > remeber, chill does not mean

for that. Harsh sounds are not always evil, scary > shit.  > 


well here's my view (and if you want it in writing that I'm not trying to
enslave or colonise you or limit your freedom or something you got it):-
Megatripolis allows no negative images anywhere.  we've debated this for
years and it's perfectly clear to me.  while I'm perfectly aware that art
should include the light and the dark our conclusion is that we get the
harsh dark up the ass 6 days a week and the aim of a truly healthy club is
to redress that bzlance to the healing light as much as it can in the
limited time that it has. but, of course, you do wot u like, mate! :-) (do
I *really* need to add that every time I say something I stronlgy
believe?)

fraser.

On Wed, 22 Mar 1995, Geoff White wrote:

> > actually I was talking about Summer of Love in the '60s (hence the "Rave 
> > Style")
> >  fraser
> 
> Umm. So were we :)
> 
> If you had been here in '92 then you would realize that the same energy
> that was responsible for the summer of love in '67 was here in full effect
> in the summer of '92, so far nothing has come close to the vibe that was 
> released that summer, but there's always hope.

While there is definately no way to top the size of that summer, I'd say
it shouldn't be to hard to top the "vibe" aspect of it. I myself would
prefer a small intimate "summer of love" full of dedicated people, then
the big one full of people going out because it was the new "cool" thing
to do, that we got in '92. How many of those so called dedicated "ravers"
do you see going out now. While there is no doubt the summer of '92 went
the fuck off energy wise, I beleive the dedication to the way of life was
missing.  

		Josh

yes, vladimir, let's move on to more positive stuff. others can point you
to internet stuff on the zippies more accurately than I, a mere internet
beginner.  but I could start with a definition of zippy.  a zippy is
someone (ANYONE, whether he's ever heard of me or anything) who, seeing
the imbalance between hir 2 hemnsipheres, HIPPY & Tecnoperson (Raver), is
trying to harmonise hir hemispheres, both in hirself and on hir planet. 
Rainbow Ravers.  it's not something you JOIN and, in my experience, most
thinking ravers, on first hearing about it, realise they already are
zippies. so all it does is help focus what we're all about.  and 
sometimes it helps you see allies where you never suspected them and also 
sometimes helps you see that so-called freinds & allies are, in fact, 
not.  a "capitalist pig" business man who's doing a yoga class is as 
much a zippy as a hippy who's starting hir own little hemp business, see? 

could go on and on, but ask another question, and let's see if we can't 
slowly move this ship into calmer and more focused waters.  
fraser
