Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 09:37:21 -0800
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199503231737.JAA01004@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: ANNOUNCE: RaveMed call for participation
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


		        R A V E  -  M E D
		        _________________

	RaveMed is a special program for special people.  Over the last
	few years, something very special has been happening to, and
	with, the young people of this planet.  Through the medium of
	all night dance parties, young people (of all ages) have learned
	to re-connect with themselves, each other, and the planet at
	large.  A new form of tribalism has emerged, but this is not
	the tribalism of promoting a single family clan or lineage, the
	CyberTribe is global in it's ancestral home and incorporates
	families of every, shape, color and hue.  In it's zeal to expand,
	become aware, and to reach out to other aspects of itself,
	sometimes the urgency of forming and having a gathering has
	caused certain safety aspects to be over looked.  It is the
	purpose of RaveMed to step out and fill the gap that can make
	these gatherings safe, healthy, fun and enlightening.

	RaveMed is designed to train participants to be more
	responsible and aware of the safety and well being of
	themselves, the people around them, and the community at large
	(which ultimately includes the entire planet).  Participants
	receive training in CPR/First Aid, Drug Awareness, Aids/HIV
	awareness, basic ecology, and crisis counceling.  Introductory
	elements of all of these principles are taught over a 1 month
	period on 4 successive Saturdays (8 a.m. to 5 p.m.) with two
	evening classes per week in between the saturdays (Monday,
	Thursday, 7 - 10pm).  On the forth saturday the group goes on
	an "Expedition" to a state park or other remote area to
	practice what they have learned, to perform some service (like
	cleaning up a beach) and to have a graduation ceremony.  It is
	the goal of the program to train a group of individuals that
	can be available, free of charge as a safety team for all night
	dance parties in urban as well as remote venues.  It is hoped
	that the skills learned in the program will not only benefit
	the "Rave" community as a whole but will be taken out into the
	world at large. It is also hoped that through this program a
	bridge can be built between the Rave Community at large and
	other elements of society who have it in their charter to look
	after the safety and well-being of individuals.  Our work and
	effort is based on the premise that there is nothing wrong with
	dancing all night, it is the birthright of every individual
	on this planet, as long as it is done with the safety and
	respect of the participants and the community at large.  To
	this end, we dedicate this program.

	Here is a very preliminary outline of what will be taught:


	Week 1:
		Monday:	Orientation, history, affinity groups
	      Thursday:	What is responsibility, rave related safety, sound/laser
	      Saturday:	CPR/First Aid instruction

	Week 2:
		Monday:	safety drill, CPR practice
	      Thursday:	anatomy of consciousness
	      Saturday:	Drug Awareness training

	Week 3:
		Monday:	Drug emergency drills, legal issues
	      Thursday:	Interacting with authority, Police officer visit
	      Saturday:	Crisis Counceling, Strategic Questioning

	Week 4:
		Monday:	Drills, expedition planning
	      Thursday:	expedition planning
	      Saturday:	Expedition, ecology workshop,clean-up, graduation
		Sunday:	Clean-Up group sharing, ecology workshop






	If you can help out in anyway shape or form PLEASE contact me,

	Geoff at ravemed@nexsys.net. Specifically we need people who
	are certified CPR/First Aid instructors, Drug Awareness instructors
	people with experience in crisis counceling, lawyers, police
	officers willing to talk openly before a group and many others.
	If you can donate anything to the cause please contact me at the
	e-mail address above or at (415)965-2384.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 
Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>

	              RAVE: For a better tomorrow

		--PGP Public key available upon request--
     "If I can't trance, I don't want to be part of your revolution"

if anyone out there thinks we are all slaves under this democracy, let's
  think back over whut we mite've done the past week....


   were you able to go wherever you wanted? were you able to drive a
     car down any street? (construction zones not included)

   were you able to go to the store and buy any type of food for your
     family so they could get proper nourishment?

   were you able to say what you wanted to whoever you wanted? (this
     list is a prime example of that)

   when you went home, were all the neighbors recording your every move
     so they could relay that to neighborhood fink squads?

   has anyone in your family vanished without a trace after annoying
     the government?

   if you want to change your career, do you have to ask the government
     first?


let's face it; in a lot of third world (and even some first world) 
  countries, these above conditions occur daily!
it's true that sometimes authorities here overstep their bounds, but
  there's usually a public outcry at the very least; in a authoritarian
    state, you don't get no chance to outcry unless you want something
      to get chopped off yer body

by and large, things aren't too bad here in the US; of course, that
  shouldn't encourage apathy like you see in the suburban dream, where
    people think they've already "got it all"......

(flame retardant on)

Dave Scruton

some evidence of our longevity: 
1)a video of ethan dancing @ marx meadow with andrew in a baby backpack. 
2)a tape of scott hardkiss playing a GOOD groove @da DNA on one of those
eternal sunday mornings 
3)tape of B.R.A.D. tearing up @ FLOPPY'S(do any of you old schoolers
remember mr. floppy? 
4)staff buttons from PSYCHIC T.V.'s first U.S. appearance @ (again) mr.
floppy's 
5)many bad memories of Toontown @ 177 Townsend 
6)over 500 hours of tape of almost every dj that has ever graced a pair of
decks in sf 
7)a whole house decorated almost exclusively with rave memorabilia 
8)about 20 lbs of flyers(very few duplicates),dating back as far as
1990,from all over the world. 
 
this is turning my hair grey... 
there are a lot of us "ol'timers" amongst you all, so any time any of you
want to study some history... 
 
peace&positivity, 
g-n-c 
house archives

take your words into consideration.

> 
> if anyone out there thinks we are all slaves under this democracy, let's
>   think back over whut we mite've done the past week....
> 
> 
>    were you able to go wherever you wanted? were you able to drive a
>      car down any street? (construction zones not included)
> 
	no, i don't have a car, can't afford one.


>    were you able to go to the store and buy any type of food for your
>      family so they could get proper nourishment?
	
	no, i have to limit my food-buying to what fits in my budget, and sadly, 
	organically-grown food, IMO the only really healthy food one can eat, 
	tends to be more expensive.

> >    were you able to say what you wanted to 
	whoever you wanted? (this list is a prime example of that)
> 
	no - i'd like to have my views published all over the country, 
	not only on the net (which isn't accessible to that many people), but 
	it's simply too costly	

>    has anyone in your family vanished without a trace after annoying
>      the government?

	no, but i know of many U.S. political prisoners who are, in a sense, 
	"family"> 

> 
> 
> let's face it; in a lot of third world (and even some first world) 
>   countries, these above conditions occur daily!
> it's true that sometimes authorities here overstep their bounds, but
>   there's usually a public outcry at the very least; in a authoritarian
>     state, you don't get no chance to outcry unless you want something
>       to get chopped off yer body
> 
> by and large, things aren't too bad here in the US; of course, that
>   shouldn't encourage apathy like you see in the suburban dream, where
>     people think they've already "got it all"......
> 
> (flame retardant on)
> 
> Dave Scruton
> 

granted, i have a better life here in the u.s. than i might in a third 
world country (unless of course i were part of the priveleged elite in 
that country).  however, things ARE bad here in the u.s. - look at the # 
of homeless, look at the money spent on "defense" and what's left over 
for social programs...

i don't think we are "slaves in this democracy" - but i do not think this 
is a democracy!  real democracy is participatory, and is inconsistent 
with capitalism - we all do not have equal voices here, and it should be 
obvious who controls our government.  

oh, and regarding a "public outcry" at injustice - usually there's one 
only if people involved have the time, and the resources, and the 
know-how to organize, and even then most of the press may censor it.

in love and @,

monicat

> 
> 
> well here's my view (and if you want it in writing that I'm not trying to
> enslave or colonise you or limit your freedom or something you got it):-
> Megatripolis allows no negative images anywhere.  we've debated this for
> years and it's perfectly clear to me.  while I'm perfectly aware that art
> should include the light and the dark our conclusion is that we get the
> harsh dark up the ass 6 days a week and the aim of a truly healthy club is
> to redress that bzlance to the healing light as much as it can in the
> limited time that it has. but, of course, you do wot u like, mate! :-) (do
> 
> fraser.

okay, what exactly is a negative image?  i don't know the song "coming up 
yer ass" (but if someone wants to play it for me that would be rad!), but 
if it has to do with buttsex, how is that negative?  buttsex is a 
wonderful form of sexual activity ...

so what is a negative image?  we could agree that "violent" images are 
negative, but sometimes there's a grey area: for instance, images of 
consensual sm ... violent to some, ecstatic to others...

myself, i prefer life-affirming "images" at parties.  but sometimes a 
good dark techno set (provided the vibe/atmosphere at the party is not 
dark), which moves into joy and celebration, is what i need!

>(You missed the party dude! :)


WELL THEN WHAT SHOULD WE CALL IT?
I hereby declare a competition for the naming of the child we are about to
birth this summer - globally.
LOVE has a good ring to it, but the media need to have an easy entry point.
Lets see, if we can tie this in with the UN 50 anniversary - United Nations
of Love? (calling it UN OF RAVE is too exclusive) any ideas??

- david dei

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 23 13:51:49 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA29371; Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:51:49 -0800
Received: from shell1.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA29362; Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:51:45 -0800
Received: from [204.156.129.173] (megatrip.vip.best.com [204.156.129.173]) by shell1.best.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA12721 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:51:23 -0800

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:53:23 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)
Subject: NEWS: U.S.-Human Rights: Washington Faces Test At U.N. Hearings
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

we definitely need a more representative structure - does the following
story about a particular country wish you could vote for a better reality?

>U.S.-Human Rights: Washington Faces Test At U.N. Hearings
>
>   By Farhan Haq
>
>United Nations, Mar 22 (IPS) - The United States may face an
>uphill battle next week when it appears for the first time
>before  the U.N. human rights committee here, rights groups say.
>
>   Washington faces a particularly thorny problem over both its
>low level of compliance with U.N. and international human rights
>covenants, and the qualifications it has attached to those few
>covenants it has signed.
>
>   ''Things look set to get pretty hot next week,'' predicts
>Andrew Clapham, a spokesman for Amnesty International, the
>London-based rights group. The U.S. delegation will meet the
>human rights committee in New York next Wednesday.
>
>   Clapham argues that the U.S. position on the death penalty
>may  prove a bone of contention at a time when recent U.N.
>covenants  seek to limit capital punishment, if not ban it
>altogether.
>
>   The United States maintains the right to execute juveniles
>below the age of 18, in defiance of the international covenant
>on  civil and political rights (ICCPR), which Washington
>ratified in  1992. Such a practice violates article six of the
>covenant.
>
>   But in ratifying the covenant, Washington added a reservation
>to the effect that U.S. states may continue to abide by laws
>allowing minors to be executed. It has held fast to that stance
>even though, Clapham notes, the ICCPR specifically listed
>article  six as a 'non-derogable' right from which countries
>cannot depart  even during national emergencies.
>
>   Since 1990, the United States has executed more juveniles
>than  all of the rest of the world put together. Over that time,
>six  children were executed in the United States, and one each
>in Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and Yemen. By the end of last year,
>amnesty estimated that 37 juveniles faced death sentences in 12
>U.S. states.
>
>   Washington has similarly entered reservations to clauses in
>both the ICCPR and the convention on torture which prohibit
>''cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment''. The United States
>says it will comply with those laws only if they do not go
>beyond the protections of the U.S. constitution's own
>prohibition on ''cruel and unusual punishment''.
>
>   ''The lengthy reservations that the United States attaches to
>ratifications of covenants ensures that it is not taking any new
>steps'' to comply with the standards, an analyst at New York's
>lawyers' committee for human rights notes.
>
>   ''That essentially misses the point,'' the analyst, speaking
>on condition of anonymity, argues. The U.N. Human Rights
>Committee has made clear that no country can attach so many
>reservations that it effectively commits itself to doing
>nothing, she adds.
>
>   Washington's unwillingness to face any international scrutiny
>is a mystery to many rights activists who point to the U.S.
>penchant for prodding other nations to improve their human
>rights  performance.
>
>   ''We use the process when it works for us, but don't want the
>process when it works against us,'' contends Morton Sklar, who
>chairs the Science and Human Rights Programme at the Washington-
>based American Association for the Advancement of Science.
>
>   But Sklar adds that the United States has improved its human
>rights posture in recent years, after decades of refusing to
>adhere to most of the international covenants on prisoner's,
>women and children's rights.
>
>   The United States has ratified only 11 of 25 international
>rights covenants, leaving it ''pretty low on the totem pole,''
>Sklar says. But, although it has many rulings to ratify, Sklar
>believes that momentum to adhere to international rights
>covenants has gained speed.
>
>   ''It took years for us to get to the point we're at now,'' he
>notes. Sklar contends that, during the 1950s and much of the
>1960s, Washington resisted any outside scrutiny of its domestic
>policy because of its racially discriminatory laws against black
>people.
>
>   With the scrapping of the racially exclusive 'Jim Crow' laws
>since that era, the United States has been more ready to face
>any  examination of its laws and practices. But some racially-
>tinged  subjects -- notably the rights of prisoners and the
>death penalty --  remain off limits.
>
>   In a report released this week on U.S. human rights, Amnesty
>International argues that, ''despite judicial safeguards, the
>death penalty remains both unfair and discriminatory in
>practice.''
>
>   Amnesty's research shows that killers of white people earn
>the  death penalty far more often than killers of blacks,
>although  blacks and whites are homicide victims in roughly
>equal numbers.
>
>   The report adds that the death penalty ''is imposed
>disproportionately on the poor, minorities, the mentally ill or
>retarded and those without adequate legal counsel.''
>
>   Ill treatment in police custody or in prison is also common,
>amnesty says. The rights group says that the U.S. prison
>population of 1.4 million people confronts a growing number of
>abuses, from beatings and restraints to denial of medical care.
>
>   ''The massive increase in the U.S. prison population in the
>past few years appears to have ... led to an increase in the
>incidence of ill treatment in some states,'' it adds. The United
>States now has one of the highest rates of incarceration in the
>world, and the country's prisons contain more young black men
>than its universities. (end/ips/fah/jl/95)
>
>

                           Megatripolis Parallel University
                                     megatrip@best.com

good music if you can ignore the subset of 1015 patrons who won't be there
for the music.  I may head out to Pure Space tonight and get more flyers
and post an update tomorrow...  Most of the new stuff here is stuff
people have been sending me - thanks!  (you know who you are)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.07.9503222115.A9386-c100000@indigo.ucdavis.edu>

Anybody who thinks the SF rave scene is not xenophobic is, quite frankly, 
talking out of their arse.  I have been going to raves here for over a 
year and a half and I could probably count the number of African 
Americans I have seen on my finger's (all right, that is a slight 
over-statement).  (And, as everybody is probably sick of hearing this 
(particually if you are American) again) It's not like that in England.  
Here everything is segrergated and the rave scene is no exception.  In 
England white people go reggae and hip-hop clubs with-out thinking 
twice but here I don't even know where decent hip-hop clubs and reggae 
clubs/parties are.  This is because the music at raves here is segragated 
as well where as in England we played raggae, acid jazz, old funk/rock; 
different floors, different kinds of music.  That way different people 
turn for the different music and then have the oppotunity to get into the 
other kinds of music their as well.  There used to be a club in London 
where their was a goth room, a raggae/dub room, a techno room, and a 
retro chill-out room (and many a great raver was born out of that scene; 
let me tell you.....).  This is how you get a mixture at parties because 
the strength of any scene comes from the power of the excellence of it's 
music and different kinds of music attract different kinds of people.  
But nobody here is interested in doing that.  And why should they when 
their are thousands and thousands of white trash kids just lining up with 
their $10
And this go's to heart of America.  In England we have a much more sense 
of us (ie the poor) against them situation whereas here it is poor white 
against poor black, poor white against poor white, rich black verses rich 
white and so on; not good.  All of my friends are very cool but even only 
they have one or two friends who are African American.  In England half 
my friends where African English yet here I have only ever met the 
Africans Americans that my friends know.  Why?  Because when I go out to 
raves all I meet are white kids because they are the only ones who go to 
raves here.  If a club/space was used for the idea I mentioned above I 
feel that, with-in a year that the SF scene would be long way down the 
path to solving the problem.  Don't forget that until the Acid House 
scene of 1986 that we in Britain got over this problem and this was one 
of the ways that we did it; it worked in 1986 and it particually worked 
well in 1991 when the techno scene in England was starting to kick off.  
Because don't forget that acid house/rave music was mostly written by 
whites as well (they were certainly the caterlyst) and the African English 
got into it at a later date.  It is a good idea; it worked before.
David is quite right with what he was saying.  Right on!
Yours Tristan.

> if anyone out there thinks we are all slaves under this democracy, let's
>   think back over whut we mite've done the past week....
> 
> 
>    were you able to go wherever you wanted? were you able to drive a
>      car down any street? (construction zones not included)
> 
>    were you able to go to the store and buy any type of food for your
>      family so they could get proper nourishment?
> 
>    were you able to say what you wanted to whoever you wanted? (this
>      list is a prime example of that)
> 
>    when you went home, were all the neighbors recording your every move
>      so they could relay that to neighborhood fink squads?
> 
>    has anyone in your family vanished without a trace after annoying
>      the government?
> 
>    if you want to change your career, do you have to ask the government
>      first?
> 
> 
> let's face it; in a lot of third world (and even some first world) 
>   countries, these above conditions occur daily!
> it's true that sometimes authorities here overstep their bounds, but
>   there's usually a public outcry at the very least; in a authoritarian
>     state, you don't get no chance to outcry unless you want something
>       to get chopped off yer body
> 
> by and large, things aren't too bad here in the US; of course, that
>   shouldn't encourage apathy like you see in the suburban dream, where
>     people think they've already "got it all"......
> 
> (flame retardant on)

I think you are probably right, dave.  I noticed in the original Glabal 
Solar Cenemonies posted by Dan that this new age of knowledge was 
preceded by the age of belief and wondered if a lot of these 
very-touchy-seeming comments I've been attracting every time I open my 
mouth is people rebelling against the age of belief.  if that's the case 
may I make it clear (yet again) that I would be totally stupified (not to 
say bored stiff) if people "followed" what I'm saying.  think and then, if 
eventually convinced, act. but I'm certainly not going to stop saying 
what I *know*.   fraser

> encouraged for countless generations. Let's not give them any help.

From: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Drugs & criminals (a long story)
X-Mailer: UGate [Ver. 1.94]

>property (money, houses, cars) confiscated even > before charges

I'd just like to tell ya'll a little story about something that 
happened to a friend and me about a week ago:

It was 3am and my friend was leaving my house. My dog and I were 
walking him out to his car. We were chit-chatting, saying goodnight, 
etc. The police were around the corner and up the street a 1/2 block 
conducting a neighborhood sweep. A cop, in  car, was leaving the 
sweep but saw us from his car. He screeched to a halt, jumped out of 
his car with billy club in hand, and told us not to move. He asked 
what we were doing and we told him. He asked for IDs. Mine was 
upstairs in my apartment and I told him that. He confiscated cash 
from both my friend and me. He took $110 from my friend and the fresh 
$20 I had stuffed into my pocket after going to the ATM a few hours 
earlier. He was able to confiscate this cash because we were standing 
on the street at what is considered by the "norm" to be an odd hour 
to be awake and standing on the street, and because my neighborhood 
is a known "crack" neighborhood.

To my knowledge there is no curfew in Oakland. I have no warrants, 
I've never been arrested for anything, my ID is current (but he 
wouldn't let me get it from upstairs), I live in the building in 
front of which my friend and I were standing, my friend had an 18x24" 
sketch pad under his arm...an unlikely item for a crack dealer to be 
carrying, I think. Yet the Oakland police confiscated our cash and 
now I have to take a copy of my paycheck stub, with a date no more 
than a month old, downtown for verification and then they will mail 
me a reimbursement check...10 working days after I produce my paycheck 
stub!

Who is the criminal in this picture?! And I wonder what the cop might 
have done to us had it *not* been so obvious that we are not crack 
dealers?

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 17:19:33 -0800
Subject: A Blast from the Past

In view of all the snarling on the list here the last couple of days,
I went back and looked at some of the archives from the spring of 1993
(available on hyperreal).  While there were disagreements and so forth,
what strikes me is how heartfelt the feelings were about the scene then,
people really trying to think clearly and express their thoughts about
the changes occurring at the time and the reasons for us to be involved.

We can't keep saying the same things over and over again, that's not
what I'm after here.  My point is, let's keep our attention on what's
happening now and avoid the personalized attacks and especially the
generalizations ("all X are Y") which overshoot the point one has to
make and elicit equally overbroad counter-reactions from those who
feel (often incorrectly) that they are being attacked.  

It was just about two years ago that Malachy was badly injured in a car
wreck on the way back from a Full Moon massive.  I still think that was
a pivotal moment for the SF house/techno/rave/underground, because it
meant he could no longer shoulder the burden of being the focal point
for underground events, which was becoming overwhelming in any event.
And that led, in many ways, to Friends & Family and many other good
things that have happened in spite of the difficulties we've been through.

Right now, it's just about springtime, even up here in rainy Portland, and
I'm looking at the very faint outlines of a rainbow right outside the
window where I'm typing this.  It's a reminder to me that here we are
on this planet, it's the only one we've got, and we owe it some attention
and each other some respect (if not complete agreement!), or what's the
point?

c u in the future
phred

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 18:36:34 -0800
To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>,
        "M. Lane Gilchrist" <gilchris@indigo.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re: SFRAVES XENOPHOBIA
Cc: David Dei <megatrip@best.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com

I'm not surprised to see Tristan extolling the virtues of UK society
in the sense that there is more racial integration there.  At some
levels this is true and some it is not; it is also true that there
is far more overt racism and violence in Britain.  It's not for nothing
that Gary Clail declaims against "bigotry, intolerance and *racial*
intolerance" in "Human Nature."  

Furthermore, to claim that the rave scene in the UK circa 1986 brough
the youth of different races together for the first time is simply
nonsense.  That era played an important and heartening role, in my view,
to restrengthening ties of a historical nature that go back through the
Mod and Two-Tone era of 1979 (when I was last in Britain), Two-Tone being
the record label and an explicit recognition of the multi-racial 
characteristics of the Mod Revival of the time featuring bands like The
Selecter, and the broad support at the time across racial boundaries for
bands like The Clash (remember "Guns of Brixton" and even "White Riot"
and "White Man in Hammersmith Palais") and dub poet Linton Kwesi Johnson.

For more on all this, consult Dick Hebdige's seminal little book, "Cut
'n' Mix," which is not only an excellent backgrounder to the UK music
scene but also does a musical/cultural analysis better than almost
anything non-academic I've read.

And you don't have to stop in the late 1970s to trace these developments.
You can go back further to the era of the original Mods and
Teddies, and even the original Mod anthem, "Skinhead Moonstomp," when
there were no racist skinheads, just kids who preferred to shave off their
hair the way that others of the time were growing it long.  

I'm not going to teach the cultural history of Britain to those who were
born and have lived there, of course; but I am trying to get across my
limited historical knowledge on this issue.  I am very wary of overwrought
claims on behalf of the house/rave/techno/underground, feeling as I do 
that the changes and advances that it has already made and continues to
make are amazing and valid enough in themselves. 

Most of the analysis I've read says that social divisions in the UK are
far more determined by class than race, but that race continues to play
a complicating role as always in these matters.  

While in San Francisco many events attract mostly a white audience, many
others have more of a mixture; that's one of the things that attracted me
to this scene to begin with, and it's still the case to some degree at the
clubs.  Although it is definitively a *club* night with little raver
overtones, I think that the Friday night combined clubs at 1015 Folsom are
heading in a good direction, with the totally cool hip hop Dig club on 
the upstairs floor (we had Charlotte just freakin' totally last Friday,
meanwhile my friend DJ Collage who did the chant on Dub Tribe's "Mother
Earth" is chatting up the lyrics to "Original Nuttah" right in time
with her beat, which just made me crack up), the original disco-city
crowd in the smaller downstairs room, Mark Farina spinning outstanding
trippy jazz and house for Zendada in the basement, and Tracy, Simon,
Jeno and Spun twisting our minds and jackin' our bodies under the aegis
of Mark Ameba and Brothers & Sisters in the main room.  And like I said,
despite the fact it's a *club* crowd, it's mixed by race, gender, age,
presumably sexual orientation and everything else.  Not a perfect mix,
but a mix.  And the same can be found in varying degrees at DV8 and the
Sound Factory too.  

The point is,

You've got to remember, we're all part of the same family.

phred

By the way, Tristan is dead wrong about one thing.  There were definitely
important white producers in the early acid house scene, but here I think
the definitive thing you can say is that house and acid house came out
of Chicago, New York and (branching off into the real, early techno)
Detroit, then London, primarily out of clubs that catered to a large
degree to the black gay disco crowd.  Like any generalization, this is
not entirely true, but it's a realistic way of summing it up.  Let's 
give credit where due, but let's not forget that house music, and all music,
belongs to no single person or group, it belongs to us all, and it's up
to us to listen, learn, enjoy, teach and create it as fits our own
circumstances.  I hope we can put *this* particular issue to rest.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 23 20:15:56 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id UAA28747; Thu, 23 Mar 1995 20:15:56 -0800

>if anyone out there thinks we are all slaves under this democracy, let's
>  think back over whut we mite've done the past week....
>
>
>   were you able to go wherever you wanted? were you able to drive a
>     car down any street? (construction zones not included)
>
>   were you able to go to the store and buy any type of food for your
>     family so they could get proper nourishment?
>
>   were you able to say what you wanted to whoever you wanted? (this
>     list is a prime example of that)
>
>   when you went home, were all the neighbors recording your every move
>     so they could relay that to neighborhood fink squads?
>
>   has anyone in your family vanished without a trace after annoying
>     the government?
>
>   if you want to change your career, do you have to ask the government
>     first?
>
 My definition of freedom extends beyond whether I am able to drive a car
to the store to by food. Having food and a car does not mean you are a free
person.  Here are just a few things that I can't do as citizen of the US:

1. I can't choose what I would like to ingest in my body to alter my
consciousness.  In fact, if I am suspected of using or selling these
illegal chemicals and plants the government can tap my phone, search my
house, etc. If I am found guilty of having illegal plants or chemicals then
the government can put me in a jail cell as well as seize my house, car,
computer or anything else they would like. Millions of dollars are spent
trying to catch people who use these chemicals or plants.  Nearly 10
million people have been put in jail since the 60's for marijuanna alone.
Most of these were for possesion of under an ounce.  That is not freedom.

2. I can't feed the homeless.  More than 700 people were arrested last year
in SF for feeding the hungry and the homeless. If you want to know more
about this than I suggest looking into Food Not Bombs.  They are arrested
almost every day for feeding people who need food.  It is a sick and
depraved to throw people in jail for this offense.  This is not freedom.

3.I can't get married to someone who is the same sex as I am.  The
advantages of having the government sanction your marriage are many. People
get tax breaks and other benifits if they are married.  This is the
governments way of trying to control the lifestyle that people choose to
live. It is not the act of a government that wants people to be free to
make their own decsisions.

4.I cant join the armed forces(although I wouldn't want to) and announce my
sexual preference if it happens to be the wrong one.

5.There are also 7 words which I cannot say on radio or TV without the FCC
fining the broadcaster hundreds of thousands of dollars.  Offensive or not
people should be able to broadcast whatever they like on public airwaves
even if that includes "offensive" material.

These are just a few of the things that we cannot do that are prohibited by
law.
>
>let's face it; in a lot of third world (and even some first world)
>  countries, these above conditions occur daily!
>it's true that sometimes authorities here overstep their bounds, but
>  there's usually a public outcry at the very least; in a authoritarian
>    state, you don't get no chance to outcry unless you want something
>      to get chopped off yer body
I think what you mean is a toltalitarion government not authoritarian. We
do definetly have a authoritarian government, but not a totalitarian one.
But their are cases where the distinciton is little. Take for instance,,
Judy Bari of Earth First! She was driving through the streets of Oakland
when a car bomb exploded nearly permanently crippling her and her
passenger.  The FBI then proceeded to launch a massive investigaition of
her and Earth First(a total of 700 pages were compiled). Sounds a little
suspicious doesn't it?
        As far as conditions in third world countries. Many of the people
in these countries suffer at the hands of their government.  We should be
aware that many of these repressive government get economic as well as
military aid from the United States. And in many instances the US has
stepped in when the people in these contries tried to take control of their
government. If you need examples you should read about US foreign policy
from a source other than a newspaper or a television.
>by and large, things aren't too bad here in the US; of course, that
>  shouldn't encourage apathy like you see in the suburban dream, where
>    people think they've already "got it all"......
>
>(flame retardant on)
>
>Dave Scruton

If you think things aren't bad here perhaps you should look into the eyes
of the next person you see hungry on the streets, or perhaps you should
take a tour of a prison, or a stroll through some poor neighberhoods.
Please do. It is very importent that people come to an understanding of the
world we live in. I also recomend a movie about thought control in a
democratic society. It is called Manufacturing Consent, I highly recomend
it. It might even change your life.

From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)

Cc: "M. Lane Gilchrist" <gilchris@indigo.ucdavis.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com

What I find absolutely amazing about the post below is that it is a really
good example of the conventional wisdom in america that goes "racism here -
duh, what problem, we got black artists, we got hip hop whats the problem"

If we want to have an intelligent discussion about xenophobia and racism in
america, then lets start by putting some of the puzzle together.

Can anyone answer the following question - why are there american-indian
reservations? From my experience, I can see absolutely no difference with
aparthied which was a system of "seperate but equal" development, and the
situation here.

In fact, I recently posted an in depth analysis of the SYSTEM as I see It
on the Well, which I really think you should all read because it seems that
SFRAVERS have a naive if anything understanding of the true implications of
Segregation. So I will post this for everyones benefit, so that at least we
can begin to aware ourselves of what it is that we are doing - Now please,
bare with me if i seem overly eager to get my views across - my only
defense in this instance is this - THE PLANET MADE ME DO IT.

- david dei

In the interests of a better understanding of what it is that we are
fighting, herewith PART ONE of UNDERTHROWING THE STATE OF UNJUSTICE -
Apartheid Geography - its Global.

The basic premise of Apartheid, or apartness, was a policy of seperate
development. Hendrik Verwoerd the man who coined the term (and who went
fishing with my grandfather) believed in a meritocracy. "The merit which
counts is not only the merit of the individual ... the merits of races and
groups must also count.." he maintained. And so a masterful plan was
developed whereby people were classified by race, and would live "seperate
but equal" lives. Each race group would have its own homeland, and an
entire country was segregated and partitioned along racial lines.

This new system of Grand Apartheid  in which indigenous nations would
receive limited self-government on reservations or homeland areas was then
replicated and patterned in the South Africa's urban centers necessitating
intricate city planning in the modernist vein. Entirely  new suburbs were
created and mixed areas destroyed, as Lewis Mumford had already invisioned.
These perfect garden suburben utopias were seperated by natural and
artificial obstacles. Barriers such as highways, industrial areas and
natural boundaries such as mountains were also factored into the equation.

Surrounding the urban city center, which had now been converted into a
giant-size modernist hell (with mammoth layout and elevated highways) were
the suburbs postioned in concentric circles, accessible by only one or two
exits off anonymous highways. White areas had the choicest zones, with
suburbs or townships for coloureds (people of mixed race) further out, and
black townships at least an hours drive from the centre being the most
isolated.

 For an example of this Apartheid townplanning one has only to tour the
city of Los Angeles. There one finds suburbs clearly seperated along class
and race lines, with the richer and whiter areas such as Beverley Hills
occupying the high ground and lower class, black areas such as South
Central isolated from these higher areas by the major arterial freeways
like Earthquake prone Santa Monica freeway.

The idea is an intriguingly basic one - By creating seemingly natural
barriers to personal contact, like sheer physical distance, you effectively
prevent the possiblity of intraclass contact. So a yuppie is unlikely to
bump into a South Centralite  going about his business in Santa Monica or
Beverley Hills. The result is a seemingly natural sheen of orderly
existance. As Hobbes has noted, everyone feels as if they have a place in
the socius or body of society. The king or president appears to draw his
natural authority from his position as palace dweller. The Whitehouse,
conveying semantic authority coded via its very archetecture and physical
location.

Power in turn flows through the internal geography of the legislature, its
tiered seating, its positioning of the speaker and parties as in a Royal
Court, diluting outwards into increasingly less important levels. Senate to
House of Representatives to State Legislatures and feudal lords to the
instruments of coercion such as police, military, psychiatrists to card
carrying voting citizens, to prodigal citizens to illegal aliens and
finally to citizens of neighbouring countries and peripheral zones.

The illusion of orderliness is completed by the maintenance of permanently
disenfranchised outsiders. These Economic and Geographic serfs of the Third
World can never enter the inner sanctum of authority, the security
council/whitehouse. More importantly, they are not even aware of their
position, for the illusion at this most basic level is complete.

 Military Strategy dictates that in order to rule a people, one must first
divide and then conquor., the basic ballgame invented by the Caesers of the
Roman Empire is seen in the establishment of feudal warlords or fascists
these tithe collectors (from those who carry the fasces or ritual sticks of
power) carry out the will of the president/king/emporer/security council,
insulating the emporer from rebellion. Any attempt at uprising is doomed to
failure, as the riots in Los Angeles and Central American conflicts so
clearly demonstrate.
dillemma

NEXT: Why the underthrowing of the system in South Africa, being but a
branch of the global tree, gives us a key to underthrowing the entire
bushel.

Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950323224423.17917B-100000@shell1.best.com>

CHEMICA SUTRA REPORT 

Last Saturday, near the end (about 4 am) of the Megatripolis Parallel
University's first event of the Spring, the CHEMICA SUTRA Technoerotic
Expedition (a book rave launch of the new Better Sex Through Chemistry - A
Guide to the New Prosexual Drugs by John Morgenthaler and Dan Joy) we
asked DJ Cathy of KSFS Radio to go around the guests, discreetly
recording their impressions of the evening. 

The transcripts of these interviews are starting to come in and we found
them so inspiring and illuminating that we thought it might be a good idea
to publish some of them here.  Especially so as our announcement of the
first Chemica Sutra Expedition on sfraves 3 weeks ago, and of our hope to
bridge some age gaps between RC (Rave Culture) and the surrounding, older 
generation, drew some criticism and some doubts. 

Let's start, then, with a father and son who attended *together*.  It was
the father's second attendance at a rave, the son's first. 
________________________________________________________________________
RICHIE:
"it was a beautiful celebration of a lot of different things coming
together.  firstly for me it the gapping of the generations, the merging
of different levels. 

what the whole gathering was about is that we all live in different
dimensions, we can be very articulate about explaining the qualities and
the effects of certain drugs but we can also *express* them.  and we can
be liberated in the fact that other people can express what *we* cannot. 
there are those who are perfected in certain areas and we realise that our
different individual styles and spirits are all expressions of one dynamic
united field of vision. 

this parallel university was kind of focused on the erotic .. sex is
limitless, and pleasure indefinitely prolonged is what part of us wants. 
but sex can be fragmentary, casual, it can have no meaning, the meaning
here was the spirit of the people, the community. 

the party brought all that out by people being very contented with their
own different realms of expression, expertise.  some talked about their
pharmacological knowledge, others danced, there were exotic dancers, belly
dancers, there were erotic slides to inspire the mind.  the dancefloor for
me was the metaphor for dissolving ignorance, for moving through different
chambers and finally flinging yourself into the dance of the spirit. 

it all worked together, certainly for me, like we were pioneers finding
mood chemicals that might enhance, but not being dependent on those,
seeing that dance is the way to get your body in motion, the dancing on
the floor was like the integration of all the different knowledges put
into the form, the ecstatic rhythm of dance. 

so it was a divine mosaic of the wonderous personality of the people
promoting a consciousness of ourselves as limitless, that we can enjoy
ourselves, be comfortable with ourselves, but always guided by a focus. 
when sensation is informed by knowledge it definitely moves into a realm
that everyone can enjoy." 

________________________________________________________________________
The second is with Belinda, from Spain, who said she had attended many 
raves in Spain but never anything like this: 

"this amazing house is just a beautiful place to have a party like this,
because there's a lot of feeling and years in this place.  everyone was so
full of feeling, the atmosphere was so, how you say it, user-friendly? 
the dancefloor was wonderful.  the music was great. it was a really good
party.  just wonderful. and really different." 

[more to follow]

with purposely trying to get more people of a certain sex/race to go out,

I'll admit to not knowing all that much about the 60's, but it seems to me
that the media played a major role in killing the Hippys. It was no longer
special to be a Hippy because there were all these suburban kids growing
their hair long, smoking pot & saying "peace & love" without knowing what
it *realy* meant. The media has changed SO much since then, it pretty much
dominates all the information the masses get & has gone to the extemes of
exploitation. It realy scares me to think of what would happen to the
scene if it got so big that is was extremely common media/commercialism bate.

		Josh

I guess this is the Tristan everyone talks about.  It would be nice if he
had his own id.  Just call me nuts for protocol.  Between he and Fraser I
don't know which gets the Ultra CrackerJack Award for Genius. If not that
then they are surely Blue Ribbon Winners...in any case, we know there are
few who can have more to say than I.  So without haste, I analyze the
critic.

>Anybody who thinks the SF rave scene is not xenophobic is, quite frankly,
>talking out of their arse.

Thanks for telling me how to think.  Thanks for criticisizing my thought
before I had a chance to think it.  Man, that gave me much more time to
think about other things....

There is much more to the SF rave scene than can be represented by any one
club, group of people , etc.  It is a MECCA, where even people like you can
make a difference.  For good or for bad.  You seem to criticize without
offering any real solution.  Just plain complaints, and continuing to do so
long after your point was made.  From your first post everyone knew where
you stood.  I think we're smart enough to understand the subtely of your
statements...give people some credit.

The fact is, you have made statements with relatively little history or
understanding of the place you attempt to critique.  You have no sense of
the place, and  are far to busy trying to mold everything to your liking,
instead of trying to find your own vibe or flow.  You basically violate the
ethic by trying to pound things into peoples heads over and over.  And
making little attempt at understanding why you're getting such viceral
reactions.  Relax man, it's only a party...you take yourself way to
seriously, so much so, you not only become irritating, but farcical (is
that like popsicle? ).

>I have been going to raves here for over a
>year and a half and I could probably count the number of African
>Americans I have seen on my finger's (all right, that is a slight
>over-statement).

Huh? MANY people on this list might consider you a newcomer.  But looking
at the various responses, most if not all, never mentioned how long they
have been in the scene here in SF.  By my standards great restraint ;).
Suffice it to say most people on the list have been around long enough to
know what they like and dislike.  And they, unlike many others, have made
an attempt on their own, and from my view w/o profit in mind, to create
THIER vision of what dance/music culture is all about!  If you don't like
it fine.  You can criticize it, although it would be much more helpful if
you gave suggestions, even helped out.  But it seems some bug crawled up
yer butt, and you have no intention other than to disrupt, and cause
commotion (with a c).  Quite counterproductive, as well as a waste of time.
The 'scene' here is way past that type of counterproductive behaviour.  I
don't find the same level of backbiting as I did a year ago.  People have
generally gathered into their camps & posses and formed thier own tribes.
And generally, things are moving along, slowly right now, but moving.
There are still many diehards and many converts that catch da beat.
There's litlle DJ/Promoter spy vs spy anymore, excpet in limited quarters.
And people are getting along, or at least making an attempt.

As for African Americans at parties, once again, you speak without
understanding the FULL history of the matter.  Most of all, since you
exhibit no sense of SF history; you didn't note an increase in the number
of brothers and sisters going out.  Alot of things had to change about the
scene for this to happen.  And from my view, it's going to get bettah!
People have already begun to act on this problem, along with other
problems.  The tribes will eventually gather if any part of this 'movement'
is real.

>(And, as everybody is probably sick of hearing this
>(particually if you are American) again) It's not like that in England.
>Here everything is segrergated and the rave scene is no exception.

I really despise people who criticize a country without living there for
significant periods of time.  And what do you know of American
sensibilites.  It is due to staments like these that many have said, in one
form or another "Welcome to California, now LEAVE!".  I'll have a big heart
and forgive this statement, since he obviously doesn't know that the music
came from the black gay scene.  History would have precluded him from
making such ignorant banter.  He , because he is so new to SF, has never
been to a Five Foot Tongue, or even the legendary Toon Town.  Therefore he
would not know how many blacks, latinos, whites, etc., gays, strights,
bi's, tv's, aliens, were at many of these events.  And from the START they
were all MIXED affairs.  Things have stratified a bit, you're partially
correct, but it was not always so.  And todays condition is on the mend
(ravewise, country wise I have my doubts at times).

>In
>England white people go reggae and hip-hop clubs with-out thinking
>twice but here I don't even know where decent hip-hop clubs and reggae
>clubs/parties are.

So because you don't know where everything is, it is obviously not
happening.  First I'll call you clueless, but true to form, I will try to
help.  Try Jazzid-Up (or is it Mushroom Jazz), on Folsom on Mondays.  Also
try Pepper, the maybe defunct Butter, better yet Dig!..or you could do the
boat party...'sup to you.


>This is because the music at raves here is segragated
>as well where as in England we played raggae, acid jazz, old funk/rock;
>different floors, different kinds of music.  That way different people
>turn for the different music and then have the oppotunity to get into the
>other kinds of music their as well.

Oh yes reverend, preach that word!...We need direction!  YES, TELL US OH
GREAT TEACHER, HOW IS ONE TO ACHIEVE SUCH NIRVANA....geez...

>There used to be a club in London

Here comes the London reference, the setup for the comparison follows.
Just watch....

>where their was a goth room, a raggae/dub room, a techno room, and a
>retro chill-out room (and many a great raver was born out of that scene;
>let me tell you.....).  This is how you get a mixture at parties because
>the strength of any scene comes from the power of the excellence of it's
>music and different kinds of music attract different kinds of people.
>But nobody here is interested in doing that.

He doesn't consider the POSSIBILITY that maybe it's already been done.
Especially in the LA underground.  There have been crossover parties here
as well, but it's easier, due to the density to have two seperate clubs,
rather than two sharing the space.  SF doesn't have the type of buildings
for such an event, and promoters ego's are still a bit to large to gather
any two houses togehter.  That may take a bit more time.

>And why should they when
>their are thousands and thousands of white trash kids just lining up with
>their $10
>And this go's to heart of America.

A quote from the Movie BladeRunner is in order:"He's the kind of man that
use to call a black man, nigger."

You're quite judgemental, prejudicial, and racist. There is little wonder
why it was so easy to defeat old King George.

>In England

[cut!]

Person, I really hate it when people criticiize something without at least
making an attempt to understand it.  You are a brute, and have little
regard for the feelings of others, much less the hard work that many do.

You don't know what's going on here or in RealitySF, sicne you haven't been
here long enough to catch the beat.  You went to F & F , didn't have a good
time, said your piece...and continued to say your piece.  We heard you
twice the first time.

Next, you and others who have an equally naive sense of SF and the Bay
Area, try to negate it.  And consider it a place where you can teach the
natives a lesson.  Your King gave that shit up over 200 years ago, so why
don't you?

Fact is, F & F  had enough heart to carry out what they FIRST SET OUT TO
DO, create parties that unfied people and considered all as it's brothers
and sisters, all the while making it accessible to people.  And I might
add, at very low cost.  Mistakes were made, certainly, but don't try to
tell people how bad of a time they really had.  How in the hell would you
know? Being so busy being upset about being at a party you don't like.  You
spend much time in wasted emotional cycles.  You didn't have a good time,
yet others did.  That's pretty much it.  They have accepted your opinion,
and respected it.  Why don't *you* respect others opinions.  Thats how it's
done in SF man (ala Sammy Davis Jr.).  Get a clue.

I am sorry if my viceral response upset anyone, that was not my intent.  I
wish people would act more than talk.  Gotta give F & F credit for walkin'
the walk. And takin' hella people for the ride...right on!

Saudi 5,
John

Flavah's on!

At 11:00 PM 23/3/95 -0800, Josh Bates wrote:
>On Thu, 23 Mar 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>
>> Anybody who thinks the SF rave scene is not xenophobic is, quite frankly,
>> talking out of their arse.  I have been going to raves here for over a
>> year and a half and I could probably count the number of African
>> Americans I have seen on my finger's
>
>IMHO the difference is that most people here don't make the distinction
>between black & white. I don't notice a lack of any racial group because I
>don't label them with the color of their skin. I think there's a problem
>with purposely trying to get more people of a certain sex/race to go out,
>it seems kinda phony.
>
>> Because don't forget that acid house/rave music was mostly written by
>> whites as well (they were certainly the caterlyst) and the African English
>> got into it at a later date.
>
>If you're getting into the race thing... Basically all of the artists who
>started house/techno/acid-house were African-American. I honestly can't
>name one white originator from Chicago, Detroit or New York, can you?
>
>                Josh

Listen -the system lied to us, when we got wise to the black/white thing,
they changed the rules - they called us african-american, asian-american,
illegal alien. but one thing they did'nt call us was HUMAN.

Once upon a time I grew up in a country where they called a black man - a
kaffir, then they called him a non-european, then they called him a
"plural" then they called him a "communist" then they called him a "black",
until only last year, they called him south african.

You can  change the words, but you can't change the principle.

So I say yo MR RACIST, yes, you are a racist not because you talk about
black or white, not because you don't label, but because you refer to THEM
not US - you EXCLUDE instead of INCLUDING, you SET YOURSELF APART.

JOSH says "I don't notice a lack of any racial group because I
don't label them with the color of their skin."
                  ^^^^^
but you label THEM  nevertheless as OUTSIDERS.

NOW please do not attempt a defence, because I do this only to illustrate
what should be clear to you and all other ravers, that this system of which
i speak is more complex than we imagine, we each have but a piece of the
puzzle, which is why we need to seriously discuss  HOW we are to CHANGE. I
am totally assured as to all your intentions. We do things only for the
best reasons, but the problem is not with having the right intention, but
instead with lifting the veils from our eyes and Seeing the injustice
around us.

It is totally clear to me that American Apartheid is alive and well and
breeding quitely in the minds of this MTV generation. so it is about time
that we rid ourselves of our patriotic numbness and redefine ourselves as
GLOBAL CITIZENS - with a duty to seek out injustice wherever we find it,
and to STOP the shit in a constructive way.

INjustice is not merely a point of view of another channel as equally valid
as the channel you're currently watching. It is real, and has real
consequences. I recently made a posting dissing americans in general,
hoping that at the very least there might be some voice willing to consider
the opinion that there is something gravely wrong with what is happening
here. All I received back was anger - how dare I generalise, as if the
opinion that this country consumes 75% of the worlds resources were just an
opinion, that might only hold valid for some US citizens.

Well, this POV did'nt work for the germans in ww11 - "what, you have
absolutely no recollection of anything amiss fraulein?And you never
participated in the holocaust?"

the idea of collective guilt is an interesting if unpopular one, which I am
quite prepared to defend. As I am quite prepared to defend my position
regarding my experience in South Africa.
In fact, only once my generation of south africans set things on track down
south, did I feel able to begin participation in other struggles such as
the american one, for I too remained responsible for the success or failure
of the society into which I was born.

SO my SF friends - DO not be alarmed if I continue to badger you all UNTIL
YOU BEGIN TO ACCEPT A BIT OF THE RESPONSIBILITY FOR PUTTING RIGHT THE
WRONGS COMMITTED BY THIS COUNTRY EVEN IF THEY WERE COMMITTED BY A PREVIOUS
GENERATION because our dystanies are all intertwined.


- david dei

understanding why he would label someone on this list a "racist".

I'm about at the point where I want to ask Brian to close the list down
for a couple of days to give the loudmouths here a chance to rethink
what they are doing.  

The point, as a current favorite track of mine goes, is to move BEYOND
THE EGO.  

As I often do when confounded by the ego-centric spoutings of my fellow
humans, I check in with the wisdom of Robert Nesta Marley:

   Until the color of a man's skin 
   Is of no more consequence
   Than the color of his eyes . . .

I know everyone here subscribes to that future.  Now *think* how you
are going to get there, and think about how you will do so through your
thoughts expressed on this very list.  

If everyone shouts, nobody gets heard.

Gol darn, I'm getting tired of waving this Rod of Correction around!!

pitifull non-living-non-thinking-humans, I make my own damn vocabulary & I say
their races. I have some patience with them but you're starting to make me
wish this was a segragated list. I can just see how you would respond if
called a racist "I got plenty of black friends, I helped free the brothers
in South Africa". Do you include yourself in the race you call Black? You
say "us" right? I do not include myself in any racial group, I could never
say "us jews", or "us whites", implying that the "them" be a group of
people defined by their race. It may be a flaw of mine that I do consider
some people outsiders, in one way I consider everybody outsiders afterall
their not inside me, but they are always given a chance to become
"insiders" & are not placed in/out-side the group based on pety things such a
race.

> what should be clear to you and all other ravers

Well the jet lag is just sorting itself out, and I'm missin' ya
already.

I'd just like to say a massive thanks to all you guys over there for a
totally top weekend.

Went shopping all day Friday, got me two pitch (tempo) cd deck and a
portable DAT machine and saved myself nearly a thousand pounds ($1500).
Then of see Black Dog, wow what a night, haven't heard "Tour De France"
in a club in long time *awesome*. Bumped into an old friend that I
hadn't seen in two years by total coincident, we looked like a couple
of schools girls, screamimg at each other. His name is Darrell or Mr
Pleasure as I found out, say hi if anyone knows him.

Then of to Alcatraz, yes I had to do the tourist thing, it was supposed
to be a work trip.

And then you guessed it, Saturday night, Friends & Family, wow, wow,
and extra triple helpings of wow. Absolutely banging, what an atmosphere.
I brought a couple of work colleagues along and although some of them
couldn't quite get their head round the music, they all commented on how
friendly the thing was. I must of left before it was busted and boy was
it packed. Thanks to those in the queue that let me back in to get my
coat, derr thick or what.

As for F&F in the UK if anyone wants to drop me a mail we could do a
club swap, I was talking to some friends over here that run a few doo's
here in London and they're right up for a session over there. So how
about it, F&F meets Bumpy Campers.

So long for now, and remember ya got to get out of it, to get inta it
;-)

Cheers

LCD

Some quotes from recent posts , with my comments [ ids removed on purpose ]
> ... I don't notice a lack of any racial group because I
> >don't label them with the color of their skin. I think there's a problem
> >with purposely trying to get more people of a certain sex/race to go out,
> >it seems kinda phony.

 It's that modern American self-segregation thing. Recrational integration 
happens voluntarily ; I predict this type of voluntary segregation will 
decrease , but not disappear , when the various ethnic sub-cultures in this 
nation have more effect and input into defining regional cultures. 

> Listen -the system lied to us, when we got wise to the black/white thing,
> they changed the rules - they called us african-american, asian-american,
> illegal alien. but one thing they did'nt call us was HUMAN.

 "the system" == the people who came up with and promoted the use of
                 the terms african-american, asian-american ( and don't
                 forget euro-american !) (sounds like something that
                 requires metric tools...) ????

 By now the writer of this paragraph about "the system" has been informed
by other folks via email about the history of "*-american" labelling and
catagorization in the US.   
   
> You can change the words, but you can't change the principle.
 And , apart from "the system" using labelling to hide unfair/toxic 
behaviour against a peoples - there's also the failure of labelling
in and of itself to change the way people feel about a group. It was very
educational for me , 10 years ago , to hear some teenagers use the word
"gay" as a perjorative term for weird behaviour. All the effort expended
by well-meaning gays and straights to replace "homo","faggot", and "queer"
with "gay" didn't change the hate of the gay-bashers , just their 
terminology. The principle was unaffected. 

( In the text below , words in <> are added by me ) 
> So I say yo MR RACIST, yes, you <JOSH> are a racist ...
> ... 
> NOW please do not attempt a defence, because I do this only to illustrate

 Let me try a paraphrasing here - "I have called one particular person , 
Josh, a racist , in order to get enough of a rise out of you folks so
that you would be illuminated to the rightness of my positions "

> NOW please do not attempt a defence, because I do this only to illustrate
> what should be clear to you and all other ravers, that this system of which
> i speak is more complex than we imagine, we each have but a piece of the
> puzzle, which is why we need to seriously discuss  HOW we are to CHANGE.

 "HOW *we* are to CHANGE" - at least he's willing to admit he needs some
 changing too ... ( or maybe his "we" is like Josh's use of "them" ?)
 
>  I
> am totally assured as to all your intentions.

 I'm sure his intentions are good too ( no satirical content meant here )

 YIKES! I'm late for work! ( more comments later ).

On Thu, 23 Mar 1995, David Jacobs wrote:

> Well folks if you are going to get pedantic about this, I point out that
> the Isle of Mann is not part of Britain but is part of the United Kingdom
> and then there are the Channel Islands, all that remain of the Duchy of
> Normandy so that when Elizabeth visits she is not Queen but the Duchess of
> Normandy. But the Channel Islands are not usually considered part of the
> United Kingdom.
> -David the Pedantic Anarchist
> 
> 

 Firstly my point was in no way meant to piss Iain off and I`m sure that 
was understood.
 It was not merely being pedantic, but an important political point. 
Ireland was invaded by Britain, because Britain could not maintain 
control over it as just another colony it was forced to bring it under 
the direct control of the state, thus forming the U.K. with the act of union.
 This act was one of direct political control over another country, and 
therefore is an important point to understand. Or maybe the Irish people 
who have suffered under the boot of British oppression for 200 yrs and 
continually fought against it should just shut up and stop being pedantic?
                           Doug the think before you speak Anarchist.
P.S. FTQ :-)



----- End Included Message -----

Subject: confusion about raving
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 09:41:46 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2158      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

All of these thoughts about raving, what it is, what it isn't.  The 
agreements the disagreements.  Do I know what it is?
Not really.
All I know, and I don't know much, is that when I go to a rave with some 
attitude about how the rave should be and I see things contrary to my 
preconceived rightousness of raving I find that I'm not having that good 
a time.  I might ask myself, am I at a rave?  or is this just some party.

As I start to ask myself these questions I take notice of my confusion, 
as I realize I don't have any definite answer.  As I embrace my confusion 
I start to get a sence and feeling of clarity.

I start to realize, that raving for me starts within myself.  In that 
exploration I start to acknowledge my feelings and accept what I'm 
experiencing.  Through this process of loving my experience, I start to 
experience harmony amongst my feelings, whether they relate or contradict
one another.  As I then look around me, I then feel that everything I see 
is part of raving.  I feel GREAT!  Everything is dancing, and it is 
beautiful to see the different styles of dance.  For even with the 
differences, there are similarities.

Wow, some journey, sorry if I went off on a tangent.  I still don't know 
exactly what raving is, when I look inside myself everything I find, 
whatever that is seems to be a part of it.

I want to thank everyone for their contributions about what raving is for 
them.  Some I feel good about.  Some I feel some resistance, which then 
reminds me that raving is also an exploration.  

Finding peace and harmony amongst my acceptance and what I resist.  I'm 
not exactly sure how to do all that, but its seems that raving helps.  
For me raving is more than a dance party, but a way of life, and much 
more.  So much more that I can't say what it is.  

When I experience that harmony amongst the differences, there is a 
feeling of extacy.  It is so wonderful when I am in that place in myself 
and someone else is at that place in them, there is an incredible feeling 
when our paths meet because we are in the same place.  It is that feeling 
of sharing that brings me extensive JOY.


peter

    be VERY mixed, lotsa latinos and afro-americanz;

    LA, and is naturally skewed towards the white/asian groups of
      people . . . .

On Fri, 24 Mar 1995, Peter Fogel wrote:

> All of these thoughts about raving, what it is, what it isn't.  The 
> agreements the disagreements.  Do I know what it is?
> Not really.

   Nor I -- though I do like the idea that:

                   TO RAVE IS TO AFFIRM

   I mostly attend the Golden Gate Park raves. Usually I bring my 
juggling equipment, because juggling to techno/house/whatever is an 
energizer. I also like being able to contribute something back, since 
everyone else is pitching in their energy by djing, dancing, passing 
around potato chips, or just smiling a lot.
   Going to a good rave is a lot like stepping into a bath of strong
rhythms and good feelings that emerge from a community moving together
in synch. 

   -- Arthur
      Yea@BayMOO

hey, i never said that life in the us was absolutely perfect and that
  there were posies popping up in the sidewalks everywhere; i wuz just
    trying to draw a contrast between the extremely lucky life that most
     of us have versus the extremely nasty conditions over 1/3 of the
      world's population lives in.
  if you think the homeless and hungry in our streets have it bad off,
    let's look at the squatter cities (CITIES of 100,000+) of people
      living in cardboard boxes around cities like Manilla, Rio, Mexico City,
        Guatamala City, Johannesburg (correct me on this one if i'm wrong)
          Delhi, etc.  
  in these places people don't sit on the corner begging for quarters
    from yuppies; THEY GET SHOT AT if they show their asses anywhere
      near the proper parts of the city. kids are hunted down for sport
       in brazil; they inhale bags full o'
         glue and other inhalants just to kill reality.
  which brings this already-too-long screed to ingestion of substances.
    (bigtime IMHO)  i'm not coming out on either side of the legalization
      issue here, but people really have got to look at chemicals as a
        LUXURY when there are millions dying worldwide of disease and
          starvation.  true, there are homeless dying in newyork of
            TB, but how many cholera cases do you see????
(--flamezoff---)

Dave Scruton
  ( living in comparitive luxury )

I *did* say, is that there is no inherent racism in the rave scene as far 
as I've seen, and I've been on the scene for at least 3 years.

also feel like we as a country are making progress on this problem.  If 
anything, I'd say that the vibes of happiness and love that stem from 
raves help anti-racism on all sides.

What do you think?

> You can  change the words, but you can't change the principle.
>

> black or white, not because you don't label, but because you refer to THEM
> not US - you EXCLUDE instead of INCLUDING, you SET YOURSELF APART.
>

> don't label them with the color of their skin."
>                   ^^^^^

So you think that we should refer to all of us as us?  But I think that 
each culture should be its own "them", and have its own identity!  That's 
why I would refer to any other race as them, because they each in turn 
have their own culture, and cultural identities.  And every culture is 
different.  But this doesn't mean that we can't live together.  Right?  
What do you want the White Culture to do?  Accept all others as the 
same as them, or accept all others as different but equal?  I vote for 
the latter.

Precedence: bulk

Well, I though this might be a tough nut to crack, but was not prepared for
the level of DENIAL.

I suppose we can put this down to that "rugged individualism" taught in
this society. So obviously any attempt to talk about SOCIETY is going to
run into flack by those so heavily brainwashed that they cannot even begin
to imagine what a society without this principle might be like. Again, I
said I would be willing to defend my position that there is such a thing as
collective guilt. As yet NOT ONE INDIVIDUAL on this list has stood up and
even tried to claim some responsiblity for America or tried to move towards
where this all should be heading which is out of the present state of
DENIAL to an ACCEPTANCE that things are definitly WRONG and need CHANGING.
There's a bit of discussion  going on in the democracy slaves thread, but
as usual its mainly an exchange of what ifs, without anyone coming to any
agreement.

Now I know that it would probably be a lot easier if I always referred to
this in an ABSTRACT way instead of using individuals to demonstrate my
point.   So what I'll do is erase references to names while keeping the
examples so as to prevent the loss of face that results in flamage. What
blows me away is that most of the responses seem to be trying to defend the
RIGHT TO BE A RACIST and  THE RIGHT TO SET ONESELF APART.

This idea of INDIVIDUAL FREEDOM - that we should allow all types of
behaviour and thought in the infinite diversity of the universe is perhaps
fundemental to american society. Coupled with this is the idea of
RELATIVITY -
that just as each idea is equally valid, all possiblities have relative meaning.

Example A

>Yeah sure man I'M A RACIST. I differentiate between living-humans & those
>pitifull non-living-non-thinking-humans, I make my own damn vocabulary & I say
>their races. I have some patience with them but you're starting to make me
>wish this was a segragated list.

Here we see the classic american defence of last resort -
< I make my own damn vocabulary & I say
their races. >

 What the writer is defending is his intrinsic ability to GOVERN HIS OWN
SELF - to SAY what he likes and so on.

And here we have an sfraver who actually restates the above:

>His message refers to members of any
>racial group as "them" in reference to judgement. It didn't sound like it
>was a matter of the use of "us" vs. "them" but rather "me(as an individual"
>vs. "them." Your argument denies the possibility of the individual as a
>seperate and distinct entity WITHIN a group.

 And here we have perhaps the quaint motivation for this insider/outsider thing:

>It may be a flaw of mine that I do consider
>some people outsiders, in one way I consider everybody outsiders afterall
>their not inside me, but they are always given a chance to become
>"insiders" & are not placed in/out-side the group based on pety things such a
>race.

Now some rambling in the way of explanation:

SEGREGATION: the seperation of the whole into its constituent parts. The
marking of territory. A line of difference seperating two objects.

In South Africa and the Deep South, segregation was OVERT. The seperation
was mainly along class and race lines, with WHITES ONLY signs deliniating
the areas in which people could or could not travel.

In the 1984/5  overt segregation in south africa ended and the signs were
torn down as they had been in the Deep South in the 60s. But as we all
know, things did not end there.

The end of OVERT American Aparthied in the 60s was merely replaced with a
more tenacious form of COVERT apartheid. Instead of segregating people
along clearly racial lines, the policing of society would occur by
completing  the process and reasoning of segregation. - NOW ALL AMERICANS
were segregated into INDIVIDUAL PARTS. Thus Rugged Individualism became
merely a code word for Seperation.

The Community Uprisings of the 60s had to be prevented at all costs.
Express orders were given by the Nixon Administration which hold to this
day, to prevent at all costs the rise of any figure capable of uniting the
people - black and white. (Hence the Luther-King and Malcolm X
asassinations.) The splintering and disarming of the PEOPLE was helped by
an interesting process of cultural relativism - a black nation was carved
up as the indian nation before it - into its "tribal" parts. The idea of
"black conscousness" in the 60s had been one of inclusion of all those
oppressed by the colonials (although flawed by its exclusion of the
majority of WASPS who had not commited class suicide ie given up there
inheritance) where everyone who was not white was black - thus the idea of
asian-american did not exist. An asian was considered black as was a native
american. We can now begin to see the pattern. Fragmentation, Splintering,
Alienation

Now thats such an underused word nowadays Alienation - the ideas developed
by Albert Camus, Frantz Fanon that were so fashionable in the 60s, the idea
that it was possible for an individual to be CUT_OFF from not only Society
but even his own intrinsic nature.

So what we have here are two parallel histories, but with very different
consequences.

In south africa right now people have embraced a POLITICS OF INCLUSION -
all children have become OUR CHILDREN ,all people have become OUR PEOPLE.
No one including the most rightwing individual has been excluded. Speaking
to the previous generation, I still find it amazing that all of a sudden
their lives have changed - my mother after years of being a boring
housewife chatting to other old hens has suddenly reawakened her talent as
an artist. Everywhere people feel as if ANYTHING and EVERYTHING is
possible. Spontaneous outbreaks of OPTIMISM have become the order of the
Day.

Which is why I believe in RAVE - because what rave teaches -is this - it is
possible to join in the dance, in the community without LOSING your
INDIVIDUALITY.

IN FACT, ones individuality is enhanced, healed, awakened by the COMMUNITY
VIBE. For what we have in Rave is an ANTIDOTE to the splintering, the
fragmentation ,the seperation of global apartheid.

BUT let me rest my case with just one addition - WE NEED TO RAVE WITH
PURPOSE and INTENTION. Otherwise, rave will remain just another segregated
area. We need to take the communitarian spirit generated each week on the
dancefloor OUT into the Streets, into our homes, into our places of work
and worship. That way we begin to assuage the collective guilt, and burden
of our generation, by changing the world, remaking it in a brighter shade
of rave.

This is what we did in South Africa, and just as it worked down there, it
is bound to work over here.

- david dei

                           Megatripolis Parallel University
                                     megatrip@best.com

>> not US - you EXCLUDE instead of INCLUDING, you SET YOURSELF APART.
