>So you think that we should refer to all of us as us?  But I think that
>each culture should be its own "them", and have its own identity!  That's
>why I would refer to any other race as them, because they each in turn
>have their own culture, and cultural identities.  And every culture is
>different.  But this doesn't mean that we can't live together.  Right?
>What do you want the White Culture to do?  Accept all others as the
>same as them, or accept all others as different but equal?  I vote for
>the latter.

different but equal?
difference - an idea of seperation. (lets all read Derrida)
seperate but equal is exactly the policy of apartheid -
I think it was Mills or Locke who defined the idea of a group or nation as
"a common myth about ones ancestry, and a common hatred for ones neighbours"

I would rather settle for the idea of HUMAN, and call the other stuff flavor.

- david dei

                     It can happen here

--------------------------------------
Date: 3/9/95 4:29 PM
From: Andrew Boyd
it can happen here:

During the debate in the House of February 7 over the House Republicans'
Bill about the Exclusionary Rule, the House Black Caucus introduced an
amendment to the bill that the Republicans promptly voted down.  The
amendment turned out to be the Fourth Amendment of the Constitution,
verbatim.  The House Republicans were "chagrined."  The vote was 303-121,
meaning that a number of Democrats joined the Republicans.  The Fourth
Amendment reads: "The right of the people to be secure in their persons,
houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures,
shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue but upon probable cause,
supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to
be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

Frazer and David are entertaining me with a brand of selective hearing  , a 
panache for insensitivity, and a kind of special sharing that I only found in 
jail from the loudest inmates. Usually they get moved around a lot. But of 
course I find confusion and harshness inspiring.

I am still rushing from the thrill of last weekend's Friends and Family.
This Saturday I had hoped the Jungle party would be outdoors but I've been 
told, indoors $5, 415.995.4699

I was sure last year was going to be the big one for raving in S.F.
In L.A. a lot of people dropped out and were waiting for the next fad,
lots of retired ravers everywhere. We are in it for the long haul now.
At Ameba our favorite thing is to direct visitors to raves and learn about the 
big world of raving out there. Fads in consumer society must always come 
and go .Culture is a big commodity. The British have been selling culture for 
a long time now. Some come here to share and some come to exploit the 
sheep, especially us fury California ones. I respect the Wicked crew because 
they lift speakers and amps (especially that red haired bloke).

From: "Dana WATANABE" <DWATANAB@uci.edu>

Subject: babbbling pomposity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 17:45:51 PST

Ever since F&F was first beign ripped on, i've been
meaning to post somethign where i dribble on about something
or other.  At first, it was going to be a very vicious
attack on anything that dared attack F&F,
but i wanted to abide by the suggestion that we wait and
sit on vile filled messages
(okay.. its finals week and i didnt have time)

anyhow.. now that i have sat on everything i was thinking
over the past week and totally forgotten anything
that i had thought of that would have been mistakenly 
interpretted as intelligent

ANyhow.. i do think that more than enough bilious messages
have been posted on this subject that i think
that that can and should be left behind us now,
but i guess i shouldnt tell people what they should post
about because well.. thats wrong or somethign
(i suppose i should kill the sarcasm if this is supposed to be positive)

Ummm... basically i want to say that i have (i dont think)
ever been to a Friends and Family party.  Mostly
because i live in socal and poor timing on trips there.
REGARDLESS.  I DO know that the people who put on F&F 
parties do NOT deserve to be stomped on.  Criticized? Yes.
Given tips and pointers on how to make better parties? Yes.
BUT.  These people are doing something for which their
payment is a loss of their own personal time, loss of sleep
added stress in their lives, pontential MAJOR trouble
with law enforcement, getting bitched at for what they do wrong
(or dont do wrong) AND the positive response in
personal feedback that they get from people. 

In _MY_ opinion, ANYONE who does as much work as is put
into these parties deserves Praise before they start getting criticized.
But that's just me.  I really have to especially say with this group,
though, becuase i have seen them at other parties, 
no.. it's beyond seeing.. it's just being there
and seeing them working at getting everything going
and i dunno.. maybe i was just always in a wierd state of mind
or soemthing, but .. like when ethan was tearing down
teh stuff at nag champa and we drove to his house
and was were greeted by this wonderful smiling child's face at teh window
and we tromped through his house at some ungodly
hour to return the sound equipment that he didnt expect
to get any money for lending... well the whole morning
of disassembling nag champa, the attitude of everyone
was much different than most other promoters i know
i dont know if it was really visible, but it was incredibly tangible..

i think, though that we all need to realize that different
people speak in different ways (geee.. i shoudl get a philosophy degree)
some people choose to send email (and ltos of it) to sfraves
to discuss what happened at a party and others will 
just send private mail to the people they want to let know how they feel
and others wont even send any mail because that's just
not what they do or feel like at teh time.
to me, it shoudl be noted that just because it seems like 90%
of the email about F&F is incredibly positive,
it in no way means that 90% of the people there had an incredible time
or that 90% of the people on sfraves had an increedible time,
just that 90% of the people posting did...

It also seems like it needs to be reemphasized that differnt people
look for differnt types of parties (whoa.. he's going for the masters now)
some like small low scale parties, some like large crazy extravagant parties
some like parties with only one kind of music, others like diversity
some want Budweiser Presents... 
others would rather die than have alcohol and/or corporate sponsorship

it seems unaffective to criticize someone for not throwing the
kind of party that one wants to see when the person throwing
the party was looking for something different

i mean, if i were to throw a party with some solid soulful groovey music
and was told that everything was nice, but the music was too housey...
it's like.. um yeah. thanks.

diversity should not jsut be about the ethnic background
or the type of music playing.. but to the types of parties as well...
we should, IMneverHO, try to support each other in 
throwing differnt types of parties, because it promotes health in a scene

but i think the most important thing right now that needs focus
would be in trying to communicate without letting a bunch
of other bullshit get in the way...
BUT it is going to be there, and i think for now
we jsut have to recognize that it will be there,
and that we shoudl try not to react to the bullshit
so much as what is really being communicated.

i mean when someone calls you a fuck, not to be initially offended
until you try to understand why you are being called a fuck..
if its because there is a lot of emotion involved in what the person
is saying adn that is the only means that they have to express it
if its because they call everyone inlcuding their mom a fuck
or if its because they are being lame and just in a pissy mood

AND when you call someone a fuck you should pretty m,uch realize
that you have most likely closed off any form of real communication
and are just entering into a realm of bullshitting that
will probably be centered around defending or attacking the egos
that are involved in the conversation

or that when someone explains the vast amoutn of experience that they have
they should see that it could be taken as just ego stroking in public

BUt respect is still due to other people, and people who have
different experiences should always be listened to

i dunno...it's just kinda sad for me that the one
week i take to actually try to read my Sfraves mail
its filled with what seems like more attacking than usual
but it's not like it hasnt always been here
and isnt jsut a means of our collectively growing up
and learning or not about each other

 ,
dana
 
"I knew my life was complete when i found out
that a piece of furniture was named after me."
	- me

On Thu, 23 Mar 1995 SCRUTON@PAELE.dnet.hac.com wrote:

> if anyone out there thinks we are all slaves under this democracy, let's
>   think back over whut we mite've done the past week....
[snip]
> let's face it; in a lot of third world (and even some first world) 
>   countries, these above conditions occur daily!
> it's true that sometimes authorities here overstep their bounds, but
>   there's usually a public outcry at the very least; in a authoritarian
>     state, you don't get no chance to outcry unless you want something
>       to get chopped off yer body

	Leave the country on a plane destined for Europe. I have never 
had a problem with customs going out of the country. The cops have NEVER 
felt like they were out to do me in (even in London where people seemed 
to complain constantly about their attitudes, I have never felt threaten. 
Of course I have never been to a demonstration where they decide to 
charge into a crowd on horseback ;) ). Each time I come back through 
customs here, the weight of the "authorities" descends back upon my 
shoulders. "Let's see what's in the backpack sonny. What are you doing 
with this bottle sonny?! What else you got? You know we got laws..." 
Funny, I seem to be obeying them when I pass through customs. It has been 
said that cops have big egos (Sean I think). They like to make their 
presence felt, but not to make people feel safe, and until they do that 
(and that is supposed to be why we have such great numbers of them, so 
there is less crime and people do not have to be afraid right?) I will 
probably growl even if I do not agree with the attitude I mentioned. 
Maybe we live under a democratic society in which we can say certain 
things and hopefully not be falsely charged, but our authorities have 
managed to firmly implant the notion that our constitutionl rights can be 
waived in the interest of "justice", even if such an act destorys 
someone's life, all the authorities are going to do is say sorry.

dave

Sorry to post a review about a weekly thingy,  but...

Last night at 11:30pm I made the left turn onto Old Oakland Road from the 
Brokaw exit off 880 and then the right into the Selections parking lot to 
find cars all over the place.  What the heck is going on?  This is 
thursday night in San Jose for crying out loud!

Pay the 5 bux and jump into the fracas... Rick Preston was getting whacky 
and the crowd was eating it up.  Bouncing swaying bodies all feeling the 
whackiness in unison riding a small dancefloor under a parachute. What a 
packet of fun.  After this evening, work today was cake.

Anyhow, next thursday is Markie, Solar and Mattski.  Sounds a-ok to me.

Walrus
o.O

"We are now faced with the fact that tomorrow is today. We are confronted 
with the fierce urgency of now. In this unfolding conudrum of life and 
history there is such a thing as being too late. Procrastination is still 
the thief of time. Life often leaves us standing bare, naked and dejected 
with a lost opportunity... We may cry out desperately for time to pause 
in her passage, but time is deaf to every plea and rushes on. Over the 
bleached bones and jumbled residues of numerous civilizations are written 
the pathetic words :'Too late'... We still have a choice today: 
nonviolent coexsistence or violent coannihilation. This may well be 
mankinds last chance to choose between chaos and community."
							- M.L. King
It is not suprising to see this provocative thread move through this list 
at this time. Our times our wrought with peril and we can no longer go on 
ignoring the ills of the past and present which threaten our future.War, 
racism, ecological destruction and social decay are bringing our species 
and the Earth to the brink of catastrophe. In the midst of the decay 
there is also hope for re-forming the world into something more peaceful 
and loving. Whether we like it or not rave culture in many ways is 
embedded within and accelerating this transformation.

These issues are complex and this medium is still very young. We all have 
a long way to go. Education is integral for peaceful and prosperous 
evolution. We must learn from our mistakes and move on with open hearts 
and a willingness to try new things. There are a lot of people in 
the U.S. and all around the world who are deluding themselves when they 
deny the severity of the issues that face us. Most people are in such 
serious denial because they are afraid. Fear inhibits transformation. 
For the learning process to be effective we need a space free from fear.
For me , at times raves have provided a safe space of celebration in 
which I could see beyond the limits of my social conditioning and my own 
fears.

As we try to experiment with the synalogue (many to many discussion) that 
is SFRaves we should try to cultivate styles of communication which can 
tackle difficult issues, express the maximum amount of individuality 
while also maintaining an openness for different opinions in a friendly 
discussion aimed  at the the development of insight and understanding.

Two books on racism that I find interesting are:

_Race Matters_ by Cornel West &

_Yearning: Race,Gender & Cultural Politics_ by bell hooks

both available at decent bookstores in the area

Yours in Transformation,
ronan

that has been done.

Forwarded message:
> From wps.com!deke Fri Mar 24 15:19:22 1995
> From: Deke Motif Nihilson <deke@wps.com>
> Message-Id: <199503242220.OAA20350@fido.wps.com>
> Subject: EMERGENCY! Headwaters Forest Faces the Axe
> To: iww-list@fido.wps.com
> Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 14:20:44 -0800 (PST)
> Cc: deke@fido.wps.com (Deke Motif Nihilson)
> X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
> MIME-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
> Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
> Content-Length: 4084      
> 
> Forwarded from the paper version sent out by Mendo/Humboldt/Local 1 
> Earth First!
> dated 22 March 1995
> 
> *****beginning of message*****
> 
> HEADWATERS FOREST RED ALERT!
> Cutting Can Begin Tuesday, March 28
> 
> The unthinkable is actually happening. The California Department of 
> Forestry (CDF) has approved Maxxam's plan to cut ancient redwoods in the 
> pristine Headwaters grove, and logging could begin next week. On Tuesday, 
> March 28, CDF and Maxxam will be doing a walk-through inspection of 
> Headwaters grove to decide which trees to cut. As soon as the inspection 
> is done, logging can begin.
> 
> To add to the outrage, Maxxam has not even filed a timber harvest plan 
> for Tuesday's cutting, as should be required under the California Forest 
> Practices Act. Instead they are planning to cut Headwaters under an 
> "exemption" just granted by the CDF. CDF's exemption logging rules allow 
> Maxxam to cut up to 10% of the trees, under the guise that they are "dead 
> or dying," with no public review, and without being subject to most 
> environmental restraints. In addition to the 10% of standing trees, they 
> can also take as many downed trees as they want.
> 
> Maxxam head Charles Hurwitz says he is ready to cut, but he is willing to 
> sell if a buyer can be found to pay the $500 million ransom he is 
> demanding for these trees he stole in a junk bond scam. Hurwitz also says 
> they will voluntarily hold off cutting between April 1 and September 30, 
> so the endangered Murrelets can complete their nesting season before he 
> slaughters their habitat. But even if he holds to this non-binding 
> promise, a lot of damage can be done between the March 28 approval date 
> and the April 1 voluntary moratorium. And Maxxam has refused to agree not 
> to cut during that period. Hurwitz is certainly not above dropping trees 
> in this ancient grove, even if his ultimate plan is to sell it.
> 
> EPIC and the Sierra Club are in the process of filing several lawsuits to 
> try and stop the cut. But this all happened so quickly, with so little 
> public notice or time to prepare, that the lawsuits will not be in until 
> next week, and we do not know if a hearing can even be scheduled before 
> the logging begins.
> 
> But we can't count on either of these avenues to keep Maxxam from cutting 
> Headwaters Forest. Only a huge mobilization of public outrage can prevent 
> this atrocity. And so we have been put in the position of having to 
> instantly organize a full-scale response. When Maxxam and CDF walk 
> through Headwaters grove and mark trees for cutting on Tuesday, we must 
> be there to protest. If they try to log, we must block them.
>  
> 
> Direct Action Mobilization
> 
> Because of the short notice, we cannot tell you the exact time or 
> location of the Tuesday rally yet. But we can't wait any longer to mail 
> this notice, because we need you to be there too. There will be a legal, 
> non-arrest demonstration on Tuesday, March 28, somewhere near the 
> entrance to Headwaters Forest. And there will be non-violent civil 
> disobedience in the forest any time they try to cut. We will have 
> overnight accomodations, car pools, and a bus available for the Tuesday 
> demonstration, and a base camp for the woods actions. If you can help 
> with any aspect of actions or support, we need you. Call 707-468-1660 for 
> info.
> 
> 
> Phoning and Funding
> 
> If you can't come to Headwaters, we still need your help. This instant 
> mobilization is going to cost a bundle, as we have to cover phones, 
> transportation, base camp equipment, etc. etc. Funding is desperately 
> needed. Please make checks out to Earth First!, and mail them to: 
> Earth First!, 106 West Standley, Ukiah CA  95482
> 
> You can also help by calling Governor Pete Wilson at 916-445-2841. Wilson 
> could stop this cut in a minute if he wanted, just by ordering the Board 
> of Forestry to enforce the law. Wilson has just announced that he is 
> meeting with Maxxam for one more round of negotiations on Headwaters. 
> Call him and demand that he enforce the Forest Practices Act and stop the 
> cut in Headwaters Forest. No trades, no deals. Just stop the cut.
> 
> *****end of message*****
>

David Dei, you sure make a lot of accusations for someone who knows few
if any of us personally.

You say "as yet not one individual on this list has stood up and taken
responsibility for America."  Has it ever occurred to you in your
self-righteous, ego-stoking orations that you might be WRONG?  Some of
what you're saying may have a basis, but you have taken advantage of
a community in some shock and self-evaluation following the bust of
the F&F party last Saturday, *taken advantage*, I say again, of our
emotional vulnerability at this point to press your personal guilt
tripping on us.  

And I won't stand for it, not a moment longer.

Please, I beg of you, cease your emotional hooliganism.  We are interested
in what you have to say, not your attacks on our character and our efforts
to help each other, our house nation, this country, our planet, of which
it is increasingly clear you know vanishingly little.

My friends here will vouch for the fact that I have never flamed anyone
like this on this list in public.  Take this as a measure of my extreme
displeasure and the fact that many others are standing by waiting for
this to settle down so we can return to the great and small issues that
await us.  

Now I've said my piece, so I will stand down.

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 25 01:31:28 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id BAA02888; Sat, 25 Mar 1995 01:31:28 -0800

	id AA17194; Sat, 25 Mar 1995 02:31:27 -0700
Message-Id: <9503250931.AA17194@selway.umt.edu>
To: "San FranDisco Raver's List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: I am a xenophobic racist...
Date: Sat, 25 Mar 95 02:31:21 -0700
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@selway.umt.edu>
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	This is too gahdamn much! I've stayed out of this till now,
but Frazer and David have gone COMPLETELY over the edge.

David Dei the Wise Leader spaketh unto us:
> Well, I though this might be a tough nut to crack, but was not prepared for
> the level of DENIAL.

	You're going to have to back yourself up on this one,
mister. Denial of what? Denial that we're racist? Denial that America
is fucked up? Denial that I, Forrest Norvell (stepping outside the
veil of my net.personality for the moment), am personally responsible
for the suffering of a poor African child that I've never even seen?
Your words are very slippery and vague; if you're going to take people
to task you could at least say what the hell you're talking about.

> I suppose we can put this down to that "rugged individualism" taught in
> this society. So obviously any attempt to talk about SOCIETY is going to
> run into flack by those so heavily brainwashed that they cannot even begin
> to imagine what a society without this principle might be like. Again, I
> said I would be willing to defend my position that there is such a thing as
> collective guilt. As yet NOT ONE INDIVIDUAL on this list has stood up and
> even tried to claim some responsiblity for America or tried to move towards
> where this all should be heading which is out of the present state of
> DENIAL to an ACCEPTANCE that things are definitly WRONG and need CHANGING.
> There's a bit of discussion  going on in the democracy slaves thread, but
> as usual its mainly an exchange of what ifs, without anyone coming to any
> agreement.

	I am going to do something I generally avoid: I am going to
use my ruggedly individualistic perogative to call you a knob,
David. I think most folks on sfraves are quite aware of America's
SOCIETAL problems when it comes to sensitive issues like racism,
xenophobia, sexism, and ageism. I'd even go so far to say that the
list is more sensitive to these issues than most other forums,
anywhere in the world! I also think that most of the people on this
list do not think they bear much blame for America's current sad state
when it comes to these matters. If every person on this list, working
in coordination with each other, were to dedicate the rest of their
lives to solving these problems, they wouldn't be able to do it. The
reason people don't talk about these issues as much as they probably
should is that we've already won all the easy, surface battles.
	Now we have to change how people think, which isn't nearly as
easy. It's easier to get courts to enforce busing than it is to change
the thinking of somebody that's grown up steeped in everyday racism,
as you should know. Things aren't all peaches and cream in South
Africa, after all, now are they? (The battle brewing over schooling is
but one of the many areas where South Africa is still far from
Utopian.)
	And by practicing the kind of divisive proselytizing you're
engaging in, you are not only pissing us off in the short run, you may
be permanently turning some people off to the ideas you're
espousing. Every time some hard-right Christian preacher comes to our
campus and screams "All of you are whores!" at women walking by, he or
she has wrecked Christianity's credibility with all of the thinking
people that listen to her or him.

> Now I know that it would probably be a lot easier if I always referred to
> this in an ABSTRACT way instead of using individuals to demonstrate my
> point.   So what I'll do is erase references to names while keeping the
> examples so as to prevent the loss of face that results in flamage. What
> blows me away is that most of the responses seem to be trying to defend the
> RIGHT TO BE A RACIST and  THE RIGHT TO SET ONESELF APART.

	Quite simply, you're wrong, or you're reading a different list
than I am. Not only that, it's a little late for you to "erase
references to names." What little credibility you had left with me
disappeared when you flat-out accused Josh of being racist. Making
such a bold accusation towards somebody you don't know is scandalously
arrogant, as well as being the grossest possible breach of
net.etiquette.
	People seem to be trying very hard to defend their rights
_not_ to be racist, in the face of your accusations. And I'm very
hard-pressed to find any fault in taking pride in individuality, as
long as everybody recognizes that most great accomplishments are the
work of groups and not individuals. That is, I may be a heck of a
special person, but if I do anything particularly wonderful, that's
more an expression of the fact that I'm surrounded by wonderful people
than any genius on my part. You can have it both ways here.

> This idea of INDIVIDUAL FREEDOM - that we should allow all types of
> behaviour and thought in the infinite diversity of the universe is perhaps
> fundemental to american society. Coupled with this is the idea of
> RELATIVITY -
> that just as each idea is equally valid, all possiblities have relative
> meaning.

	You and my conservative Christian Republican grandfather would
get along wonderfully. He talks like this all the time. Of course, he
thinks that everybody should be conservative, God-fearing, and
Republican like him, so that we can reclaim America's former glory.
	With all due respect, it's very hard to avoid falling into a
relativistic worldview when you're barraged from all sides by people
telling you that everything you think is wrong and/or criminally
stupid. I may be an opinionated fuck and _know_ (on some level or
another) that my moral system is complete, consistent, and
fundamentally right, but what do you and I do when we discover that
both of our convictions are equally strong but our beliefs completely
divergent?
	America is a country that has been sewn together from many
different systems of belief, most of them wildly divergent. While it
would be nice if we had a homogenous culture where all of us believed
in the same values and ideals (and I'm sure that you would rather they
be your values and ideals), our history is such that that is nothing
more than wishful thinking. I live in the same state with armed nuts
who believe that taxes are not only wrong but a sin in the eyes of
God! How am I supposed to recognize their undoubted right to live and
make happy lives for themselves without deciding to live and let
live? Yeah, I think that their beliefs are stupid, but I'm sure they
think mine are just as dumb, and I don't think that either one of us
is going to be very successful in persuading the other to see things
differently.

> Example A
> 
> >Yeah sure man I'M A RACIST. I differentiate between living-humans & those
> >pitifull non-living-non-thinking-humans, I make my own damn vocabulary & I say
> >their races. I have some patience with them but you're starting to make me
> >wish this was a segragated list.
> 
> Here we see the classic american defence of last resort -
> < I make my own damn vocabulary & I say
> their races. >
> 
>  What the writer is defending is his intrinsic ability to GOVERN HIS OWN
> SELF - to SAY what he likes and so on.

	Are you being a dumbshit on purpose here? Excuse the harsh
language, but when I read the letter you quote above, what I saw was
exasperation and irony. You are claiming to be a mind-reader and KNOW
what this guy's attitudes are, and he's flipping you the bird!
	And what the fuck is so damn "classic" or "American" about
that defence? He's being sarcastic! You've filed him in a little
folder, and he's saying, in his sarcastic way, "maybe you don't know
me as well as you think you do."

> And here we have an sfraver who actually restates the above:
> 
> >His message refers to members of any
> >racial group as "them" in reference to judgement. It didn't sound like it
> >was a matter of the use of "us" vs. "them" but rather "me(as an individual"
> >vs. "them." Your argument denies the possibility of the individual as a
> >seperate and distinct entity WITHIN a group.

	Again, this is a basic matter of disagreement, but I guess I'm
not surprised at the above poster's temerity in asserting that
individuality is important. It may come as a shock to you, but there
are many ravers (myself included) who regard all of this fascination
with New Age concerns with more than a little bemusement. It is
possible to believe in the four rave cornerstones of Peace, Love,
Unity, and Respect, while still thinking that "Alien Consciousness",
the Tantra, Virtual Reality, community consciousness, and better
living through chemicals are a bargeload of bologna. "Raving" is
inevitably going to mean different things to everybody who hears the
word, because it's new and because it's something that encourages
self-exploration.

>  And here we have perhaps the quaint motivation for this insider/outsider
>  thing:
> 
> >It may be a flaw of mine that I do consider
> >some people outsiders, in one way I consider everybody outsiders afterall
> >their not inside me, but they are always given a chance to become
> >"insiders" & are not placed in/out-side the group based on pety things such a
> >race.

	You get 10 negative brownie points for the use of "quaint",
and I still fail to see how you've argued anything coherent with the
use of this quote.

> Now some rambling in the way of explanation:
> 
> SEGREGATION: the seperation of the whole into its constituent parts. The
> marking of territory. A line of difference seperating two objects.

	And the act which makes it possible for us to recognize and
respond to the world. Without the ability to separate "one" from "the
other," the world becomes an undifferentiated mass and therefore
unnavigable. I personally like being able to tell chocolate from
dirt. It makes eating much more pleasant.
	Humans like to be able to break things down into
chunks. That's just one of those psychological facts. Without
classification, there's simply too much stuff to keep track of in the
world. Every time you recognize a tree, you recognize that other stuff
_isn't_ a tree. I'm getting way out here on the philosophical limb
here, so I'll climb back in towards the trunk a little bit. Suffice it
to say that our brains wouldn't be able to work without segregation,
and that segregation is only evil when we start using specious logic
to elevate one class of things over another.

> In South Africa and the Deep South, segregation was OVERT. The seperation
> was mainly along class and race lines, with WHITES ONLY signs deliniating
> the areas in which people could or could not travel.
> 
> In the 1984/5  overt segregation in south africa ended and the signs were
> torn down as they had been in the Deep South in the 60s. But as we all
> know, things did not end there.
> 
> The end of OVERT American Aparthied in the 60s was merely replaced with a
> more tenacious form of COVERT apartheid. Instead of segregating people
> along clearly racial lines, the policing of society would occur by
> completing  the process and reasoning of segregation. - NOW ALL AMERICANS
> were segregated into INDIVIDUAL PARTS. Thus Rugged Individualism became
> merely a code word for Seperation.

	A simple question: what leads you to believe that things will
progress any differently in South Africa? It's been fewer than ten
years since apartheid officially ended. One black president does not
an integrated republic make.

> The Community Uprisings of the 60s had to be prevented at all costs.
> Express orders were given by the Nixon Administration which hold to this
> day, to prevent at all costs the rise of any figure capable of uniting the
> people - black and white. (Hence the Luther-King and Malcolm X
> asassinations.) The splintering and disarming of the PEOPLE was helped by
> an interesting process of cultural relativism - a black nation was carved
> up as the indian nation before it - into its "tribal" parts. The idea of
> "black conscousness" in the 60s had been one of inclusion of all those
> oppressed by the colonials (although flawed by its exclusion of the
> majority of WASPS who had not commited class suicide ie given up there
> inheritance) where everyone who was not white was black - thus the idea of
> asian-american did not exist. An asian was considered black as was a native
> american. We can now begin to see the pattern. Fragmentation, Splintering,
> Alienation

	I fail to see your point. Are you claiming that this
fragmentation was driven by external agitators? Should Asian-Americans
want to be considered the same as African-Americans, despite their
differing agendas? I know that's a very loaded question, and one that
I have no business answering one way or the other, but I do feel that
it's a valid question. And how does an ordinary guy of mixed European
descent (like me) stop this fragmentation? Preaching at them and
belittling them for their own ignorance?

> Now thats such an underused word nowadays Alienation - the ideas developed
> by Albert Camus, Frantz Fanon that were so fashionable in the 60s, the idea
> that it was possible for an individual to be CUT_OFF from not only Society
> but even his own intrinsic nature.

	Yeah, and as I remember, Camus was arguing that we're all
alienated, and that part of the process of acculturation is
self-alienation (as you give up part of your own individuality to make
it possible for you to be part of the society), and that this is even,
in some sense desirable. Desirable, that is, if you want to be part of
society. Beyond that, I think that Camus and you part company, he
being the curmudgeonly misanthrope that he was.

> So what we have here are two parallel histories, but with very different
> consequences.

	I don't think so....

> In south africa right now people have embraced a POLITICS OF INCLUSION -
> all children have become OUR CHILDREN ,all people have become OUR PEOPLE.
> No one including the most rightwing individual has been excluded. Speaking
> to the previous generation, I still find it amazing that all of a sudden
> their lives have changed - my mother after years of being a boring
> housewife chatting to other old hens has suddenly reawakened her talent as
> an artist. Everywhere people feel as if ANYTHING and EVERYTHING is
> possible. Spontaneous outbreaks of OPTIMISM have become the order of the
> Day.

	...because this is flat-out BULLSHIT! I honestly cannot
believe you are making such a grandiose and patently untrue statement!
Not only are your comments about your own mother sexist and ageist (as
other people have commented), South Africa hasn't even made it as far
as the late-'60s-era USA!
	Your whole argument falls apart here -- I have been following
what has been going on in South Africa, and although great strides
have been made there, there is no way you can make such a blanket
statement. What about the tribal violence? What about the huge battles
over schooling? What about the continuing black-on-black police
brutality?
	None of these things can be easily dismissed. Anybody that
reads the Economist with any regularity knows how much is still going
wrong in SA. It may well be that these problems will all be worked out
in the short- to medium-term. But it's still far too soon to paint a
picture of South Africa as Racially Harmonious Utopia and the United
States as a nation mired in its own hopeless apathy and ignorance.

> Which is why I believe in RAVE - because what rave teaches -is this - it is
> possible to join in the dance, in the community without LOSING your
> INDIVIDUALITY.
> 
> IN FACT, ones individuality is enhanced, healed, awakened by the COMMUNITY
> VIBE. For what we have in Rave is an ANTIDOTE to the splintering, the
> fragmentation ,the seperation of global apartheid.

	I agree completely and unhesitatingly with you here.

> BUT let me rest my case with just one addition - WE NEED TO RAVE WITH
> PURPOSE and INTENTION. Otherwise, rave will remain just another segregated
> area. We need to take the communitarian spirit generated each week on the
> dancefloor OUT into the Streets, into our homes, into our places of work
> and worship. That way we begin to assuage the collective guilt, and burden
> of our generation, by changing the world, remaking it in a brighter shade
> of rave.
>
> This is what we did in South Africa, and just as it worked down there, it
> is bound to work over here.

	No matter what I try to come up with to respond to this, I'm
left speechless. Both you and Frazer seem to possess the worst kind of
boundless and naively self-assured arrogance. You are saying two
completely different things at the same time, and I'm not sure which
one of the two I like less. On the one hand, you're saying that we
should all subsume our individualistic spirits into a greater
community whole (which wouldn't be bad except for how often it leads
to rampant totalitarianism), but on the other, you're seriously
claiming that raving ended apartheid (on one level or another).
	I now understand why this thread refuses to die -- every time
it shows any signs of dissipating somewhat, you and Frazer have to
subject us to another six or seven of your jingoistic and
ill-thought-out screeds. I really hate to get personal in debates, but
you've succeeded in making me very angry. I know that I'm arrogant
sometimes, but the responses from the people involved in Megatripolis
have been dizzyingly egocentric, condescending, and
self-satisfied. The only revolution you're going to start with your
current attitudes is one that seeks to get rid of you.

> - david dei

yrz sincerely,
ozymandias G desiderata

Following the father and son report posted yesterday, here are some
comments by ravers who attended the first Megatripolis Parallel University
of the year last Saturday, the CHEMICA SUTRA Technoerotic Expedition, a
book launch rave for BETTER SEX THROUGH CHEMISTRY - A GUIDE TO THE NEW
PROSEXUAL DRUGS by John Morgenthaler and Dan Joy. 

DJ PAUL Q:  I thought the whole thing was really good - good people, good
energy, loud, I liked it, it was fun ... the best thing was meeting all
sorts of people, hanging out, talking, smoking - and playing records! the
energy came together in litle groups all over the place, but the little
groups were always changing so everything kept moving .. the dancefloor
was too small but it was very well lit.  I'll let other people describe my
music, I think!  

GRAHAM:  first of all it took place in this place that's just impossible
to describe.  it's full of stuff that looks like the man who owns it
collected over years - exotica, stuffed animals and paintings - 

KATE:  it makes you think of the film Performance with Jagger.  

TOM:  it's got more stuff in it than any museum you ever go in really! 

GRAHAM:  it made the place really relaxed, as soon as I walked in here
tonight I thought MY GOD!  it's a good vibe in here, I think, a really
unsettled vibe because there are so many things from different places. 

KATE:  yeah, all the different artefacts and a really good mix of people,
and it all came together. 

GRAHAM:  I'm sure a few owners of the stuff were here tonight - that they
owned two or three hundred years ago 

TOM:  like that moose's head?! 

KATE: if I had to choose one thing, then for me it's always the music, and
that was kicking, amazing, yeah, way to go!  it was nice.  but it's also a
great play space, and being able to move around, listen to stuff, learn a
bit, you know, it's been a good experience. 

GRAHAM:  the photographs that were being projected were the best part of
the party, I thought, they're by Julia Morris, a couple of bisexual
friends of hers making love. 

JULIA:  oh man, don't ask me now, it's too early in the morning! 

GRAHAM:  no, the best thing was a lot of good interaction among the people
and the relaxed vibe. 

KATE:  the body painting too!  Jason's a great body painter, he was
painting that model all over for hours, Sparrow?  

GRAHAM:  I thought they were tattoos when I walked in. 

JULIA:  yeah, I wanted to get painted. 

TOM:  it's like having a tattoo for the night, so you get the thrill
without the pain or the paranoia that you're going to have it for the rest
of your life 

ADRIAN:  it was just a lovely experience!  the dancefloor was hot, they
were kicking it! 

DJ PAUL:  I liked the one girl who asked if I had any rock and roll
records! 

CATHY:  I thought it was a really interesting mix of people and I thought
that, even though they all came from different backgrounds and they all
had different interests, I think that the energy coalesced and everybody
became one and it was an amazing experience.  also the dancefloor was just
great, the DJ was really good and the music was moving the whole time and
everybody seemed to be having a really good time.

On Fri, 24 Mar 1995, D. Ronan Hallowell wrote:

> 
> "We are now faced with the fact that tomorrow is today. We are confronted 
> with the fierce urgency of now. In this unfolding conudrum of life and 
> history there is such a thing as being too late. Procrastination is still 
> the thief of time. Life often leaves us standing bare, naked and dejected 
> with a lost opportunity... We may cry out desperately for time to pause 
> in her passage, but time is deaf to every plea and rushes on. Over the 
> bleached bones and jumbled residues of numerous civilizations are written 
> the pathetic words :'Too late'... We still have a choice today: 
> nonviolent coexsistence or violent coannihilation. This may well be 
> mankinds last chance to choose between chaos and community."
> 							- M.L. King
> It is not suprising to see this provocative thread move through this list 
> at this time. Our times our wrought with peril and we can no longer go on 
> ignoring the ills of the past and present which threaten our future.War, 
> racism, ecological destruction and social decay are bringing our species 
> and the Earth to the brink of catastrophe. In the midst of the decay 
> there is also hope for re-forming the world into something more peaceful 
> and loving. Whether we like it or not rave culture in many ways is 
> embedded within and accelerating this transformation.
> 
> These issues are complex and this medium is still very young. We all have 
> a long way to go. Education is integral for peaceful and prosperous 
> evolution. We must learn from our mistakes and move on with open hearts 
> and a willingness to try new things. There are a lot of people in 
> the U.S. and all around the world who are deluding themselves when they 
> deny the severity of the issues that face us. Most people are in such 
> serious denial because they are afraid. Fear inhibits transformation. 
> For the learning process to be effective we need a space free from fear.
> For me , at times raves have provided a safe space of celebration in 
> which I could see beyond the limits of my social conditioning and my own 
> fears.
> 
> As we try to experiment with the synalogue (many to many discussion) that 
> is SFRaves we should try to cultivate styles of communication which can 
> tackle difficult issues, express the maximum amount of individuality 
> while also maintaining an openness for different opinions in a friendly 
> discussion aimed  at the the development of insight and understanding.
> 
> Two books on racism that I find interesting are:
> 
> _Race Matters_ by Cornel West &
> 
> _Yearning: Race,Gender & Cultural Politics_ by bell hooks
> 
> both available at decent bookstores in the area
> 
> Yours in Transformation,
> ronan
>

dear forrest, great post!  all I ask is that you and a couple of others
stop including me with what david has been saying on this subject.  I've
said almost nothing at all in this thread; indeed I posted yesterday (and
have told him ftf) that I thought he should have left this stuff till much
later when we all know each other a lot better. I have a lot of respect
for his firsthand knowledge and dedication in these matters and love for
him, of course, which I am *not* denying, but it seems I get blamed for
"leading"  the zippies, and for *not* leading the zippies.  we're all free
individuals, our common ground being our desire to unite tecno and organic
in ourselves and on our planet - which, as I've said endlessly, is a
pretty huge area of agreement which still allows within it all manner of
individual differences of emphasis and personal priorities.  that's all. 
I deeply appreciate what you've written but, as I've already said, I am
not going to get involved in this thread at all right now. of course if
you're criticising me for *something else* then let me know so I can
defend myself or 'fess up.  OK?  >:-) fraser.

> work of groups and not individuals. That is, I may be a heck of a

> more an expression of the fact that I'm surrounded by wonderful people

> stupid. I may be an opinionated fuck and _know_ (on some level or
> another) that my moral system is complete, consistent, and
> fundamentally right, but what do you and I do when we discover that
> both of our convictions are equally strong but our beliefs completely
> divergent?
> 	America is a country that has been sewn together from many
> different systems of belief, most of them wildly divergent. While it
> would be nice if we had a homogenous culture where all of us believed
> in the same values and ideals (and I'm sure that you would rather they
> be your values and ideals), our history is such that that is nothing
> more than wishful thinking. I live in the same state with armed nuts
> who believe that taxes are not only wrong but a sin in the eyes of
> God! How am I supposed to recognize their undoubted right to live and
> make happy lives for themselves without deciding to live and let
> live? Yeah, I think that their beliefs are stupid, but I'm sure they
> think mine are just as dumb, and I don't think that either one of us
> is going to be very successful in persuading the other to see things
> differently.

> 	Again, this is a basic matter of disagreement, but I guess I'm

> 	You get 10 negative brownie points for the use of "quaint",
> and I still fail to see how you've argued anything coherent with the
> use of this quote.
> 
> > Now some rambling in the way of explanation:
> > 
> > SEGREGATION: the seperation of the whole into its constituent parts. The
> > marking of territory. A line of difference seperating two objects.
> 
> 	And the act which makes it possible for us to recognize and
> respond to the world. Without the ability to separate "one" from "the
> other," the world becomes an undifferentiated mass and therefore
> unnavigable. I personally like being able to tell chocolate from
> dirt. It makes eating much more pleasant.
> 	Humans like to be able to break things down into
> chunks. That's just one of those psychological facts. Without
> classification, there's simply too much stuff to keep track of in the
> world. Every time you recognize a tree, you recognize that other stuff
> _isn't_ a tree. I'm getting way out here on the philosophical limb
> here, so I'll climb back in towards the trunk a little bit. Suffice it
> to say that our brains wouldn't be able to work without segregation,
> and that segregation is only evil when we start using specious logic
> to elevate one class of things over another.
> 
> > In South Africa and the Deep South, segregation was OVERT. The seperation
> > was mainly along class and race lines, with WHITES ONLY signs deliniating
> > the areas in which people could or could not travel.
> > 
> > In the 1984/5  overt segregation in south africa ended and the signs were
> > torn down as they had been in the Deep South in the 60s. But as we all
> > know, things did not end there.
> > 
> > The end of OVERT American Aparthied in the 60s was merely replaced with a
> > more tenacious form of COVERT apartheid. Instead of segregating people
> > along clearly racial lines, the policing of society would occur by
> > completing  the process and reasoning of segregation. - NOW ALL AMERICANS
> > were segregated into INDIVIDUAL PARTS. Thus Rugged Individualism became
> > merely a code word for Seperation.
> 
> 	A simple question: what leads you to believe that things will
> progress any differently in South Africa? It's been fewer than ten
> years since apartheid officially ended. One black president does not
> an integrated republic make.
> 
> > The Community Uprisings of the 60s had to be prevented at all costs.
> > Express orders were given by the Nixon Administration which hold to this
> > day, to prevent at all costs the rise of any figure capable of uniting the
> > people - black and white. (Hence the Luther-King and Malcolm X
> > asassinations.) The splintering and disarming of the PEOPLE was helped by
> > an interesting process of cultural relativism - a black nation was carved
> > up as the indian nation before it - into its "tribal" parts. The idea of
> > "black conscousness" in the 60s had been one of inclusion of all those
> > oppressed by the colonials (although flawed by its exclusion of the
> > majority of WASPS who had not commited class suicide ie given up there
> > inheritance) where everyone who was not white was black - thus the idea of
> > asian-american did not exist. An asian was considered black as was a native
> > american. We can now begin to see the pattern. Fragmentation, Splintering,
> > Alienation
> 
> 	I fail to see your point. Are you claiming that this
> fragmentation was driven by external agitators? Should Asian-Americans
> want to be considered the same as African-Americans, despite their
> differing agendas? I know that's a very loaded question, and one that
> I have no business answering one way or the other, but I do feel that
> it's a valid question. And how does an ordinary guy of mixed European
> descent (like me) stop this fragmentation? Preaching at them and
> belittling them for their own ignorance?
> 
> > Now thats such an underused word nowadays Alienation - the ideas developed
> > by Albert Camus, Frantz Fanon that were so fashionable in the 60s, the idea
> > that it was possible for an individual to be CUT_OFF from not only Society
> > but even his own intrinsic nature.
> 
> 	Yeah, and as I remember, Camus was arguing that we're all
> alienated, and that part of the process of acculturation is
> self-alienation (as you give up part of your own individuality to make
> it possible for you to be part of the society), and that this is even,
> in some sense desirable. Desirable, that is, if you want to be part of
> society. Beyond that, I think that Camus and you part company, he
> being the curmudgeonly misanthrope that he was.
> 
> > So what we have here are two parallel histories, but with very different
> > consequences.
> 
> 	I don't think so....
> 
> > In south africa right now people have embraced a POLITICS OF INCLUSION -
> > all children have become OUR CHILDREN ,all people have become OUR PEOPLE.
> > No one including the most rightwing individual has been excluded. Speaking
> > to the previous generation, I still find it amazing that all of a sudden
> > their lives have changed - my mother after years of being a boring
> > housewife chatting to other old hens has suddenly reawakened her talent as
> > an artist. Everywhere people feel as if ANYTHING and EVERYTHING is
> > possible. Spontaneous outbreaks of OPTIMISM have become the order of the

> 
> 	...because this is flat-out BULLSHIT! I honestly cannot
> believe you are making such a grandiose and patently untrue statement!
> Not only are your comments about your own mother sexist and ageist (as
> other people have commented), South Africa hasn't even made it as far
> as the late-'60s-era USA!
> 	Your whole argument falls apart here -- I have been following
> what has been going on in South Africa, and although great strides
> have been made there, there is no way you can make such a blanket
> statement. What about the tribal violence? What about the huge battles
> over schooling? What about the continuing black-on-black police
> brutality?
> 	None of these things can be easily dismissed. Anybody that
> reads the Economist with any regularity knows how much is still going
> wrong in SA. It may well be that these problems will all be worked out
> in the short- to medium-term. But it's still far too soon to paint a
> picture of South Africa as Racially Harmonious Utopia and the United

> 
> > Which is why I believe in RAVE - because what rave teaches -is this - it is
> > possible to join in the dance, in the community without LOSING your
> > INDIVIDUALITY.
> > 
> > IN FACT, ones individuality is enhanced, healed, awakened by the COMMUNITY

> 	I agree completely and unhesitatingly with you here.

> > BUT let me rest my case with just one addition - WE NEED TO RAVE WITH

> 	No matter what I try to come up with to respond to this, I'm

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)

Subject: Racism and Raving
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	Racism is a disease.  It is a very powerful meme that infects 
	cultures.  It can and will infect any human individual regardless
	of genetic or cultural make-up, political agenda, beliefs, etc.
	Almost every one on the planet is "Racism Positive", it is unavoidable
	if you live in the "western world". (I've never lived in the "non-
	western" world so I can't comment on that) Society at large, whether
	you are "black" or "white", teaches you to be racist.  In this country
	SKIN COLOR seems to be the way that people are racially classified.
	It has always amazed me that, for instance, well let's take a 
	"hypothetical" example...  Two "interracial couples" have children.
	(For the sake of the argument the Male of couple A is a "black african"
	from lagos, the Female is a "white celt" from Wales, the Female of
	couple B is a Senagalese "black" the Male is a "Parisian White".
	Each couple has 5 or more children who come out varying shades of 
	brown, (african genes tend to be dominant), now the fun begins...
	A "light" Male from couple A meets a "darker" Female of the B clan,
	they fall in love and have children (This is prime time kiddies:).
	One child comes out with very wavey dark blonde hair, hazel eyes
	full lips and "fair skin" (though she gets a savage tan in the summer :)
	her brother comes out with slightly darker hair, mich more kinky,
	clearly brown skin, brown eyes and long legs.  Now they both move to
	New York and go about their respective lives, one's an artist, the
	other becomes a stock broker on wall street.  Christmas comes
	and the stock broker invites their sibling to the company cocktail
	party where they introduce people to their sister/brother. The "blacks" 
	in the room say "Gee I didn't realize she was a sista" the "white"
	people in the room say "Gee I didn't realize he had "white blood" in
	the family."  The interesting thing is that from now on she will be
	looked upon as being "non-white" or "black" by anybody (on both sides
	of the political/cultural spectrum) if they see her brother or other
	"dark" people from her family.  This obsession with color, drives 
	racism in this country.  I have a friend who is "jewish" (of european
	descent) she dated lots of different people, but not many "jewish"
	(by jewish law) guys.  Finally she met one that she loved, but he
	also happened to be "black", ( His grandmother on his mother's side
	was an ashkanasi jew, which by jewish law makes him jewish) 
	He also proffessed to follow judaism (more or less).  
	Honestly thinking that her granmother would be pleased that she had 
	finally found a "nice jewish boy" she takes him home. WRONG!

	So what is to be done?  We ALL are racism positive, some are in
	advanced stages, some are in remission, but we all carry the virus.
	Part of recovery (or at least management) of the disease is to recognize
	that we all have it and that it is active to some extent, that doesn't
	make you bad, wrong, or anything and it DOESN'T MAKE YOU A RACIST.
	A RACIST is someone who exhibits symptoms of the advanced stages of the`
	disease.

	Raving, in it's pure form is a cultural anti-body or counter meme to
	racism,  But since we all carry the meme of racism and we bring that
	with us to the parties that we attend and throw, it is easy to fall
	back into racist behavior, the society at large pushes us that way.
	At a good party all of that bullshit is broken down by the Vibe.
	I have seen the Vibe so strong that it has literally put the toughest
	homeboy in tears (well maybe he got a hold of a good hit of E as well:)
	In case all of you "white" people didn't know, what is behind that
	"tough gangster" pose that people tend to lable on many people of color
	is the sadness and fear of a society that has excluded them, remember
	we/they watch the same TV as you did when you grew up.  Little children
	are naturally enthusiastic, even young black children in the ghetto
	come up believeing that they are loved and accepted by society BUT
	THEY LEARN VERY QUICKLY that that is not the case, (usually by age 10)
	all that is left is amazement, sadness, and a sense of being unloved,
	this turns into resolution, anger and rage. But if you can (and not
	everyone has the strength courage or abilities) take on the healing
	of this situation, you will see the most amazing transformation of
	your life.

	Some of us on the list are going to make an attempt this summer.

	Stay Tuned.

From: ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest.net (ken stuart)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: sfravers and the zippies
Date: 24 Mar 1995 23:17:51 GMT

Precedence: bulk

Hello,

I've been following the discussions here, concerning the zippies, F&F,
UK raves, etc.

So far, I have yet to see any explicit zippie philosophy, other than
bits and pieces - so I have to comment based on that.  If my perception
is wrong, it is only because the zippies have not posted a pointer to a
specific philosophy.  Also, I am including all of David Dei's posts
with the letterhead "Megatripolis Parallel University" on it as being
part of the zippie philosophy (otherwise he shouldn't use that .sig).

>From what I have read on hyperreal and on sfraves for a year, I think
that there is a definite difference in outlook on life between sfraves
and the zippies.

My reading is that the sfraves philosophy centers around PLUR - Peace,
Love, Unity and Respect.  This is in complete sync with The Summer of
Love in San Francisco in 1967, where the hippies put flowers into the
gun barrels of the police - and got a smile in return.  The idea here
is Love will *transform* the world -- one person at a time.

The posts of the zippies seem to center around the negativity in the
world.   They seem to feel that you can fix the problems in the world
one by one.  They don't seem to realize that these problems (racism,
poverty, etc.) are SYMPTOMS, not causes.  The cause is negativity in
people's hearts.  If you fix one problem, another will arise in its
place due to this negativity.

You don't cure darkness by studying it and informing people about the
characteristics of darkness - YOU JUST TURN ON THE LIGHT.

This is why sfraves people can't understand why someone would turn off
the music and stop the vibe - to lecture in the middle of a rave.

The vibe speaks much more eloquently than any words.

respect for all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
ken.stuart@tigerteam.org


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 25 04:07:09 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id EAA07812; Sat, 25 Mar 1995 04:07:09 -0800
Received: from mtshasta.snowcrest.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id EAA07797; Sat, 25 Mar 1995 04:07:04 -0800
Received: from macshasta.snowcrest.net (macshast@localhost) by mtshasta.snowcrest.net (8.6.5/8.6.5) with UUCP id DAA10953 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 25 Mar 1995 03:59:08 -0800
From: ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest.net (ken stuart)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: sfravers and the zippies - specifics
Date: 24 Mar 1995 23:18:59 GMT

Organization: Rich Renouf

Precedence: bulk

Hello,

Here are some specifics of why I have found the zippie philosophy to be
somewhat negative and materialistic.  This is based on what I have read
here - if this is inaccurate, then post a pointer to where we can access
text that says otherwise. 

Fraser> Laptoppling The System

This phrase illustrates a general point of view, which is that our
problems are due to "the system".  Unfortunately, if you look at Bosnia
and Russia, where much worse systems were toppled, you find that
toppling the system does nothing, by itself, to improve things.

Dei>All I received back was anger - how dare I generalise, as if the
>opinion that this country consumes 75% of the worlds resources were just an
>opinion, that might only hold valid for some US citizens.

I won't get into how this ambiguous statistic in constructed.  

Instead, I'll point out that many people I met in India with incomes of
$30 a month were a LOT happier than most rich Americans.

Material resources do not bring happiness.  So, accusing us of hogging
75% of what is a minor aspect of reality is just plain silly.

Dei>SO my SF friends - DO not be alarmed if I continue to badger you all
>UNTIL YOU BEGIN TO ACCEPT A BIT OF THE RESPONSIBILITY FOR PUTTING RIGHT THE
>WRONGS COMMITTED BY THIS COUNTRY EVEN IF THEY WERE COMMITTED BY A PREVIOUS
>GENERATION because our dystanies are all intertwined.

I'm sorry but I've never found ANY philosophical basis for this point
of view.  Each person is an individual.  There have been so many wrongs
committed in the history of the world, that it is impossible to count.
Each person *directly* involved is responsible.  Each person not involved 
is NOT responsible. 

The only way that this point of view is even conceivable is for people
to only focus on one or two wrongs (usually recent racism).  If they
bothered to open their minds to thousands of years of history, they
would understand how silly this idea is.  Are Italians responsible for
every injustice by the Romans?  Are the French responsible for the acts
of Charlemagne and Napoleon?  Are the Hungarians responsible for the
acts of Attila?  Are the Mongolians responsible for the acts of Gengis
Khan? 

:-) And, what if we are descended from Aliens?  Does that make us
responsible for injustices on Alpha Centauri?

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

1). You are right to say that their where many important white people in 
the early acid house movement particularly in the UK.
2). To say that that the acid house movement in England did not bridge 
the gap between funk (a black music but mostly listened to by whites) and 
reggae/dub/hip-hop (which was mostly listened to by blacks) is equally 
talking nonsence.  You were not in England for this movement (I was) so 
how can you comment on it?
3). I just back from Friday's at 1015 and yes you are right: their is a 
very good cross-over their and the vibe/people where a lot more racially 
mixed then at, say, Friends and Family.  This is excellent and is a good 
direction for the future.  I was well impressed!


On Thu, 23 Mar 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

> I'm not surprised to see Tristan extolling the virtues of UK society
> in the sense that there is more racial integration there.  At some
> levels this is true and some it is not; it is also true that there
> is far more overt racism and violence in Britain.  It's not for nothing
> that Gary Clail declaims against "bigotry, intolerance and *racial*
> intolerance" in "Human Nature."  
> 
> Furthermore, to claim that the rave scene in the UK circa 1986 brough
> the youth of different races together for the first time is simply
> nonsense.  That era played an important and heartening role, in my view,
> to restrengthening ties of a historical nature that go back through the
> Mod and Two-Tone era of 1979 (when I was last in Britain), Two-Tone being
> the record label and an explicit recognition of the multi-racial 
> characteristics of the Mod Revival of the time featuring bands like The
> Selecter, and the broad support at the time across racial boundaries for
> bands like The Clash (remember "Guns of Brixton" and even "White Riot"
> and "White Man in Hammersmith Palais") and dub poet Linton Kwesi Johnson.
> 
> For more on all this, consult Dick Hebdige's seminal little book, "Cut
> 'n' Mix," which is not only an excellent backgrounder to the UK music
> scene but also does a musical/cultural analysis better than almost
> anything non-academic I've read.
> 
> And you don't have to stop in the late 1970s to trace these developments.
> You can go back further to the era of the original Mods and
> Teddies, and even the original Mod anthem, "Skinhead Moonstomp," when
> there were no racist skinheads, just kids who preferred to shave off their
> hair the way that others of the time were growing it long.  
> 
> I'm not going to teach the cultural history of Britain to those who were
> born and have lived there, of course; but I am trying to get across my
> limited historical knowledge on this issue.  I am very wary of overwrought
> claims on behalf of the house/rave/techno/underground, feeling as I do 
> that the changes and advances that it has already made and continues to
> make are amazing and valid enough in themselves. 
> 
> Most of the analysis I've read says that social divisions in the UK are
> far more determined by class than race, but that race continues to play
> a complicating role as always in these matters.  
> 
> While in San Francisco many events attract mostly a white audience, many
> others have more of a mixture; that's one of the things that attracted me
> to this scene to begin with, and it's still the case to some degree at the
> clubs.  Although it is definitively a *club* night with little raver
> overtones, I think that the Friday night combined clubs at 1015 Folsom are
> heading in a good direction, with the totally cool hip hop Dig club on 
> the upstairs floor (we had Charlotte just freakin' totally last Friday,
> meanwhile my friend DJ Collage who did the chant on Dub Tribe's "Mother
> Earth" is chatting up the lyrics to "Original Nuttah" right in time
> with her beat, which just made me crack up), the original disco-city
> crowd in the smaller downstairs room, Mark Farina spinning outstanding
> trippy jazz and house for Zendada in the basement, and Tracy, Simon,
> Jeno and Spun twisting our minds and jackin' our bodies under the aegis
> of Mark Ameba and Brothers & Sisters in the main room.  And like I said,
> despite the fact it's a *club* crowd, it's mixed by race, gender, age,
> presumably sexual orientation and everything else.  Not a perfect mix,
> but a mix.  And the same can be found in varying degrees at DV8 and the
> Sound Factory too.  
> 
> The point is,
> 
> You've got to remember, we're all part of the same family.
> 
> phred
> 
> By the way, Tristan is dead wrong about one thing.  There were definitely
> important white producers in the early acid house scene, but here I think
> the definitive thing you can say is that house and acid house came out
> of Chicago, New York and (branching off into the real, early techno)
> Detroit, then London, primarily out of clubs that catered to a large
> degree to the black gay disco crowd.  Like any generalization, this is
> not entirely true, but it's a realistic way of summing it up.  Let's 
> give credit where due, but let's not forget that house music, and all music,
> belongs to no single person or group, it belongs to us all, and it's up
> to us to listen, learn, enjoy, teach and create it as fits our own
> circumstances.  I hope we can put *this* particular issue to rest.
>

On Sat, 25 Mar 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> 3). I just back from Friday's at 1015 and yes you are right: their is a 
> very good cross-over their and 

>the vibe/people where a lot more racially 
> mixed then at, say, Friends and Family.  This is excellent and is a good > 
> 

Don't take this as a flame but please :-)  don't JUDGE Friends and Family on
a racial basis. One reason the mix of F&F comes out as it does is that the
core of the group comes from sfraves ie ONLINE. I teach computer science at
college of san mateo and I can tell you firsthand that there are FAR FAR
more whites and asians involved with computers than blacks. There are of 
course many reasons for this but the fact is still the fact. Thus, whenever
I see a group that comes from a computer background I would be STUNNED to
see more blacks and hispanics than whites and asians. My PhD is in chemistry
so I know that out of 150,000 recent degrees ( over a decade ) somewhere
less than 10% when to blacks/hispanics. I can also tell you that the
people who train chemists WANT to change this and recrute actively to change
this but change is slow - especially with the breakdown of family and school
dropout rates - the problems are many!

Thus, consider that you are now online yourself. DO YOU know as many people
of color who are as "computer active" as whites and asians? Would you expect
a group of people gathering from an online forum to have as many blacks as
whites for example? So judging F&F this way is both unfair and STUPID of you.
It will get people mad. It will get you judged as an idiot if not simply
foolish or naieve. It would help you perhaps if you met more of us outside
of the arguments that have been "exploding" on sfraves recently. There seems
to be a lot of misunderstandings surfacing. Perhaps more exploring on your
part is in order ? 

The F&F group is a wonderful group of people and from all I can tell not at
all racist. In my experience we welcome ANY and EVERY smiling face that
enters regardless of skin color. From what you say online YOU seem to be the
one that goes around looking at and counting representives of skin color.
"This group doesn't have enough black" "this group has the right amount of
 black, yellow and white" etc.  Why judge individuals this way? Why judge
 groups this way ?  Why judge at all ?



Mike

 On the subject of "Racism and Raving" , I'd like to play off some ideas that
Geoff brought up in his original post, informed sometimes with my (dated)
experience of growing up and living in Honolulu , Hawaii. My inserted
comments will be in [] marks.

>  Racism is a disease.  It is a very powerful meme that infects
> cultures.  It can and will infect any human individual..
>  Society at large, whether you are "black" or "white", [ or "asian" or
> "other"] teaches you to be racist.  In this country
> SKIN COLOR seems to be the way that people are racially classified.

 Another meme that is ingrained into us as much as the mitochondria
in our cells is what I used to call "ethnicism" ... I've decided to use the
term TRIBALISM instead. This being the identification by the individual
of membership in an "WE" group - "WE" being identified by common 
culture . It is a meme with good and bad points. Good: perpetuation of folk
culture ; providing isolated mental/cultural environments for the evolution
of ideas that may  be of benefit to other tribes; providing a haven and
comfort to the individual in harsh times. Bad: Definitions of "WE"
that depend on demonising/victimizing "THEM" ;  "WE" defined often 
strongly in genetic/racial terms; isolation of "WE" from beneficial ideas
from "THEM".

 Growing up in Hawaii , I saw both the good and bad of tribalism. While
all ethnic groups tended to group together for cultural events , a common
"local" regional culture developed that was a product of inputs from all
ethnic goups. Intermarriage is common - examples of "local" tribalism
over "ethnic" tribalism. And , yes , many parents had fits when their
children decided to marry outside the ethnic tribe.  Occupations and 
unemployment often seemed to be determined by ethnicity too , sadly.

 Aside: Whenever I see the term "tribal" used on a rave flyer or other
such context , it makes me smile a wry smile ...  :-\  

> So what is to be done?  We ALL are racism positive, some are in
> advanced stages, some are in remission, but we all carry the virus.
> that we all have it and that it is active to some extent, that doesn'tze
> make you bad, wrong, or anything and it DOESN'T MAKE YOU A RACIST.

 Racism/tribalism is a part of the human condition that , like defecation ,
everybody does , but nobody should expect to be praised for, or unduly
criticised for. Of course , if you smear your "excrement" all over the street
and insist that others do too ( the KKK , Aryan Nations , etc. ) then
you've got MY bad opinion! ( I better stop using this slippery analogy 
now! )

> Raving, in it's pure form is a cultural anti-body or counter meme to
> racism,  But since we all carry the meme of racism ....it is easy to fall
> back into racist behavior....

 Any space/event that allows the different "tribes" to come together in
common good intent will do a lot to reduce the demonizing of "THEM".
( Even sporting events !  Although, they are based on the participation
in a winner-take-all ritual conflict , not a shared hedonistic event. That's
one of the reasons why I prefer dancing at raves to being a screamer 
at a football game!)

 What I'm really waiting for  is the generation of local common cultures
analogous to the "local" culture I grew up with in Hawaii. Let all the "tribes"
give input to the creation of beautiful , new , every-evolving rare flowers.

 [ Sheesh! Whatever came over me! I must be trying too hard to go in to
   work on a Saturday .... still , it's a beautiful idea  :-) ]

	Love and inter/ethno/tribal sharing to you all!
	Larry "Pass the toilet paper, please" Ching

 From what I can remember ( having never gotten around to reading the 
WIRED magazine Zippy article , and only vaguely remembering other
articles and posts about Zippy philosophy ), the two ideas I like from 
the Zippy thang are:

 Megatripolis - A space where we can conceive of a future perfect 
   society , and in turn comport ourselves according to our idea of
   how the citizens of that future perfect society would act , and
   party amongst themselves.

 Pronoia - A feeling that somewhere , someone is intending or acting
   to do you a good deed. Also , behaviour based on that feeling.

 Cool , n'est pas?

 [ Ooops! HOT! HOT! ]

          Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

On Fri, 24 Mar 1995, Fraser Clark wrote:

> suggest a 3rd choice: that the white culture should regard itself as PART

Yes, that's true.  But other cultures are in turn separate from the white 
culture, but also part of the global culture.  That doesn't mean that 
they're the same or that they should be the same, or that they should be 
considered the same.

 Partially almost rave-related -

 There are two concerts in San Francisco this April that I'm going
to , and I was wondering if anyone else was going to them too. On
Monday , April 10th , Siouxie and the Banshees ( w/ Spiritualized )
are playing at the Warfield. The other concert is Hawkind ( the 
Dave Brock version of the band ) , playing at Slim's on Tuesday, 
April 25th. Hawkwind has been doing more ambient/techno stuff
in their recent work , which I like , although I've been a fan of
theirs since the late 70's , when they did more space rock/trippy
grunge stuff. 

 After the Hawkind show ( if it got out early enough ) , I was going
to try that club that has Jungle music on Tuesday nights ( I hope 
they're still doing that in a month's time ).

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 15:03:03 -0800 (PST)

Content-Length: 1214      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is from Starhawk, the _Spiral Dance_, on trance:

	"Rhythm, whether experienced in motion, song, drumming, chanting, 
or poetic meter, also induces a state of heightened 
awareness..AfroAmerican religions depend heavily on rhythmic drumming and 
dancing to induce a trance state in which worshippers become "mounted" or 
possessed by the "orishas," the Gods and Goddesses.  The metrical rhythm 
of poetry, according to Robert Graves, induces a trance of heightened 
sensitivity.  In Craft tradition, it was believed that certain rhythms 
could induce particular emotional states.  Drummers originally 
accompanied armies because their rhythms could make men fighting mad.  
(This secret, as far as I can tell, has been lost to the military and 
Witch covens alike, only to be redicovered by the producers of disco 
music.)  Spoken trance inductions are always soft, singsong, and rhythmic.
	Boredom can also bring on trance--as generations of daydreaming 
schoolchildren have disocvered.  When we are not stimulated, sensorily, 
emotionally, or mentally, awareness turns elsewhere."
(1979, revised 1989)

i guess we now know what she might think about house music, which, as i 
understand it, once was disco.

> 
> I just called the Tribal Funk line to get information regarding their
party and heard a disturbing discourse on tagging.  Amongst other things,
it has lost us the use of the Richmond Civic Center for all night parties? 
Is this true?  Would be hella sha me if it were.  But in general, i seem
to have noticed a decline in rave party locations as of late.  What's
going on?  Are promoters having an extremely difficult time finding
locations or are they getting lazy? 

having sought locations for Your Sisters' House, and to some extent, 
friends and family, i can tell you that yes, it is extremely difficult to 
find locations, both outdoor and indoor.  this is especially true if you 
want to throw an all-ages event, or an event where alcohol is not 
served (or where your use of the space is not contingent upon how much 
the bar makes.)  

and even if you want to hold a party in your own home (if it is large 
enough), you may run into problems.  the 938 harrison st. new year's eve 
ball was invitation-only, and was held in terrence alan's home and 
workspace.  maps were handed out to partygoers depicting all the fire 
exits.  yet it was still raided.  

ah, how i love san francisco!  the space problem makes me miss new york, 
where there's so much industrial wasteland and chaos that it's much 
easier to find a site (outside manhattan), providing you don't mind a bit 
of grunge and toxicity.  

monicat
