Tristan, make sure you read carefully before you oppose something I've
said.  I don't mind when people take an opposing view to mine, but
please don't put words in my mouth or simply misconstrue what I said
because you were not careful.

In response to your point #2, I did *not* say that acid house in the UK
did not bridge the gap between races and musical scenes.  Quite the
opposite, I said I applauded how this *rebuilt* the links that had been
established as long before as the early '60s (following the influx of
people from all over the Commonwealth, including Jamaica and the British
West Indies colonies, India, Pakistan and many other places, after the
end of World War II).  In fact, I went on for several *paragraphs* on 
this theme.  

I wasn't in the UK in the 1980s, but I was there in 1979.  I specifically
remember going to the now-demolished Nashville Room in Kensington to see
a show featuring the Mod Revival band the Purple Hearts.  The crowd there
was every ethnicity and gender and what-have-you.  The big news on the
scene was the Southall police repression from that spring which brought
everyone in London's working class neighborhoods, whether white Anglo,
Pakistani, West Indian or whatever, out against the new Thatcher government.
Culture, politics, music always interact with each other.  

phred

At 10:39 PM 24/3/95 -0800, Monica and Tom wrote:
>> collective guilt. As yet NOT ONE INDIVIDUAL on this list has stood up and
>> even tried to claim some responsiblity for America or tried to move towards
>> where this all should be heading which is out of the present state of
>> DENIAL to an ACCEPTANCE that things are definitly WRONG and need CHANGING.
>
>EXCUSE ME?  what the fuck do you think my post about organizing against
>police brutality was about?!

Point taken, however I would hope that we can move on to talking about how
RAVE itself fits in with these other issues - like how we are to at the
very least we may begin to start attaching values to what RAVE stands for -
so that when we say the word RAVE - we are not just left with a "that the
one where they take drugs and do some kinda temporary community thing "

I for one, would like to see our Temporary Autonomous ZOnes becoming
PERMANENT AUTONOMOUS ZONES - at the very least, this is what we deserve. To
spend so much time building up a community only to have it retreat into the
numbness of a grey street. - We need enormous zones of permanent beauty
-places where we feel SAFE, where we are all accepted for our intrinsic
basic value - where no one see us as OUTSIDERS deserving PERSECUTION.


>i haven't been following the past two days debates because i've been
>busy, but i am extremely upset that you have taken such a patronizing
>attitude towards all of us.  many of us are activists (i've organized for
>fucking years).  many of us are
>working for change in other ways.  no shit "things are definitely wrong."
>and i KNOW my history, thank you.

But you we might be forgiven for being firmly sincere if we arrived in a
world that was so  inescapably alienating to the human spirit that
aboriginals were cordened off in RESERVES and NO WHERE could I find a SMILE
on the STREET. If anything what unnerves me and causes my almost hysterical
"raise the alarm" attitude is to see people everywhere VISIBLY UNHAPPY. A
DROUGHT  of happiness of is what I have experienced in the 18 months I have
been on the west coast. People are so afraid, they turn from your gaze,
unable to look you in the eye. On haight street a child might laugh
nervously, scared, - another is zoned out, people everywhere talk in
whispers, their hands making no gestures. Faces devoid of animation, look
silently on, I am shocked at what I see. HOW COULD this BE? HOw could an
entire Country be so visibly under STRESS, In PAIN.

SURELY there must be a reason? surely something horrifically wrong has
occured here - lets ask a few people who seem to know whats up, in fact
lets demand, demand some answers - SFRAVERS HOW CAN THIS HAPPEN - please
tell me.


>> housewife chatting to other old hens has suddenly reawakened her talent as

>> possible. Spontaneous outbreaks of OPTIMISM have become the order of the
>> Day.

>
>yeah, as well as spontaneous outbreaks of ageism and sexism, david.  old

I am refereing to spontaneous LOSS of AGEISM - suddenly those OLD HENS are
reborn as artists, alive after years of sitting in wait for death. They
have miraculously found that life has given us all a second chance at our
dreams, and everywhere optimism trickles like a fresh stream,  sprung from
some forgotten pool into the light of day.

At  2:48 PM 25/3/95 -0800, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:
>go dave!  you are so right.  perhaps it's time to unleash some moral
>indignation where it might do some good.  or at least make the gesture.

Thank you. Thank you. Clicked on this message and got an amazing energy
charge on my index finger. Well, this is precisely what I am trying to do -
to attempt some visionary  discussion in the community - so that we can at
the very least begin tying up some pieces of this jigsaw puzzle. Looking at
problems one at a time is ok, but easily leads to despondancy, only looking
at solutions runs the risk of forgetting what it is that we are trying to
solve. - we need some cogent debate on Rave, Life the Universe and
Everything - an evolving multivoiced philosophy which will provide us with
catalyzing  inspiration.

We must have the courage to look at ourselves - to examine our own
inadequices, to make hard decisions, so that we may  achieve at the very
least  " a politics naked as the clear blue light of day"  - we DEFINITELY
need shamans not priests, bards not politicians.

As to advising the direction in which rave should take - lets open this
forum to ALL constructive debate - I have many ideas about possible routes,
I have witnessed a political evolution first hand - but I do realise that
each situation is unique, but surely it would be madness to remain silent,
to always take the easy road. There is much that is at stake - much that
has occured over the past four weeks alone in the world, that needs to be
discussed by all of us. Important facts affecting our very survival have
been bumped from the news headlines.

SO let  ALL sfravers of the HEART take up Anthrax's NOBLE suggestion - lets
all write the POETRY of LIFE as WE see it - discussing the things that are
IMPORTANT to ALL OF US - and that includes the Planet - Gaia, without
stopping in fear of censorship, or flamming, or that our views are too high
or low, too loud or too soft. We must escape the constrains of
self-censorship and self-policing, and run the risk of sounding
IMPASSIONED, Idealistic, Visionary, Over-Emotional. Lets just spill our
beans, and run our raves, our lives likes wild enraptured poets making love
to the sheer beauty of life itself.

Lets show the world that SAN FRANCISCO can be the first Interplanetary Rave
Mulitversity - with discussion on absolutely every subject of importance to
raving, misbehaving,  healing and feeling, our world and worlds beyond.

- David Dei

                           Megatripolis Parallel University
                                     megatrip@best.com

>>Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com

Well, don't get me wrong this is not about me not taking note of other
viewpoints. But just because other views might not be tolarant of my
opinion does not mean that I am going to MODIFY my philosophy. If I did
that, then soon i would find myself agreeing with those who maintain that
one should not stand OUT or ALONE from the conventional wisdom. Right now
the conventional wisdom in america it that we should get our kicks where we
can, and forget about the mass of humanity around the planet, forget about
the planet itself. Love and Peace are now just Gap, Nike, Fruitopia
consumer statements. There is nothing that is not fundemental that has not
been STOLEN from us and used to sell products. DO I fall in line? Do I
listen to those on SFRAVEs who are preaching unity at all costs, even if
this means that some of us are prevented from Expressing our VIEW? IN fact
Brian Behlondorf has seriously suggested that I NOT POST ON SFRAVES AT ALL!
Am i that way out of line that my views are not to be tolarated?
Is this what rave is about - that OUTSIDERS are not WELCOME?

I suppose people would rather I did not make  uncomfortable  reality checks
- you would rather I KEPT QUIET about some unavoidable FACTS.  Is this what
I am hearing? That Rave is only about having a good time - then back to
work on monday morning. That I must OBEY authority at all costs? That Rave
is not essentiallly about FREEDOM to Dance wherever and whenever the whim
takes US?

I would rather it were about making a start at bringing together the
Rainbow Nation of God - of all tribes who have rejected slavery. That we
should  aware unity to an IDEA of Universal Acceptance of ALL PEOPLE , THAT
WE MUST AWAKEN TO OUR dystany.

Seriously - what are we doing here - is this just about a good time? or is
there more to life? Could this really be a wonderful story about the
greatest, evolution this planet has seen - a beautiful, under-rising ,  an
exotic uncovering of our TRUE nature - our common dystany,  to awaken the
greatest potential in ALL of our unique egoverses. That perhaps we are
about to make the greatest discovery since the invention of astronomy and
the greatest social event since the founding of democracy and the
acceptance of a planetary council of nations.

I put it to the VOTE - if this community of 400 plus ravers would rather I
and others, stopped talking about SOCIETY,  about the practical uncovering
of the SYSTEM and ITS Alternative - that we vote on this issue - I would
hate to end up cheerleading muy emotionally charged rantings to a
community that cannot tolerate my unique view. We have much that we can
learn from each other. I from You all and vice versa, but we can only do
this if at base level we accept that it might entail some discomfort - some
hysteria, some poetry, some hyperbole, some passion and emotion. I am
passionate about the topic of saving this planet - all I ask is that you
accept this - that I am not trying to sell anything that Blake or Shelley
did not.

Lets all Up the Evolution and increase the VIBE. I am truly sorry if this
cannot happen with myself playing a part - I would hope that at heart you
all feel my intentions are not bad, that I have SEEN a lot growing through
one evolution already, and that having done so, I might have at the very
least some interesting if unpopular insights that could strengthen the
scene in San Francisco at the very least.

All my love

David Dei

I've gotten access to hyperreal, so now I'll be maintaining the sfraves
calendar directly on that machine.  So now you should be able to get
the current rave guide (as soon as I type in new info) via ftp and
the web.  The guide will still be mailed on Thursdays, but if you
have ftp or www access, you can always get the most current listings.

Via ftp, the guide is located in /raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.txt.

I haven't actually tested the web page, but the URL should be
http://hyperreal.com/~dhchung/sfrcal.html.  Let me know if it works.
Right now, it doesn't have any fancy graphics, links to scanned in 
flyers, or any other bells and whistles, but that will be coming in
the future.

Also, both directories have the SFR phone list, which I hadn't really
been maintaining, but I went through the last few calendars and tried
to update it.

-Derek

 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o

>indignation where it might do some good.  or at least make the gesture.

> Thank you. Thank you. Clicked on this message and got an amazing energy

Umm, not to take away from the rest of you message, David (Dei, that is), 
but i think Ann was referring to the other Dave (Ilstrup, that is), who 
posted under the heading "Energy redirection, anyone?".

Which brings up the point that in a list with this much traffic, it's 
probably a good idea when replying directly under the same heading to also 
quote (or paraphrase) at least a little of the content/context (with an 
emphasis on "a little").

Back to the original post about the Communications Decency Act, if 
you want to know more, there are Web sites at:
	http://www.phantom.com/~slowdog/   
	http://uvacs.cs.virginia.edu/~hwh6k/public/S314_stuff.html
both of which include info and a pointer to a petition against its 
passage.  This may not be relevant to raves in general but it is 
certainly relevant to sfraves (and any other free-thinking mailing lists).

							gregg

societal structure that I'd just as soon forget about.  It does not 
belong here.  There are other forums more suited to what you would like 
to discuss, David.

why it *is* this and *not* that is merely inviting more of the flurry 
this list has seen over the past week.

I didn't quote this part for any particular reason other than that you

it out here.  Please, take this to another forum.  I am not agreeing or

Eventhough I don't agree with all that is said by David, Fraser, et al.
I DO believe that the stuff discussed here is VERY relevant to raving,
to the scene at large and to us all.  Far more relavent then outting
E dealers for bunk e or merely posting reviews of various parties.

Even though some of the opinions (and counter opinions are obnoxious
If we can't have these kinds of discussions here then the list isn't
really worth the bandwidth that we use.  One can always go to alt.rave
if you just want to hear about the latest music, style, drug, etc.

This list *is* about the San Francisco scene and these *are* relevent
issues here, if any of you go out half as much as I do (and I don't
go out as much as I used to) then you know that the Scene *is* becomming
more and more segregated, not only racially but musically, gender-wise
and class wise.  Please even though some of these issues are uncomfortable
for some of us, they MUST be aired.  We have been to this place before and
people always try to squish these types of discussions, we, this country, this
planet NEEDS to have open honest dialog about issues such as xenophobia and
racism. PLUR don't mean shit if we can't openly talk about these issues
without having to censor OR attack people personally.

I think we "yanks" need to step back and listen to Tristan, Fraser and David
because they provide input outside of our little closed loop.  Fraser, Tristan
and David need to realize that there are some very wise people here and some
of the things that they are talking about have been in full swing here for
YEARS, it is very annoying to some people to hear you talk about things that
many of them take for granted as if you are bringing it to us.
(Sorta like an olympic swimmer extolling the metaphysics of swimming to a 
dolphin :)

1).  Point well taken.
2).  If their are more whites and Asians on the internet (which is 
because you have to be rich to get the equipment to be online in the 
first place) then you have a moral duty to pass on information to people 
that can't afford the equipment (i.e. blacks).  Also don't forget that 
modem computer's are now available in some cafes and pretty soon they 
will be available like public telephone's.  When this happens their will 
be more blacks online but their will still be the same number of blacks 
at F&F because your average black is cool enough to go to a party that is 
not full to the brim with white trash kids.

> more whites and asians involved with computers than blacks. There are of

> I see a group that comes from a computer background I would be STUNNED to
> see more blacks and hispanics than whites and asians. My PhD is in chemistry
> so I know that out of 150,000 recent degrees ( over a decade ) somewhere
> less than 10% when to blacks/hispanics. I can also tell you that the
> people who train chemists WANT to change this and recrute actively to change
> this but change is slow - especially with the breakdown of family and school
> dropout rates - the problems are many!

well, the results of my little national poll are still coming in. I'd ask 
anyone else from other areas to post in soon.  (SEE QUESTIONNAIRE BELOW)  
results are a bit patchy and people offer different and personal reasons 
for their local activities.  sorry I'm not efficient enough to collate 
these findings better - I'd be happy to pass this on to someone more 
technically equipped but will continue in the meantime.
what do people think about this stuff so far?  is there a pattern emerging?

fraser
------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. 
it  seems like a national crackdown with all the fuk parties in midwest 
getting busted n all the chi-town, sf, n detroit parties that have been 
busted but it's not a crackdown.  it's just that in the area where the 
scene has aged a bit the cops have sort of caught on.  there have been 
"techno parties" in detroit since the mid '80's n SF got their thing 
going right along with england since SF is all cosmopolitan like n up 
with what's going on in the world.  the newer places where the scene's 
started up like around 90-92 haven't quite had long enough exposure to 
law enforcement so the police can deal with the situation.  also i know 
in detroit that almost all the parties have been in detroit so only 
detroit cops had to deal with 'em.  in other areas parties r probably 
held in various suburbs along with the inner city and it's more spread 
out.  the cops that sees those parties probably see them as a rare phenomon.

        SID
_________________________________________________________________________
2
I don't know- I think the rave scene has hit a certain "critical mass"
in the public consciousness, and people are getting concerned. I've 
seen several lists of "street drug terms" which list "rave" as a
kind of psychedelic crack house. I spect the cops are under pressure
to do something about the "rampant drug use among our young people" or
something silly like that.

As far as the North Carolina scene goes- there has definitely been
a pick up in the number of busts- two this month in separate cities
(one in Greensboro: Babylon, First Friday and one in Raleigh) where
all present were lined up and searched (this is hearsay; i wasn't there).

If it continues, I expect the rave scene will go further underground,
and we'll return to the "old days" (about 2 years ago, around here)
where most raves were organized by telephone tree.

I would be interested in finding out if this is a nationwide trend, also.

cheers,
jem
__________________________________________________________________________
3.
No problems in Pittsburgh or Baltimore or . Haven't had any such crackdown
here. Once again proving that SF and Detroit are not the center of the
raving universe. 
                                Joe
__________________________________________________________________________
4.
Here in StLouis, we've been having similar problems; supposedly the local
police recieved a grant from the DEA for a special anti-rave task force.
I do know the chief of police told a friend-rave-promoter that no
matter what permits they got, he would find a way to shut them down...

double plus ungood

ds5419@panix.com
Funk As Puck Productions

5.
Dallas, the crackdown is hitting Dallas also. Jan. 1 - They busted New
Years at 12:30. and sent thousands out into the streets on the the most
dangerous night of the year... I heard their was a RAVE task force in the
DPD. The final bust was brutal, I witnessed a cop beat a 17 year old, 90
pound kid... with no provocation. Arrests were made also... In Detroit, I
heard a major stormtrooper raid was made, everyone arrested, and the
police called the media, film crews caught the scene... I heard a bill is
about to pass in UK. virtually outlawing RAVES... Could I get more info on
SF busts and/or rave scenes?

Peace
SunDantz...

around, but they keep a pretty low profile.

________________________________________________________________________

here is the questionnaire I sent out:-

>BACKGROUND
>most people in san francisco have NOW come to realise that there is an
>ongoing police crackdown on the rave scene.  it started on January 1st and
>has continued throughout most of the Bay Area to the point where it has
>become a regular, virtually weekly thing.  the latest was last saturday
>when Friends & Family (an SFRaves internet collective) was bust at 4am,
>with a certain amount of police brutality. 

>QUESTION
>what I want to know is: is this a national or a local phenomenon?  we ask
>for reports from YOUR local area. 

>PROBLEM
>some people here still argue (or fondly wish to go on believing) that it
>is simply the mayor (who's an ex-cop) or some merely local politics that
>is causing it all.  I suppose there are even some people who are not
>convinced that there IS a crackdown.  please post a report from YOUR area,
>bearing this problem in mind as you do so. 

>PROMISE 
>We PROMISE to put the reports together and post it on alt.raves in the
>near future.  thankyou for your cooperation in this matter which is of
>consequence to us all. 

>fraser
-

Hello , Larry Ching here. Giving my reactions to Geoff's post: 
> 
> Eventhough I don't agree with all that is said by David, Fraser, et al.
> I DO believe that the stuff discussed here is VERY relevant to raving,
> to the scene at large and to us all. 
 My problem is with the wrappers many of their ideas have been contained
in ( ie - presentation ).  
> Even though some of the opinions (and counter opinions) are obnoxious

 The "eye for an eye" style of email discussion almost always
degenerates into 90% garbage posts. 

> ....( talking about important social issues )...
> If we can't have these kinds of discussions here then the list isn't
> really worth the bandwidth that we use.  One can always go to alt.rave
> if you just want to hear about the latest music, style, drug, etc.

 I unsubscribed to alt.rave a long time ago just because of the "trash"
content. 

> This list *is* about the San Francisco scene and these *are* relevent
> issues here, if any of you go out half as much as I do (and I don't
> go out as much as I used to) then you know that the Scene *is* becomming
> more and more segregated ... racially ... musically, gender-wise
> and class wise.  Please even though some of these issues are uncomfortable
> for some of us, they MUST be aired. 

 I'm chewing over some thoughts about "the Scene" , but I need inputs
from more experienced ravers ...

> ... we, this country, this
> planet NEEDS to have open honest dialog about issues such as xenophobia and
> without having to censor OR attack people personally.

> I think we "yanks" need to step back and listen to Tristan, Fraser and David
> because they provide input outside of our little closed loop.  Fraser, Tristan
> and David need to realize that there are some very wise people here and some
> of the things that they are talking about have been in full swing here for
> YEARS, it is very annoying to some people to hear you talk about things that
> many of them take for granted as if you are bringing it to us.
> (Sorta like an olympic swimmer extolling the metaphysics of swimming to a 
> dolphin :)
>

 I agree with the idea of all involved taking a calming deep breath.  I also
feel that the participants should resolve to improve the quality of 
presentation . Oracular declamations from a pedestal or slinging verbal 
offal from the gutter are both offputting , no matter how emotionally "honest"
that might be to the writer. ( So sayeth the great Ching!!! ). 

 ... wandering away from Geoff's post for a long aside:

 To the purpose of improving the quality of the postings , from David Dei
in particular , but also from other SFRavers in general ,
I have gone out on a limb and written some "helpful hints" below - I
think other folks could probably benefit too , so don't think this stuff 
only applies to him!
 
 ( If any of you "White Oppressor Devil" SFRavers out there think that
   I'm inaccurate in what I'm about to write , please make corrections )

 I think what also grates many melanin-challenged SFRavers about the recent
series of posts by David Dei is that it's obvious that he has no idea of
what a white child learns about and experiences growing up in the San
Francisco Bay area. I believe that all the major issues that David has
raised has been a topic of a discussion group at school , or in the
media , or in the local activist press. There are social interactions between
ethnic groups that children of all races experience here that David is
ignorant of ( I have an inkling of them by reading, and talking to the
young people I know who have grown up here ).

 While using the history of other countries can be useful, forcing analogies 
to a foreign experience only amplifies where the analogies fail.

 One of the worst justifications for any political action you are
trying to promote to white young people is one of "ancestral guilt". I 
believe the sins of the fathers (not to mention forefathers) should NOT
be used as an ethical cudgel against the children. ( Everybody's got
ancestors who were shits , if you go back far enough, and everyone's
got ancestors who were saintly ). Addressing present problems is much more 
friendly, practical and productive.

-----------------------

 Enough 
-----------------------

 I wish I was a wiser man , to truly and effectively fix what I think have
been some recent problems. If I am going about it the wrong way , then
I now apologize to all you folks here in SFRaves.

 It's late , and I'm tired.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
  

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 26 02:30:59 1995

Received: from netcom5.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA01865; Sun, 26 Mar 1995 02:30:56 -0800

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199503261028.CAA25195@netcom5.netcom.com>
Subject: Limitations of the medium
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 02:28:26 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1790      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 [ Ok , one more thing before I hit the sack :-)  ]

 I think that a lot of issues can be better discussed and served NOT
by being worked out via SFRAves mass mailing discussions, but by plain
old fashioned face-to-face conferences and informal meetings. Even
conference telephone calls and video teleconferences have a "delay"
and "filtering" effect that adds confusion and misunderstanding.

 The recent survey and compilation of results that Fraser just performed
is a good example of what the medium is good for - sending out a 
specific , focused request for an action - and the reporting of
results. The medium is also good for reviews , listings , and other
such things that do not require an extended question/response interaction
or assertion/rebuttal/counter-rebuttal interaction.

 Flames continue mostly through the dragging out of call-and-response,
thereby increasing the heat. Stuff that would be said , argued about , and
agreed upon in 15 minutes at a realtime/real life sit-down get dragged
out for days. 

 Therefore - what about using SFRaves to announce meetings , said meetings
to be devoted to specific topics that all attendees can come prepared
to talk about , or at least come to listen to what others have to say?
Much better that using the highly inefficient mass emailing system of
SFRaves! And , these meetings can even be scheduled for before and
after raves . One of the things I liked about the events held by "Your 
Sister's House"  were the pre-dancing discussion groups . If the promoter 
is willing , a quiet space could even be reserved for meetings AT raves , 
a la Megatripolis .

 Good night!

	Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - I also think online chat is the pits! I don't think AND type fast
  enough - that's why I'm not on vrave anymore.

> 
> well, the results of my little national poll are still coming in. I'd ask 
> anyone else from other areas to post in soon.  (SEE QUESTIONNAIRE BELOW)  
> results are a bit patchy and people offer different and personal reasons 
> for their local activities.  sorry I'm not efficient enough to collate 
> these findings better - I'd be happy to pass this on to someone more 
> technically equipped but will continue in the meantime.
> what do people think about this stuff so far?  is there a pattern emerging?

I couldn't call it a pattern just yet.  I think some areas/cities have
people on the force who have particular agendas, here in SF most long term
promoters know who these people are and tend to avoid them.  While it
is true that Mayor Jordan is the ex-chief of police, the crackdown here
in SF IMHO has more to do with "club receipts (or the lack there-of)" than
concerted political pressure.  In SF the police are just the enforcement
arm of the "club owners" or organized crime who rely on cash flow
of drink sales and admission to launder there money and do other things,
ravers just stumbled into this.  The DEA is probibly concerned, but mostly
for them it's a "dick" thing, they've been trying to get to the veil of
psychedelics that originate out here for years and they are still at it.
Some parties are an in your face affirmation that they can't stop it short
of violating lots of people`s civil right (coming this fall :)

> 
> fraser
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> 1. 
> it  seems like a national crackdown with all the fuk parties in midwest 
> getting busted n all the chi-town, sf, n detroit parties that have been 
> busted but it's not a crackdown.  it's just that in the area where the 
> scene has aged a bit the cops have sort of caught on.  there have been 
> "techno parties" in detroit since the mid '80's n SF got their thing 
> going right along with england since SF is all cosmopolitan like n up 
> with what's going on in the world.  the newer places where the scene's 
> started up like around 90-92 haven't quite had long enough exposure to 
> law enforcement so the police can deal with the situation.  also i know 
> in detroit that almost all the parties have been in detroit so only 
> detroit cops had to deal with 'em.  in other areas parties r probably 
> held in various suburbs along with the inner city and it's more spread 
> out.  the cops that sees those parties probably see them as a rare phenomon.
> 
>         SID

There is something to be said tha "rave" for SF cops are now routine,
in the long run this might become an advantage.  When it is shown that
the parties are not "out of the ordinary" for the community then we can
put more pressure on the city government to stop.

BTW don't the mayortorial elections come around either this year or next
year? 18 year olds may not have bucks but they got numbers, and an organized
block of 30,000 San Francisco ravers can do wonders for a local election.
The mere fact that city hall knows that we are organizing to vote someone
in will make them take notice.

publically come out for the decriminalization and legalization of drugs
as it is clear to him that as long as there is prohibition there will be
violence and unbridled exploitation.  I also know that at lease some of the
promoters in the city have a relationship with the city government.
With a homicide a day in the city of baltimore, the cops have been told
that they have more important things to do then harass ravers.

> here is the questionnaire I sent out:-
> 
> >BACKGROUND
> >most people in san francisco have NOW come to realise that there is an
> >ongoing police crackdown on the rave scene.  it started on January 1st and
> >has continued throughout most of the Bay Area to the point where it has
> >become a regular, virtually weekly thing.  the latest was last saturday
> >when Friends & Family (an SFRaves internet collective) was bust at 4am,
> >with a certain amount of police brutality. 

The truth of the matter is that if you become large and over-ground then you
will be forced into specific venues, this is about money more than it
is about politics (sorry to say).

Is there a nation-wide crack down?  Perhapse, but not in any publicized way.
If they made a big publicity stint about it, it would sorta be good,
because it would be blasted across the media and even though the media
would portray it as an EvilThing(tm) there would be some people out there
who would recognize it for what it really is and want it and would actively
seek it out.  The other part of our "rugged individualism" is the moment
the government tells a bunch of people that they can't have something, hords
of people who were not interested before want to know what it is that
they are being denied because if the Feds don't want us to have it it MUST
be good, more assult rifles have been sold since the ban than were in peoples
hands before the ban.  Now when and if the crackdown comes they will
undoubtedly seek for "organizers and leaders" to chop off their heads and
guess where they are going to go first, fraser :)  This will inevitably drive 
the Scene more underground which I believe may be a good thing. Or if they 
hit it hard enough, it will splatter into a thousand infectious pieces.

On Sun, 26 Mar 1995, Larry Ching wrote:

>  [ Ok , one more thing before I hit the sack :-)  ]
> 
>  I think that a lot of issues can be better discussed and served NOT
> by being worked out via SFRAves mass mailing discussions, but by plain
> old fashioned face-to-face conferences and informal meetings. Even
> conference telephone calls and video teleconferences have a "delay"
> and "filtering" effect that adds confusion and misunderstanding.
> 

Very good point. 

This is to EVERYONE:

Looking at the pattern of messages, and the flames that erupted(which I 
guiltly have been a part of) it seem that we have all been drug into 
these debates about the basis of our society, whether or not we are 
rasists,and misc. political ramblings. These are all, as they have 
proven, very volatile isssues. And they really do have a place for 
discussion. However, I really agree with Larry that there are MUCH better 
ways and forums for discussing these issues. And while I am sure that the 
people that want to continue arguing or make this list a sounding board 
for their political views will disagree, I urge everyone that feels the 
same way to simply ignore these type of posts. I for one am attempting to 
repent, and whenever I see one I am going to try real hard to find the 
letter "D" on my keyboard and press it :) . It takes two to flame(err so 
to speak) and I have found myself all to eager to indulge lately. If 
others keep indulging I really think this list will continue to 
degenerate into one hell of a mess. And there really are too many nice 
people here to let this happen....

                                               Yours Humbly,
                                                Black Adder

Subject: brothers and sisters
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 10:22:21 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Friday night I checked out brothers and sisters at 1015 folsom, for the 
first time.  If theres anyone who feels there aren't any clubs that have 
a diverse crowd, this is a good place to go.

I heard that this place has a real clubby feel to it, but gets better in 
the later hours.  First walking in, into the front room, was a crowd 
dancing to top 40, and older disco tunes.  This was alittle like stepping 
back in time when I wanted to go dancing, but didn't yet discover raves.  
There were many dancing with drinks in their hands, and there was alot of 
bumpin and grinded goin on.

After walking through I could hear some faster beats going in the main 
room.  There I discovered Galen cranking out some tunes and some familair 
ravers dancing amongst the assorted crowd.  I heard that Jeno was playing 
down stairs.  

I went downstairs, where the feel was alittle more intimate although the 
sound wasn't as good as the upstairs.  I was alternating up and down for 
awhile enjoying both.  After Galen, Garth came on.  He was playing some 
good tunes alot of them familiar, but the tempo was turned down.  This 
was a little bit of an ajustment, and part of me was hoping and expecting 
the pace to go up as I was starting to feel more energized as the night 
went on.  With my increased energy, I went back down stairs to some 
faster music.  I don't know who the dj was, but I was really having some 
fun with what he was playing.

Things really took off for me with Tracy's set in the main room after 
Garth.  There the vibe and the energy that was being shared was 
incredible.  It really felt that all differences were secondary to what 
was being shared.  Feeling that shared vibe, my inhibitions desolved 
away, and at some points I was dancing around the room connecting and 
sharing with everyone I saw.  Feeling that connectedness to the oneness 
of the vibe, peoples defences were down, and the joy of sharing was all 
around.


peter

There is nothing better than a good debate. But I don't want to debate
if it means slinging the same garbage that is slung during a
presidential debate. I like to debate about the proper ways to create a
loophole for parties so it cant get busted. I like to debate proper ways
to ingest drugs so that you can get the best from them. I like to debate
over what is socially accepted and what isn't.
I WILL NEVER TRY TO DEBATE ABOUT SEXIST, RACIST OR INMORALISTIC TOPICS.

It just so happens that getting a modem with access can be as cheap as
150 dollars (100 dollars for a computer with cheap modem and 50 dollars
for 1 year service for basic e-mail). Even cheaper if this person is a
student. If you want to debate me, pick a topic that can challenge the
intelligence on this board and not the intelligence in your *ss.


Time to smile again.

I was sleeping last night when a loud voice said "No you can't go there" 
boomed through my bedroom at about 2AM. I looked outside and could'nt see 
anything so I went back to bed. Then the voice came again saying 
something about making u-turns. It was the police outside directing 
traffic with their loudspeaker turned up to full volume. With all the 
talk about noise disturbances and such, I decided to call 911. They told 
me that a concert had just got out around SJSU and they were trying to 
prevent accidents. They appologized for the noise. I went back to bed and 
heard the voice again but much softer. They actually turned the volume 
down just 5 minutes after I called. I know there is not much point to 
this but It really felt weird to phone 911 to report the police 
disturbing my sleep. Oh well, thanks for listening ... 8-)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 26 15:26:35 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id PAA00588; Sun, 26 Mar 1995 15:26:35 -0800

Message-Id: <199503262326.PAA00290@shell1.best.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 15:28:09 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)
Subject: Dancing the System Evolution (was Xenophobia)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear SFravers

A lot of what I am about is build on RAVE being a good thing - Which is why
I would like to see a thread like the above, filled with positive ideas.
Well, it seems that I committed the cardinal sin this week of directing my
energy into a tricky subject and trying to expose a mindset that is pretty
much the dominant view leftover in each of us - the mindset that excludes
most of humanity when we talk about US. And refer to THEM. Lets say I
jumped in on the thing that probably bugs me and you the most - that
although we say a whole lot of positive stuff, we still act and think in
negative ways. In my opinion, WE are the SYSTEM, and how we THINK is how
the SYSTEM thinks. So when we see all those terrible things in the news,
and find it hard to work out why in this of all possible worlds, we have a
world in which PROP 187 exists, all we have to do is look at our selves.

It's like we have inherited a way of thinking that results in genocide. -
It seems hard to believe, but this is what I was trying to uncover in the
heart of SFRAVERs - the thing which  lurks in the hearts of us all, and
which we need to rid ourselves of in a conscious way.

Well, despite my good intentions, all I did was  recieve a lot of flack. I
suppose It might have been better to at least establish first that things
are wrong - I might know that things are drastically wrong with the way
society works, and that includes rave, but perhaps SFRAVERS have'nt worked
that one out yet.

*So  by way of apology for all the noise, here what I've learnt on sfraves
in the past week*

1. A Grab Bag of Goodwill. Its OK to bring up the occassional hip societal
problem - like S314, Digital Telephony or anger at police  brutality, but
by an large third world or environmental  problems don't quite make it.

2. Don't Taint this Baby:  Consensus is that RAVE itself should not be
tainted by any discussion which might link IT to a broad philosophy which
explains why we have a society  in which Newt Gingrich, S314, Prop 187,
Native American Segregation & Third World Genocide exists.

3.  NO opinions not Musical: Its OK to lecture or have strong opinions on
MUSIC, what style I like, what riff, what breakbeat, my version of a
particular historical thing. But its not OK to have strong opinions abouth
SOCIETY. So if I talk  strongly about Trance, no one will accuse me of
lecturing or being rude. If I talk strongly about the PLANET I open myself
to immediate flamage.

4. IT's all STYLE: SF Rave is more about STYLE than CONTENT. So again,
passion OUT, coolness IN. It's OK to talk about the night, who did what
where and when, but no talk about actually DOING something to help the
Planet.

5. Problem what problem? Again, Its OK to complain about a police bust, but
its not OK to begin drawing conclusions that there might be an outside
chance that RAVE is being specifically targeted by the authorities.

6. America is GREAT. By and large, sfravers are patriots, proud about what
this country has achieved. While they might be upset about a pet gripe,
mention  a topic that they discounted years ago - like the native american
situation and you face the ultimate flamage for being an unAmerican
outsider.

7. Raving Community is Positive: In spite of all its flaws, raving is
without a doubt - the biggest turn on to community the world has seen.
Sfravers are committed to doing community, even if its in a virtual, not
everyday thing. Its what connects all of us at base level even when we're
flaming.

Well, folks its a beautiful day, what else can I say? Its been quite a
trip, and hope we get to blast this thread into unprecedented levels of
soul searching postivity.

- David Dei


-----------------------------------------------
                           Megatripolis Parallel University
                                     megatrip@best.com

     INFORMATION, INSPIRATION & SERVICES TO THE NATION
-----------------------------------------------

To: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching), sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)
Subject: Re: Limitations of the medium
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear SF Ravers

Well, after much soul searching, lots of miss-connection, flamage, hard
opinion back and forth, anger, frustration, namecalling - that has left me
feeling emotionally drained & confused at where things really stand on
sfraves. I have this to say.

It is clear, that there are at least one or two individuals, like larry
ching, who care enough about this virtual community to take the effort to
understand and offer positive  suggestions. I am quite sorry for causing
such a high level of dissenssion in what is usually a serene and
enlightened community.  All I truly want is for us all to be able to see
eye to eye, to examine the hard and the soft things in life. What I will do
for the benefit of all is take a break from posting on SFraves for at least
the next couple of days so that things can achieve a little perspective.

A word to JOSH who is justifiably feeling hurt  after receiving my rude but
right remark - I never meant to hurt or blast you, rather I intended to
show the uncomfortable truth that we all share - that we all are found
wanting when it comes down to the nitty gritty - as the amount of rudeness
and  xenophobic shit a reaped in turn, has also demonstrated an
uncomfortable degree of intolerance  directed my way. Lets face it, even if
I was wrong, would this be the way to treat me?

Perhaps the medium is not conducive to what should really be a couple of
quick remarks, backed up by a whole lot of love. E-Mail is all too often a
cold instrument of mis-communication. A salvo is easily launched without
much thought to the matter or we Mis-Read  or even ignore or delete, as I
certainly did do on a number of occasions.

SO let me raise the banner of peace, and  announce, that I love you all in
spite of yourselves and in spite of all the anger. We are all growing and
evolving. And I have indeed learnt a lot from sfraves as I hope you will
learn at least something from me. I am not interested in one-upmanship or
winning and  competing. SO I forthwith throw my lot in with the Rave
Community for the mean time - I have no intention of standing out in the
cold forever, and as long as I am able to continue holding to my opinions,
I say this: LET US ALL CELEBRATE the FACT THAT WE HAVE MADE IT POSSIBLE TO
MEET HERE AT THE VERY LEAST. Perhaps we can hold some grand debate in the
flesh in the future
as larry suggests?

- david dei

At  2:28 AM 26/3/95 -0800, Larry Ching wrote:
> [ Ok , one more thing before I hit the sack :-)  ]
>
> I think that a lot of issues can be better discussed and served NOT
>by being worked out via SFRAves mass mailing discussions, but by plain
>old fashioned face-to-face conferences and informal meetings. Even
>conference telephone calls and video teleconferences have a "delay"
>and "filtering" effect that adds confusion and misunderstanding.
>
> The recent survey and compilation of results that Fraser just performed
>is a good example of what the medium is good for - sending out a
>specific , focused request for an action - and the reporting of
>results. The medium is also good for reviews , listings , and other
>such things that do not require an extended question/response interaction
>or assertion/rebuttal/counter-rebuttal interaction.
>
> Flames continue mostly through the dragging out of call-and-response,
>thereby increasing the heat. Stuff that would be said , argued about , and
>agreed upon in 15 minutes at a realtime/real life sit-down get dragged
>out for days.
>
> Therefore - what about using SFRaves to announce meetings , said meetings
>to be devoted to specific topics that all attendees can come prepared
>to talk about , or at least come to listen to what others have to say?
>Much better that using the highly inefficient mass emailing system of
>SFRaves! And , these meetings can even be scheduled for before and
>after raves . One of the things I liked about the events held by "Your
>Sister's House"  were the pre-dancing discussion groups . If the promoter
>is willing , a quiet space could even be reserved for meetings AT raves ,
>a la Megatripolis .
>
> Good night!
>
>        Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
>
>PS - I also think online chat is the pits! I don't think AND type fast
>  enough - that's why I'm not on vrave anymore.
>

                           Megatripolis Parallel University
                                     megatrip@best.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 26 19:06:39 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id TAA12792; Sun, 26 Mar 1995 19:06:39 -0800
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA12786; Sun, 26 Mar 1995 19:06:36 -0800
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.10/8.6.9) id TAA14961 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 26 Mar 1995 19:06:38 -0800
Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 19:06:38 -0800
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199503270306.TAA14961@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Forward Into the Future
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

For the last week or so the sfraves list has experienced an unprecedented
upheaval.  I would like to remind everyone that there have been
disagreements
and intemperate postings from time to time in the past, and we have been
able to get past that.  sfraves has been the online contact point for many
people both in the Bay Area and, like me, from outside as well, from all
over the globe in fact.  We have always had a good balance of 
"local" and outside views, in my opinion.  We have almost always had
respect for each other's views, and have from time to time taken up the
larger issues of the world that intersect to some degree with the music
and the community represented here.  

Three individuals in the past week have chosen, for their own quite
different reasons, to push their own personal agendas on us here. 
Fraser Clark, David Dei and Tristan have all, quite deliberately it
seems, pressed various of our "hot buttons," and we've responded with
various degrees of *hot*.  

We have seen Fraser and David at work in the same manner on the Well for
some months now, but basically the response there has been to step aside
and let them do what they want.  Those who wish to pay attention, and 
those who do not skip over it or go elsewhere.  

There is nothing like being accused of being provincial in your own front
yard, especially where there is some truth to it.  But then, that is
always true.  If I were to go to London, as important as it may be in
the world dance music scene, I'm sure I could point out the many faults
in their scene as compared to, say, San Francisco.  But this is almost
beside the point.

The underlying issue is this: this list is what WE want it to be.  No one
person can decide how it will work, what should be discussed, or what the
tone of the conversation is.  Those are up to all of US.  We have been
blessedly free, for the most part, of people coming on the list and wanting
to reshape its purpose to their own designs.  I think that is what I object,
most of all, in the approach that Fraser, David and Tristan have made.
As I said before, they have completely different motivations, but all three
want to remake this list according to their desires, and not soon -- now.

Despite my own aggravation at all of this, and I have said sharp things both
in public and email, I think it is well time to move past this blockage in
our development.  Fraser, David and Tristan have no more and no less right
to participate here as anyone.  I would *welcome* -- I mean this totally --
their perspectives and their input, as long as it is offered in the spirit
of sharing rather than control.  

We make up the rules of cyberspace as we go along.  Nobody can really
*enforce* anything in an open-ended, asynchronous discussion like we have
on sfraves.  What *works* is to have a shared set of values about how
conversation should proceed.  To me, the one thing that works most of all
is to focus on issues, not personalities.  Otherwise we run the risk of
devolving into a turgid pit of self-righteousness which will drive people
off the list.  And they would be right to leave if that happened.

Many of us have helped nurture this online community through the last
several years.  We have a subject matter, there are some areas we've
learned that are related but cause severe distraction to the list.
Much of that history may not be apparent to newcomers.  This is a *human
communication* process, which means it doesn't work all that well and
sometimes takes a lot longer to get to an obvious point of resolution
than we would wish.  But if we are interested in helping save our species
and take care of this planet, we better be able to maintain a high level
of respect and understanding and forgiveness and love right here on this
little list, if for no other reason than to convince ourselves that we
*can* do it.  

I urge all of us to resign from the cycle of stimulus and response we've
developed in the last week.  I'm guilty of it too and I'm not gonna do
it no more.  This is my last posting on these general subjects (for at
least a while I hope!)

I don't think anyone here has bad intentions or hidden agendas.  We should
however respect and learn from our different perspectives and experiences,
because without that we can't grow.

see you in the future
phred

Dear SF-Ravers,

Since we had a most glorious day here in Sacramento I took it upon
myself(with the aid of two friends) to do some special activity. After
roller blading in Capitol park for about 2 hours under a glorious
mid-day sun, we headed toward the river banks.

We went to watch everyone enjoy the sun. It's a great thing to do(wacth
others enjoy something that is free for all).Don't worry I'm getting
somewhere. We saw a large litter pile at the end of the beach. When we
got closer we noticed there were more of these piles farther down. I
decided to inform the park ranger, and asked if we could help. The ranger
gave us a smile that is probably still stuck to his face. As we cleaned
up two piles, about ten others joined in helping us. It was a great
feeling I had knowing I didn't even have to ask for their help. I once
again have restored faith for humanity. I just hope next time there will
be no garbage!

statistics. Because I never asked any Sysop the ratio of black/whites.

ask. So I did!

the ones with at least Internet E-mail(some had better access). You, as
well as I, would be suprised by the answers.

oh well

Too many posts today (sorry) and I'm very tired. Take care all
Time for bed

Hello sfravers, 

	First I want to say that finally it has been sunny and 
beautiful for two straight days!!!! Second I wanted to know if anyone 
who read the post about the Headwaters Forest actions has any additional 
information they can send me. I don't know very much about this 
subject, but I feel it is truely important! I called the number numerous 
times, but they never answer the phone. I keep leaving messages...

	Anyhow, appearently a company Maxxam has gotten permishion to 
start logging in the Headwaters forest and there is going to be a 
non-violent rally on tuesday, march 28. The group "Earth First" is 
putting that together and they stated, they need support. Their phone 
number is (707) 468-1660. Please call and try to get as much info as you 
can about this. It is very important that we make a stand and protect 
our forests!!! I don't remember the location of the forest, but I seem 
to remember it being really close. 

	I think we all need to give our support to the Earth First 
organization, no matter what it we can give. Money, phone calls to the 
Governor, or just our presence at the rally!!! Please participate...

	Their number once again is (707) 468-1660!!!!! Call!!!!!!

Peace, love and harmony to all,

Greg Sandler

ps. Can somebody please foward me the original message from Earth First? 
Thanx!!!!!! We all need to work together in harmony to solve this 
problem! And remember, always respect your mother EARTH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

On Sun, 26 Mar 1995, Randall Wright wrote:

> 
> I was sleeping last night when a loud voice said "No you can't go there" 
> boomed through my bedroom at about 2AM. I looked outside and could'nt see 
> anything so I went back to bed. Then the voice came again saying 
> something about making u-turns. It was the police outside directing 
> traffic with their loudspeaker turned up to full volume. With all the 
> talk about noise disturbances and such, I decided to call 911. They told 
> me that a concert had just got out around SJSU and they were trying to 
> prevent accidents. They appologized for the noise. I went back to bed and 
> heard the voice again but much softer. They actually turned the volume 
> down just 5 minutes after I called. I know there is not much point to 
> this but It really felt weird to phone 911 to report the police 
> disturbing my sleep. Oh well, thanks for listening ... 8-)

RESEND

Dear All;

	Once again my provider is having mail problems, so if you receive 
this more than twice just delete the others, thanks and sorry. Please 
send any complaints to sysop@liberty.com.

B. DARKNESS

Dear All;

	I been in this kinda emotional funk latey, and I didn't get out of
it until I heard this song. The song is called Goddess by Soho, off the
Goddess CD. Once you sucessfully get all the lyrics off the CD, not an
easy task even with an EQ and headphones. As you read them I realized 
that the song was basically an affirmation written primarially for womyn.

	Music for me has always been a great refuge and shelter, and its 
funny that when I'm down, whether it's on the radio, or me picking up one 
of my 150 CD's, I seem to always get the message I need. So I wanted to 
share it with you all. 

	It's a great song, off a great CD, but unfortunely came out 1990 
when main stream radio was just starting to play alterative stuff. Their 
big hit "Hippy Chick" did actually get a lot of air play, but they seemed 
to have forgotten about the rest of the CD.

	I'm not a musican, but the rhythm tracks of the songs that weren't
considered "hits" are definately programmed and very techno like, so check it
out. If I could digitized the song into a reasonable 16 bit Stereo format
file size I would send it along with it, but with an SB16, that file would
be huge. 

	I believe in the Goddess concept, I believe that to varing degrees
there is a Goddess alive and well in us all, including we men. So when the
message in the song reached my brain in just clicked. Hope you find this
affirmation useful, I did, and after all the negativity on this list as of
late I think its very appropriate. The lyrics follow: 

(text) = denotes my changes to the affirmation so it fit me, make any 
changes necessary so that it fits you, the song is really cool
[text] = denotes helpful notes

GODDESS by Soho

You are of female(male) gender, are you not? [male voice asking the ?]
That is correct
Ah, ah, ah .....
[whispered names of people/stuff, most unregonizible]
I lay my heart on the line
I've had enough
Big girls(boys) don't cry, cry; why why ... ??? [sampled and warped line 
						from the orginal Motown hit]

I am housewife(massage therapist)
I am bad, [in the positive sense meaning strong, a force to be reckoned with]
I am midwife(engineer)
I am yours
I am flame
I am love
I am confident, I've had enough

Refrain, repeat 8x
Got to be a Goddess

I am whole
I am sore
I am for choices, I was born
I am short(tall)
I am wide(thin)
Now I am free and I claim my life

Refrain, repeat 8x
Got to be a Goddess

I refuse to be like the rest
These womyn(men) in their straight dress(suits)
Their life is just a beauty(sports) contest
I am not like that and don't you forget it

Refrain, repeat 8x
Got to be a Goddess


		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		a.k.a. BRIAN DARKNESS, LMT/BSEE/CET
		(510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com
	
			"The message is LOVE"

ps If you didn't get a copy of this privately, that means I don't have 
your e-mail address, so please don't be offended, and if you have any 
affirmations that you find help you though your day please pass them back 
to me, thanks :)

To the SFRaves list , but especially to all the folks involved in this
weekend's flame-fest:

 Remeber that there will be a whole bunch of folks who will be logging 
on and reading their SFRaves email for the first time since Friday.
This is because many folks only have email access at their workplace.
They may make replies and generate email to you in response to posts
that have already been worked over by you and the other weekend 
warriors . It's common for some folks to reacte to something at the top
of their email pile before they've read everything.

 I say this because some of the folks involved may still be newcomers
to the give-and-take of this email medium of communication.

	Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I'll remind david he's sworn off answering anyway for 2 days.  and I - 
well, I'd like to point out to the 3 people who've lumped me in with this 
xenophobia thread that in fact I don't think I've said a single word on it.

oh, and while I'm writing to you, larry, thanks huuuuggellly for your 
wisdom over these last few days.  and thanks for the positive things 
you've said about zippydom.  but couldn't you add the definition of zippy 
itself to your list of megatripolis and pronoia?

zippy - someone who, realising an imbalance between the Tecnoperson and 
the Hippy hemispheres in hir own brain and on hir planet, is acting to 
harmonise them once more.  (NOTE: "acting to" - NOT achieved it - 
nobody's done that yet, it's merely a dirrection.)

is that a useful focus we could all agree on?

CAREFUL BEFORE YOU ANSWER.  being, as is well established over here, 
the pushy kind of guy I am [>:-)] I'm likely to follow up an 
affirmative from you with TWO more!  fraser

It was once said by either Dan Quayle or Pat Buchanan that a 
Conservative is anyone who cares for the well-being of their
family and community, and because of this,  most people in this
country are at heart, political Conservatives, whether 
they refer to themselves as one or not.

I think you'll find that a lot of people don't like to be labelled.  Like
stereotyping, it oversimplifies who we are; which can be insulting.  You'd
be surprised at how many people here do not even refer to themselves
as "ravers".

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 27 08:08:34 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id IAA19850; Mon, 27 Mar 1995 08:08:34 -0800
Received: from netcom10.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id IAA19841; Mon, 27 Mar 1995 08:08:30 -0800
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom10.netcom.com (8.6.11/Netcom)
	id IAA26631; Mon, 27 Mar 1995 08:05:51 -0800
Message-Id: <199503271605.IAA26631@netcom10.netcom.com>
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 08:17:41 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: one night review...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Stompy was happening quite large @ 171 King street this weekend.  An all
Chicago affair featuring Mark Farina (happy birthday my man!), DJ, and the
unstoppable Derrick Carter.  All I can say is the shit was PHAT!

I didn't get to hear Mark Farina, since I went to the show at about 1:00.
I did get a chance to hear Diz & Derrick.  I am AMWAYS happy to see talent
come from other places to SF.  Why?  Because with all thaty SF has to offer
in terms of music, it seems at times that we really just barely penetrate
the surfeace of any musical genre.  Yeah, we got trance, jungle, some
house, tribal, italian, etc. but I have RARELY heard DJ's , especially
nowadays, really work the music, much less work a crowd.  It's refreshing
to see people from outta town come here and give SF a taste of what it must
be like elsewhere.

Well to say the least SF still has a way to go in many respects.  And the
afforementioned three DJ's showed how true that paradigm is.  They FUCKED
IT UP!!!!

For those people who've been in a debate about the diversity of SF rave
scene, I only have one word....PRESTON.  Preston, of all the mf's who throw
parties here, has in my estimation THE most mixed crowd!  There were PLENTY
of people of ALL persuasions, colors, sexual types, you name it!  P-Dog has
consistently been able to attract a wide variety of folx to his events.  To
get a taste of what SF used to be like, diversity wise, consider a Stompy
event sometime....anyway back to the music....Diz dropped some serious
grooves that got people moving.  SF, not being used to DJ's with such a
deep house sense, took a while to warm up to Diz's set.  But you could see,
in a very short time, that people were gettin' the message.  The MIXING
was, by any account, the smoothest I have heard, EVER at any event I've
been to in California.  Mark Farina's rep. as a smooth mixer
notwithstanding, Diz & Derrick mixed flawless sets.  They also WORKED the
mix.  They made the music move in ways seldom heard at events.  Very
physical sets, and of course, HIGH on emotional content.  Diz got the crowd
moving, but by then then last record went on and....

You heard a voice over the PA: "Just wanna say happy birthday to my friend
Mark Farina on his 26th.  Happy birthday!  Awright, now I'm gonna play
something a little funky! Have a good time!"  And you knew then that it was
none other than Derrick Carter.  To say that he put motherfuckers in
another dimension would be understatement.  Between his mix, selection of
records, and general style, he had every person in there yelling and
screaming for more.  All be told, a 4.5 hour set.  PROPER!!!  He played
shit, for the most part that you'd be hard pressed to find (esp.
considering many of the cuts were first pressings, and test pressings), he
really did a number on folx. He did some backspinning shit, TO THE BEAT,
and then went right into another mix in seconds!  He was cueued up and
ready for the next record in SECONDS.  And get this, no horses, or
trainwrecks!  Truly a pro! Derrick made me trip out from just the music.
There was really no need for drugs of any kind, the music did it all!  I
had to leave early since I had too much to do the next day.  I walked as
slowly as possible to catch any beat that might happen to follow me out the
door. All I can say at this point is that Chicago is my next stop.

DJ's:  I have been thoroughly impressed with the brothas who have mastered
the decks.  Looking back on the past year, the best party IMO, was Wicked
with Pierre.  This year, it will be quite hard to top Stompy for sheer
music madness.  DJ's in SF should take note, and see how it's done.  Any
doubt that house music at one time was/is the domain of brotha's/sistah's
should check out some of the Af. Am. talent that is responsible for the
continuation of a great musical tradition.  Nobody does it better....

JSL's dream team '95:  Mark Farina, Derrick Carter, Pierre, Jeno, & Markie.
4 hours each. 3 tt's, with a tag team duel between Mark & Derrick vs Jeno &
Markie, with Pierre freelancing between teams.  SICK!!!!!

Audi 5,
John


R.I.P Eric "Eazy-E" Wright.

                "Prejudice is the reason of fools." - Voltaire
              jsl@netcom.com - public key available upon request

Sorry, no header info... I forwarded this to someone else and 
accidentally killed the original post... 

> Date: 3/9/95 4:29 PM
> From: Andrew Boyd
> Subject: it can happen here
> 
> During the debate in the House of February 7 over the House Republicans'
> Bill about the Exclusionary Rule, the House Black Caucus introduced an
> amendment to the bill that the Republicans promptly voted down.  The
> amendment turned out to be the Fourth Amendment of the Constitution,
> verbatim.  The House Republicans were "chagrined."  The vote was 303-121,
> meaning that a number of Democrats joined the Republicans.  The Fourth
> Amendment reads: "The right of the people to be secure in their persons,
> houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures,
> shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue but upon probable cause,
> supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to
> be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

 To quote my sister Cathy, "The scary part is that the people running our 
 government don't even know what the Fourth Amendment _says_.
 It's like getting into a car with someone who's never even had their 
 learner's permit and saying `Ok. Drive.'"
 							-Alex

 /\   alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |   our immortality."  -Goethe  /\

Hello beautiful people,

	To make this quick, I read Sig's post about coming to harmony 
and having everyone sign the document that she is sending to the 
Governor. I think that is a great idea and I was talking to "Earth 
First" about this,( getting more info, writing letters, and donating 
money.) They said that we should do everything we can to bring this out 
(public), and that most importantly we all need to be at the rally on 
tuesday!!
	I got some info on that: Tuesday, mach 28th @ 10:00am. There 
will be a legal, non-violent rally at the Headwaters Forest. the phone 
number is (707) 468-1660. Directions to the rally (you might want to 
call first, cause I suck at relaying directions!!):

	Take 101 north to highway 36. Take highway 36 east to Fisher. 
Turn left on Fisher. Go two miles and your there!!!!! You will see lots 
of people and signs, (your basic protesting material!)

	That might be kinda far for some of you but please understand, 
that if you don't drive up to Headwaters this time to help it, you might 
not get to drive up to Headwaters at all... Protect our mother earth!!!

	I also wanted to say that if you are coming to Harmony and you 
feel like donating extra money to this assosiation please do. We will be 
collecting donations for Earth First at the door. I have arranged this 
with them personally. Also I am not sure yet, but Harmony will hopefully 
be donating 100% of it's profits, (if we actually have any!) to the 
Earth First assosiation. I have not worked that out with everyone 
involved in Harmony. Please understand there are many people involved 
and it has to be a group decision. But I know we will donate a big 
percentage, (I don't know how much yet! Hopefully 100%!!!) 

Protect our mother,

Shroomy

In regard to this whole zippie thing, which I haven't really followed, if
their idea is to fix the world bit by bit, then they're going about it all
wrong.
Our world is one huge connected system which basically cannot be looked at as
independent parts.  Everything has to be fixed basically all at the same
time, but who knows how that is possible.
The movie Mind Walk does an excellent job of explaining this.

---------- Text of forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 22:11:31 -0800
From: Robert and Terri Mykland <mykland@netcom.com>
To: pliskin@nexsys.net
Subject: ART/TECH Society Survey

This survey is going out to all the people worldwide who responded to my 
posting about the Art/Tech idea group forming in California and the 
potential of a newsletter.  Here's a reprint for those of you who didn't 
see the original posting:

------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'm organizing a weekly meeting of people interested in the collision 
between art and technology and what can come of it.  Engineers, artists, 
philosophers, and futurists, whether professional or amateur, are 
invited.  The first meeting will be held in Scotts Valley, California, 
but subsequent meetings may be happening anywhere in Santa Cruz or Santa 
Clara counties depending on where interested people are concentrated.

The meeting will be a place to try out ideas, get technical and artistic 
advice, and collaborate.  We'll make up the rules as we go along.

Even if you're out of the area, contact me if you're interested.  An 
electronic or paper newsletter is likely.

I'm a twelve year veteran engineer with a broad background.  I studied 
physics at Cal, designed servo drives as an electrical engineer, and 
have in recent years been creating applications for Windows and the 
Macintosh.  Seven months ago, I decided I didn't have to choose between 
being a geek and being related to people, that I could express myself 
artistically using technology and automation itself as my medium.  Thus 
my particular form of geek art was born.

Have you noticed that all these labor saving devices we surround 
ourselves with don't really seem to save labor?  Despite endless 
marketing and herculean engineering, it seems pretty obvious that 
gadgets don't equate with a better life.

The challenge and the promise of the art I'm proposing is to break the 
vicious cycle of gadgetry for gadgetry's sake.  The cell phones and 
faxes and VCRs that surround us today are like a noise that sucks our 
energy into figuring it out enough to survive another day.  Not good or 
bad, but a distracting noise.  What I'm proposing is that we completely 
alter our relationship to technology by inventing music from that 
unfocused noise.

Art expressed in the way things work.  A future where technology is 
shaped artfully to be in tune with humanity and nature.  A future where 
humanity sees this harmony as a birthright.

Hope to hear from you.

-- RM.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

In my on-line discussions with many of you, the newsletter became a very 
definite reality.  The first issue will happen March 1 and will contain 
people's shared information (see below), the results of the survey 
below, meeting times for the Santa Cruz / Santa Clara county areas and 
perhaps other areas, and maybe even some articles.

Many other great ideas arose that I want to run by all of you and invite 
you to participate in.  They are mentioned in the survey below, but 
aren't by any means a complete list.  Please add your ideas and comments 
at the bottom of the survey.

Below the survey, I've included another copy filled out by me so that 
you can know where I'm coming from better.  (Also, it might clear up 
confusion if at some point I've given bad directions in the survey.)

Thanks again to all of you for responding and sharing your great ideas 
and advice with me.  Let's keep it going.  Here's to the future!

-- Robert.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

EMAIL GROUP
All the great people worldwide who responded to my post can communicate 
with each other via email.  To this end, please grant me permission to 
share your name, email address, and a short statement from you with 
others in this group.  I will only distribute what you include between 
the lines of asterisks below.  Also, this information will only be 
distributed within our group.

************************************************************************

Name:

Physical address:(Please include at least city, state/province, country)

Email address:

Phone number:

My statement:



I know a few cool things about:

I want to learn:

I want advice on:

************************************************************************


LOCAL GROUPS
Many people have mentioned to me that they want to form local Art/Tech 
idea groups in their areas...

Yes	Maybe		No

				together is a good idea.
( )	( )		( )	I want to participate in a local Art/Tech group.
( )	( )		( )	I want to help organize a local Art/Tech group.
( )	( )		( )	I've already organized a local group!
( )	( )		( )	I want to help with inter-group links:video,etc.
					(not necessarily technical work)


SANTA CRUZ / SANTA CLARA GROUP
What are good times for you to meet?
How does Friday, 24 February, from 7 PM to 9 PM, in Scotts Valley sound?


PUBLIC SHOWS
These could range from art exhibits to virtual exhibits of various kinds 
on the Internet.  Physical exhibits could feature live theater or dance 
performances.

Yes	Maybe		No
( )	( )		( )	Having a physical exhibit is a good idea.
( )	( )		( )	Having a virtual exhibit is a good idea.
( )	( )		( )	I want to contribute to a physical exhibit.
( )	( )		( )	I want to contribute to a virtual exhibit.
				(Let your imagination run wild here -- even if
				you specialize in an art form that doesn't lend
				itself to pictorial or video representation, new
				tools like QuickTime VR might be able to provide
				a way to present some of the impact of your work
				in a virtual form.  Granted, it's nothing like
				real life...)
( )	( )		( )	I want to help organize a show in my area.
( )	( )		( )	I want to help organize a touring exhibit.
( )	( )		( )	I want to help organize a virtual exhibit.
( )	( )		( )	I've organized exhibits/festivals in the past.


NEWSGROUP

via USENET!

				the past.


NEWSLETTER
I envision an electronic newsletter.  It would begin as a mass mailing 
like this survey.  My dream is that it could grow into a place where we 
could more fully and directly share our ideas and dreams by 
incorporating graphics, sound clips, animations, video clips, and 
virtual environments.

Yes	Maybe		No
( )	( )		( )	An electronic newsletter is a good idea.
( )	( )		( )	A paper version is important.
( )	( )		( )	I want to receive the newsletter.
( )	( )		( )	I want to contribute to the newsletter.
( )	( )		( )	I want to work on newsletter software.

				another language -->              <--.

			(USA, California, 200 km south of San Francisco,
			near the ocean)

Email address:	mykland@netcom.com

Phone number:	1-408-438-4698

My statement:
I'm a beginning artist whose medium is technology and automation.  I 
decided to become an artist eight months ago after twelve years of being 
an engineer.

I know a few cool things about: software design, analog and digital 
electronic (circuit) design, motion control & robotics, and physics.

I want to learn: how to draw and use color more effectively, and 
animation.

I want advice on: how to express my ideas and the possibilities I see 
for the world, both through my art and through the written word.

************************************************************************
