Subject: [3] CHEMICA SUTRA REPORT
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950328063048.9443A-100000@shell1.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk




here's the last of the catalogued artefacts from the CHEMICA SUTRA
EXPEDITION into the future perfect state, the Parallel University's first 
playshop of the spring term.  these are the actual staements of the
three other partygoers that cathy chose to interview in the wee small
hours. 

though we'd actually hoped to present something a bit more like a research
report on the event, the truth is pretty much everybody got a tad too
dreamy sipping PROSEXPLUS, the new prosexual smart drink that was included
in the ticket. this *was* a book rave launch, after all, to celebrate the
launch of the new Book BETTER SEX THROGH CHEMISTRY - A GUIDE TO THE NEW
PROSEXUAL DRAUGS which Timothy Leary has hailed as "probably the first
chapter in the chemical Karma Sutra for the next millennium." 

we promise to get it more worked out at the next one. April 21st (clashing
with Organic, but then this Parallel University event, the CHEMICA SUTRA
TECNOEROTIC EXPEDITION PARTY, can only accomodate 100 people maximum
anyway, and probably half of *them* are not yet ravers)


SFRAVERS DAN AND WILL, FOLLOWED BY JEAN FROM MISSOURI

DAN: if I had to choose *one* thing about tonight's party I'd have to say
the location.  we've never been to a place like this before, just an
amazing trip place.  

WILL:  for me the topper has to be the people, I mean this was a *people*
party.  and like a good rave on the dance floor there was all this high
energy and face to face eye-contact dancing.  but I have to agree this
place is the visual equivalent of what Edgar Allen Poe did.  I'd describe
the energy as high consciousness.  there was a lot of real talk about
things that we enjoy, ranging from Dan Joy's Better Sex Through Chemistry
thing, and that was just the springboard.  you know, for me the real party
is a people party where you have real contact with people and this was
superb in that way. 

DAN:  I feel the same.  I met a lot of nice people.  I caught most of
DanUs speech and it was interesting, I watched the belly dancer, the
tantric dancer, I was out on that floor for hours. 

WILL:  Paul Q is a great DJ.  and Lucy was different, but I'm
also a reader so the one thing that's going to prove it all for me is I
bought the book, and I'm going to read it and find out.  these are all
learning tools, whether they are nutrients or drugs or disciplines,
theyUre things we can practise to ...  grow. 

DAN:  I only tried one drink the nurse was handing out.  I felt a litle
warm, okay, nothing incredibly virile or anything.  but my trip went
really well with the sex drinks.  really good for socialising. 

JEAN;  Oh oh, it was wonderful, the lights, the rhythm, I really feel it
very deeply.  when IUm dancing I feel like a woman.  plus the freedom, it
seemed like a really free place to meet people and share.  a very eclectic
group in the extreme, in pretty bizarre surroundings, I was out on that
floor for hours.  totally great way to get to know each other more deeply. 
it was super. the one thing I'll take away from my first visit to the
Parallel University is that we're all experimenting with life in one way
or the other.  you could say new highs but it's new ways of *being* more
than anything. 


--------------------------------------------------------------------
              Megatripolis - The Future Perfect State
          fraser@megatripolis.org & megatrip@well.com 
            Tel: 415 752 7702  INFOLINE: 415 LAB 2323
             Web Page: http://www.megatripolis.org
 Usenet: alt.culture.zippies * The Well: Topic 54, House Conference

\


seriously, as far as pop music since the 60's, england has kicked ass.

but let's not forget that most great classical compositions from the
  18th century came from the continent; classical is still the basis
    for much of what we call "progressive" or "art" rock, as well as
      many other pop styles.

also, india's ragas, which are at least 1000 years old, have been
  incredibly influential of late, and are IN NO WAY themselves
    influenced by anything english, since they don't use the same
      scale intonations.

not to mention latin-american and carribean styles, which come from
  african and indigenous rythyms; they've got 1/5 of the world's 
    population boogying to a non-english type of music (reggae
     partially excluded due to London influence)

and then theres pure asian styles, korean, japanese, chinese, indonesian,
  etc., which are no where near western styles, either in use of
    instruments, tempo, vocals, etc.

hey, anglo-philes, get out there (like george harrison did) and
  LISTEN TO MORE DIFFERENT MUSIC!!!

Dave Scruton

Greetings fellow cybertribers and SF Ravers!

My name is Mike, and I'm a student at Columbia University all the way 
over in New York City.  And when I'm not a student, I'm living in New 
York City too...
I love the big apple, but I need to get a break; to get some 
perspective.  This summer I'm planning to live in San Francisco (along 
with a large contingent of other east coasters, btw..be warned :)) I have 
alot of friends who live in the bay, and seeing their pictures and 
hearing their stories is not enough...I want to live it and breathe it, 
explore the west coast, go hiking in the mountains and hills.

The only problem is finding a place to live.  I'm a rookie at locating 
housing for myself, because I usually just live at home or at school.  
I'm very scared of going to San Fran and not finding anywhere to live, 
and end up living on the street or something.  I'm pretty sure it will 
never quite come to that, but I would be much more relaxed and excited 
about going to the coast if I had some kind of reasonable assurance of a 
place to stay.
THIS IS WHERE YOU COME IN (there's always some kind of catch...)  If you 
need a roomate, someone to sublet, or know of any kind of room opening up 
in the city (preferably san fran, because thats where I'm applying for 
jobs) PLEASE LET ME KNOW.  I am a great roomate, having went through a 
year of hell at school...I always clean up fro myself, am good with the 
rent, etc. I am looking for something cheap tho...hopefully not too much 
more than  400 a month.  I'd really love to room with a SF native too... 
someone who could intropduce me to people and show me the town.
Or if you know of any alternatives to housing- co-ops, hostels, dorms, 
etc. please pass stuff on to me. 
If you'd like to talk more, please write back at mg162@columbia.edu, or 
call me at 212-853-4800.  I really hope things work out for the summer, 
because I can't wait to feel the SF vibe, and add my own brand of 
east-coast vibeism to it.  
In any case, I can't wait till May hits....just being on this list for a 
few days has already gotten me so siked up for the summer.  Help me make 
my dream a pleasant reality! 
Peace and talk to you all later...
__________________________________________________________________________
| mg162 @ columbia . edu  _______   a knife, a fork, a bottle and a cork: |
| michael  d  gwertzman   _______   that's the way we spell New York.     |

not on the internet. Yes, Petey'soffice is not saying anything about 
whther or not he even has one on his desk, how do we let these people get 
in office. I recommend calling his election campain people, they will 
lite a fire under his butt quicker that a fax will.

Peace & Love
Brian Darkness

Hey brian.  I just called that first number, and they referred me to the
Governor's Office.  The number for there is 1-916-445-1445.  His fax is
1-916-445-4633, like you said.  They also gave me the mail address, which
is:

        "Honorable" Governor Wilson
        State Capital
        Sacramento, CA 95814

When I called that number, a guy picked, and listened to all I had to say
in a very friendly manner.  He also tried to explain to me the reasons for
the Headwater Forest thing.  He said that they were going to cut down dead
trees for some lame reason.  I also complained about his newest policies
regarding the endangered species act, to which the gentleman replied by
saying it was to aid farmers in Watsonville to get their farms up again
after floods.  I didn't agree with a word he said, and told him so.  I said
that the ecosystem of our state is way more fragile than Wilson is treating
it.  He needs to take another look at his policies.

PLEASE, I encourage everyone to  call this number, or fax, or at least mail
Wilson!  Our voices do count!  Just remind him, like Brian said, that you
will not vote for such a pompous ass(but in nicer terms).  I am now living
in Connecticut, but I still called, because I believe in saving our
beautiful state!  I encourage everyone to go to Harmony and donate money to
Earth First, or to go out to rallies demonstrating against these lame laws.
But make sure to call.  A phone call takes but a few minutes of your time.
It well worth the effort.

Oh, and the person who answered the phone said that Wilson does not and
will not have an email address for a while longer.  He cites security
problems as the reason, and says that there have been breaches of other
people's accounts.  Once they can elininate the threat of violoations to
security, he will get an email address.  That should be within the next ten
or twenty years.

Save our state, save our planet.

Love,



Rob McCord (BR '98)
mcrobt@minerva.cis.yale.edu

Precedence: bulk

>From the San Jose Mercury under the State News in Brief, thier's an article about the Headwaters Forrest.  Headline is AGREEMENT BARS LOGGING ON 8,000 ACRES.
It basically says that Environmentalists and the company in question, Pacific Lumber Co. have come to a temporary agreement concerning the Headwaters Forest.  It's a 30-day agreement that should block logging until a judge can figure out whether Pacific Lumber must file a timber harvesting plan.  So far, state officials have accepted the companies plan to use dead, dying and diseased trees in two North Coast tracts, but environmental groups that those trees are important 
also.

Just thought I'd pass the information on to all of you since their seemed to
be interest concerning this issue.

Love and Peace

--
Jorge Montoya
fx277@kanga.ins.cwru.edu

Actually although there is a good deal of great music coming out of brittan
overall I still prefer much the continent has to offer. In the 70's
the space music from Germany for example:  Tangerine Dream, Ashra, 
Von Deyen, Kraftwerk then groups from France such as Heldon and lately
I've been hearing another great round of stuff from Germany and the
various dutch and scandanavian musicians produce some stuff that is often
lesser known but tastey....

Anyone who says brittan has it all is being far too provincial ( and
restrictive ) for my personal taste. But then I prefer much that brittan
produces over M Jackson and Madonna fur sur!

My $.02

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 28 17:53:35 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA03635; Tue, 28 Mar 1995 17:53:35 -0800
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id RAA03628; Tue, 28 Mar 1995 17:53:31 -0800
Received: from xinet.COM by xinet.COM via SMTP (940715.SGI.405/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for sfraves@hyperreal.com id AA25318; Tue, 28 Mar 95 17:49:38 -0800
Message-Id: <9503290149.AA25318@xinet.COM>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 17:52:26 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: One Ravers Delight (long, personal, stick with it)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I shaved my head!

Hey, what else is an SF Raver to do in the desert?  I mean, I had already
spent the better part of the day soaking in the natural hot springs,
eating, drinking, smoking, and hunting for cool rocks, so the mood struck
me to shave my head and I acted on it.  Feel free to rub it next time we
dance near each other.

But this band-width usage isn't about just me, or my head, it's about a
lone raver's experience in a non-raver's world...

The third night in the desert was the craziest.  Whenever you get 22 people
together partaking in outdoor activities, wherein every decision is part of
a collective, it's hard to come to agreements that please the whole all the
time.  (You know the adage, I shant repeat it.)  Dinners were pretty much
planned; tubbing, drinking, smoking, and dosing were up to the individual
-- I partook amply in the first three and declined the last reluctantly.
As for music, the dividing lines ran as deep as the gourges in the
beautiful Inyo Mountain range that we stared upon for hours.  The
atmosphere is so relaxed though, that it wasn't as if there were huge
debates going on over the music.  (Which I wish was the case here, but of
the 286 posts that I got to review today, a vast majority were snide
bickering about a lot of non-rave related bullshit.  Fraser if you've made
it this far, maybe you could consolidate your thoughts, and keep your posts
to, um, say, like five a day?  I mean if I see that little ad for
Megatripolis again, I just may scream....)

Anyway, I never made a big deal about not getting to crank up some of the
nice tapes I had brought to dance to; it just wouldn't have been
appropriate to complain.  I had to be resourceful, and I had to take
whatever I could when it was offered.  The moment came at about ten o'clock
Saturday night...

The sky was fucking huge.  I mean just so full of stars you could truly get
a "feel" for the three dimensional aspect of the solar system.  The
constelations took on new meaning with the clarity of their outline
(Orion's bow was especially nice to see again).  I realized it was my time
to act.  Most people were sitting around the fire, and no one seemed to
care when the tape of whoknowswhat ended.  I had to choose something that
would appeal to 21 non-ravers, so I grabbed the worn and wonderful Orb's
Adventures Beyond the Ultra World.  Now, I don't want to start a massive
thread about whether or not The Orb is "Techno" music, but under the
circustances, it was closer to techno than, say, Janes Addiction.  The
trucks were parked in a semi circle, and I snuck around to the non-fire
side and rolled down the window.  I was alone and quickly ran around to
tell a few people who I thought might want to share the experience, but no
one responded when I whispered "There's a rave going on on the other side
of the cars.  Sssshhhh."  Wink wink.  They probably thought I was tripping
or something, but I wasn't.

THIS IS WHERE YOU COME IN!!

I ran back to the other side of the cars and for a moment I felt alone.
Well, I mean, I *was* alone, but I felt lonely, and we all know there's a
difference between being alone and being lonely.  Here I was with a bald
head and more stars staring down on me than you could shake your ass at.
But I will tell you this my friends, when Little Fluffy Clouds came on and
I sank my teeth into that drug we call music, I thought so hard of you that
I could fairly see you dancing with me.  Let me point out again I was not
on hallucinogens, but just really really happy to take 45 minutes to dance
and sing and look at the stars and think about all the friends and family
I've encountered in the past year.  My feeling of being lonely was
assuaged, my feet were moving fast, the stars were shining, I had this big
fucking grin on my face and wonderful thoughts of you in my head,  and when
it was all over I sat down near the fire and grinned like lovers that had
just run off and had a quickie without anyone knowing.

The point of this story is this:  The scene is what *YOU* make it.  Someone
will have the best time of their life at the rave you had the worst; and
vice versa.  People may come into our scene and tell us that it's wrong, or
that it can be done better, or that it can be an enormous global movement.
Well, I for one don't know if I want that, because before it gets that far
it will be turned into a fucking circus, a marketing wet dream -- a lost
dream.  This isn't about getting bigger in attendance, it's about getting
bigger within yourself.

All kinds of people will sniff at our scene, but only those that are honest
about why they are there will stay long enough to make an impact.  Only
those that get the shiver of chills when they walk down the stairs at some
new venue and first hear the thump, thump, thump...and turn to the stranger
with a beaming face next to them and grab their hand and yell gleefully
"This is going to be a great party!!" will care to stay on board.  You
can't dish out the kind of love we are trying to spread with a firehose, it
must be hand fed one drop at a time.  I say we do not attempt to lambaste
the people with our movement, but let them discover individually the
treasure we have hidden and that we pull out every weekend for heat, and
love, and life.  It's not about who's doing it better, nor who's doing it
bigger, but that we are doing it at all.

And it's about being alone under the desert stars and having the littlest
rave possible -- A rave of one with the love and spirit of one thousand.
Thank you for sharing it with me; I could hardly wait to tell you about it.

Tony

P.S.  My suggestion for the name of our summer of raving?  I like:  Nothing
Mediaworthy to See Here.

Look; I've been living here for two years and have yet to hear a decent 
American piece of techno.  England, on the other hand mainly because 
this is where the best composer that the techno as a music has ever know 
- ie Richard H.Kirk - lives and work's.  Just check out any of the last 
three "Caberet Voltaire Albums, or the last three Sandos albums, or the 
first three Orb albums.  Their simply is no comparison between this 
music and anything that has come out of America in the last three years.  
The same can be said, with the exception of The Red Hot Chilli Pepper's, 
about rock music as well.
Face it: weather one likes it or not Britain, artisticly, has pretty much 
always been at the forefront in the world.  Pro-portionatly, we have made 
more fundamental discoveries, made and developed more kinds of music 
down the ages, written the greatest and most important books, then all 
the other countries of the world put together.  America is just a mere 
babe in her mother's arm's by comparison.
Yours Tristan.

> 	I believe in the Goddess concept, I believe that to varing degrees
> there is a Goddess alive and well in us all, including we men. So when the
> message in the song reached my brain in just clicked. Hope you find this

Refreshing to see some affirmation on the list.  thank you Brian Darkness.  I 
had forgoten about that album so I broke it out and listened to it while I 
read your post.  Very nice.

I thought I would share with the list my own favorite life affirming song.  
The song is called "Love and Anger" by Kate Bush off her album The Sensual 
World.  It's a beautiful triumphant piece with a solid rythm track at about 
128 bpm.  I allways think it would sound so hot dropped in at the end of an 
uplifting proggressive house set.  If I can ever find it on vinyl I'm gonna do 
just that.

I think that alot of the anger expressed on this list lately is stems from the 
feeling of helplessness about how fucked up the world around us has become.  
And I think if we recognize it as that, we can change it.   
Enough said.  Check out the lyrics.

Love and Anger   by Kate Bush

It lay there, it lay deep inside me.
it's so deep i don't think that I can Speak about it.
It could take me all my life,
But it would only take a moment to tell you what i'm thinking
But I don't know if I'm ready yet

What would I do without you?

And a little piece of hope holding us together
Looking for a moment that will never happen
Living in the gap between past and future
Take away the stone and the timber
And a little piece of rope won't hold it together

If you can't tell your sister
If you can't tell your priest
'Coz it's so deep you don't think that you can Speak about it to anyone...
Can you tell it to your heart?
Can you find it in your heart to let go of these feelings
Like a bell to a southerly wind
We could be like two strings beating 
speaking in sympathy
What would we do without you?
Two strings speak in sympathy.

Take away the love and the anger
And a little piece of hope holding us together
Looking for a moment that will never happen
Living in the gap between past and future
Take away the stone and the timber
And a little piece of rope won't hold it together.

We're building a house of the future together     <--- yes we are :) :)
What would we do without you?                     <--- yes ALL of you. :) :)
Well' if it's so deep you don't think that you can speak about it
Just remember to reach out and touch the past and the future.
Well, if it's so deep you don't think you can speak about it.
Don't ever think that you can't change the past and the future!!!   :)

But just you wait and see - someone will come to help you.

        I started putting the Headwaters Logging Alert on the WWW.  You can
get to the pages thru http://gladstone.uoregon.edu/~drenalin/knowledge.html
Part of our goal as the Cloud Factory is to help spread info  so if you
have something you think we might be able to put up send it to us
(drenalin@gladstone.uoregon.edu) and we will get it on the WWW.  If their
are any volunteers we need a sample letter to governor Wilson about the
Headwaters issue.  Our focus is to make it *easy* for people to do
something about what is happening now, for instance just saving a letter
and then printing it and signing it and mailing it...not too hard.  We are
also starting a list of pertinent addresses for people to contact please
send any addresses of nonprofit activist groups or politicians or anyone
that people need to know how to get in touch with and we'll try to organize
it coherently.

love drenalin

glad to read your story, tony.  it made me smile!

i had a similar experience in glaciar national park when i was making my 
way across country to move here.  we had just straight up from sounthern 
utah, had run out of gas at the continental divide, and had had maybe an 
hour of sleep.  after setting up camp at glaciar, we thought, aw hell, 
let's drive thru the park.  OH MY GODDESS!  words cannot express the awe 
and excitement i felt so close to the sky, staring at evergreen woods and 
waterfalls ... it truly was a sacred place.  in this state of rapture, i 
started hearing musick in my head from a tape by dante - jazzy, very 
celebratory, slightly melancholy.  i just smiled and smiled with my mouth 
hanging open.  

the next day we were driving thru the park again, and we stopped at a 
bridge and waterfall for a bit.  my friend wandered around, while i took 
out our cassette player and brought it with the dante tape (and a plastic 
sheet to protect it from the light mist) to the bridge, where i danced 
and danced, not alone but in the presence of the ancestors and forest 
spirits.  i believe i probably called the four powers (four elements - 
earth, air, fire, water) as well.

when i finished and walked back to the car, my friend looked at me and 
said, nicely, "you're crazy."  i smiled and thought, "yup, glad to be 
this way."

so thank you, tony, for bringing me to that memory (i feel all excited 
inside right now just thinking about it!)

take care,
monicat

Precedence: bulk

Ah, but Simon, you *can't* blame us (at least not initially) for the
Bee Gees.  That, erm, honor belongs to that *other* former colony 
"diwn endah."  :-)

All this blather about the UK having the greatest music bar none is just
silly.  New Orleans, Kinshasa and Rio could make equally strong claims to
London in their own way.  

But the *real* point is, this is the era when a techno musician from Detroit
can blend ideas from the local scene plus Chicago, New York, LA, SF, 
Kingston, Warsaw, Melbourne, Maracaibo, Yogyakarta, Stockholm and loads
of places we've never ever heard of, produce the raw tracks in Germany,
do the mixdown in London, final production in Rotterdam, and release it
on an Italian label with cross-licensing to one in Scotland that is
then released by a subsidiary of a Belgian distributor using a wholesaler
in New York selling it to people from London living in San Francisco at
a store run by someone who used to live in Houston.  And then listened to
by people of every complexion, gender, political belief, height, handedness
and length of time since they last talked to their mum and yah know what?

It sounds like music every single time.

see you in the future
phred

"Why make it simple & easy
 when you can make it complex & wonderful!"

I have been watching this thread  and made one minor comment.Though I 
have been vexed at some of the rather inane comments made I had decided 
to stay out of the conversation cuz I simply don't have time for such things 
and I'm generally not into flaming. However the recent ignorant and 
racist comments by Tristan have compelled me to respond. This is an 
unabashed flame against Tristan. You are a pompous ass!

-Tristan "Face it: whether one likes it or not Britain ,artistically, has 
pretty much always been at the forefront in the world. Proportionately, 
we have made more fundamental discoveries, made and developed more kinds 
of music down the ages, written the greatest & most important books then 
all the other countries in the world put together."

This is total crap. Don't forget Britain was one of the founders of the 
Industrial Revolution which has polluted the Earth and are the premier 
example of the horrors of colonialism. (Oh yes you were slave traders too).
I've lived in Britain and there is plenty of racism and a variety of 
other social ills. There are also some beautiful people and great artists 
(like all other cultures). Music wise British rock and roll was a rip off 
of African-American blues, British house & techno would be nowhere 
without Detroit & Chicago and the Orb would be nowhere without Dub (again 
a primarily black musical genre).

Get your head out of your ass you self absorbed bore.

Yours,
Ronan

I vote this is the highest finest thing I've heard here on sfraves in the
admittedly short time I've been hanging out here with my loud friends. eq
has hit the button.  you *do* have to fix it all at once, not in bits, and
if you're basically trying to fix everything at the same time then what
you're actually doing is trying to correct the fault in *every* piece and
that's why zippies are always getting into hot water. 
 
I'd say zippies (and I didn't invent zippies, you know, I just spotted a 
new emerging cultural meme which I could describe (and have described, in 
many ways.  for example the zippy type is beyond political corectness - 
which is exactly the way of trying to sort the world out bit by bit. 
zippies in increasing numbers throughout the "West", products of the 
cultural end times in which they live, just *know* that that way will 
*never* work in time.

a zippy type would say, maybe, for each of course has hir own bouquet of 
intersts and priorities, natutrally, "I'm about saving the fuckin planet, 
mate, *then* I'll think about sorting things out like giving up smoking."  
or giving up swearing when we've worked out the planet.  OK?".  or maybe 
even washing.  or going out to look for a job. or talking politely, heh!  
>;-)

(good liberal parent types might be able to tolerate up to this point,
but no further.  because the next steps are too logical and uncomfortable
for them to handle.  if the only historically sane way is to fix all the
bits at the same time, then there is no point in getting involved in
anyone particular political action.  indeed whzat we mean by "political
action"  becomes a wste of the zippy's energy because s&he *knows* that
s&he must find a *much* more *political* way - there is no time for
anything less. 

I think the best, fstest and least painful way (and most political
strategy) is to encourage the growh of a new "youth meme" and help to
spread it and make it fashionbale globally.  RC (Rave Culture) is already 
doing it, now it's just verblaising the actual aims.  hence zippy - 
trying to balance hir tecno and hippy hemispheres and the hemispheres of 
hir planet.

I'm saying that's how an increasing number of young aware people are 
starting to see things, though they may not quite have put it in those 
terms to themselves. the last thing I'll say for now is really dangerous 
stuff to say with "get every bit right" types listening but here goes. 

I often find when I talk to the younger raver types that, if you ask them
why they rave, they often can 't tell you much.  but, if you say, do you
think it's about dancing yourself free of cultural conditioning, or into a
shamanic state THEN THEY'RE ABLE to see it and verbalise it. 

"nuff for now.
fraser

on your first good point I'd respond that we're now at a point (I'd say 
not just approaching it in a decade or two or even half way through but 
even near the end of any real chance to do something about it) wehre 
being "conserve-ative" of your community now means acting globally. 
 and with all speed.  republicans, indeed, are about the only americans I
see who give any sign of being alarmed by the state of the out-of-control
system.  they're *almost" to my point of view that it's the sytem itself
that is our only problem. this could be a long long thread, Isuppose. 
here's one more thought on iut. 

on the labelling, stereotyping point:  language is nothing but labelling. 
language itself is simplifying an indescribable process so we can tak
about it. I think american culture (to use two extremely oversimplified 
words to avoid making it personal) is very ready for a new, positive, 
idealistic and determined almost reckless youthquake heavenbent on 
balancing their own inner life and at the same time sorting out their 
planet *all at once* (as elm tree put it).
the "label" zippy is merely a word to try to talk about this new type.  
(and also, yes, to try to influence it to some extent) and it can help to 
spread such a meme faster.
and, as I've said:  speed is of the essence IMHO
fraser

Fraser says:
> respect bro, I know you're one of the head honchos around here.

Thanks for the positive thought, but other than being one of many 
hyperreal archive maintainers, I have as much real authority in this 
forum as you do.  

>  republicans, indeed, are about the only americans I
> see who give any sign of being alarmed by the state of the out-of-control
> system. 

So are you saying that part of your mission here in San Francisco is to 
help us think more like Republicans?   I would never have guessed.

> they're *almost" to my point of view that it's the sytem itself
> that is our only problem. 

This is where I think our differences are.  It is my belief that the 
"system" is merely a symptom of the collective state of human nature.  
What's important about raving in all this talk about global change is that 
the rave experience can often bring a positive awareness to this basic
nature as well as help teach us to transcend the limitations of our 
human-ness altogether.

While I'm all in favor of people getting involved with trying to influence 
the system itself, I see the role of raving mainly as a promoter of
individual mental and spiritual health.  If Rave(tm) becomes a 
sociopolitical movement engaging itself with the world's obvious problems, 
then it will become part of the current system which is structured to 
incorporate and absorb such forces, no matter how progressive or 
revolutionary they may seem.

I would guess that most people on SFRaves (even the nonRepublicans :) agree 
with you that the system is pretty fucked up.  But a lot of us want to 
preserve raving as an experience that runs deeper and purer - more to the 
heart of who/what we are.  Hopefully, enlightenment at a such fundamental 
level, as vague and abstract as that might be, will eventually lead to more 
tangible advancements in the overall human condition.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com

Received: from DECNET-MAIL (SCRUTON@PAELE)

 Wed, 29 Mar 1995 09:59:51 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 09:59:51 -0800 (PST)
Subject: why are dead & dying trees important?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <01HOPCYDFP8200TOYI@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN1::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


you mite wonder why environmentalists want the lumber co to stay away from
  dead or dying trees in the forest; well, there are several reasons:

  1: large dead hollow trees which are still standing make excellent
       nesting sites for hawks, eagles, and owls

  2: fallen trees, as they start to decay, become "nurse logs", which
       actually provide the mulch from which young trees start and flourish.

  3: removing a large log from an old growth forest is usually done
       by dragging it out with chains.  this can do severe damage to the
         root structure of the surrounding forest, and can even kill
           adjacent oldgrowth trees

Dave Scruton

This is a big story in the European Press at the moment, that for some
curious reason hasn't made it over the Atlantic. Since global warming is a
reality threatening lowlying cities like San Francisco, we should at the
very least know where we stand (in the water as it were)
- david dei
>
>ENVIRONMENT: Rich Countries Fall Short Of Global Warming Targets
>
>   By Pratap Chatterjee
>
>WASHINGTON, Mar 24 (IPS) - Europe, Japan and North America will
>emit between six and ten percent more greenhouse gases during
>the  year 2000 than they pledged at the Earth Summit in 1992,
>say analysts on the eve of a major international conference on
>global warming in Berlin.
>
>   More than 150 countries have pledged to reduce their
>emissions  of greenhouse gases to 1990 levels by the year 2000.
>The first  meeting of those countries which have ratified this
>agreement  starts in Berlin next Tuesday and will last two
>weeks.
>
>   The convention was based on a 1990 warning by the
>Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) that the
>planet's surface is warming as a result of the increasing
>accumulation in the atmosphere of greenhouse gases, like carbon
>dioxide and methane, which trap heat from the sun.
>
>   The scientists estimated that these emissions would have to
>be  cut back by at least 60 percent to stop the warming trend.
>Failure to do so, they warned, could result in the eventual
>submergence of whole islands in the pacific ocean and coastal
>cities due to the melting of the polar ice caps.
>
>   Other effects could include the loss of agricultural areas to
>scrubland or desert, and a rise in famine and pestilence.
>
>   But U.S. government figures show that energy-related carbon
>emissions had reached 1,373 million metric tonnes in 1993, a 2.5
>percent increase over 1992 and a level that scientists did not
>think that this country would reach until 1996. The American
>council for an energy-efficient economy estimates that the
>United  States will exceed the 2000 target by six percent.
>
>   Last year the Japanese government said Japan would exceed the
>1990 target by 3.1 percent in the year 2000.
>
>   Canada has already announced that it will surpass the target
>by 10 percent, while unpublished memos from the European
>commission obtained by IPS show that Europe's emissions will
>exceed the target by six to eight percent.
>
>   So far, negotiations leading up to the berlin meeting have
>failed to produce any agreement on what needs to be done next,
>and activists say some governments, backed by oil interests, are
>trying to prevent any decisions from being taken.
>
>   ''What we expect to see at the meeting next week is ten days
>of arguments on procedural matters to effectively block any new
>agreements,'' says Karan Capoor, international liasion for the
>U.S.-based Environmental Defense Fund (edf).
>
>   The effort is being led by two countries -- Saudia Arabia and
>Kuwait -- which stand to lose from any agreement to reduce
>emissions. As two of the world's largest producers of oil, which
>emits carbon dioxide when burnt, the Saudis and Kuwaitis are
>worried that if countries cut back or tax petroleum, their
>export  income will suffer.
>
>   Capoor says they will try to obtain a seat on the
>convention's  governing board. As of now, the Alliance Of Small
>Island States  (AOSIS), whose member-states have most the most
>to lose if  scientists' predictions come true, has a seat on the
>board along  with ten other countries.
>
>   ''The oil producers says that they are the most affected
>financially so they should also have a seat,'' says Capoor.
>
>   In addition, the oil producers want to change a rule
>governing  decision-making. They are hoping to get agreement
>that consensus -- instead of a voting majority -- will become
>the board's governing principle.
>
>   Thus, new protocols, such as one proposed by the AOSIS
>countries, to cut emissions by 20 percent from 1990 levels by
>the  year 2005, could be blocked by only one or two countries
>which  refused to go along.
>
>   Yet another proposal from the United States would eliminate
>new targets altogether. Rafe Pomerance, the U.S. deputy
>assistant  secretary of state for environment and development,
>says that his  country will propose a two-year analysis to
>figure what countries  could achieve after 2000.
>
>   ''Our specific structural proposal will offer a common menu
>of  options from which governments can pick in order to suit
>their  particular programme,'' he told reporters on Wednesday.
>
>   But activists say Washington is avoiding its responsibilities
>in order to keep oil and industry happy. ''It's really a
>political problem -- not a technology problem -- that we are
>talking about,'' says Alden Meyer, the director for climate and
>energy policy at the union of concerned scientists in
>Washington.
>
>   ''The U.S. has other proposals such as joint implementation
>whereby we would pay other countries to protect their forests to
>absorb greenhouse gases. Frankly, all this will paralyse the
>process because what we need is reductions of existing
>emissions,'' he added.
>
>   ''If developed countries can't cut back on their emissions
>it's going to create a credibility gap, because developing
>countries are going to say, 'why should we do anything about our
>emissions','' says Liz Baratt Brown of the natural resources
>defense council in Washington. (ends/ips/pc/95)
>
>

-----------------------------------------------
                           REALITY TECHNICIANS INTERNATIONAL
                                     megatrip@best.com

     INFORMATION, INSPIRATION & SERVICES TO THE NATION

I think more people need to take Larry's suggestion
because it seems fairly obvious that 
Tristan is just slagging US music 
to be a sarcastic contrast against his statements
about the SF rave culture lacking racial diversity

As has been pointed out, most of the good music that has 
come out of Britain has just been a bunch of 
White boys from the UK re-working things
that were invented by Black Americans
(americans = people from North or South America, not just the US)

(the major exception to this were people who 
took stuff from the Ramones, like the Clash or the Sex Pistols
but i would never put the Sex Pistols in the "good music" category
and the Clash also stole from reggae)

so i think that Tristan is just trying to point out the
fact that we all need to be more aware of our musical
history and notice how much we owe to african-american culture
for the music that it has provided to us

This is a really important thing.  As part of a culture that
isn't the "main" culture of the U.S., we don't have 
people who are going to put us in High School history books.
We need to make sure that we keep track of our history ourselves,
spreading it Orally (well.. Electronically)... saving fliers,
saving zines, saving sfraves archives.  These are our history books.

I really can't stress how important i think it is to learn
the history of this or any culture that one is a part of.
Recently, i've just been seeing in so many ways how 
the knowledge of the history of a culture can be an incredible benefit.

Anyhow... just wanted to thank Tristan for bringing the point out,
although i would probably reccommend not being so obtuse next time...
you know how us Yanks just don't get sarcasm :)

 ,
dana
 
"I knew my life was complete when i found out
that a piece of furniture was named after me."
	- me

REPLY FROM: Atherton, Darren

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

you mite wonder why environmentalists want the lumber co to stay away from
  dead or dying trees in the forest; well, there are several reasons:

  1: large dead hollow trees which are still standing make excellent
       nesting sites for hawks, eagles, and owls

  2: fallen trees, as they start to decay, become "nurse logs", which
       actually provide the mulch from which young trees start and flourish.

  3: removing a large log from an old growth forest is usually done
       by dragging it out with chains.  this can do severe damage to the
         root structure of the surrounding forest, and can even kill
           adjacent oldgrowth trees

Dave Scruton

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 29 11:51:06 1995

Subject: who came first/"stealing"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Ok, I don't wan't to add to the whole UK debate, but I am distressed that
the idea of "who came first" seems to be a dramatic subject.

The issue of "who came first" in music is absurd.  All music comes from     
somewhere, although sometimes the references are more blatant than others.  

Dana-"i would never put the Sex Pistols in the "good music" category
and the Clash also stole from reggae)"

By necessity we listen to the world at large to influence what we create. It
is not what you use to construct something, or even how you constructed it.
The end product is what matters.

Stravinsky (Igor, not on SFRaves)"Good composers borrow, great composers
STEAL."

Paul

Subject: CHILDREN: Record Numbers Of Poor Children In USA
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A reason to get rave-positive child-friendly society off the ground ASAP?


>Children: Record Numbers Of Poor Children In USA
>
>   By Yvette Collymore
>
>Washington, Mar 29 (IPS) - The latest outlook for U.S. children
>is  grim: one in three will fall into poverty, drop out of
>school, or face abuse or neglect before adulthood - and this is
>even before anticipated cuts in Federal funds for child care.
>
>   The Washington-based Children's Defense Fund (CDF) Tuesday
>served up the projection as it released its findings that the
>number of poor children in the United States increased last year
>to nearly 16 million -- the highest number since 1964.
>
>   The CDF, which uses a range of indicators to gauge conditions
>facing children, says one in four homeless persons in the United
>States last year was a child under 18 years, and the number of
>children reported abused or neglected in 1993 was almost three
>million.
>
>   The assessment comes just days after the House of
>Representatives approved what promises to be the most
>comprehensive overhaul of the U.S. social welfare system since
>the Great Depression. The CDF says the estimated 46-billion-
>dollar assault on child nutrition, child care, foster care, and
>adoption services goes beyond just budget cuts.
>
>   Lawmakers in the Republican-controlled House Friday voted for
>welfare legislation that would terminate the Federal guarantee
>of  cash benefits for poor families and slash Federal aid by 66
>billion dollars.
>
>   Under the legislation, which now goes before the Senate,
>Federal rules would change for 40 aid programmes that serve
>roughly one in 10 people in the United States. They cover school
>lunches, disability payments, foster families, and nutrition
>subsidies for pregnant women and infant children.
>
>   ''At a time when nearly 16 million children are poor, almost
>three million are abused and neglected, and 400,000 drop out of
>school, Congress should be strengthening rather than permanently
>shredding federal child protections and recklessly slashing
>child  investments,'' said CDF president Marian Wright Edelman,
>who  unveiled the group's annual report.
>
>   In place of current aid programmes, states would get five
>block grants or lump sum payments for cash assistance and job
>training, child care, services for abused children, and child
>and family nutrition.
>
>   ''There appears to be no moral line House leaders will not
>cross in their reckless rush to reinvent American social policy
>and values,'' said Edelman, referring to the legislation, one of
>the items in the Republicans' 'Contract With America'.
>
>   According to the CDF, the House leaders' efforts to replace
>child entitlements with block grants will cause countless
>children around the country to be left behind.
>
>   The agency predicts that states will be forced to reduce
>benefits or the number of children served by health care,
>feeding, or child care services during a recession or natural
>disaster if there are more children in need.
>
>   Edelman's organisation warns that children in many U.S.
>states  would quickly feel the effects of entitlement cuts as
>states begin receiving fewer dollars even in the current
>financial year.
>
>   The CDF estimates that fewer dollars for child care
>assistance  would mean that, by the year 2000, the parents of at
>least 378,000 children could face not getting a job or losing
>one because they do not have safe day care for their children.
>
>   The CDF is stressing that the ''shameful numbers'' contained
>in its report have ''small, individual faces, and feelings, and
>suffering''.
>
>   It reports that more than 5,000 children and teens in the
>country died by gunfire in 1992 -- one child every 98 minutes.
>
>   A record level of 14.2 million children relied on food stamps
>to eat in 1993, up 51 percent since 1989. More than 9.4 million
>children had no health insurance in 1993, an increase of more
>than 800,000 since 1992.
>
>   Also, while 60 percent of mothers with children under age six
>are working, 35 percent of homes providing family child care
>were  found to be of such poor quality last year that they were
>likely  to harm children's development.
>
>   The CDF favours welfare reform that decreases child and
>family  poverty, prevents dependency, and encourages work. It
>says block  grants can be crafted that maintain child
>entitlements while  increasing state flexibility, improving
>service delivery and  maintaining at least current levels of aid
>to children.
>(end/ips/yjc/jl/95)
>
>

David Dei, dear heart, what has possessed you to inflict yet another
interesting, important but essentially off-subject topic on sfraves?

Don't fight me on this one, pal.  I have you covered any way you turn.
I co-wrote and steered through the Oregon Legislature in 1989 the law
requiring the Oregon Department of Energy to produce a detailed study
of global climate change and its effects on our state, plus a commitment
to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to the levels set by the 1988 Toronto
conference.  Oregon so far is the only state to have gone to such lengths
to deal with the global climate change issue, and that well in advance of
the Rio conference and subsequent developments.

Therefore, I think my credentials are in order to make the following
suggestion.

And let me say it again: this topic, as you've posed it, is not directly
germane to sfraves, plus it appears to have been a reposting of a
copyrighted news story (also a no-no under the Berne Convention and
netiquette).

It would be perfectly appropriate, in my view, to post that you are
interested in discussing political, cultural, social and environmental
issues of concern to ravers and invite us to join a separate mailing
list to do so.  I hope you do that instead of continually inflicting
your agenda on us as if we were so many errant schoolchildren.

Sincerely yours,
phred

I have appreciated the racism thread as it added to the punch of the Bell 
Hooks book I've been reading.Her main point I think is 'to talk about racism 
when you talk about sexism and don't leave out the context of a white 
supremist capitalist patriarchy'.  However, and I think this could relate to 
Lee's post, That dancing and having group altered consciousness experience 
are very political in and of themselves .I think having ecstatic experiences can 
contribute to your person in a way that allows you in return to be able to 
affect things in a positive way. The problem with beating people in the head 
with statistics and then accusing them of being in denial is that your personal 
Pain hampers the positive effect your good intentions might have had.
Correct me if I'm wrong but has your experience as a South African given 
you insight into race issues globally? Personal healing is also part of the rave 
experience.

93- kind of like Lollapalooza, but with more hip-hop and jazz, and big dj 
lineups and tents?

sprouting here, how will it play out in clubs?

vibes and crowds gathered, as opposed to less eclectic  parties

        Reply to:   RE>>week-long planet lovers
--------------------------------------
Date: 3/29/95 8:30 AM
To: Nathan Moser
From: Lee Fogel
...
While I'm all in favor of people getting involved with trying to influence 
the system itself, I see the role of raving mainly as a promoter of
individual mental and spiritual health.  If Rave(tm) becomes a 
sociopolitical movement engaging itself with the world's obvious problems, 
then it will become part of the current system which is structured to 
incorporate and absorb such forces, no matter how progressive or 
revolutionary they may seem.
...
Lee
----------------------------------------
I partially agree - I don't think sociopolitics would inevitably and 
unavoidably dilute rave. It is _the_ major concern when you start trying 
to evaulate rave in terms of politics, though.

For point of reference, consider the dadaist stuff, Artaud and Breton. They 
make our local Zippie friends look polite. Endearing statements like "All 
writing is pigshit!" In trying to bring about revolution through art, they 
tried to create an anti-aesthetic so vile and destructive that "the 
system" of their day would choke trying to absorb it. Nowadays, we use 
"avant garde" to describe automobile interiors.
-nate

>event. I do not have the time at this point to do it alone. So to get things 
>started- "any insurance brokers out there willing to write a two-day policy on 
>an entire mountain"?

Sorry about the late reply -- i was off-continent (not incontinent) for
the last 2 weeks, and I'm still not "home"....

Anyways, I'm wondering if insurance is really necessary. Why not, along
with the ticket sales, force each person attending to sign a liability
waiver (prolly need ID to ensure validity)? Skip insurance entirely --
it's a scam and we shouldn't be giving any more money to the holders of
our economic-slavery shackles than we have to. People should learn to
take responsibility for themselves and their own stupid actions, even
when "fucked up"... Treat partying like a consensual act -- you're
there of your own volition and if you're worried about consequences,
don't go.

Either that or I completely misunderstood, and the point of 
"insuring the whole mountain" is to be sure that a band of marauding
gangstas with jackhammers doesn't chisel away at the mountain in
a meth-inspired labor of anti-sysiphus...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2340      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Subject: Raving and politics (was week-long planet lovers)

Ideas about political implications of raving...

>>While I'm all in favor of people getting involved with trying to influence 
>>the system itself, I see the role of raving mainly as a promoter of
>>individual mental and spiritual health.  If Rave(tm) becomes a 
>>sociopolitical movement engaging itself with the world's obvious problems, 
>>then it will become part of the current system which is structured to 
>>incorporate and absorb such forces, no matter how progressive or 
>>revolutionary they may seem.
>>-lee 
>
>I partially agree - I don't think sociopolitics would inevitably and 
>unavoidably dilute rave. It is _the_ major concern when you start trying 
>to evaulate rave in terms of politics, though.
>
>For point of reference, consider the dadaist stuff, Artaud and Breton. They 
>make our local Zippie friends look polite. Endearing statements like "All 
>writing is pigshit!" In trying to bring about revolution through art, they 
>tried to create an anti-aesthetic so vile and destructive that "the 
>system" of their day would choke trying to absorb it. Nowadays, we use 
>"avant garde" to describe automobile interiors.
>-nate

If you care about socio-politics and you care about raving, the two should
not be lumped together, IMHO. It's clear, even if only from the last few weeks
on this list, that there's people coming from alot of different directions 
that are into this. Why alienate them with an ideology?

Many people involved in all sorts of great political concerns wouldn't be 
caught dead at a rave, either. That's not to say that stuff shouldn't be
brought up on the list. It doesn't strike me that any of the political
issues brought up in the last week are really out of place. We just can't 
get to the point where one person is saying to another "How can you call 
yourself a raver if you don't support xyz?". You get the idea... but as Lee 
pointed out earlier, many of us don't want to be called ravers anyway... :) 

I think people here know what they're doing and doing it well! (Not to suggest
that you meant otherwise) The main political concern should be to fight 
anything that restricts access to spaces (indoor or out) for parties. 
That's number one. But then this raises the issue of above vs. underground...

My $0.02 

-Dave

> Fraser says:
> > respect bro, I know you're one of the head honchos around here.
> 
> Thanks for the positive thought, but other than being one of many 
> hyperreal archive maintainers, I have as much real authority in this 
> forum as you do.  
> 
> >  republicans, indeed, are about the only americans I
> > see who give any sign of being alarmed by the state of the out-of-control
> > system. 
> 
> So are you saying that part of your mission here in San Francisco is to 
> help us think more like Republicans?   I would never have guessed.
> 
> > they're *almost" to my point of view that it's the sytem itself
> > that is our only problem. 
> 
> This is where I think our differences are.  It is my belief that the 
> "system" is merely a symptom of the collective state of human nature.  
> What's important about raving in all this talk about global change is that 
> the rave experience can often bring a positive awareness to this basic
> nature as well as help teach us to transcend the limitations of our 
> human-ness altogether.
> 
> While I'm all in favor of people getting involved with trying to influence 
> the system itself, I see the role of raving mainly as a promoter of
> individual mental and spiritual health.  If Rave(tm) becomes a 
> sociopolitical movement engaging itself with the world's obvious problems, 
> then it will become part of the current system which is structured to 
> incorporate and absorb such forces, no matter how progressive or 
> revolutionary they may seem.
> 
> I would guess that most people on SFRaves (even the nonRepublicans :) agree 
> with you that the system is pretty fucked up.  But a lot of us want to 
> preserve raving as an experience that runs deeper and purer - more to the 
> heart of who/what we are.  Hopefully, enlightenment at a such fundamental 
> level, as vague and abstract as that might be, will eventually lead to more 
> tangible advancements in the overall human condition.
> 
> Lee
> ____________________________________________________________________________
> lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> 
Let me just do a slight edit on your last 2 lines, lee,  and we might be in 
FULL agreement.

"Hopefully enlightenment at such a fundamental level .. will lead to 
.. tangible advancements in the overall human existence."

I'm in total agreement with that statement.  Our only dispute will be in 
the time frame which I think is *indredibly* short

the situation which you describe in the line I edited out "as vague and
abstract as that might be" is *exactly* the one I'm trying to adress.  for
notice that you say yourself that the enlightenment that RC can offer is
at a "fundamental" level; there's nothing in fact abstract about it at
all, it's *fundmaental*, it's *real*, it's *accumulating* in a lot of
people and *spreading* at warp speed.  it's just "vaguely"  understood. 

and I'm much more optimistic than you about its spread. this is no shallow
fashion and one of the greatest strengths within RC that I've noticed is
that everywhere it breaks out the local population actually believes
*their* scene is just the best and purest.  I think that's great!  

and even more importantly, nonstop shamanic drun dancing is one of the
most ancient and powerful *technologies* for personal and social change. 
from Elvis NOT swinging *his* hips on tv in the '50s, to millions of
people swinging *their* hips and every other pzrt in the '90s..  the
changes RC brings about are so "fundamental" that the packaging is
*relatively* unimportant

fraser

Subject: bpm program for Newton

I have written a bpm program for the Newton PDA.  Tap the button in time
with the music
and it reads out the bpm in real time.  There are also fields for artist and
title, and the
ability to copy the info to a note  (no database yet).

It is bpm.sit (stuffit format) on newton.uiowa.edu
in /submissions.  It is also on hyperreal.com in /incoming  (unless the
admins have moved
it to some place more appropriate by now).

The saavy Mr. Scruton (scruton@paele.dnet.hac.com) extols:
>also, india's ragas, which are at least 1000 years old, have been
> incredibly influential of late, and are IN NO WAY themselves
>    influenced by anything english, since they don't use the same
>     scale intonations.
>
>  LISTEN TO MORE DIFFERENT MUSIC!!!
>

This is really easy in the Bay Area, where there are lots of India stores,
especially in Berkeley, Fremont and Santa Clara
(I think there are some in S.F. as well - on Mission?).

India music cassettes are *really* cheap $1.99 to $3.49 - ie you can get 5 or
more, for the cost of one DJ tape. :-)

A good place to go is Shrimati's on the east end of University in Berkeley
(somewhere in the last few blocks before UC, on the north side of the
street).  They have a great selection and the dude there is helpful and
knowledgable.

Besides "classical" India music you can also get "Bhangra" (from the UK)
which combines traditional India folk music with techno/hip-hop.  "Kamlee
Rave" by Amarjit Sidhu is a good place to start with Bhangra music.

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

There is a world wide web site for the Congress, but I don't remember it
right now.  It has the addresses of all congressmen.  I wrote to Norm
Mintea once, asking his opinion on Prop 187.  I received an automated
message back immediately, thanking me for writing.  The message stated that
he would not write back through email due to security problems.  All
correspondence from that point on would be done through mail, if I had
included an address.  So I mailed my address and my letter once more.  It's
been over four weeks and I still haven't received a response.

I'll try and find that site tonight and post it, so that people can have
the email addresses at their disposal.

Peace and Love,


Rob McCord (BR '98)

Although Wicked will/may be doing a Full Moon party, I hope it does NOT
de-rail the plans of others on the list or elsewhere from attempting to do
the same.  There is plenty of room for more than one posse to throw a FM
party.

So if you want to attend the Wicked crew's party, go ahead.

If you want to start your OWN party, go ahead.

The sky's the limit, and there needs to be more than one place to go when
the moon is pumped anyway.

Peace,
John

P.S.  There will also be plenty of parties to go to this weekend as well.
I just hope NONE of them get busted (especially those ug events held in
not-so-legal places).  Good luck partying this weekend!  And be safe!

When only the glories of the past can make one proud of one's country 
what other form of debate can I take?  Don't forget, not everyone is 
lucky enough to come from a country where the 2nd World War is talked 
about as a distant memory and Nam is seen to have been a silly mistake.  
The US has no sense of history; any that it did had was abrieviated in 
the pledge of alliegence.  Here if some thing is a year old it is all 
ready out of date.
We gave life to the modern world and the modern world, like weed killer, 
polouted everything it germinated and scattered it's seeds of pollution 
through out the modern world.  And it was those seeds that planted the 
US, Germany and Japan.

Hey All,

John mentioned:

> Although Wicked will/may be doing a Full Moon party, I hope it does NOT
> de-rail the plans of others on the list or elsewhere from attempting to do
> the same.  There is plenty of room for more than one posse to throw a FM

Might also reduce the risk of busts. If more of us are doing outdoor 
parties, two things might happen.

	-	The "Authorities" start getting used to the idea of our 
		parties. Perhaps to the point where tolerance is more 
		common than not.

	-	Increased public awareness as to the true nature of our 
		events. Don't know about you, but every person I've brought to 
		an outdoor party has left with a rather positive image. 

Any ideas?

-Jonas

Dear phred

I'm not sure whether to be outraged that you consider saving the planet
from destruction an "interesting, important but essentially off-subject
topic" or puzzled at this clear display of denial that things are wrong,
backed up your "I have you covered any way you turn" attitude after which
you recite the Berne Convention on me?

Free your mind and your planet might follow.

David Dei

PS Since when is saving the planet NOT a rave issue? Or was all that shit
just for decoration? Do other ravers agree on this?

At  2:59 PM 29/3/95 -0800, Fred Heutte wrote:
>David Dei, dear heart, what has possessed you to inflict yet another
>interesting, important but essentially off-subject topic on sfraves?
>
>Don't fight me on this one, pal.  I have you covered any way you turn.
>I co-wrote and steered through the Oregon Legislature in 1989 the law
>requiring the Oregon Department of Energy to produce a detailed study
>of global climate change and its effects on our state, plus a commitment
>to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to the levels set by the 1988 Toronto
>conference.  Oregon so far is the only state to have gone to such lengths
>to deal with the global climate change issue, and that well in advance of
>the Rio conference and subsequent developments.
>
>Therefore, I think my credentials are in order to make the following
>suggestion.
>
>And let me say it again: this topic, as you've posed it, is not directly
>germane to sfraves, plus it appears to have been a reposting of a
>copyrighted news story (also a no-no under the Berne Convention and
>netiquette).
>
>It would be perfectly appropriate, in my view, to post that you are
>interested in discussing political, cultural, social and environmental
>issues of concern to ravers and invite us to join a separate mailing
>list to do so.  I hope you do that instead of continually inflicting
>your agenda on us as if we were so many errant schoolchildren.
>
>Sincerely yours,
>phred

	When I see David D. or Fraser carry an Amp or Speaker cab
	or see them walk up the hill, unarmmed to negotiate with
	a squad of police in riot gear, or "Vibe" a bunch of Cops
	into letting the party continue in only the way that a full
	on "Rave God{dess}" can or talk a kid down from a bad trip, 
	or negotiate with the mayor of a major metropolitan city 
	to let their parties go on unmolested, or pull some poor 
	raver whoose suffering from hypothermia off of an off-shore 
	rock when the tide's coming in or work to establish e-mail
	and internet links in areas of africa or native american 
	reservations, or stand tall and support their friends when the
	DEA is at the door or do anything like the above (these are things
	that I personally know that people on the list have done).
	Then I'll believe that you guys walk the walk instead of just
	talking the talk.

	I think less talk and more action is in order, there is an old growth
	forest a few miles north of here that needs saving RIGHT NOW!
	If you got some free time on your hands, I'm sure a 1000 year
	redwood could use your help.

hang out? Any popular chill-out or after-hours places with a REAL breakfast?

don't think so) as it have to go there afterwards(NAB)?

Thanks in advance for any reply.

> PS Since when is saving the planet NOT a rave issue? Or was all that shit
> just for decoration? Do other ravers agree on this?

Since when is saving the planet a rave issue?  How is it that you seem to 
be dictating the rave and non-rave issues?  It seems that if an issue 
falls within David Dei's agenda, then it *is* a rave issue.  That is 
wrong and...prejudiced, David.

There most likely exist some people who enjoy going to raves who are not 
concerned with saving the planet--perhaps even on this list.  You are 
subtley dealing in hypocrisy by forcing your agenda on us here and 
denouncing those who see its irrelevance.

Please contact the sysadmins at best.com for help with creating your own 
newsgroup or mailing list or similar forum.  David, what you persist in 
doing is an internet crime of sorts--your access can be suspended if 
someone complains to those at best.com.

There are people both in and out of raving who would like to discuss 
those issues that interest you.  Create your own discussion group and 
then publicly invite them to join.

	Sami

it seems like this should almost be a monthly posting type thing
except people probably read those as much as they read
the welcome message in the first place

i snipped and cut everything out that i didnt 
really feel needed to be re-mentioned 

> 	Welcome to the San Fransisco/Bay Area RAVE mailing list!
> 
>  		       ***PLEASE READ THIS***
> 
> 	This mailing list is dedicated to discussion involving the
> rave/ underground club/techno scene now developing here in the Bay
> Area. 
> 
> 	Appropriate topics include: announcements of upcoming events;
> reviews of previous shows/DJ's/new records, etc; discussion about
> SF-related and rave- culture-related topics, like smart drinks;
> discussion about rave-related stories on TV/in the newspaper, etc.
> Ideally we should try and stay away from, "Hey, did you catch that
> Orbital song on "Beverly Hills 90210" last week?"  stuff, or from
> over-generalizing ourselves: "Can Depeche Mode be considered "techno"?
> ", etc. But, other than that, I want it to be pretty free form. The
> list should _not_ be about rave scenes in other parts of the world; an
> occasional post about a huge megaevent in LA or a monthly report on
> the scene in other cities might be okay, but remember there was a
> reason this is called SFRaves; if you want to start a mailing list for
> your area, ask your sysadmin, as that was all I had to do. If that
> fails, there's alt.raves, the USENET newsgroup, where you can post
> just about anything you want.
> 
> 
> 	Please bear in mind that you are entering a virtual community;
> that the people here exhibit a friendliness and familiarity with each
> other, and while criticism of posts is not discouraged, please treat
> other people's posts with the same respect you'd want yours treated.

Personally, i DO think that sfraves should talk about politics
and talk about how raving fits within the world,
but i would not necesarily agree that any topic
should be thrown in at any time.

I think that the topic needs to fit within a relation to 
stuff going on in SF.  That is, yes, the extermination of
whales is a bad thing, information on it is really nice,
and i DO think that killing off all the whales will affect
us as humans and therefore affect us as ravers,
BUT it doesn't really have anything to do with
rave culture in SF other than through abstraction.

Maybe if you wanted to get a Green Peace like expedition going
and we could hold a couple year long rave on a boat
that would try to stop whale hunters... well post away...
but other than that...

Or, i think the issue of race and raving is an important one
to deal with as it is somethign that, well.. has to do with raving.
Or race and online access is important in figuring out
why which types of peopel are going to be on sfraves.

just some thoughts

 ,
dana

that a piece of furniture was named after me."
	- me

At 10:08 AM 30/3/95 -0800, Geoff White wrote:
>        When I see David D. or Fraser carry an Amp or Speaker cab
>        or see them walk up the hill, unarmmed to negotiate with
>        a squad of police in riot gear, or "Vibe" a bunch of Cops
>        into letting the party continue in only the way that a full
>        on "Rave God{dess}" can or talk a kid down from a bad trip,
>        or negotiate with the mayor of a major metropolitan city
>        to let their parties go on unmolested, or pull some poor
>        raver whoose suffering from hypothermia off of an off-shore

>        and internet links in areas of africa or native american

>        Then I'll believe that you guys walk the walk instead of just

>        I think less talk and more action is in order, there is an old growth
>        forest a few miles north of here that needs saving RIGHT NOW!
>        If you got some free time on your hands, I'm sure a 1000 year
>        redwood could use your help.

Agreed. Its definitely in the Doing that we live our lives, although what I
would reccommend is a balance between walking and talking - as too much of
either one - too cerebral or too physical  - would represent imbalance.

But the record will speak, on Fraser's part I find his well-publicised
(Newsweek) sneak-in of a soundsystem into the Kaibab National Forest,
particularly charming.

As for myself - I've had rubber bullets fired at me by South African Riot
Police, defied censorship laws, escaped a military draft, contravened
interracial mixing laws, published banned tracts and other inhuman laws too
numerous to mention, and even now find myself in contravention of a
particularly well publicised  law. ;-)

Which is not to say that I am recommend the breaking of law as such, but
rather the following of more fundemental and basic life-positive laws -
like the preservation of life  and love.

One thing I have learnt (although have much trouble practicing as seen in
the flame war last week), is this. A warrior choses his battles carefully.
There is no sense in commiting a suicidal act just to illustrate a point,
neither is anything won by standing up to a bullet. But, somewhere between
the zen of doing nothing and the yoga of doing something, we must make a
stand. Looking at all major battles in history, both social and political,
only those who dared to venture into the Territory of  RISK ever achieved
their goals.

- david dei

PS So how do we save these Redwoods, as well as the Children, and a whole
host of things like our freedom to dance wherever the whim takes us? This
is what I hope sfravers will want to talk about and then when all the
talking is done, dance onwards into action.

	Hi Everyone,

I got some mail regardng my last post about going out this weekend so
I wanted to make some clarificatios as well as some other proposals
and info that might be useful.


NOTE:  There was some RUBBISH posted a few eeks back regardign 
Technics SL1200 MK2 decks.  They are curently avaialble at Uncle
Ralphs.  They are asking $425 or some other ridiculous price.  I paid
$399 for my pair.  And quoted the prices of Good Guys, & Whole Earth
acces (on Steven's Creek) as my source.  The Whole Earth Access on
Stevens Creek in Sunnyvale/Cupertino/San Jose (I hate this tri-county
south bay shit), quoted me $399 for the one in the box, and $359 for
the COMPLETELY unused floor model.  I called Sam Ash in NJ/NY (I hate
that dual-state east coast shit), and they quoted me a price of $439.
 They would NOT go down to $399.

As far as I am concerned, the prices of late are a rip-off.  It was
not 3 months ago when you could get decks for $375 at most places, so
me thinks that due to the demand, Technics has either rasied the
price to it's distributors, or there is serious price fixing goin on.
 In any case, these decks are FAR from being extinct.  Good luck on
the best deal!!!

=== 
First off, I know nothing about ny particualr busts that mry or
may not ocu this weekend, so don't let that deter you from going out.
 What IS going on is an internal investigation of the SFPD.  The SF
DA is also involved.  It seems as though there is a crackdown on the
cops for accepting $$$ from clubowners.  It also seems that the
clubowners got together and decided to stop paying the cops.  The
cops are pissed off and have been taking retaliatory ,measures
against most of the clubs in the area who have stopped paying them
off.  Expect increased enforcement at legal venues as well as
increased crackdowns on "non-permitted" events.  The cops in this
city have long been accepting $$$ from various local industries.  Now
that they've been outed, they are pissed off, and are BOUND to take
it out on someone.  Word to the wise, when/if the cops come to any
event, exit quietly, and quickly.  Most of all, don't antagonize them
by asking them ANY questions.  If asked any questions, answer them in
a respectful manner, lest you get bludgeoned like Rodney King.  I
know it shouldn't be this way, but it's better than waiting for YEARS
to collect $$$ from a lawsuit due to excessive force.  Just leave the
friggin party, and keep your catcalls to a minimum.  This too will
pass.

Get active politically in the effort to allow partying by folx who
are 18+.  18+ people can vote, and you can make a difference.  Get
motivated to change the curent SF climate.  You can make a
difference. 
++++

Wicked/FMM:  With all due respect to the Wicked posse.

I hope that NONE of you were intimidated by the posts from Markie &
outasite.  Yes, they are part of the FM posse, but so what?  They do
not own the full Moon, and are not the first ones to start throwing
events based upon a lunar cycle.  There NEEDS to be more than 1 event
thrown during these cycles, and the FMM posse shold not be the ONLY
people doing such events.  Here's why...

-It's easier to track/bust 1 FMM event than 2. -The attendance at the
most recent FMM's have been realtively small.  Probably due to
organizational problems, as well as what may be a change in the way
FMM's are done.  Could also be a change in the philosophy of the
parties from larger events to smaller more intimate ones. 
-The current FMM is sketchy at best and starts too late for most to
attend.  Probably due to crowd control.  There should be a
posse/group of folx who can have it more regularly and more bust
free.  All that's really required is some research, some local PR,
some heart, some equipment, good standing, keeping promises, and a
bit of luck thrown in for ood measure.  IT CAN BE DONE BY THOSE WITH
THE HEART TO DO IT! 
-FMM by the Wicked posse is OLD.  Time for some
new blood and some new ideas.  Maybe even some new people spinning?
:)  Diversity is all good.  A new FMM party with a differnet posse
open up whole new realm of possibilities. 
-There are plenty of people on this list with connections that
would allow some to have an FMM on privte land.  Yes, this wod
require some planning, heart, promises, etc. but it could be done. 
Why not use such conections to further the goals/intentions of people
on the list?

Just some ideas...I for one would go to such an event (I used to HATE
outdoor parties), if properly planned and executed.  If they started
earlier and were closer to home there woulds be greater opprtunity
for me and others to go out.  People in SF and the BAY area are
waiting, TRUST THAT!

++++

Plug/plug:  I'm supposed to be spinning at an event this Saturday,
along with some other guests.  I do NOT want the event posted on the
list, so if interested, drop me a line and I'll fill you in on the
details.

Word of mouth is BEST!  Fuck info lines!!!!

SF UG '95 - Let the tribes begin to gather!

Have a safe & happy weekend, John

P.S.  Sorry for the typos, but SimpleText sux.

peace out.

Hi, all!

I think getting people to sign a waiver is an excellent idea!
However, I'm pretty sure that in legalese it doesn't go very far 
towards protecting the promoters/venue providers. I've read about this 
issue in regard to people/businesses that offer hiking tours. 
apparently, the loophole works something like this:

hiker/raver signs waiver, hiker/raver sustains some kind of 
injury while hiking on a professionally guided tour/raving 
at certain site, hiker/raver decides to sue guide service/promoter,
hiker/raver easily invalidates the legality of the waiver by 
citing a (any) lack of information, e.g. "I was not informed when 
signing the waiver that there was a steep, sedimentary incline on 
the northwest face of the mountain." 

Unfortunately, the argument of nondisclosure of ALL 
possible dangers allows hiker/raver to easily bypass the waiver 
with regard to taking legal action. Not a professional opinion;
just what I heard. 

your lady of consumer protection-

jocelyn
