>newsgroup or mailing list or similar forum.  David, what you persist in
>doing is an internet crime of sorts--your access can be suspended if
>someone complains to those at best.com.

I love the way you seem so sure about this. Firstly I am committing no
crime I can think of other than voicing an opinion that is not yours. I
doubt whether the folks at best.com would consider my talking about a topic
well within the gamut of the  Sfraves Constitution, a crime either. In fact
just recently someone made a posting to this effect. What I find curious is
how you got this "lynch mob" idea in a specifically communitarian forum?

>There are people both in and out of raving who would like to discuss
>those issues that interest you.  Create your own discussion group and
>then publicly invite them to join.
>
>        Sami

or perhaps you could develop a bit of tolerance for a thread on the
politics of raving (in fact there already is one) so then just hit the
delete key whenever you see me and a whole bunch of sfravers talking about
SAVING THE PLANET USING RAVE.  We can agree to disagree, I don't see why
you should force a split in the community, surely there might come a time
when you'll also find the need to talk about how we continue raving in an
emerging tropical climate (now that el nino has become a fixture in
california). Planetary change is occuring at a rapid rate, lets not go into
FUTURE SHOCK, without some good vibe antidote

- david dei

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 08:50:47 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9503301650.AA12362@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: week-long planet lovers
Cc: fraser@megatripolis.org, lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lee:
> Hopefully enlightenment at such a fundamental level, as vague and 
> abstract as that might be, will lead to tangible advancements in the
> overall human condition.

Fraser:
>...there's nothing in fact abstract about it at
> all, it's *fundmaental*, it's *real*, it's *accumulating* in a lot of
> people and *spreading* at warp speed.  
>...
>and even more importantly, nonstop shamanic drun dancing is one of the
>most ancient and powerful *technologies* for personal and social change. 
>...
>the changes RC brings about are so "fundamental" that the packaging is
>*relatively* unimportant

I appreciate your optimism.  Around here, we get excited when ravers can
remember to pick up their trash after an outdoor party.  Considering that
I can't even convince most of my raver friends that they should vote, I'm 
curious as to what signs of significant social change due to RC I should 
be on the lookout for.  Greater tolerance towards illegal immigrants?  
Widespread reduction in television ratings?   

Or are you taking the self-fulfilling prophecy approach?: Get enough people 
to believe that something great is happening, and it will.  If so, I wish 
you luck, because most ravers I know are just not that easily lead.

One advantage of coaching our dreams in terms of a very long time frame
is that we can focus on maintaining and improving the foundation on which
our dreams are based without becoming emotionally enslaved by grandiose 
expectations.  I've seen an awful lot of idealists, mesmerized by what 
raving seems to promise, get discouraged and leave the scene after a 
year or two.

My personal belief is that although humanity is still fucking up the planet 
in a major way, our collective consciousness has been gradually improving, 
and will continue to improve, not because of raving, but because Truth 
ultimately must prevail.  I see the long term establishment and spread of 
rave culture as part of this ongoing positive process.  Let's remember that 
the essence of Rhythm goes far beyond the state of our society.  When our 
bodies and mind become one with the beat, consciousness merges with the 
pulsating forces of the past/present/future Universe.  Planets may come and 
go, but Rhythm is eternal.

Lee

PS - This list is beginning to look like a left-wing version of
Cypherpunks -- a bunch of political discussions with little relevance
to the list's charter and everybody involved assuming that everyone
else shares the same values and opinions as them, which of course
isn't true. The main difference between the cpunx and the folks on
this list is that over _there_ they think that all cypherpunks are
cranky, conservative libertarians, and over _here_ you seem to think
that all SFravers are progressive activists.

points this time around are pretty much on the mark, _for his
politics_), but I think we should all remember that there are as many
definitions of raving and what "rave culture" is as there are ravers.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 30 11:56:52 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA27162; Thu, 30 Mar 1995 11:56:52 -0800
Received: from mothra.nts.uci.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA27155; Thu, 30 Mar 1995 11:56:49 -0800

Received: by mothra.nts.uci.edu id AA12608
  (5.65c/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Thu, 30 Mar 1995 11:56:44 -0800
From: "Dana WATANABE" <DWATANAB@uci.edu>
Message-Id: <199503301956.AA12608@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
Subject: race and raving and netting
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 11:56:44 PST
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

recently people were talking about what types of the lack
or lack of a lack of african american ravers and netters.

it was pointed out that because there are fewer
african americans online, there would be fewer
at sfraves based events.  it seems that some people
thought that that was an innaccurate statement.

Last year, i wrote my undergrad thesis on the topic of
women being on-line.  It went through a few metamorphesises 
to end up being a pile of bullshit.  Regardless, i spent
a lot of time thinking about the issue of access,
not just for women, but for everyone.  In a time where
being connected is becoming more crucial every day,
it seems to me that thinking about what types of access people
have is really important.

Online, the issue of race really doesn't matter.  People
don't inherently have a race attached to them online.  
They can have an ethnicity attached and, through that, race,
which does confuse the issue, but there the ethnicity 
holds a more important position.  I'm saying this because
it's important to realize that there is obviously not
just one culture in teh US and not just one culture online.
Some cultures in the US create an atmosphere where people
are likely to get connected and get online.  The amount
of cultures and sub-cultures and whatever else that 
are doing this is growing.   

I think it's important, though, to look at who is getting
connected, how and why.  For example, in the past two
years on campus, i have gone from having two or three 
friends connected to email to having all but a few having accounts.
So i tried to examine the reasons that i could tell
that many of them avoided getting it at first
and now seem to spend half their lives hanging out on the net.

Why?  Well because there are lots of groups of people
that don't get connected for reasons that have to do
with what group they belong to.  How many people
just dont get email because they have a phobia of dealing with computers?
What can be done to change this phobia into a tolerance or appreciation?

Gender, ethnicity and class have a hell of a lot of influence
on whether or not you are likely to be using computers.
I'm not saying that there aren't lower class latinas online,
there are, but i bet percentage wise there are a hell of
a lot less than middle class caucasian women.

So i think its a good idea to try to figure out why...

Why do i think that?  I dunno.. i think when it really comes down to it:
i have trouble having close relationships with people who
are not connected to the net.  There are a lot of people
who i think i miss out on having a close relationship with
(especially in the rave scene) because they arent net connected.
SO i want to figure out what I can do to help my friends get connected.
I don't think it's just giving them a computer and a modem
and netcom's fone number.

What does this have to do with raving?  Well the people who i want
to get connected are mostly ravers, so i think the question
to ask is how to make email a part of the rave experience 
in a way that makes people want to use it.

I mean a lot of people have found out about raving through the net.
but how many people have found out about the net through raving?

I bet in the SF area especially there are a bunch of people
who would NOT be online if it werent for sfraves.
So how can this be more incorporated to build a stronger
or at least more connected community?

You could also take this idea into figuring out how to get
more people from groups like lower class anyone,
or african americans or latino/as or whatevers to get into email
and the scene at the same time..

again... just some thoughts.

 ,
dana
 
"I knew my life was complete when i found out
that a piece of furniture was named after me."
	- me

Tony wrote:

>I sank my teeth into that drug we call music, I thought so hard of you 
>that I could fairly see you dancing with me.  Let me point out again I was 
>not on hallucinogens, but just really really happy to take 45 minutes to 
>dance and sing and look at the stars and think about all the friends and 
>family I've encountered in the past year.  My feeling of being lonely was 
>assuaged, my feet were moving fast, the stars were shining, I had this big 
>fucking grin on my face and wonderful thoughts of you in my head,  and 
>when it was all over I sat down near the fire and grinned like lovers that 
>had just run off and had a quickie without anyone knowing.

This reminds me of the best rave I was at:  by myself at the top of Half 
Dome (Yosemite NP).  I had been backpacking in the backcountry and was on 
my way out.  I camped at the base of half dome (just before the steps).  
Stupid me had decided to go camping during the one of the moster storms of 
january.  It had been raing/snowing/sleeting/lightning for the last three 
days and had cleared about 1 hour earlier.  Made dinner and noticed that 
the sky had cleared.  I climbed up half dome (made it to the top at about 
11pm).  I had the world to myself.  The storm was running out to the east. 
I was small in the scheme of things, yet I ruled the earth.

Mother Nature provided the setting: lights/effects by Mr. Lightning to the 
east, sound/DJ by various creatures and thunder provided the beat.  I think 
this has been the first and only time I have been musically inclined (I 
have zero musical talent).  The music building in my head was nothing I had 
heard before.  The beat and energy lifted me like nothing I had felt 
before.  I wish I could read music because I might have been able to write 
parts of it down but alas, it is lost.  I spent three hours dancing by 
myself on the top of the world totally free.  Nothing has ever brought me 
that close to nirvana.

>The point of this story is this:  The scene is what *YOU* make it.  
>Someone will have the best time of their life at the rave you had the 
>worst; and vice versa.

I totally agree.  Having just moved out here only a few months ago, I 
definetly have my opinion about what the scene should be.  But that does 
not make the scene here any better or worse than anywhere else.  If you 
don't like it, move or try and change it, but don't just criticize it.  Be 
constructive and make a difference.  There are no absolutes in this world 
just varying degrees of gray.

>And it's about being alone under the desert stars and having the littlest 
>rave possible -- A rave of one with the love and spirit of one thousand. 
>Thank you for sharing it with me; I could hardly wait to tell you about 
>it.

It is an amazing experience to be alone and humbled and *ALIVE* is nature 
feeling it energy coursing through you.  <the chills set in as think about 
it>

On another note:
Seeing as I am new up here, what is the best way to get dialed into things 
in this town <places to get flyers, phone trees, mailing lists, etc>?  I 
did finally manage to find this list through pure luck.  :-)  

lot's o' love!
mike

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 30 12:39:50 1995

From: robj@netcom.com (Rob Jellinghaus)
Message-Id: <199503302037.MAA01497@netcom8.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Community, "splitting up", online raveness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think splinter mailing lists from sf-raves are a fine idea.
sfraves-announce, sfraves-activism, sfraves-music, sfraves-planning?
All online groups that grow beyond a certain size start experiencing
flamage and disagreement about what is/isn't appropriate and what the
topic is supposed to be, especially when it's heartfelt stuff like
religion, politics, sex, and music--definite ingredients here on
sfraves.

Splitting up into many lists isn't splitting "the community"--it's
letting the community find its own level.  (Especially here, where our
roots 'n' origins are in our real-life, real rhythm, ravely
gatherings, not which email group we read.)

Many will read more than one list, or use mail tools to collect
mail so they can read it later.  Eventually, I think our whole
notion of "subject" and "topic" will change.  This email stuff is
just the beginning....

Rob

From: litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org (Monica and Tom)
Subject: politics and raving
To: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:39:55 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9503291620.AA25565@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM> from "Lee Fogel" at Mar 29, 95 08:20:48 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2753      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lee Fogel wrote:
> 
> While I'm all in favor of people getting involved with trying to influence 
> the system itself, I see the role of raving mainly as a promoter of
> individual mental and spiritual health.  If Rave(tm) becomes a 
> sociopolitical movement engaging itself with the world's obvious problems, 
> then it will become part of the current system which is structured to 
> incorporate and absorb such forces, no matter how progressive or 
> revolutionary they may seem.

i really have to disagree.  first, raving can be seen as a promoter of 
COLLECTIVE mental and spiritual health, which is in itself political, 
oppositional to a system based on greed and consumption and with no real 
understanding of "health."  further, i see raves as TAZs (Temporary 
Autonomous Zones), where we can practice living as if we are free.  
i see freedom (the anarchist revolution big techno potluck shindig!) as a 
PROCESS, 
again, we learn to live and take care of ourselves as if we are free, in 
a world we imagine (free of sexism, racism, heterosexism ... all forms of 
authoritarian repression).  when we organize parties collectively we 
learn how work can be done without hierarchies.  

in addition, gathering together to create healthy communities in a culture 
that seeks to divide us, or 
give us a false sense of community based on mtv and consumption, is a 
radical and political act.  creating art and play outside of the 
marketplace (renegades and benefits) is a radical and poltical act.  

further, raves can be a place where we share information - on health, 
spirituality, political and social movements and ideas ...  and of course 
we can fundraise, which is CLEARLY and example of "rave...engaging itself 
with the world's most obvious problems."  

every time i rave, i voice my protest against "the system" (who says 
protests have to be covered by the mass media-demons?)  every minute i 
spend organizing parties with a purpose is my protest against a system 
that sees play either as superfluous, or as a "leisure-time hobby."  NO - 
raving, right now, gives me LIFE.  work just pays the rent and puts 
food on the table (and tries to suck all my life-energy out of me - sigh.)

of course, i'll continue to do the "regular" kind of political work 
(voting, marching, letter-writing...)...NOT because i believe this is the 
way to freedom, but because we'll get trampled all over if we don't!  

so there's my rant for the day.  and since we've been making book 
recommendations lately, i have to add Hakim Bey's TAZ and IMMEDIATISM (if 
you try to ignore his anti-abortion gibberish in TAZ).  as well as 
Starhawk's TRUTH OR DARE.  


take care everyone,
monicat
"We will build the new society in the shell of the old" - IWW

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 30 12:57:01 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id MAA01727; Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:57:01 -0800
Received: from ix4.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA01717; Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:56:58 -0800

	id MAA16300; Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:53:45 -0800

well, it's not a rave, but it's really goofy fun...

yes, the annual st. stupid's day parade is upon us again!  each year on 
april 1, revelers honor st. stupid by acting, well, stupid in a parade 
downtown.  this year it starts at 1:00 at the transamerica building.  
dress stupidly and be prepared to be, well, stupid.

monicat

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: This Week's SFR Calendar
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 14:09:50 PST

Precedence: bulk


The SFRaves Calendar is now accessible on the Web and via ftp!  This
means you can get the most up-to-date calendar I have anytime during
the week, instead of waiting till Thursdays.  I still have to work on
cleaning up the formatting (I need to find a way to automatically have
the line breaks preserved), straighten out some problems with trying
to move info back and forth between two accounts (right now I can't
view the html document at the same geographic place I edit it), and
fixing some of the links.  Let me know if you have any other
suggestions.

To access the calendar, from http://hyperreal.com/, you can click on
"Regional mailing list archives", then "San Franciscan Raves", then
"calendar"; or you can go directly to 
http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html.  The ftp calendar is
hyperreal.com:/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.txt.  The SF Area Phone list
is also available there.  Finally, please send updates to
dhchung@hyperreal.com now.

Anyway, this weekend looks huge.  I don't think I need to give you any
recommendations, since I don't think you can go wrong with this selection.
Let's all meet up at Sunset on Sunday though :)

    ----------------------

(WWW: http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html)

Subject: Re: One Ravers Delight (long, personal, stick with it)

On Tue, 28 Mar 1995, Tony Rotundo wrote:

> 
> 
> The point of this story is this:  The scene is what *YOU* make it.  Someone
> will have the best time of their life at the rave you had the worst; and
> vice versa.  People may come into our scene and tell us that it's wrong, or
> that it can be done better, or that it can be an enormous global movement.
> Well, I for one don't know if I want that, because before it gets that far
> it will be turned into a fucking circus, a marketing wet dream -- a lost
> dream.  This isn't about getting bigger in attendance, it's about getting
> bigger within yourself.
> 
> All kinds of people will sniff at our scene, but only those that are honest
> about why they are there will stay long enough to make an impact.  Only
> those that get the shiver of chills when they walk down the stairs at some
> new venue and first hear the thump, thump, thump...and turn to the stranger
> with a beaming face next to them and grab their hand and yell gleefully
> "This is going to be a great party!!" will care to stay on board.  You
> can't dish out the kind of love we are trying to spread with a firehose, it
> must be hand fed one drop at a time.  I say we do not attempt to lambaste
> the people with our movement, but let them discover individually the
> treasure we have hidden and that we pull out every weekend for heat, and
> love, and life.  It's not about who's doing it better, nor who's doing it
> bigger, but that we are doing it at all.
> 
> And it's about being alone under the desert stars and having the littlest
> rave possible -- A rave of one with the love and spirit of one thousand.
> Thank you for sharing it with me; I could hardly wait to tell you about it.
> 
> Tony
> 
> P.S.  My suggestion for the name of our summer of raving?  I like:  Nothing
> Mediaworthy to See Here.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 

I haven't checked my mail in a few days so I just got around to reading
Tony's post.  I think Tony has summed up exactly how I feel about our
scene and what it means to be a part of it.  This is the kind of positive
energy post that I first subscribed to this list for.  The bickering that
has gone on over the last week made me wonder what was happening to the
scene, Tony's post reminded me that there are still a lot of people out
there with the positive vibe that keeps me going out to parties.

Thanks & Keep Smilin'

Andrew

> 
> okay, i know i'm going to feel like a jerk for asking, but... to 
> those who have been so angrily harshing on our fine nation, if you hate 
> the states so much, why don't you consider moving canada or mexico, or 
> maybe clear off the continent, even?
> 
> 
>                                             curiously,
>                                                sig

well, maybe i'm trying to resist and agitate in the belly of the beast.
maybe i was born here so why the fuck should i have to leave?
maybe i'd like to move off the continent, at least for a while, but i 
don't have a european or other passport or much money.
maybe there's things i like about the u.s. 
maybe there's no anarchist land i can run to.

monicat

# point taken- at least upon arresting people police are supposed to 
# read you your rights so that you can be "aware" that you may be 
# waiving them- too bad this isn't the case before arrest, eh? 

yeah, but the real problem is that police in this line of work are true
experts at one thing -- manipulating people -- especially people who
don't understand what's going on, don't know the process, don't
understand what is a formality and what to be concerned about, 
and are scared shitless.  This is where lawyers understand the games.

The police inspectors well practiced at this, and suckered me rather
easily.  They flattered me and said they knew I understood all of this,
and i know this was just a formality, and I just needed to sign here.

At this point, they could have told the judge (lied to him) that I had
confessed to anything they wanted to say, and it would have worked,
because I had waived my rights, basically giving them permission to
do it.



happiness, strick



( carboning the list, because it just can't be said often enuf. 
  even when you know your rights, you still need to know all
  the ways you'll be suckered.  until it really happens to you
  once, you don't know what it's like, and it's easy to get
  arrogant.  that's why the military does repeated training for 
  handling interrogations.  my uncle, a colonel in air force,
  says he flunked his first few interrogations, when he was
  being trained.

  and thanks to whoever (was it amoeba?) posted the other 
  info a week or two ago, about handling police at parties --
  that was useful!
)

to be concerned about this - it doesn't have anything to do with the charter
of the list.  The same holds for UK music vs. US music, where to buy the best
drugs, etc etc.  I will remove people who post excessive amounts of off-topic
messages - it is a privilege to be here and use Hyperreal's CPU and
bandwidth, not a right, and just because I'm very lassaiz-faire about my
mailing list moderation does not mean I won't take action when needed.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 10:15:22 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
To: ameba@netcom.com, "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Liability Insurance (was our forest...)

     Hi all!  This is my first post to the group after lurking on and off 
     for quite a while. Guess I finally have something relevant to say in 
     response to Niels' great idea on a liability waiver.
     
     While in theory people should take responsibility for theirselves, the 
     reality is that greed often gets in the way.  If someone gets hurt and 
     their parent or friend realizes that they can take advantage of the 
     situation, lawsuits are filed.  
     
     I'm part of a dance collective that hosts smoke-free, alcohol-free 
     dance jams as well as drum and dance weekends.  We have people sign 
     liability waivers _but_ there's a few other things we do to cover 
     ourselves since the waiver doesn't carry much weight in court.
     
     1)  If a person is under 18  (we have all age events), the parent has 
     to sign for them.
     
     2)  We ensure the locale carries site insurance (no renegade stuff for 
     planned events).
     
     Having a person sign a waiver is a reminder for them to be responsible 
     more than avoiding lawsuits for our group.  We've looked into 
     liability insurance and one way to go around it is to have someone 
     teach a movement class to cover an event. (I carry personal liability 
     insurance for teaching dance classes and teach a contact improv class 
     prior to a dance jam.) 
     
     For one or two-day events, insurance brokers are not in abundance but 
     they are out there since many cities require you take out a policy if 
     you host an event when renting their sites.  I'm sure other promoters 
     can fill you in on the details.
     
     As I write this, questions start to come up for me about "rave 
     culture" and responsibility.  There's a happy medium but do we really 
     want a signed list of attendees on a waiver?  Personally, I don't 
     think it's a problem, but what if a rave gets busted and the list gets 
     confiscated?  There's not alot of incrimination but anonymity (sp?) is 
     lost and it reminds me of big brother.
     
     I'd like to discuss this with other interested parties sometime.  I'd 
     also like to discuss (off-line) a ravish-related _but_ different item:
     
     A promoter friend and I are exploring ways to integrate the fine arts, 
     performing arts, and holistic arts into an acceptable form of 
     celebration and ritual.  Kinda ravey but not, kinda lollapollaza but 
     not, kinda Megatripolis but not.  He's done some stuff in Ireland and 
     I've done some work here and now we're at a point of sharing ideas and 
     creating something viable.  If you're interested in exploring this 
     with us, let me know.  I can expand on some of what we envision, but I 
     don't want to waste bandwidth so e-mail or call me if you're 
     interested.   
     
     I'm so glad I finally have a reason to post.  I've been wanting to 
     meet y'all for awhile.  I'm looking forward to meeting sfravers this 
     weekend.  After I figure out what I'm wearing and where I'll be, I'll 
     let you know.
     
     Hugs and smiles,
     Diane
     
     H 415/322-6794
     W 415/813-7457
     

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: our forest-our land-our earth

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 07:04:13 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@geko.com.au (John Draper)
Subject: Raving in Sydney

  Greetings all you SFRavers back home...  I finally got a SLIP connection
and have Netscape running.    WOW!  What a difference over lynx...

  Anyway,  last weekend I went to my first Totem event called Pyramedia,
very conveniently located 100 feet from where I live here in Kings Cross.

  A little about Kings Cross...  I would have to call this section of
Sydney the most interesting place I've ever lived.   My front door leads
right onto the main drag..  where there are tons is strip joints,  flashey
disco's,  and hundreds of international restaurants all within a short
walking distance from my front door.

  This place stays awake 24 hours a day...  Bars and nightlubs are also
open 24 hours a day.   Drinking age is 18 yrs old,  and very few venues
even bother to check ID's.    About the only thing I don't like are the
street whores who get really agressive,  and literally grab your arm and
say "Want to have a good time?".

  Pretty soon,   I plan on taking a longer trek across Australia,  and
plan on visiting Darwyn,   Byron Bay,   and possibly Perth and Alice
Springs,  which means I will be missing some raves...  Arghhh!!!

  As I had mentioned,   raves are mainstream here,   and almost every
week,  they have what AusRaver OLD SCHOOL'ers call "Kiddie raves",  geared
mostly towards the very young crowd,  and feature mostly hard core,  or
Happy Hard core.

  This last weekends Pyramedia by Totum featured mostly German Hard
trance,  and I really went off.    This coming weekend is another
Sabatage,   which I'm probably going to make,   rather then go to
a kiddie rave called Smerf Village II.   Gack,  that smerf village
flyer is HUGE,   a big fat glossy 5 pager flyer.    I intend to
collect as many rave flyers as I can to bring back and show all
of you,   as well as trying to bring back some vinyl,  CD's and DAT's

  I'm also writing my OWN techno tune,  and will be bringing that
back with me as well.   Yesterday,  I layed down the drums,   Hi Hats,
and Base line for the first segment of my techno tune,   which is
at 150 BPM's.    Tommorrow,   I intend to overlay more segments,
using an Atari computer,  driving a host of MIDI devices,   having
a ball creating my own music.

  Here in Sydney,  there is a collective group of about 10 - 20 bands
called the 'Clan Analogue" who gather each week at the Bently Bar,
every Wednesday,  and DJ as well as have live performances.

 Although,  we are heading towards our winter down here,  the weather
here has been about 78 degrees high,  and 67 degrees low,   with sunney
skies.

  Today,  I had to go to Geko,   my local internet provider,   to get
SLIP installed on my laptop,  and had to take the ferry.    WOW!   What
a amazing transpo system they have here.    These ferrys are double hull
boats,  and accellerate with amazing speed and manouvering abilities.

  Sydney is a bery huge city of 5 million people,  and dispite the
massive population,   has little or no air and water pollution.   It has
many bays,  and water inlets,   and a very efficient ferry system.

  Today,  my ferry ride brought me right next to Sydneys modern Opra
theator.

  Anyway,   I hope you all are keeping the scene alive,  as I've been
following the SF rave scene very closly from here,   reading all of the
SFRave mail,  as well as the AusRave mail.    With Eudora,  which I
finally got running,   I can filter the mail into seperate files,  and
keep track much more easily.    Not only that,   but I've been Webbing
into the local SJ Mercury news,   catching up on all the local news,
as if I've never left.

  Here in Australia,  the Internet is now MAINSTREAM in such a way,
that "triple-M" the local Rock station uses CU-SeeMe and has listeners
plug in and send their pictures over the internet.   All radio call-ins
are now over internet,  but the real problem is their back bone data
bandwidths just cannot handle such a massive amount of traffic.

  There is just ONE 25 Megabit link between Australia and the USA,
which just isn't cutting it as far as bandwidth is concerned.   There is
NO publically available ISDN,   but in other ways,   Australia is FAR
AHEAD of the USA in certain technologies,  and lax laws.

  Anyway,  soon I'll be starting my trek across this huge vast land mass,
populated by only 20 million people.   I mean it's really amazing,  once
you get away from the coast how vast and empty the land areas are.

  In the afternoons,  the sun is so fierce and gnarley here,  that you
cannot stay out in the sun without sun block,   due in part because of
the lack of ozone protection.

  All the forces here are opposite to what I'm used to....  The sun goes
around the sky sorta backwards,   the moon is upside down,   people drive
on the LEFT side of the road,  and water goes down the drain in the opposite
direction.   So,  my energy levels are balancing out...   causing a really
strange realization of how important it is to be balanced,  and how much
the forces play a part in my general life in the USA.

   My energy level I think has also increased,   as I'm still religiously
doing my energy blockage removal,   and people here are so amazed at how
old I am,  and still out there groovin with such high energy.   I think these
opposite forces I'm experiencing is sort of unwinding me or making my
whole psyche sorta unravel.

   Anyway,   As I read SFRaves,  I'm getting the impression that all of
you fine folks north of the Equator are keeping the scene alive,  and
now that I've been here exactly a month,   I'm fitting in here quite
well,   being very independent from my AusRave friends,   and getting
around like a local.    I'm even learning a lot of AusSpeak...  :-)

   So,  please keep your promise and keep the scene alive up there,
just like I'm doing down here....    I miss ya all....  But I'll be
back in 2 more months....

Cheers - And keep the scene alive...
Crunchman from Down unda...

On Thu, 30 Mar 1995, David Dei wrote:
> PS So how do we save these Redwoods, as well as the Children, and a whole
> host of things like our freedom to dance wherever the whim takes us? This
> is what I hope sfravers will want to talk about and then when all the
> talking is done, dance onwards into action.

But is this really appropriate for an online format with 300+ users?  As 
a collective that throws low cost parties the Cloud Factory has trouble 
working things out in person with ten people.  The scope of the ideas you 
are talking about do not necessarily present themselves as easily as you 
think they do.  as suggested before there need be a mailing list that is 
open for those interested to discuss these things, most on this list I 
feel didn't join it to save the world per se.  I personally do things in 
my life to work on it but did not join this forum to waste my day reading 
about thoughts...posts like monicats on the other hand are very useful, 
they contain:

1. pertinent info
2. contact info
3. not a lot of bullshit opinion on the topic
4. they end after the first message so that those who feel compelled to 
act can do so on their own time.

love scott

Ah, mijos, a week of library work, as well as licking my wounds as I
finally finalized a dead end relationship.And what have i learned?

                  Basically, the reason why I rave: Friends
                 (and much better music than the palladium:)

You keep me coming back, you make my belly fill with butterflies when I
hear the thump-thump and turn and smile and meet new people who smile back.
When someone cares when I am down, and someone who will drag their problems
into my world for help, and then laugh at them with me another day.

A lot of you  got me through this last one, and it's been a long, hard
time. And if this term paper gets done, then I'll return all those hugs I
received, somewhere, sometime, this weekend. Thanks, folks, I needed that!

Lotsa love,

At  3:53 PM 30/3/95 -0800, Brian Behlendorf wrote:
>On Wed, 29 Mar 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:
>> David Dei, dear heart, what has possessed you to inflict yet another
>> interesting, important but essentially off-subject topic on sfraves?
>
>Phred is right.  This is NOT appropriate to this forum, important as it may
>be.  I don't care if you think that someone who calls themselves a raver has
>to be concerned about this - it doesn't have anything to do with the charter
>of the list.  The same holds for UK music vs. US music, where to buy the best
>drugs, etc etc.  I will remove people who post excessive amounts of off-topic
>messages - it is a privilege to be here and use Hyperreal's CPU and
>bandwidth, not a right, and just because I'm very lassaiz-faire about my
>mailing list moderation does not mean I won't take action when needed.
>
>        Brian

Brian, with all due respect. Is this list a dictatorship or a democracy? If
its a democracy in any way, then perhaps you might like to poll sfravers
about exactly what it is they would like to see carried, in way of an
effort to maintain the communal aspect of this list. So far, although there
might be a lot of loud and upset voices in the crowd, I still see messages
of support , usually from the less vocal posters. And it would be a shame
to see real debate on issues affecting us all - even a thread which you
have decided is off-topic namely Raving the Planet Love, to disappear
because of a few careless words.

I hope you see my point and not my religion.

David Dei.

So far we got one vote for SFravers being allowed to discuss Local Raving
in a broader Planetary Context with three against and it looks like the
planet might lose the vote!  Do we get to dance on the grass or not?  I'm
quite prepared  for a narrow cast party-only rave list - as invisaged by
Brian, but somehow I sense that not all SFravers agree with this. Theres
been quite a bit of info on the Redwoods, some Earth First! info, etc etc
posted to this list over the last week. Lets at least know where we ravers
stand.

- david dei

support your planet and get your local reps to pressure Clinton to ratify
the Treaty and stop the El Nino Effect that Dumped water on Cali last
week..

As Brian B. has pointed out in the past, this is a very high volume 
mailing list, and while off topic social issues might be tangentially
related to the purposes of this list, they are not going to be 
solved here. If you want to thrash some issue out, invite others on 
this list to take it to private email.  


Bob H.

On Thu, 30 Mar 1995, David Dei wrote:

> So far we got one vote for SFravers being allowed to discuss Local Raving
> in a broader Planetary Context with three against and it looks like the
> planet might lose the vote!  

Oh please! The theatrics are quite uneccessary. The point you seem to 
missing is that no one is saying that these matters are unimportant. NO ONE.

The point is that there are more appropriate places to discuss these 
issues. That is one of the reasons for USENET. Persons with interests in 
SPECIFIC areas can subscribe to a newsgroup to discuss SPECIFIC issues 
pertaining to the subject of the newsgroup. Otherwise, you end up with a 
quagmire of newsgroup-unrelated threads, which is what SFraves seems to 
have been degenerating into (*IMHO*) While I personally believe your 
intentions to be heart-felt and well-intentioned, it does not alter the 
fact that the posts have little to do with the purpose of SfRaves. 
It is, and has always been, up to the discretion of the moderator of any 
group(USENET or listserver in our case) the scope of the discussion
in a particular newsgroup.
 
 The scope in the case of SfRaves is outlined clearly in the welcoming 
message. If you have any questions about appropriate posting, please read 
ANY basic net-etiquite guide. 
  
The planet is not "losing" if people choose not to support your 
newsgroup-unrelated postings here. Your energy can be better and more 
effectively spent in areas or newsgroups that have relevance to your 
postings. 

For example: Personally, I do care about the Earth, but think 
the Earth Firsters go too far in certain respects. Is this subject worth 
discussing? Of course. Is this the proper forum, according to the intent 
of this group as outlined by Brian? NO.

                                                Black Adder

ask yourself:  why do so many really good people get so involved in what 
is often a rip-off, never happens kind of situation and with less "show" 
than the smallest national rock&roll band could muster?  WHY??  unless 
you think it's just sily - which you obviously don't - then it *must* be 
deep, fundamental and life-changing.  and if it *is* then it *must* be one 
of the most socially relevant forces in our culture and on our planet 
today.  and I'm tired of hearing about "new Ravers" not clearing up 
afterwards (even if I get tired of clearing up after 'em).  of course they 
don"t!  that's *exactly* why RC must spread. RC *changes* people.

but I don't think anyone's disagreeing, are they?  does anyone involved 
say it's not fundamental and life-changing? 
or, more divisive, who takes the position that we *don't* want RC to 
spread?  that, as I'd caricature such a position (and I've encountered it 
hundreds of times in the old festival scene in the UK over the decades) 
they'd rather have an exclusive little scene as the planet disappears 
futher down the plughole?
fraser

On Thu, 30 Mar 1995, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Lee:
> > Hopefully enlightenment at such a fundamental level, as vague and 
> > abstract as that might be, will lead to tangible advancements in the
> > overall human condition.
> 
> Fraser:
> >...there's nothing in fact abstract about it at
> > all, it's *fundmaental*, it's *real*, it's *accumulating* in a lot of
> > people and *spreading* at warp speed.  
> >...
> >and even more importantly, nonstop shamanic drun dancing is one of the
> >most ancient and powerful *technologies* for personal and social change. 
> >...
> >the changes RC brings about are so "fundamental" that the packaging is
> >*relatively* unimportant
> 
> I appreciate your optimism.  Around here, we get excited when ravers can
> remember to pick up their trash after an outdoor party.  Considering that
> I can't even convince most of my raver friends that they should vote, I'm 
> curious as to what signs of significant social change due to RC I should 
> be on the lookout for.  Greater tolerance towards illegal immigrants?  
> Widespread reduction in television ratings?   
> 
> Or are you taking the self-fulfilling prophecy approach?: Get enough people 
> to believe that something great is happening, and it will.  If so, I wish 
> you luck, because most ravers I know are just not that easily lead.
> 
> One advantage of coaching our dreams in terms of a very long time frame
> is that we can focus on maintaining and improving the foundation on which
> our dreams are based without becoming emotionally enslaved by grandiose 
> expectations.  I've seen an awful lot of idealists, mesmerized by what 
> raving seems to promise, get discouraged and leave the scene after a 
> year or two.
> 
> My personal belief is that although humanity is still fucking up the planet 
> in a major way, our collective consciousness has been gradually improving, 
> and will continue to improve, not because of raving, but because Truth 
> ultimately must prevail.  I see the long term establishment and spread of 
> rave culture as part of this ongoing positive process.  Let's remember that 
> the essence of Rhythm goes far beyond the state of our society.  When our 
> bodies and mind become one with the beat, consciousness merges with the 
> pulsating forces of the past/present/future Universe.  Planets may come and 
> go, but Rhythm is eternal.
> 
> Lee
> ____________________________________________________________________________
> lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> 
> 
> 
>

	I think it's time that we all start respecting our diifferences and

	In massage school and while learning yoga, individually was stress
as being scared, it is what we are, wonderfully unique; there is no else
like you or me, we are all masterpieces in our own rights. I stronly
encouage you to all see that in yourselfs, love it, and you will be able
to love, except, and at least tolerate almost anyone, and know their all a
necessary part of the plan. 	

	When I excepted that I was a totally unique person; a masterpiece,
I was able to see it in others, almost anyone. If your don't see that in
yourself, I would like to make two suggestions, go to an art mus-se-em and
look at objects that are one of a kind(that both disgust you & bring you
joy), and sometime pick up a lite Anatomy & Phislogy book, read it, and
wonder, at what you are. 

	Our country was based on Freedom of Speach and it must apply to all.
I forget what Supreme Court Justice said that freedom speach stops at 
yelling fire in a dark crowded movie theater, I don't think thats 
happening here. 

	I forget what American Revolutionary fiqure said "Beware the
tear-ren-e of the Majority." Many came here to San Francisco, because we
were consider different and either not welcomed, or longed for other kind
people. 

	It really saddens me to see us, a very connected group of kind 
people, fighting amonst ourselves. But another part of see the conflict 
as change, and I do believe for the most part change is necessary for the 
survival of all things. But I know we all have enough positivity in us to 
acomplish this change in a respectful and affirming manner.

	I'm not going to tell my brothers and sisters to stop, but I will
ask however, do you feel good, about what you are doing? I hope the answer
brings some awareness into your lifes, thanks :)

to be true, which is why the check is in yer mouth and I promise not to
come in the mail!

I've signed many a liability waiver myself, and have bought many a
ticket that includes an explicit waiver. That's where the idea
sprung.... as to whether it's legally valid, that's just a matter of
who can come up with the higher-priced armani-clad lawyer and pay off
teams of "experts" to lie for your side in court, just enough to
convince a jury of idiots too losing to find a way out of jury duty...
(ahem.... :-) ) This ain't democracy, ya know, it's a moneyocracy....

me while raving... I guess I'm just pining for that flaming chalice of
KGB while I'm still away from home...

things about this party:
	First, if your coming, please respect the location that we are 
using. This means don't tear up the furniture, NO TAGGING, etc. Bring 
whatever you want to, as long as it makes you happy! There will be a map 
point to avoid overcrowding. We ask that you call the voice mail @ 6pm 
and get the directions to the map point. 408.486.9591 For those of you 
coming from the north bay, the map point will be in Santa Cruz. Now 
comes the tricky part! You must go to the map point and get an 
invitation, then bring it with you to the party. You won't be able to 
enter without a invitation. We are making a limited amount of tickets so 
get there early to ensure you get in. Also the fist 50 people get in for 
half price($5). Please don't come to the map point before we open it up, 
and that will be @ 7:30 pm.
	Also, when you do show up please realize that the location does 
have neighbors so please, please be very quiet as you park and walk to 
the location!!!! You can make all the noise in the world once inside, 
thanx!!!!!!:)

You guys made it look great!!!!!!!

party as soon as Harmony is done and can move the system. (5 am.ish)

come, come with tons of love, smiles, hugs, and energy to dance your 
asses off!!!!!!!!!!  408.486.9591

I am not sure if you all remember that SFRaves is not a place for non-rave related
mail, personal point and counterpoint posts (people can only take so much of a thread),
and flames.... I hope you realise that at this rate maybe sfraves should be
separated into three categories, calendar only, announcements/other rave realted
reviews, and rave politics. But I doubt that will ever happen. Even though sfravers talk 
about various things that they counters while raving whether it has to do with
guns, racism, cops, etc., just remember that there are other people out there who are
really not interested in a deep discussion on those issues. That is why there are
other newsgroups, mailing lists, and web sites. Make a list about sites with the
related topics, post about it, meet at a place or meet on vrave or start a small alias 
mailing list about it. I suggest people read the following below carefully. A long
time ago, sfraves got so out of hand, that Brian turned off the list for a week. 
So think before you hit that "r" key too soon. 

Cindy
______________________________________________________________________________________

				  
			
Some guidelines for posting to SFRaves.  Print this out and tape it to your computer for
handy reference.  This list will be given to all new members from now on.  

1) First realize that

        a) SFRaves is a large mailing list. 

        b) The volume is already quite high. 

        c) For every editorial or opinion there are hundreds of
           possible replies. 

        d) Topics of world import such as feminism and race relations
           will *always* be with us, at least for the current generation,
           and while discussion about them is important the issues *won't*
           be resolved by just talking about them here on the list.  They
           are appropriate here as long as they aren't more appropriate
           in soc.feminism, etc. 

        e) Ego has NO PLACE on the mailing list. 

        f) Even with a high signal-to-noise ratio, a high volume means more
           people skim articles than actually read them.  This is a bad thing.  
  
2) Now for the general rules: 
        
        a) NO PERSONAL ATTACKS - even if someone is being a complete
           jerk and everyone agrees, please refrain from flaming him/her
           in public.  Send him/her all the private email you want.  If
           they flame you first, be the wise one and take the argument
           off the list.  If he/she is truely being a jerk everyone knows
           it anyways.  The difference between a well-reasoned argument
           and a personal flame should be quite clear. 
        
        b) Try and set an upper limit to your number of posts to 2 a day. 
           Making more is fine, but as you're typing your third make *sure*
           it's something that's worth the time of the 250 people you are
           sending it to. 
        
        c) BREVITY IS THE SOUL OF WIT.  Paragraphs prove you have a point. 
        
        d) Ranting is the opposite of raving (thanks to rth@netcom.com for
           reminding us)
        
        e) Don't reply to a post until you have read your entire mail
           queue and made sure no one else has replied exactly what you
           would say. 
        
        f) Refrain from making "me too" posts, where you simply add "I agree" 
           to the bottom of a quoted message. 
        
        g) If you reply to a post someone makes, READ EVERY WORD THEY SAY
           CAREFULLY, and in the absence of facial and hand gestures interpret
           their comments in the best possible light.  It's very hard for the
           "TV" generation (which we are whther you own a TV or not) to know
           how to communicate without visual cues.  Make sure you understand
           what the other person is saying. 
        
        h) If a conversation turns into a particulary heated argument, wait
           at least an hour before making your reply, to allow you to see
           what they are saying in the absence of a testosterone rush. 
        
        i) Be SURE of what you are saying when you say it.  Proofread your
           comments several times.  Make sure your use of certain words is
           the generally accepted use by the community at large, not what
           *you* think that usage should implicate.  


We are at the brink of something BIG here, and SFRaves can be a part of it.  But only if 
we keep ourselves as high quality as we've been in the past, and these guidelines are a 
part of it.  Anyone who's spent a good deal of time on the net knows these as part of an 
unwritten policy, but they bear repeated for those who are new.  

The Conciousness Revolution has begun. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~sin-wave~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
kawakami@usfca.edu  silent@mobius.usfca.edu   cindy@hyperreal.com   cindy@organic.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~infrasonic~~~~~~~~~~~~audible~~~~~~~~~~~~~ultrasonic~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
                             http://hyperreal.com/~cindy

Hi ya'll :)


Some thoughts...

A list is not a democracy. Someone puts up hard earned cash and
a lot of work to get/maintain a list. Just because one subscribes to 
a list does not mean that one has any rights at all. The use of a list 
is a privelege. Not a right. 

The *best* that one can expect from a list administrator/owner is a 
benevolent dictatorship. 

I believe that this list allows all of us *off topic* subjects all
the time. The objection I hear and share is the constant badgering 
by those with agendae delivering sermons on the same topics.  

Tell me once. I will take your point into consideration.
Tell me twice. I will become irritated.
Tell me thrice and I will associate your cause with your obnoxious
behaviour. That will not win your cause support. 


hugz

brian

> Well... count this as a vote FOR interesting off-topic postings & a big
> fat vote against people who selectively flame someone for who he is
> instead of what it is he's posting. 

If that's really happening, that is totally lame.  but _i_ don't see that
(i could just be blind) i see some people getting shit
for trying to take over someone else's list and shape it into what they want

> It's fucking bullshit, if one of the
> more established people posted some enviornmental stuff (and there's been
> *alot* of that over the years) there's no way he'd get flamed, especialy
> by the list administrator. 			~~~~

*ahem* :)

> Face it most stuff is gonna be considered
> off-topic by somebody. While I may disagree strongly with David's
> approach, there's no reason to selectively enforce a very hazy rule on
> him, that other people break just as much.

People shouldn't make/enforce rules unless they will and can always enforce it?
Hmmm... see i think the rule isn't that you NEVER post off-topic,
the rule is you don't go fucking overboard and post new "off-topic"
things everyday and that you dont generate half of sfraves mail
in continuing a thread of people flaming you...

Let's say, someone pops on the sfraves list and is heavily involved in an
organization that was focused around caring for neurotic cats.
She thinks that people on Sfraves would want to know and possibly
join the organztion, so she posts some info to the list.
She also wants to plan a benefit rave for the organization,
so she brings up that topic too.  People seem interested,
so there is a bit of discussion about what the focus and all that will be.
When the discussion starts to get technical, it jumps
over to the sfraves-planner list.

Then... Cindy, let's say, recently got involved with an 
involved with an organziation that takes care of a park
or some such and she posts about the organization to the list
and mention the next time she is goign out to do some groundskeeping.
ANd wants to plan a party or something to benefit the group
and celebrate in the park.  People don't really seem
interested, but Cindy keeps talking about it expressing
how important it is to take care of the earth
because we wont have a place to rave if there is no earth.
A lot of people ask her to stop, but she just says
that this is something we can't afford to ignore.

Now, in the first scenario, i don't see anyone getting flamed...
sure cats arent really rave related so someone grumbles,
but if there is only one or two complaints, 
i don't see much happening with this.

Second scenario. No it's not likely Cindy will be just kicked off the list.
but if she were to keep at it...

I mean let's say a group of people were building a house together,
it's a very open house, that anyone is allowed into
to help build it and maintain it.
If one of the people who were there originally to lay the foundation
wanted to redecorate or add another room or something,
and the rest didn't there would be a lot of discussion i'm sure
and it would take awhile before an ultimatimum was made.
But if someone came in and helped out a little bit
and then started talking about redecoration and
started being really loud and persistent...
well i think they would be asked to calm down or leave
and if they didnt calm down or leave, would be booted.

Brian made teh down payment on this here house,
and is the one who owns the deed to teh property.
He invited us all in here to help make his house a better place
but i think it was definitely with the notion that it was still his house
and he would mostly let us design it as we wish,
but he could veto any plans on changes to the blue prints.


once again.. just some thoughts... (none of which may even closely
resemble reality)

 ,
dana

that a piece of furniture was named after me."
	- me

Look folks, there's no law that says you can only belong to one mailing list
or newsgroup, and that that mailing list or newsgroup has to include every
subject you find appropriate.  There are plenty of newsgroups that deal with
politics, plenty that deal with the environment, just about every subject you
can think of.  And you can read them *all*, or any combination you want. 
That's why the anarchy (er, panarchy) of the net succeeds - information
organizes itself, and unorganized sources of information perish.  It's the
only way to deal with the gigabytes of public data the net generates each
day, and it's pretty successful.  The system breaks down when users 
ignore the structure of this system, and it's up to the other users of a 
particular resource to keep it usable by pointing the errant user to the 
other right places.  

There's a newsgroup called "ba.politics" which is focused on politics and 
activism in the bay area.  There's also "alt.activism" I think, in fact a 
family of them.  If there's an issue coming up, like old-growth logging, 
which you think is something people on sfraves should know about, the 
right thing to post is "hey, I've started a topic on the proposed bill to 
log redwoods over in ba.politics - come join us", and to carry the 
conversation over there.  Or start a mailing list over on best.com if 
it's an issue not covered by any other forum.  

There's no reason to overload SFRaves with stuff that's only marginally 
related, even though there's probably a high correlation in the type 
of people interested in the issue.  

	Brian

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: edm@jessica.stanford.edu (Ed McGuigan)
Subject: CHEMICA SUTRA lurker belated view (long)
Cc: fraser@megatripolis.org
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Before memory fades too much, I wanted to post at least a partial review of
Megatripolis/ParallelU/Chemica Sutra by someone not connected with
producing the event.  As a disclaimer, my perspective is colored by
(occasional intricate rainbow patterns) advanced age (51) and limited rave
experience (several but infrequent - 1st Gathering anniversary at
Concourse, early Equinox in warehouse, some Sunsets and GG park days, ...).
But I have been reading many sfraves posts daily for the last 3? years
since the beginning of the mailing list (Hi Brian B) when we lived in SF
(now in Palo Alto), and the postings often bring light and smiles into my
days.

Chemica Sutra attracted me by the early start time (and endtime for me - I
was home by 3am, so I probably missed some), by the Parallel Univ & topic
(I had participated in the "Free U" in Palo Alto around '69 or so), and by
the net controversy about Fraser, Zippys, etc.

I won't attempt to describe the space, but it blew me away from when I
first walked in the door and continued to surprise me all evening with new
discoveries.  Not to spoil all the surprises, but Laughing Sal, formerly of
Playland At The Beach (if anyone remembers) was standing there with her big
smile all night.

Even tho the party was small in numbers (max 100?), for me it was like a
microcosm of the huge Gathering with varied activities in different rooms
the constituents of which changed as attendees mixed and regrouped.  The
small dance area seemed to reach critical mass with as few as half a dozen
dancers and was  constant source of great sounds, fine lights, and high
vibes that often caught me like a whirlpool and danced me around until I
spun out recharged lured away to other attractions.  Smoking was out back,
so the air was unusually breathable for a party (perhaps a little musty
with the old artifacts collection).

The talks were interesting, the performers mesmerizing. Slight
disappointment that the pagan punch was too subtle for me (but not the
"nurse" that served it).  But for me the uniform acceptance and
friendliness in a group of such diverse ages was unique (at some parties I
feel out of place when most folks are younger than my kids).  The people I
met were great!  Kind Kate befriended and guided me several times.  Fraser
seems to me genuinely called to his role in making it happen and spreading
the word (and the word is Love).  Will told tantalizing tales of shamanic
travel in South America.  Tantrika Daniela led me to a nice gathering of
loving folks and mellow music the next night.  Dan inspired me to rise
before dawn to greet the age of Itza.  Magenta is magic!!!

So I clearly enjoyed Chemica Sutra and came away with renewed hope and
revitalized interest in the culture, if I can just get to more raves that
are not so far past my bedtime.

Grateful,
- Ed
